HEADLINE: MARKETS & INVESTING; 
Some Opportunities Are Seen in Bonds

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
"Problems create opportunities," says Frederick B. Taylor, the chief investment officer at the United States Trust Company.
 That is the rationale for his advice this year: buy the sectors of the bond market that had the worst of it last year -- investment-grade corporate bonds and high-yield, or junk, bonds -- "as long as you pick well." 
 Junk bonds had a terrible 2000, putting in their worst performance since 1990 relative to Treasuries. The return for the Merrill Lynch high-yield index is a negative 5.1 percent, or 18.5 percentage points below the return for Treasuries; that is significantly below its 13 percentage-point underperformance in 1990. The 5.1 percent decline is also the worst in the history of the Merrill index, which goes back to 1987, outdoing the 4.4 percent decline in 1990. 
For investment-grade corporate bonds it was the worst performance, relative to Treasuries, since 1981, according to Merrill Lynch's bond indexes. But in this case the underperformance was not as painful for investors because the return for corporates did rise on the year, just less than Treasuries.
Still, high-quality corporate returns, up 9.1 percent, were so far below those for Treasury notes and bonds, up 13.4 percent, that the investment-grade corporate bond market -- despite the higher yields it always offers -- lost the performance edge it has enjoyed over Treasuries since the bond debacle of 1994. The investment-grade corporate bond market now trails Treasuries in cumulative return 61.5 percent to 62.2 percent over those six years.
What happened? Concerns about slowing economic growth raised fears of corporate credit problems, especially in the telecommunications sector. Investors responded to those fears by selling, sending yields on junk bonds to double-digit levels and on high-grade corporate bonds to high single digits.
But it is this sell-off that has created the opportunity. "No one wants to own bonds," says Kathleen C. Gaffney, a corporate bond portfolio manager at Loomis Sayles & Company in Boston, a signal to many that it is a good time to buy.
With average yields of 14.2 percent on junk bonds and more than 7.3 percent on investment-grade corporates, both categories are attractive, especially at a time when the stock market is putting in its worst performance in more than two decades. But on top of this, these junk and investment-grade bonds also offer an opportunity for nice capital gains. Their prices have been driven down in some cases to levels that assume a recession. And if that proves to be a bad forecast, the prices should rally.
What has made this bet more attractive is the recent shift in thinking at the Federal Reserve, where policy makers have now signaled that they expect to cut interest rates soon, possibly as early as this month. The negative economic signs may yet get worse before they get better, but the Fed's willingness to act does suggest there is a smaller chance of a recession.
The rally in both the investment-grade and junk markets since the first indication of this policy shift on Dec. 5 shows that some investors are already jumping back into the corporate sector.
"The Fed is saying that I am not going to make this worse," said William Cunningham, the corporate bond strategist at Chase Securities. So even though there is probably more pain to come as the economy slows further, he said that "it is probably time to look at selected sectors."
These include banks and financial companies, which he said are the types of companies that usually benefit first when the Fed begins to cut rates and investors think more of rebound than recession. As for high yield, Mr. Taylor of United States Trust suggests buying a fund because that provides the diversification necessary to mitigate the negative impact from some of the companies actually defaulting on their bonds.
In the case of Treasuries, it is hard to believe that they can repeat their performance of last year, when notes and bonds returned 13.4 percent and longer-term Treasuries, with maturities of 10 years or more, returned an average of 20.2 percent, according to Merrill Lynch indexes. 
Treasuries had many things going for them: the expectation of slowing economic growth, growing government surpluses and the consequent reduction in issuance of new Treasury debt, the beginning of the actual buying back of existing Treasury debt and the expectation, confirmed by Fed policy makers at their Dec. 19 meeting, that the Fed will be cutting interest rates soon.
But, for this year, many analysts think that Treasuries have already priced in several Fed rate cuts and an economic slowdown to 2 percent or lower. The yield on the March futures contract on the Federal funds rate has plunged almost half a percentage point, to 6 percent in the last two months, signaling that many investors expect the Fed to make two quarter-point cuts in its benchmark interest rate by the end of the first quarter.
This does not mean that Treasury interest rates will not move lower this year, only that it is unlikely they will have the kind of move they experienced last year, when the yield on the 10-year note dropped to 5.10 percent from 6.44 percent and the yield on the 30-year bond plunged to 5.46 percent from 6.48 percent. At the end of the year, Treasury yields from two years to 30 years were at their lowest levels since early 1999, just after long-term rates had reached their lowest level in more than 30 years at the end of 1998.
One of the forces that accounted for much of the move in longer-term Treasuries last year will be around again this year. That is a continued decline in the issuance of new Treasury securities and the elimination of the issuance of others as the country continues to enjoy large budget surpluses. This decrease in supply only makes the securities more attractive, driving the yields even lower than economic fundamentals might justify.
This year the Treasury could stop selling new 30-year bonds. One-year Treasury bills are expected to be eliminated as soon as the new Bush Treasury can get up to full gear, and the issuance of the two-year note will be cut drastically, from monthly sales to just eight times or even four times a year.
This new diminished supply of shorter-term securities should add extra downward pressure on these Treasury rates this year.

HEADLINE: Missing the Mark in 2000, Stocks Look for a Steadying Hand Ahead 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Wearied by a market gone haywire, investors were greatly relieved in December when Alan Greenspan went on full alert, at the ready to cut interest rates to get the economy moving in the right direction again.
 But investors must still wonder: Will Mr. Greenspan's hoped-for moves result in a swift and sturdy return to the good old days of steadily rising stock prices? 
 Many strategists say they believe that the early part of the year will be positive for stock indexes, if only because of the psychological boost a new year, a new president and Mr. Greenspan's avowed vigilance will give investors. But the jury is still out on whether the Federal Reserve Board chairman's anticipated monetary policy moves will turn around the economy -- and stock prices -- as quickly in 2001 as they have in periods of distress throughout the 1990's. 
At issue is the nature of the current economic slowdown. The decline in the stock market may well prompt consumers to rein in their spending, keeping the economy from rebounding. And immense capital expenditures by corporations in recent years, much of which was financed by free and easy capital markets, may curtail new spending, putting a recovery in that sector in doubt. Both possibilities pose for Mr. Greenspan a set of economy-related challenges that are quite different from the market-related crises he has attacked so successfully in the recent past. 
Like many strategists, Stefan Abrams, chief investment officer for asset allocation at the Company of the West, thinks that even though the economy is going to start the year quite weak, the financial markets will perform reasonably well as investors anticipate help from Mr. Greenspan on interest rates. "But somewhere in the middle of the first quarter," he said, "we're going to say 'Is the economy still deteriorating? Is the consumer still sated? And has business, through its high-tech spending, overbuilt the capital stock?' If so, then there could be cause for considerable concern because, if we need to jump-start aggregate demand, lowering interest rates may not do enough." 
For the moment, investors are happy to be rid of stock market 2000. All of the broad market indexes ended the year in negative territory, but the indexes most heavily weighted toward technology fared the worst. The Dow Jones industrial average held up the best of the three most famous gauges, losing 6.2 percent compared with a 10.1 percent decline in the Standard & Poor's 500 index and a 39.3 percent plunge in the Nasdaq composite. 
But even the devastation in the Nasdaq composite does not tell the whole painful story of 2000 in the market. Many of the stocks that had captured investors' fancies -- particularly in the Internet sector -- have lost three-quarters of their value or more. And as of Dec. 22, according to statisticians at Salomon Smith Barney, Nasdaq stocks had declined on average 54.4 percent from their 52-week highs, well below the 44.5 percent declines seen in these shares during the market crash of 1987.
Looking ahead, most individual investors seem certain Mr. Greenspan will deliver them from the stock market troubles seen in 2000. In a survey of 1,000 investors conducted late last month by Strong Funds, a mutual fund organization in Milwaukee, 42.6 percent said they believed that the stock market would rise at least 10 percent this year, while 34.8 percent said they expected it to be mostly flat. Only 20.3 percent think the market will decline by 10 percent or more. 
The main reason for this optimism is investors' faith in Mr. Greenspan. Of those surveyed, 43.3 percent said that the Fed chairman would have the greatest impact on the market in 2001, well above the 35.6 percent of investors who said that corporate profits would be the driving force in the market. And if the president-elect has any delusions about who is in charge, only 6.8 percent of those interviewed said George W. Bush would be the prime mover of stocks in 2001, below even the 7.4 percent who thought world events would have the biggest impact.
The vote of confidence in Mr. Greenspan is undoubtedly pleasing to him and certainly well earned, as he has helped guide the economy to an expansion that last year became the nation's longest. But the expansion now appears to be fading, and it will take more than just a few waves of his magic wand to restore the glow to the nation's economy and its stocks. Economists estimate, for example, that roughly a year must pass before interest rate cuts work their way fully into the economy.
"An expeditious easing of monetary policy is necessary if the U.S. is to remain safely distanced from recession in the early part of the year," said John Lonski, chief economist at Moody's Investors Service. He estimated that the federal funds rate would have to fall to 5.75 percent, from the current 6.25 percent, before lenders would become less risk-averse and begin providing borrowers with funds again. 
Adding to the complexity of the Fed's task is the increasingly significant role that the stock market has played in recent years among consumers. In the third quarter of 2000, stocks held by individuals, private pension funds and state and local government retirement funds accounted for 61 percent of all financial assets owned in those quarters, according to Safian Investment Research in White Plains. Ten years earlier, stocks made up just 31 percent of all financial assets held by those individuals and institutions.
Because so many more Americans took up stock investing in the 1990's, the market's rise contributed to a strong economy. As stock prices soared, consumers felt wealthier, if only on paper. Many expanded their houses, bought second homes or purchased new cars, dishwashers and clothing. Manufacturers of those goods scrambled to meet demand. 
Now that stock prices have plummeted, consumers may will ration their spending and perhaps even save some of their money, keeping economic growth in the doldrums. "The consumer is usually the last to slow down," said Lorraine T. Corbett, vice president at Safian Investment Research. "Once the consumer starts to pull back, that's when things start to decline." 
Consumers certainly have reason to retrench. According to researchers at International Strategy and Investment in New York, investors have lost $3 trillion in market value since stocks peaked in March, a sum equal to one-third of the country's nominal gross domestic product. 
What would really begin to worry Ms. Corbett and other economists is a change in the employment picture, with large numbers of workers being laid off. "If the job market stays where it is, you may not see a severe slowdown," Ms. Corbett said. "People may cut back a little bit because they want to wait and see what happens. But, if they're fearful of losing their jobs, that's something else."
Mr. Lonski echoed that view. "What worries me is how a declining equity market coupled with a slowdown in corporate profitability will affect hiring activity," he said. "If earnings slow significantly while stock prices are falling sharply, companies have all the more reason to downsize. Then it may be difficult to avoid a recession."
Although most economists expect economic growth simply to slow this year, some strategists wonder whether stocks are signaling a recession. Travails in the stock market are not always accurate in telling the economic future, but during the last four recessions, according to I.S.I., declines in the stock market preceded drops in gross domestic product. 
During the severe bear market of 1974, for example, the S.& P. fell 48.2 percent from peak to trough; in the recession that began in the middle of that decline, economic output fell 3.4 percent. In 1980, the S.& P. 500 fell 17.1 percent and the recession that year shaved 2.2 percent off G.D.P. That was a mild recession, but equity investors had sniffed it out. 
Judging from the past, if stocks have already bottomed, with the S.& P. 500 off 13.6 percent at year-end from its March peak, any downturn in the nation's economy could prove to be fleeting. But many strategists say they think that the early months of 2001 will be unsettling in the economy and that the elements for an acceleration in growth -- including hefty bonuses and big tax refunds -- are not in place this year. This suggests that the stock market may not make a big rebound. 
Investors may take a wait-and-see attitude because it is not yet clear just what kind of slowdown is unfolding. In recent years, Mr. Abrams argued, recessions have been a result of modest inventory bulges that were quickly worked off. More worrisome would be a slowdown based on extreme levels of overcapacity among the nation's manufacturers. That could result in a much deeper, more prolonged downturn.
"If we are not going through a short-term cycle caused largely by inventory but if, in fact, we've entered a capital bust, then the Fed is not going to be so powerful," Mr. Abrams said. 
Capital expenditures in information technology, he noted, now amount to 8 percent of gross domestic product and have been adding two percentage points or more to the nation's economic growth. Recently, Mr. Abrams said, growth in new orders in the United States has dropped to zero. And if that does not improve soon, he added, the slump is going to be longer and deeper than people expect. What's more, lower interest rates won't help right away.
"It's not just a question of clearing a few Jeep Cherokees off the lot," he said. "The Fed can't just snap its fingers. It's going to take longer to take it through." 
What kind of a stock market will investors encounter if the Fed's moves indeed prove to be less potent this year? In one repect, the market should look familiar: only those companies with solid earnings will perform well. Former tech glamour stocks, if they have no earnings, will continue to lose ground.
David Sowerby, portfolio manager at Loomis, Sayles & Company, said: "If I were to describe the stock market in 2001 in one word, it would be 'balanced.' As in years past, good stocks with good fundamentals and good earnings will go up."

HEADLINE: The Surplus and the Tax Cut 

 BODY:
The Clinton administration released projections last week showing that the estimated federal surplus will hit $5 trillion over the next 10 years, almost $1 trillion more than previously expected. Supporters of President-elect George W. Bush say that the bigger surplus now expected will provide the wherewithal to pass Mr. Bush's proposed $1.9 trillion tax cut, which the Bush team believes is needed to spur an economy that is slowing down. But a careful look at the numbers shows that the Bush plan remains a bad fiscal idea. 
 Start with the fact that $2.5 trillion of the projected surplus comes from Social Security and another $500 billion or so comes from Medicare. Both pots of money are essentially off limits. Congress appears committed to using the extra money from these programs to pay down the federal debt -- a use that does not affect the solvency of either program but does improve the overall health of the future economy. So that leaves only about $2 trillion of the projected $5 trillion surplus for tax cuts and new government spending. 
 But fiscal matters are not nearly as rosy as the new estimates suggest. The White House projections assume that federal programs other than Social Security, Medicare and Medicaid will not expand over the next decade. That is unrealistic. The cost of making likely additions to defense capabilities and to some domestic programs and of preserving popular tax credits that are scheduled to expire would eat up an additional $600 billion or more out of the surplus. That would leave only $1.4 trillion available for tax cuts and all other spending increases. 
Mr. Bush's overly generous tax cut plan would wipe out virtually the entire remaining surplus. That would leave him no money to help, as he has promised, low-income families buy health insurance -- which could cost $600 billion over 10 years -- or to add prescription drugs to Medicare, which could cost $200 billion over 10 years. 
Beyond fiscal feasibility, supporters of Mr. Bush argue that a big tax cut is needed to spur an economy that, they say, may be flirting with recession. This argument, too, is weak. Tax policy is rarely used to offset the ups and downs of a modern economy because it is too hard to time the impact of a tax cut. 
Congress would probably not pass a major tax cut bill until the fall, and consumers would likely not respond for many months thereafter. It could be well more than a year before any significant increase in consumer spending kicked in, and by that time the economic slowdown the tax cut sought to reverse might already be long past. Most economists look to monetary policy, which can be changed rapidly and often by the Federal Reserve, to keep the economy on an even keel.
The Bush plan is the wrong economic elixir. But a smaller, targeted tax cut could indeed make sense. Rather than awarding the bulk of tax cuts to the wealthy, as the Bush plan would do, the better idea is to focus tax cuts on low-income families, those whose earnings have slipped during most of the last 30 years. 
Congress could provide a tax credit to offset the cost of health insurance, for example. It could use tax credits to offset the impact of payroll taxes, which hit poor families proportionately harder than wealthy families. Modest tax cuts targeted in this way would make a fine use of any unclaimed federal revenues.

HEADLINE: Singapore Shows Strong Growth 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: SINGAPORE, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
Singapore continues to stave off predictions that slowing demand for electronics in the United States will crimp its economic growth.
 The Ministry of Trade and Industry issued preliminary figures today estimating that Singapore's economy expanded 10.1 percent last year, with growth in the last three months of the year beating the government's own expectations. 
 Demand for electronics remained strong in 2000, the ministry said, but it forecast that growth this year would slow to 5 percent to 7 percent.
Singapore and countries across Asia are bracing for faltering growth in the United States, which would reduce demand for the region's exports. Chartered Semiconductor Manufacturing, a leading maker of custom chips, said recently that it might cut its forecast for 2001 sales and profits, after the Dell Computer Corporation and I.B.M. said that they expected sales growth to moderate.
Sales growth is expected to slow further in the first quarter, Tan Tzu Ping, an economist with J. P. Morgan & Company, told Bloomberg News. "Manufacturing will decline through the first half of 2001, even as services output plateaus."
Underscoring the prospects of slower global demand, export growth in November was 8.1 percent, half what it was a year earlier. Growth was 16.3 percent in October and 11.7 percent in September.
Singapore's goods-producing industries, which include manufacturing and construction, grew 12.4 percent in the fourth quarter from a year ago, compared with 11.4 percent in the third period. The sector accounts for about one-quarter of gross domestic product.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
In 2000, fewer companies paid dividends to investors and more of the same lies ahead.

BYLINE:  By Floyd Norris 

 BODY:
DIVIDENDS on stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 fell 2.5 percent last year, making it the first decline in nearly a decade and the first one ever that could not easily be explained by economic factors or government regulations. It was the largest decline in nearly half a century.
 The decline reflected both economic problems for some companies and the fact that many companies in recent years have chosen not to pay dividends, largely on the theory that investors are interested more in capital gains than in income from dividend payments. 
 "Each year the number of companies in the S.& P. 500 not paying dividends grows," said Arnold Kaufman, the editor of S.& P.'s Outlook newsletter, which released the figures. 
At the end of last year, 372 of the 500 companies in the index, the major index of large stocks in the American market, paid dividends. That was down from 402 a year earlier and 418 at the end of 1998. Most of the decline came from the fact that companies leaving the index, often because they were acquired by other companies, usually paid dividends while their replacements often did not.
Still, until last year, the overall dividends paid by America's largest companies had risen each year since the recession year of 1991. The decline in 2000 provided evidence that more companies are running low on cash despite the long-running economic expansion. In recent weeks, companies like AT&T, First Union and Xerox have announced cuts in their dividends.
In addition, notes Greg Jensen of Bridgewater Associates, a money-management firm, the number of companies announcing plans to buy back their own shares has fallen during the last several months, as have plans for takeovers to be paid in cash.
Until last year, investors seemed to not value dividends very much. In both 1998 and 1999, reported Howard Silverblatt of Standard & Poor's, nonpayers in the index rose far more rapidly than those that paid dividends. But last year, when the S.& P. 500 fell 10.1 percent, the entire decline was caused by falls in the nondividend paying stocks, while the average stock that paid dividends rose 15.7 percent.
The decline of 2.5 percent in dividends paid by companies in the S.& P. 500 was the first decrease since a drop of 1 percent in 1991, when the most recent recession ended and when the operating profits of companies in the S.& P. 500 fell 14.8 percent. By contrast, S.& P. estimates that operating profits rose 10.8 percent in 2000, which was lower than the 16.8 percent gain registered in 1999 but well above the increases of the previous three years, when dividends were rising.
The last time dividends on the S.& P. 500 fell by more than they did last year was in 1951, when they fell 4.1 percent while profits were plunging 14 percent.
The S.& P. index, which dates back to 1928, has had declines in dividends in only 10 previous years -- 1931, 1932, 1933, 1938, 1942, 1951, 1958, 1970, 1971 and 1991. In each of them, save for 1971, the economy was in recession for at least part of the year, or corporate profits plunged, or both. In 1971, dividend increases were held down by provisions of President Richard M. Nixon's wage-price controls.
The chances for another decline in dividends this year appear to be good, whether or not the economy goes into a recession. By the end of last year, the indicated dividend rate -- that is, the amount that would be paid in 2001 if no companies in the index raised or reduced their payouts -- was 2.2 percent below the amount that was actually paid in 2000. Thus it would take dividend increases of at least that amount to preserve the overall 2000 payout figure.
Over all last year, including all companies in the United States stock market, S.& P. counted 1,496 dividend increase announcements, down 12 percent from 1999 and the lowest for any year since 1992. 
Nonetheless, reductions or omissions of dividends remain uncommon, in large part because investors often react angrily to announcements of such moves.
S.& P. counted 77 announcements of dividend cuts in 2000, up 24 percent from the year before. But it said the 60 announcements of dividend eliminations were 27 percent less than in 1999.

HEADLINE: THE NEEDIEST CASES; 
Contributors Pass Along Their Own Good Fortune

BYLINE:  By AARON DONOVAN 

 BODY:
The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund has received nearly $870,000 more in contributions than it had by this point last year. If donations continue to flow in at the rate they did last year, the fund will have been given more money than in any other year in its 89-year history.
 There are still two months to go before the annual appeal ends, on the last day of February. 
 During the current appeal, the fund, which supports seven of New York's oldest and most respected charities, has received $4,884,782.59 from readers of The Times and the trusts, foundations and estates that they manage. At an equivalent point last year, the fund had received $4,015,217.81. The highest final total was $6,701,122.57, given during the 1998-99 appeal. 
Many readers send short notes along with their donations.
"Up until last week I was reading the letters, but last week the volume became so great that we hired an intern to do it," said Kyung Park, the New York Times accountant who keeps track of gifts to the fund. "A lot of people felt they are very blessed, economically, and a lot of them say they wish they could give more."
The fund has grown in part because of many large gifts from readers. So far in the current appeal, the fund has received 572 gifts of $1,000 or more, many from trusts and foundations, but many from individuals.
"I earn more money than I need to to buy food and pay my mortgage," said a 34-year-old investment banker who lives on the Upper East Side and gave $1,500 on Nov. 24. He spoke on the condition that his name not be used. "I consider it an obligation to give money to people who can't provide their children with a meal, or don't have any place to live, or who are sick and can't pay their medical expenses."
Another Upper East Sider, William W. Donnell, gave $1,000 on Nov. 26, and included a note: "Thank you for your continued efforts in reaching out to the least fortunate."
On Dec. 2, Julia W. Stern, a humanities professor at Western Connecticut State University, gave $1,000 in memory of her mother, Alexandra Werner. Mrs. Werner died in 1997 at the age of 97, after more than 50 years of giving -- and encouraging others to give -- to the Neediest Cases Fund.
"When I was 5, she started me in on the Neediest Cases," recalled Mrs. Stern, who grew up in the South Bronx but now lives in Newtown, Conn. "She would tell me at Christmas time that rather than asking for things, I should be giving."
And while officials at the fund and at the seven New York charities that it supports are grateful for the large contributions, they said they are also pleased when someone makes a smaller donation.
"We're mightily pleased at the record pace of contributions this year, but what's even more satisfying is that the number of donors has gone up by 11 percent," said Jack Rosenthal, president of The New York Times Company Foundation, which administers the Neediest Cases Fund.
Wan Tisnower, who came to the United States in 1969 from Thailand, gave $300 on Oct. 18, along with a note that said, "Please use this fund to help the neediest person."
Dr. Tisnower, who runs a day care center in Philadelphia, worked in a Chicago plastic factory for $1.60 an hour when she first came to the United States. She said she was inspired to give after reading an article in January 1999 about a Mexican immigrant in Queens who had to give back a borrowed sewing machine. The Neediest Cases Fund paid for a new sewing machine for the woman, who was then able to continue running her small business.
"I read it and I was impressed," Dr. Tisnower said. "I was an immigrant myself, and I know that it's hard to come here for the first time."

HEADLINE: MANAGEMENT: The Power of a Familiar Face; 
Ex-Executives Come Back to Fix Troubled Companies

BYLINE:  By JULIE FLAHERTY 

DATELINE: WESTBORO, Mass. 

 BODY:
Striding toward the elevators on the way to his office, Peter Gyenes does a double take and stops to straighten a plaque on the wall. No, he is not a perfectionist, he says. His operating principle is closer to something he read on a poster that his daughters gave him: "If something can go wrong, fix it. Murphy's Law doesn't apply here."
 Something did go wrong here. This used to be the headquarters of Ardent Software, and Mr. Gyenes was chief executive. Then, in December 1999, he announced the sale of Ardent to Informix, a California maker of database software, for $1.1 billion in Informix stock. 
 No sooner had he started making plans for an early retirement of traveling and serving on several corporate boards, however, than Informix's fortunes took a turn for the worse. Revenue in the first two quarters of 2000 declined, earnings faltered and the stock skidded to $2.63 from a high of $21.25. The value of the 250,000 shares he owned fell to $657,500 from about $5.31 million and the potential payoff of his 1.5 million options was threatened. Last July, Informix ousted its chief executive, Jean-Yves Dexmier, and asked Mr. Gyenes (pronounced GAN-esh) to take his place. 
Suddenly, he was back in his old corner office, going from the role of lame-duck executive of a company with $49 million in annual revenue to a man expected to fix one five times that size. He is now six months into his new job, with a mission to comfort Wall Street, lift employee morale and save his own shares of Informix from turning into worthless paper.
Mr. Gyenes has some illustrious company in making this particular executive journey. Corporate boards have grown increasingly impatient of late with chief executives who fall below expectations, as the sudden departures of M. Douglas Ivester from Coca-Cola and Michael C. Hawley from Gillette illustrated. Yet finding seasoned managers who are up to the job of succeeding them can be difficult. An obvious candidate, corporate governance experts say, is the person who ran a business the company recently acquired.
That is what Cabletron Systems did when it replaced its chief executive in 1999 with the former head of Yago Systems, a company it had acquired the year before. And that is what Bank One did, also in 1999, when it found an emergency replacement for John B. McCoy, the man who engineered the bank's purchase of First Chicago NBD a year earlier. It named First Chicago's former chief executive, Verne G. Istock, as interim chief executive, and after a permanent chief was named, he remained as president. Like those companies, Informix "didn't have to go find a devil they didn't know," said Robert Kenzer, chairman of the Kenzer Corporation, an executive recruiter. After all, Mr. Kenzer said, Informix was paying not only for the company, but the expertise that came with it. "They paid a billion bucks for this devil," he said. "It makes sense."
Or as Mr. Gyenes put it: "I was there. I'm the profile of a C.E.O., and I was sitting right there, and I didn't have a job."
After signing over Ardent in March, Mr. Gyenes stayed as a new member of the Informix board and witnessed firsthand the disaster in the making. Les Denend, an Informix board member since 1998, said that he and other directors felt they had little choice but to ask for Mr. Dexmier's resignation within days of the disclosure of the company's second-quarter results.
While he called Mr. Dexmier a hard worker and smart strategist who put in "unbelievable amounts of time," the board concluded that he did not have the experience of putting theory into practice, Mr. Denend said. Mr. Gyenes, on the other hand, had already steered Ardent through various mergers.
And his fellow board members did not have to twist his arm. "I have probably a bigger stake in this than anybody else sitting around the table there," he said. "But you know, more than that, I have a sense of responsibility for this whole thing."
Robert Tholemeier, an analyst with First Security Van Kasper in San Francisco, said he thought ownership was the key. "If he had no stock, he wouldn't have felt nearly as responsible as he does now," Mr. Tholemeier said. "Nothing like looking at your own personal wealth to make you feel responsible."
But perhaps it is just as well. Mr. Gyenes's colleagues, citing his penchant for firing off e-mail messages at 4 a.m. and calling them on weekends, said retirement would not have fit his temperament anyway. He himself acknowledges that the last time he took two weeks off was on his honeymoon 30 years ago. And a vacation to Israel soon after he joined Informix turned into a string of meetings with Informix representatives in the Middle East and long-distance cell-phone calls to the United States.
When he stepped back into the fray last summer, he found an acquisition nightmare. Combining Ardent and Informix was supposed to give customers a single source for databases and the software to interpret the data they garnered. But customers were unsure whether they could use one without the other, and confusion seemed to be the word of the day.
So Mr. Gyenes embarked on a world tour, meeting with customers and employees to discuss what was happening. It was the customers who pointed out that his own sales representatives were low on morale and wanted to quit.
"They said, 'You guys have got to get your act together as a company,' " he recalled.
Mr. Gyenes, 55, says he thinks he can do that with some straight talk, a skill he learned in part from his family. He was born in Hungary, but at age 9 moved to New York City, where his father, who spoke no English, started a textile import business. His brother took a job pushing carts in the garment district so that he could translate between his father and his American business associates as they haggled in the streets.
He worked his way through Columbia, where he earned a bachelor's degree in mathematics and then an M.B.A. His first job was as a computer operator overseeing some of the room-size machines used at I.B.M.
After a series of management positions in the United States and Europe, Mr. Gyenes was hired by Vmark Software in Massachusetts in 1966 as chief executive with a mission to help it expand. He sought out Vmark's primary competitor, a private company, and quickly arranged to meet with its owner to talk about a merger of equals.
"I made him like me," Mr. Gyenes said, achieving the crucial first step to any acquisition. Within two years, he had bought not only that company but three others and had given Vmark the new name of Ardent.
"We kept reloading the gun fast," said Charles Kane, a member of the Vmark management team. While acquisitions are "never smooth sailing," Mr. Kane said, he and Mr. Gyenes developed a plan of action that seemed to work. "The thing is to make the decisions and don't sit on them," he said. "When we made choices on people to stay or leave the company, we did it up front, so when they came together we were ready to execute right away, not waiting until the first quarter to end."
One of Mr. Gyenes's first strikes at Informix was consolidating the financial and administrative departments and streamlining the sales force, eliminating more than 400 positions in the process, or about a tenth of the total. He calls the reorganization a process of being "ruthlessly focused."
Another big change was moving the Informix corporate headquarters from Menlo Park, Calif., to the old Ardent office building in Westboro. But because Mr. Gyenes had persuaded some key former Ardent executives to stick with their posts, most of the management team was on the East Coast anyway.
The headquarters site was less of an issue, Mr. Denend said, but "the culture needed a little shaking up."
The severest jostle is still to come. Having helped engineer the splicing together of Ardent and Informix, Mr. Gyenes is now focused on splitting them apart again, this time along different lines. He plans to carve out a new company, as yet unnamed, that would help companies make use of their data warehouses.
Drew Brosseau, an analyst with SG Cowen, likes the plan. "They are taking an intelligent strategy to try to solve a difficult problem," he said.
Still, analysts say that Informix's problems go much deeper than its merger woes. In 1997, accounting irregularities led to lawsuits and an investigation by the Securities and Exchange Commission. In January 2000, Informix agreed to settle with the S.E.C., without admitting or denying the commission's findings. Poor leadership and marketing strategy accelerated a downturn, said Mr. Tholemeier, the analyst.
"It's been a three-year disaster," he said. "I don't think the merger really was a major contribution."
The largest cloud that continues to hover over Informix is competition -- it is a distant second to the industry leader Oracle -- in a data-warehousing field that has matured and an economy that is softening.
"At some level, they don't have a lot of choices," Mr. Brosseau said. "They are a second-tier player in a business with big, strong competitors."
The market remains skeptical. Informix stock closed on Jan. 2 at $3.19, only 56 cents above its low. "They frankly have to start to show some momentum over the next six months or so," Mr. Brosseau said. "Otherwise, it's going to get that much harder."

CORRECTION-DATE: January 5, 2001

 CORRECTION:
Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day on Wednesday about former executives who return to fix troubled companies misstated the date Peter Gyenes joined Vmark Software as chief executive. It was 1996, not 1966. A picture caption misidentified the man shown with Mr. Gyenes. He was Jim Foy, president of Informix's database company, not Peter Fiore, president of the parent. 
The article also misstated the revenue of Ardent Software before it was bought by Informix. The figure was $160 million for the year; $49 million was for the fourth quarter.

HEADLINE: Cambodian Deputies Back War Crimes Court 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
After months of delay, the Cambodia National Assembly voted today to create a special tribunal, with help from the United Nations, to try the leaders of the murderous Khmer Rouge regime of the 1970's.
 Many political and technical pitfalls still lie ahead, and officials and experts said that it might be years before any of the aging leaders face trial and that some could evade justice altogether. 
 "I cannot say how many years, but it will take time," the assembly's president, Norodom Ranariddh, said on Friday.
The assembly acted surprisingly quickly, after just two days of consideration and with little debate. But it remained unclear whether Prime Minister Hun Sen, who orchestrates most political events, truly wants a trial to proceed. 
"It's a step forward," said a diplomat with long experience in Cambodia, "but we know that the roads are very rocky here. Based on past experience I would at this stage tread very carefully."
Though there was a show trial for absent defendants in 1979, no one has yet been brought into court to answer for the deaths of more than a million people when the Communist Khmer Rouge ruled Cambodia from 1975 to 1979.
When its guerrilla resistance collapsed at the end of the 1990's, most of its surviving leaders were granted amnesty and have been left alone to live in quiet retirement. Its supreme leader, Pol Pot, died in 1998.
The measure passed today, based on an American formula, involves a cumbersome compromise in which both Cambodian and foreign prosecutors and judges would jointly select the defendants and jointly reach their verdicts. The foreign judges would be in the minority but would hold veto power over decisions.
The compromise was made necessary by the resistance of Mr. Hun Sen, who is seeking to keep control of the process and who has engaged in what one political expert, Kao Kim Hourn, called "a policy of ambiguity" regarding his intentions.
Both foreign and domestic critics say the formula leaves the process vulnerable to the corruption and political manipulation that characterize the Cambodian legal system.
"Maybe it will function well -- maybe -- but we are concerned," said Kek Galabru, the head of Cambodia's leading human rights group, Licadho. "It is difficult to find independent judges in Cambodia, and most of the judges and prosecutors are not professional. And also there is the problem of corruption. So it will be difficult for the United Nations-appointed judges and prosecutors to work with the Cambodian team."
Sara Colm, the Cambodia representative of the New York-based group Human Rights Watch, expressed a widely held concern that the mixed-tribunal formula might set a precedent in which future United Nations courts could be similarly diluted by local political pressures.
She said a difficult process of negotiation with the United Nations over the last four years has been "a steady retreat" from the ideal of an impartial international tribunal.
"The concern is that by relying so much on the Cambodian judiciary -- which has been torn apart by the Khmer Rouge years and is still in the process of rebuilding -- that a tribunal of this nature would not be able to offer the fairness and transparency that is required," she said.
By selecting and pressuring the Cambodian members of the tribunal, she said, the government could determine who is prosecuted and how defendants are judged.
Mr. Hun Sen has said that at least one Khmer Rouge leader, Ieng Sary, should not be tried, although his name is one of the main half dozen raised by proponents of the trials.
Mr. Hun Sen has alternated between urging that the past be buried and forgotten and urging that a trial proceed to exorcise the ghosts of the past. Foreign envoys who have visited him have emerged alternately encouraged and frustrated.
His policy of ambiguity involves balancing pressures from both internal and external groups, including demands for a trial from most Western nations and pressure against a trial from China, a long-term sponsor of the Khmer Rouge. Both sides wield significant economic and political influence in Cambodia.
Though he likes to call himself a strongman -- and often acts like one -- Mr. Hun Sen faces internal pressures from his party. A number of its top officials, like Mr. Hun Sen himself, were themselves low-level Khmer Rouge cadre and fear that prosecutors could cast a wide net.
The measure passed today explicitly takes that concern into account, specifying that only those "most responsible" for atrocities would be put on trial.
Critics say, though, that any prior limitation on the defendants could stymie a fair and unfettered investigation. A great deal of documentary evidence has been gathered by a Cambodian documentation center, but legal experts say that witness interviews are central to successful prosecutions.
The names of the surviving leaders and suspects are well known. In addition to Mr. Ieng Sary, two top leaders who surrendered two years ago -- Nuon Chea and Khieu Samphan -- live in a remote enclave near the Thai border under a provisional amnesty, surrounded by former Khmer Rouge fighters who were once under their command. Documentary evidence has also been gathered implicating Mr. Ieng Sary's wife, Ieng Thirith.
Two other prominent figures who did not surrender and were not granted amnesty by the government -- Ta Mok and Kaing Khek Ieu, the commandant of the Khmer Rouge torture chamber, Tuol Sleng -- have been jailed and could be the first defendants to be brought into court.
Mr. Hun Sen has warned of instability if a trial proceeds, and he has been suspected of fomenting violence himself when it suits his ends. Most experts dismiss the possibility of any concerted Khmer Rouge backlash.
But a number of steps remain to be taken before any trial can proceed. The measure passed today must be approved by a newly created and usually passive Senate as well as a Constitutional Council before being signed into law by King Norodom Sihanouk.
Then a new round of negotiations with the United Nations over procedures and technicalities would begin. Only then could the expensive and complex process begin of setting up a court, choosing prosecutors and judges and investigating potential defendants.
"This has been the easy part," said Mr. Kao Kim Hourn, the director of the Cambodian Institute for Cooperation and Peace. "The more challenging part will be putting together the team -- particularly the Cambodian team -- and having the two teams work together in setting up the court."
And even that will only be a start, he said.
"The other, more challenging, part will be how to encourage those alleged Khmer Rouge leaders to come forward to appear in the court," he said. "Very challenging. And what would happen if they would not show up in court?"

HEADLINE: How to Lower The Cost of Drugs 

BYLINE:  By Uwe E. Reinhardt; Uwe E. Reinhardt is a professor of economics and public affairs at Princeton University.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J. 

 BODY:
American consumers lost little last week when the Clinton administration scuttled a drug-import bill passed with much fanfare last year by a Congress facing an election. The bill was intended to curb the rapidly rising costs of prescription drugs to patients and health insurers by allowing Americans to buy American-made medications at the lower, regulated prices found abroad.
 In the hunt for affordable prescription drugs, that bill was a toothless tiger. True, drugmakers charge more in America, lowering the price tag for foreign customers that resist higher prices. But this "price discrimination," as economists call it, is a common one in industries that have high fixed costs but marginal production costs. For pharmaceutical companies, research and development costs are high, but the cost of making the pills are relatively low. That's why they can sell their products at cut-rate prices to foreign buyers, who otherwise could not afford them. 
 The problem with price discrimination in the drug industry is its morally troublesome impact on the millions of Americans -- many of them elderly -- who don't have insurance coverage for such drugs. But the proper response to this inequity and to high drug prices generally is not importing our exports. Instead, American health insurers and consumers should do what prudent buyers do in other markets: evaluate products before paying for them.
Rising prices are driven by a growing stream of new, "me-too" medications -- concentrated in the antihistamine, antidepressant and anticholesterol categories -- that typically cost twice or three times as much as the drugs they replace. And neither the medical profession nor insurers have shown much interest in finding out if the higher-priced drugs offer commensurately superior benefits. 
For drug prices to drop, that must change. Private insurers and the government should agree to set aside just 1 percent of their collective yearly spending on prescription drugs and endow a $1 billion research institute. Such a private, nonprofit institute would be an authoritative, independent source of reputable research into whether new, improved drugs are, indeed, significantly new and improved.
Armed with such research, insurance companies could then adopt a system of "reference pricing," which has been used successfully in Germany to curb drug spending. Under that system, insurers reimburse patients fully only for the relatively low-cost effective drugs, but require consumers who want a higher-priced alternative to pay the price difference. 
To be sure, efficacy is not always the issue for patients, even well-informed ones. Some new drugs offer more convenient dosages or somewhat fewer side effects. A judicious system of reference pricing could reimburse consumers at a slightly higher rate for the newer drug, but still require that consumers who want the marginally better medication pay more out of their own pockets. 
Patients should always be able to spend their own money on the latest drugs, if they wish to. But if drug spending is to be curbed, patients cannot receive financing for slightly improved medications at whatever cost. Independent research and reference pricing are a solution -- a market solution that puts power where it belongs -- on the demand side.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
Medical Concern Growing Over Shortages of Drugs
Doctors, pharmacists and regulators are increasingly concerned about what they say are more frequent drug shortages. Where a few years ago a hospital might have a shortage of one or two critical drugs a year, the number in the last year has been closer to two dozen.
 There is no single reason for the shortages. Some stem from the drug industry's rapid consolidation. In some cases, regulators found problems at factories making the drugs and shut down production until processes were improved. And some big drug companies have stopped making the older drugs and have instead reserved factory capacity for newer drugs, which make more money. Page A1. 

AT&T to Increase Its Cable Rates
AT&T said that it would increase its cable television rates by an average of 4.8 percent this year even as it secured a big credit line arranged by some of the nation's largest banks. AT&T said the rate increase reflected higher costs, particularly increased payments to cable networks for programming. Shares of AT&T rose $1, to $18.25. C4.

Yahoo to Ban Sale of Hate Material
After months of pressure from anti-hate groups, Yahoo said that it would use human reviewers and software to keep hateful and violent material out of its auctions, classified sections and shopping areas. C2.

Dividends Fall 2.5% for S.& P. 500
Dividends on stocks in the Standard & Poor's 500 fell 2.5 percent last year, making it the first decline in nearly a decade and the first one ever that could not easily be explained by economic factors or government regulations. Floyd Norris: Market Place. C9.

A Makeover for the Maytag Man
The "lonely" Maytag repairman, one of the best-known characters in advertising since his introduction in 1967, is getting recast and rethought for a new generation of consumers. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C8.

'Dirty Fingernails' 80 Hours a Week
Wade Dokken, the chief executive of American Skandia, a financial services concern in Shelton, Conn., is always asking people to criticize him. "How do you learn and become someone in life without that?" he said. He describes his management style as "dirty fingernails" and works 80 hours a week. "The only way I see balancing work and family is I don't do social things. My life is work, children, my wife and church." The Boss. C6.

Legend to Resume Some Service
Legend Airlines, which offered first-class service at coach prices for fliers to and from Dallas until it was forced into bankruptcy, has found new investors and plans to resume service to New York and Washington. Joe Sharkey: Business Travel. C8.

HEADLINE: Factory Index Fell Sharply Last Month 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
United States manufacturers received sharply fewer orders, made fewer products and employed fewer workers in December than they did in the previous month, sending a closely watched index of manufacturing activity to its lowest level since 1991.
 Over the course of 2000, the index fell more steeply than in any year since 1979, according to a report released yesterday by the National Association of Purchasing Management. Last month, the index stood at 43.7, down from 47.7 in November, suggesting that the overall economy was growing at a rate of less than 1 percent a year, based on historical patterns, the association said. A reading above 50 indicates growth in manufacturing, while a reading below that level indicates a contraction. 
 The unexpectedly steep decline helped send the dollar to its lowest exchange level against the euro in six months as traders bet that Europe might now be economically stronger than the United States. Wall Street's principal stock gauges fell yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index closing at 2,291.86, down 7.23 percent on the first trading day of 2001.
The manufacturing report added a new intensity to the debate over whether the United States economy was headed for a recession this year. The one-fifth of the economy devoted to manufacturing has already fallen beyond the stage of slow growth and is now shrinking, according to the index. 
New orders dropped particularly steeply in December, suggesting that a rebound was unlikely in the next few months, said Norbert J. Ore, the head of the committee that publishes the purchasing association's report. In addition to orders, the index measures production, inventories, delivery times and employment by surveying purchasing managers across the United States.
The services sector, though, continues to expand, albeit less rapidly than in early 2000, and most economists still expect the country to avoid a recession this year. Many analysts think that the Federal Reserve is ready to soon cut interest rates, and some note that energy prices have begun falling. 
Still, the decline in manufacturing, coming on top of a falling stock market, weak holiday sales and slower growth in technology investments by businesses, has increased the economy's vulnerability. A minority of economists argue that even without a shock -- like an unexpected oil shortage or major bankruptcy -- the economy will contract in 2001. For example, Robert J. Barbera, chief economist at the investment firm of Hoenig & Company, said yesterday that the manufacturing index's low level suggested that the country slipped into a recession in the fourth quarter of 2000.
Either way, the index offered the latest evidence that economic activity has slowed much more rapidly than executives, investors and Federal Reserve economists were predicting even a few months ago. Analysts now expect the Fed to cut interest rates either late this month or at its meeting after that, in March, to encourage new spending. Bonds rose yesterday in anticipation of a rate cut.
But the Fed's job could be complicated by lingering fears of inflation. Despite the slowdown, manufacturers reported paying higher prices in December than they did in previous months, raising the specter of 1970's-style stagflation, in which a combination of rising prices and slowing growth handcuffs the Federal Reserve.
The Fed raised rates six times in 1999 and 2000 to put the brakes on a fast-growing economy that some worried would spur inflation. In recent months, those increases have combined with rising debt, higher energy costs and falling stock prices to make both consumers and businesses wary about expensive new purchases. At its most recent meeting, the Fed switched its so-called bias, announcing that it thought a recession was a greater threat than inflation.
Personal spending on big-ticket items, like cars and refrigerators, has fallen sharply since the middle of 2000, while corporate investment in computers and software -- a linchpin of the decade-long boom -- is no longer growing as rapidly as it was. As a result, inventories have begun to swell, and manufacturers like Ford and Whirlpool have laid off workers.
Some economists are worried that the rapid slowdown is entering a vicious cycle, in which job losses create nervousness more broadly among consumers, leading to less spending and, eventually, more layoffs. "The more abrupt a slowdown is, the more uncertainty there is about how deep it will go," said Joel Prakken, chairman of Macroeconomic Advisers, a consulting firm in St. Louis.
Analysts said they were looking to Friday's employment report as the next key indicator of how quickly the Fed is likely to reduce interest rates.
The Dana Corporation, a $13 billion maker of automotive components based in Toledo, Ohio, is typical of the slumping manufacturing sector. Through the first half of 2000, orders for axles that turn the wheels of large trucks continued growing robustly, causing truck makers like Navistar and Volvo to increase production, said Gary J. Corrigan, a spokesman for Dana. 
Last summer, however, truck orders began falling sharply, leaving companies with excess inventory. Manufacturers then cut their orders from suppliers like Dana. Its sales have dropped, and the company has laid off 5,000 of its 80,000 workers in recent months, Mr. Corrigan said.
Only one of the 20 manufacturing industries tracked by the index -- printing and publishing -- said its business improved last month.
Perhaps the one piece of good news, Mr. Ore of the purchasing association said, is a widespread decline in inventories, which indicates that companies are able to sell enough goods to begin emptying their warehouses.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Continuing Investor Worries Keep Stocks Sliding in 2001

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks began 2001 the way they finished 2000 -- plunging -- as investors continued to worry about the impact of slowing economic growth on corporate profits.
 The batting about of the "R" word -- recession -- is making investors even more jumpy because that could turn the slower growth in profits that many investors are now expecting into a decline in profits. 
 As usual, the technology sector took the lead yesterday, with the Nasdaq composite index down 7.2 percent, led by a 13 percent decline in Cisco Systems. The Nasdaq, which closed at 2,291.86, slipping 178.66 points, is now down to where it was in March 1999, having lost nearly all the gains of the last two years. 
It was the worst percentage decline for the technology-heavy Nasdaq since April 14 last year, when it fell 9.7 percent, and the seventh-worst daily percentage decline in history.
"This continuing unwinding of the technology overinvestment is dominating the market," said Richard E. Cripps, chief market strategist at Legg Mason Wood Walker in Baltimore. "The carnage in technology is exaggerating the overall weakness in the market." The problem, he said, is that he expects the technology "bloodbath" to continue for a while.
The Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.3 percent, weighed down by a 6 percent slide in Boeing, a stock that had a really good year in 2000. The Dow closed at 10,646.15, falling 140.70 points. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 2.8 percent, or 37.01 points, to 1,283.27.
But the bond market rallied as investors got another signal that the economy was slowing. The National Association of Purchasing Management reported that its factory index fell to 43.7 percent in December, its lowest reading since April 1991, the month after the end of the last recession. A reading below 50 signals that the manufacturing sector is contracting.
That news sent bond prices higher and yields lower, with the Treasury's 10-year note breaking below 5 percent for the first time since February 1999. Bonds were also helped by investors fleeing from the stock market.
Both the purchasing management report and the continued worries about the outlook for stocks are going to turn investor focus more sharply on the Federal Reserve. Just a month ago, when Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Fed, signaled that the central bank was ready to cut interest rates at the hint of a recession, many analysts were forecasting a rate cut by the end of the first quarter.
But as more data have showed growth slowing swiftly -- and as more and more Wall Street economists have been revising their economic forecasts downward -- analysts are now saying the Fed will cut interest rates at its next meeting Jan. 30-31, if not before.
"Investors have to figure out whether we are in for slower profit growth and one or two Fed easings or declining profits and a sharp decline in the federal funds rate," which is the central bank's benchmark short-term interest rate, said Robert J. Barbera, the chief economist at Hoenig & Company in Rye Brook, N.Y. "I am in the latter camp," he added, saying that he sees enough signs now to believe that the economy is in a recession.
Mr. Cripps said that he was not sure if there would be a recession. But, he said, "it will feel like it whether we are down 1 percent or up 1 percent."
The decline yesterday was no surprise. Even after finishing the worst year in more than two decades for stocks, many analysts warned that the beginning of 2001 would be rough because all the bad news about weak earnings and slowing economic growth is not out yet.
The first-quarter earnings forecast for the S.& P. 500 is already down to 4.7 percent, from 15.6 percent on Oct. 1, according to First Call/Thomson Financial.
In addition to Cisco and Boeing, the market was led lower by declines in Veritas Software, EMC, Oracle, Qualcomm and other technology stocks.
Dane Lewis, an analyst at Robertson Stephens Inc., downgraded a group of network storage and security companies, including EMC, which was off $12.19, to $54.31; Veritas, down $21.50, to $66; Network Appliance, off $12.75, to $51.44; and Internet Security Systems, off $13.25, to $65.19.
He said, in a report on the investment bank's Web site, that recent industry checks suggested that information technology purchases for storage would fall sharply in the first quarter of this year. He also said that companies were likely to delay plans for network expansion, which will cut into purchases of products to detect vulnerability and intrusion.
In the afternoon, Boeing, which fell $4, to $62, reported that it had delivered 489 jetliners last year, one short of its forecast of 490. But analysts expect it to be hurt by the economic slowdown. Investors might also be anxious to lock in profits after Boeing surged 59 percent last year.
Mr. Cripps said that stocks were also pushed lower by people who had delayed taking a capital gain until the new year. A lot of the popular technology stocks that fell sharply last year were still up over the last several years. And by selling them yesterday, the investor postponed the capital gain until April 2002, rather than paying up by this April.
But because these stocks have been falling so fast, these investors pulled the trigger as soon as the new year began.
Among the stocks fighting the downward trend were Exxon Mobil, up $2.19, to $89.13. Exxon and other energy stocks are being bolstered by talk among members of the Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries about cutting production this month to stop the recent decline in the price of crude oil. From a peak of $37.20 a barrel on Sept. 20, it has dropped to $27.21.
In the Treasury market, the price of the 10-year note rose 1 17/32, to 106 12/32. The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell 4.91 percent, from 5.10 percent Friday. The yield on the 30-year bond dropped to 5.34 percent from 5.46 percent Friday.

HEADLINE: LESSONS; 
Poverty and Achievement, And Great Misconceptions

BYLINE:  By Richard Rothstein; E-mail: rrothstein@nytimes.com

 BODY:
EVERYONE wants to raise the achievement of low-income pupils, but there is little agreement on how to do so. One approach is to identify exceptional schools and seek to copy their techniques.
 In that spirit, the conservative Heritage Foundation has studied 21 schools with both high poverty and high achievement. In its report, "No Excuses," Heritage claims that these schools succeed because their principals defy public education bureaucracies, substitute basics for progressive education fads, do a lot of testing, fire uninspiring teachers (or harass them until they leave) and refuse to blame poverty or other family disadvantage for low scores. 
 In such ways, the report says, these schools escape a destructive "cult of public education."
Yet it seems that ideology, not evidence, inspired the conclusion.
Three of the 21 schools that the report identified are private, and several of the public schools are at least partly selective. A Queens school it chose, P.S. 122, includes a program for gifted pupils drawn from the entire district, so its high average scores tell us little about how to improve achievement of the most disadvantaged children.
The report's biggest flaw is its assumption that poverty alone defines the problems of the low-income school. Rather, schools with consistently low scores typically have children for whom poverty per se is only one problem. They also suffer crime-ridden neighborhoods, broken families, parental stress, inadequate housing and poor health.
Data on school demography, however, usually disclose only pupils eligible for subsidized lunches. This includes some with family income as high as $30,000. These are often children with stable homes and parents regularly employed. It is foolish for the "No Excuses" report to suggest that if some schools in such places succeed, schools with much poorer children who have multiple social and economic problems can too.
Consider Bennett-Kew Elementary School in Inglewood, Calif., a "No Excuses" school. Its pupils are in the lunch program, but 30 percent have parents who graduated from college, a rate higher than the national average; 12 percent have parents with graduate degrees. Bennett-Kew may be terrific, but can schools filled with the children of high school dropouts learn much from it?
Or consider another "No Excuses" school, Morse Elementary in Cambridge, Mass. It has bilingual classes in Korean and Chinese for children of graduate students and faculty members at Harvard University and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. Graduate students may have incomes low enough for their children to get subsidized lunches, but schools with children of less literate immigrants cannot just as easily post high scores.
"No Excuses" says its 21 schools succeed by discarding whole language, "new" math and social promotion. But evidence does not support this at several of its schools. The Amelia Earhart School in Chicago mixes whole language and phonics, and rarely holds back students who are below grade level (though it does give them extra help).
Some of the schools that rely heavily on phonics have a curious test score pattern, with higher scores in early grades but lower scores later. This is true, for example, at the Mabel B. Wesley School in Houston, which has won national acclaim for a scripted program of drill in basics.
Samuel Casey Carter, author of the report, says such score declines in upper grades occur at all schools. For older pupils, he says, exams test not just phonetic skills but also comprehension, and are harder.
But that explanation makes no sense. Scores are reported as national percentiles. So, by definition, at every grade half the nation's pupils are above the 50th percentile and half below it. If ranks drop in a school as pupils move to upper grades, they must be doing worse compared with pupils elsewhere than when they were younger. Their school may be sacrificing comprehension to excessive focus on phonics.
Some "No Excuses" schools score well on commercial tests, but poorly on state exams aligned with a richer curriculum. Thus, the Healthy Start Academy in Durham, N.C., has high scores on some tests, but North Carolina designates it "low performing" because its state scores are so low. This inconsistency, too, may result from emphasizing basic skills to the exclusion of more advanced thinking that new state standards require.
The Heritage Foundation highlights some practices that do breed success. These include teacher collaboration, strong leadership and parent involvement. But it also highlights others, like near-exclusive drill in phonics and computation, that seem inspired more by ideology than results.
Regrettably, the report as a whole is enveloped in such contempt for most public education that its valid messages are lost.

CORRECTION-DATE: January 5, 2001

 CORRECTION:
The Lessons column on Wednesday, about a report by the Heritage Foundation on successful practices at 21 schools, referred incorrectly to a bilingual education program at Morse Elementary in Cambridge, Mass. It teaches only in Korean, not also in Chinese.

HEADLINE: Pataki Seeks New Measures Against Guns 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
Five months after New York adopted the nation's strictest gun controls, Gov. George E. Pataki today called for a campaign against illegal gun trafficking, with tougher criminal penalties and the creation of a state police team.
 The proposals amount to an admission that the changes made last year will make little difference as long as guns are easy to buy in other states and import into New York, a point his aides acknowledged. The proposals also further underscore the vast distance between Mr. Pataki, a Republican, and the national Republican Party on gun controls. 
 "We think it's an important, very important, next step in reducing crime," the governor said, speaking to reporters at the swearing-in of a new judge of the Court of Appeals, Victoria A. Graffeo.
Mr. Pataki's comments signaled his first major policy proposal for the new year, one of several he will offer on Wednesday in his annual State of the State speech. Unlike recent years, when rent control, tax cuts or health care subsidies dominated the agenda here, this year presents no overarching issue for the governor and the State Legislature, but there is also no shortage of important matters to address.
State lawmakers are worried that New York could face an electric power shortage like the one in California, and Mr. Pataki said today that he had some plans for avoiding that fate.
This year, New York also faces a number of problems whose solutions may run into the billions of dollars, like renewing the Child Health Plus program, finding a new source of money for the nearly broke toxic waste cleanup program, and figuring out how to pay for planned mass transit projects after voters rejected a $3.8 billion transportation bond act in November.
The Republican leader of the State Senate, Joseph L. Bruno, has staked out investment in biotechnology research, energy conservation and, in light of last year's controversy in Florida, changes in election procedures as his primary issues. "The objective, really, is to create access, ready access, so that people can vote that want to vote," he said today.
Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, a Democrat, is still dealing with the fallout from an attempt by a rival faction to topple him last year. The Assembly will weigh a number of proposals intended, in part, to address dissidents' concerns and loosen the power of the speaker. Mr. Silver must also select a new majority leader, the second-highest post in the chamber, a choice that is fraught with regional and factional jealousies.
Mr. Pataki will propose his 2001-2002 budget next Tuesday, and some legislators are predicting that after sizable spending increases in recent years, growth could be less this time because of a slowing economy and promised tax cuts that take effect this year. The governor has proposed a modest package of tax cuts for businesses and homeowners, and today he called for expansion of the Empire Zone program, in which the state offers incentives for employers to move to blighted areas.
But the issues that end up lighting a fire under the Capitol are often ones that were not widely anticipated at the start of the year, making prediction a dicey game. Last year, Mr. Pataki waited until March to propose a sweeping gun control package, catching legislators in both parties by surprise. Despite considerable opposition from Senate Republicans, the package was passed in June, and Mr. Pataki signed it in August.
The new law will make New York the first state to require "ballistic fingerprinting" of all new guns sold, so that the telltale markings they leave on bullets and shell casings can be entered into a state computer database. The law requires criminal background checks on buyers at gun shows, bans assault weapons, raises the age for buying a handgun to 21 from 18, requires that trigger locks be included with all new handguns sold, and requires gun owners to report lost or stolen guns to the police within 24 hours.
Today, the governor proposed the creation of a new unit within the state police devoted exclusively to combating illegal gun trafficking. Law enforcement officials say that three of every four guns used in crimes in New York were originally sold in another state and then imported and sold here illegally.
Mr. Pataki and his aides would not say how big the antigun unit would be, but he said he would devote "substantial resources" to it.
The governor called for longer prison sentences for illegal gun possession and possession with intent to sell. He said he would also close loopholes that prosecutors have long complained allow traffickers to avoid the harsh penalties for illegal sales of several guns at once.

HEADLINE: COMPANY BRIEFS 

 BODY:
 FERRO CORP., Cleveland, a maker of chemicals and plastics, said it had acquired the EMCA-Remex unit of the National Starch and Chemical Company, Bridgewater, N.J., for an undisclosed price to broaden its electronic-pastes product line. National Starch and Chemical is a unit of Imperial Chemical Industries of Britain.

SBA COMMUNICATIONS CORP., Boca Raton, Fla., which owns equipment used to relay cellular-phone signals, said it had acquired 127 antenna towers from US Unwired Inc., Lake Charles, La., for about $40 million in cash. US Unwired is a network affiliate of the PCS Group of Sprint.

NACCO INDUSTRIES INC.,Mayfield Heights, Ohio, which designs, makes and markets forklift trucks and also owns coal mining and household appliance companies, said it would close Nacco Materials Handling Group Inc., its lift truck assembly plant subsidiary in Danville, Ill., putting about 680 people out of work in a phase-out covering 12 to 18 months.

TYLER TECHNOLOGIES INC., Dallas, an information-management company, has sold the land records business unit of its subsidiary, the Business Resources Corporation, to Affiliated Computer Services Inc., an information-processing services company, also of Dallas, for $71 million in cash.

INTERGRAPH CORP., Huntsville, Ala., a computer services company, said it had completed the sale of three engineering-software product lines to the closely held Bentley Systems Inc., Exton, Pa., for about $40 million. Bentley, which is 30 percent owned by Intergraph, provides technology services to engineering, construction and architectural markets.

HEADLINE: Metro Business Briefing; 
COUNTIES' CREDIT RATINGS

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 The credit-worthiness of New York's counties is generally average and getting better, though some continue to struggle, a Wall Street firm says. Moody's Investors Service found the counties around New York City to be in good shape -- except for deficit-plagued Nassau County, which saw its credit rating drop in 2000 -- and some pockets of strength upstate. 
And some small, chiefly rural counties continued to be deemed worse-than-average credit risks because of factors like higher unemployment rates, debt, poverty rates, the wealth of residents, population losses, recently built housing stocks and tax revenues. Marcy Block, a Moody's analyst, said that among regions of the state, the Catskills had the lowest median credit rating of Baa1, while the North Country, the Mohawk Valley and western New York were a notch ahead at A3. The Finger Lakes region had the strongest median credit rating at A1. County credit-ratings range from the best, Aaa, to the worst, Baa3.

HEADLINE: Soros Sees a Hard Landing for the U.S. 

BYLINE:  Reuters 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Jan. 2 

 BODY:
George Soros, the billionaire financier, told a Chilean newspaper that the United States economy was in for a "bouncy and hard" landing, but his main concern was for spillover turmoil in emerging markets.
 In an interview with Chile's El Mercurio newspaper, Mr. 
Soros also said he believed that a global crisis was inevitable even though he expected the Federal Reserve to lower key interest rates aggressively early this year. 
 "I believe that it will be bouncy and hard," the newspaper quoted him as saying. "A hard landing means a slowdown and could eventually turn into a recession or in low growth for a couple of quarters. We are in a fairly classic slowdown cycle in the United States. 
"But I am much more worried about the consequences on the edge of the system because this edge has been weakened because of the 1997-1998 crisis, and I believe will have more serious repercussions in distant regions, such as Southeast Asia."
Mr. Soros said the problem with the looming crisis was inadequate capital flows from industrial nations to emerging nations.
