HEADLINE: THE RATE CUT: THE ADVISER; 
Contrarian of Boom Decade Put in Bush Inner Circle

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
While America celebrated a decade of prosperity, Lawrence B. Lindsey spent the 1990's warning of an imminent economic tightening.
 Consumers were spending far beyond their means, he said. The nation depended too much on foreign lending. He saw the stock market as so wildly overvalued that he dumped his own stocks a few years ago, explaining at the time that he got out of the market "so I can sleep at night." 
 Mr. Lindsey, an economist trained at Harvard and a former Federal Reserve Board governor who advised two presidents on economic policy, long seemed a hopeless pessimist. Today, he looked like a vindicated prophet.
President-elect George W. Bush named Mr. Lindsey, 46, as his White House economic adviser, formalizing Mr. Lindsey's role as the incoming administration's top thinker on economic matters. The appointment came the same day Mr. Bush presided over a conference in Austin to promote the tax cuts Mr. Lindsey has designed as a way to protect the nation against an economic slump, and just an hour after the Fed confirmed a gloomier outlook for the economy with a sharp cut in interest rates.
"Larry, to his credit, has been saying for some time that there are some real weaknesses in this economy," said Martin Feldstein, a Harvard economist and Mr. Lindsey's longtime mentor. "It sure looks that way now."
In his new post, Mr. Lindsey will have the president's ear on all matters economic, including tax policy, Social Security, the budget and economic relations with major foreign allies, like Japan and the European Union. That continues the role he played during the campaign, when Mr. Lindsey shaped the proposals for a $1.6 trillion tax cut, a Social Security overhaul and other core issues in Mr. Bush's campaign.
But his power within the new administration remains uncertain. His appointment came relatively late in the Bush transition, after all cabinet posts had been filled and much of the rest of the White House team was in place. Although Mr. Lindsey was once thought of as a potential Treasury secretary, that position went to Paul H. O'Neill, the retired chief executive of Alcoa and a Republican heavyweight who has his own strong views on economic management.
Mr. Lindsey has not been assigned either of the titles normally bestowed on the administration's top economist. Mr. Bush named him assistant to the president for economic affairs, but has yet to say who will head the Council of Economic Advisers or the National Economic Council, the two posts that carry the most bureaucratic weight on economic matters in the White House.
"We'll let you know," Mr. Bush said in response to a question on the matter. "Not to diminish Mr. Lindsey," he added.
It remains possible that Mr. Lindsey will be named to one or both of those positions. But the failure to do so today leaves open the possibility that Mr. Lindsey will have to share responsibilities with another economist or that Mr. Bush will permit other cabinet departments, including Treasury and Commerce, to exercise more influence over economic policy than they had during the Clinton administration, two people connected with the Bush transition said.
Still, it is hard to diminish Mr. Lindsey. Seated beside Mr. Bush today at the economic conference, he was both far taller and wider than the president-elect. His sunny demeanor seemed to defy his dour predictions about the economy.
While other economists said the Clinton-era economic expansion could quickly run out of steam, few had Mr. Lindsey's economic insight and political instinct.
Lawrence Benjamin Lindsey is married with two children. He was born July 18, 1954, in Peekskill, N.Y., to parents who taught at public schools. He attended Bowdoin College in Maine, where he sold hot dogs to help pay his college bills.
He went to Harvard to get his doctorate in economics. There he met Mr. Feldstein, a leading macroeconomist who became President Ronald Reagan's chief economic adviser and brought Mr. Lindsey, then in his late 20's, to the White House.
Mr. Lindsey returned to Harvard to complete his dissertation and became one of the nation's leading specialists on tax policy. He has sought to diagnose how taxes affect economic growth, corporate investment and consumer savings and spending. He has also been a leading defender of President Reagan's 1981 tax cuts. A 1990 book he wrote on the subject, "The Growth Experiment," concluded that the sharp reduction in tax rates revolutionized the American economy at relatively little cost to the federal government.
He returned to Washington as an economic adviser to President George Bush, who appointed him a Federal Reserve Board governor. Mr. Lindsey was one of the youngest people to hold the post. Mr. Lindsey developed a close relationship with Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman.
Though he is a somewhat shame-faced supply-sider -- he rejects the label and has tempered his championship of tax cuts with measures intended to aid lower income groups -- Mr. Lindsey has become a hero to conservative economists, one of the most eloquent and persistent defenders of Reaganomics.
"Larry has always been a little over the top in support of the Reagan tax cuts," said Alan Blinder, who worked with Mr. Lindsey when the two were Fed governors and who is now an economist at Princeton University. But Mr. Blinder, who has sparred repeatedly with Mr. Lindsey and served as one of Vice President Al Gore's top advisers, said Mr. Lindsey was a smart, multidimensional economist who, unlike some supply-siders, does not focus exclusively on taxes.
"There is more to life than marginal tax rates, and he knows it," Mr. Blinder said.
As the 2000 presidential race approached, Mr. Lindsey frequently wrote op-ed articles staking out positions on a variety of economic topics. He criticized the way the Clinton administration managed the dollar.
He has repeatedly said that the Clinton administration has bungled relations with Japan, the world's second-largest economy, and has called for a more cooperative relationship with that nation.
But the main issue that ingratiated Mr. Lindsey to the president-elect was taxes. Mr. Lindsey drew up a plan to reduce rates for all taxpayers, including a reduction in the top rate to 33 percent from 39.6 percent. He argued passionately that the tax reductions would prompt consumers to save more money, helping insulate the nation from a deep recession if the long boom -- which he has repeatedly called a bubble -- were to pop.
Democrats criticized the tax cut as a giveaway to the rich that threatened the drive to reduce government debt. The warnings were echoed by many mainstream economists, especially because the nation's economy at the time the tax plan was proposed seemed poised to overheat, rather than contract.
But Mr. Lindsey, like Cassandra, has stuck to his forecast, and he will now have a chance to help a president push for tax reductions at a time when the economy appears to have cooled dramatically.

HEADLINE: THE RATE CUT: THE STRATEGY; 
The First Cut is Not Taxes

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
In using his power over interest rates yesterday, Alan Greenspan found himself in the middle of a debate over whether his move would help or hinder President-elect George W. Bush's push to enact a big tax cut.
 In one view, Mr. Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, ratified all the warnings that Mr. Bush and his team had issued in recent weeks about the risks of a downturn, and signaled that the economy needed all the help it could get. A tax cut, in this view, is more necessary than ever to give the economy a kick. 
 Alternatively, Mr. Greenspan is acting pre-emptively, before the new administration takes office, to assert that the central bank has things under control. Monetary policy, not fiscal policy, is the appropriate and most effective tool, in this view, for managing the ups and downs of the business cycle, and while there might be a case for a tax cut, it should not be driven by short-term economic conditions.
Is Mr. Greenspan Mr. Bush's new best friend? Or is he a nemesis?
"There are two diametrically opposed ways to read this," said Alan S. Blinder, a former Fed vice chairman who was an adviser to Vice President Al Gore in the presidential campaign.
"One is that Greenspan has now thrown in his lot with Bush-Cheney in terms of the danger of the economy going to hell," he said.
"The other way is to read this as verifying the view of almost all economists that are not in the actual or hoped-for employ of the Bush administration that if you're going to take action to bolster the economy it better be through monetary policy because the Fed can act quickly. Greenspan is aware that he is sort of doing both," Mr. Blinder said. 
The Federal Reserve nearly always acts on the basis of economic conditions, and there is nothing to suggest that its decision to cut interest rates yesterday was motivated by anything but a desire to steer away from a looming recession. But Mr. Greenspan is one of the most experienced of Washington hands, and he is well aware that he operates in a very political context. In a city where politics and economics are inextricably mixed, he commands considerable sway, sometimes more than he intends, on issues not directly under his purview.
Mr. Greenspan has a somewhat complicated view of tax cuts, one that allows both supporters and opponents of Mr. Bush's plan to claim him as an ally.
As the federal budget surplus has grown in recent years, Mr. Greenspan has repeatedly stressed that the first priority should be to pay down the national debt. His position helped President Clinton and Democrats in Congress to block Republican tax cuts over the last few years.
But Mr. Greenspan is an ideological conservative with a strong belief that reducing taxes helps improve the economy's ability to grow over the long run. And he has always left himself some wiggle room by saying that if the choice is between cutting taxes or increasing government spending, he much prefers tax cuts.
With projections of the surplus rising almost by the month, Mr. Greenspan could also signal down the road that there is enough money on the table to reduce the debt substantially and have enough left over for a sizable tax cut. And with Mr. Bush pledging to hold down government spending, Mr. Greenspan could have cover to say that the risks of profligacy are under control.
In Washington, members of both parties are looking closely at the emerging relationship between Mr. Bush and Mr. Greenspan, especially given the rocky relationship between the Fed chairman and Mr. Bush's father, who has blamed the Fed in part for his loss in 1992.
It was no doubt an accident of timing that Mr. Greenspan acted so muscularly on a day when Mr. Bush was meeting with business executives to build a case for his plan to cut taxes by $1.6 trillion over 10 years -- the same day on which Congress convened to begin considering the president-elect's agenda.
But it was hard to miss the symbolism of the Fed trumping Mr. Bush's message of the day, even if inadvertently. And the timing served to intensify the debate over the merits of Mr. Bush's tax plan.
Before the Fed's surprise decision, Democratic leaders were signaling that the downturn had reached a stage where they were open to a bigger tax cut than they would have supported a few months ago, though not one as big as Republicans were pressing for. 
After the Fed's announcement, Democrats suggested that if the Fed were successful, there would be less need to make the tax cut as big as Mr. Bush wants, or to rush it through Congress.
"I think most economists would argue that reducing the interest rate has more immediate impact on spurring the economy than anything we can do with taxes," said Senator Tom Daschle of South Dakota, the Democratic leader. "So I think it does to a certain extent take away the argument that we've got to point to taxes as the only way to continue to see this economic growth. We're going to be able to do it and we can do it through lower interest rates."
Republicans said monetary policy and fiscal policy could work hand in hand.

HEADLINE: THE RATE CUT: THE REACTION; 
Bush Cheers Fed's Action And Tax Cut

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 3 

 BODY:
Surprised and buoyed by Alan Greenspan's sudden cut in interest rates, President-elect George W. Bush and a group of American business leaders he was meeting with today said the Federal Reserve chairman's action underscored the need for a deep, across-the-board tax cut to sustain economic growth.
 "One of the messages Mr. Greenspan sent was that we need bold action, not only at the Fed, but I would interpret that to mean bold action in the halls of Congress to make sure this economy stays vibrant," Mr. Bush told reporters today, shortly after an aide interrupted his lunch with the executives to pass on the news that the financial landscape had changed as they were meeting. John F. Welch Jr., the soon-to-retire chairman of General Electric, said the group responded by "raising a glass of water" in a toast to Mr. Greenspan. 
 Mr. Bush, brushing past Mr. Greenspan's reservations about deep tax cuts, added: "I think it's really important for members of the Congress to understand that the tax relief plan I've put forth is an integral part of economic recovery." 
At the same time, Mr. Bush was clearly trying to ensure that the rate cut did not take the wind out of his tax plan, arguing today that an easing of interest rates was not enough. "I think that if you were to talk to the business leaders here, they'll tell you that a rate reduction of one-half percent is not enough to serve as a stimulus to encourage capital formation, economic growth, job creation," he said. "It's going to require not only monetary policy reform but also fiscal policy reform."
Mr. Bush's aides said that the interest rate cut was likely to set the relationship between the incoming president and the Fed chairman off to a good start -- in sharp contrast to the frosty interchanges between Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Bush's father, the former president. The elder Mr. Bush blamed Mr. Greenspan for not moving fast enough to speed the recovery from the recession of the early 1990's that ultimately cost the former president the 1992 election. 
After their lunch with the president-elect was over, a parade of executives who flew in here today for the modest economic discussions -- they lasted only two and a half hours -- endorsed Mr. Bush's tax cut plan. That was hardly a surprise: the invitation list was heavily skewed toward big contributors to the Bush presidential campaign last year and toward business executives and economists who were known for their agreement with Mr. Bush's economic strategy.
"There was zippo argument on the need for a tax cut, none whatsoever," said Floyd Kvamme, the Silicon Valley venture capitalist who has occasionally been named as a possible "technology czar" in the Bush White House. "We didn't discuss the details, but the direction that everyone wanted to go was clear. The only question was how fast it could be done."
In fact, Mr. Bush's aides voiced the hope today that their effort to win support for a broad tax cut got a significant political boost today. By acting between meetings of the Fed's governing board, an unusual step, Mr. Greenspan was essentially endorsing the more dire view of the American slowdown that Mr. Bush and his vice president-elect, Dick Cheney, have been describing in recent weeks. That is in considerable contrast to the Clinton administration's portrayal of the economy; in fact, during his visit to Washington just before Christmas, Mr. Bush sat silently in the Oval Office as Mr. Clinton recited a series of economic projections that made the slowdown sound considerably less severe.
But the numbers have worsened ever since, and Mr. Bush's aides have said, when speaking on condition that their names not be used, that Mr. Clinton was simply trying to preserve his legacy as the president who commanded one of the most spectacular rises in American economic history. 
Even some Democrats appear to be moving gingerly in Mr. Bush's direction. This morning, just hours before the Fed announcement, Richard Gephardt, the House minority leader, said of a tax cut: "It may be that it has to get bigger because a recession is looming, and we've got economic worries out there." 
Democrats had previously avoided uttering the word recession. But Mr. Gephardt added: "We're going to fight over the complexion of it. What is it? Who gets it? How much do they get? We think hard-working middle-income families, people trying to get in the middle class, are the ones that really need this tax cut, not the people at the top. I think we can work out a compromise where everybody gets some of what they want." 
After the Fed's announcement, however, Tom Daschle, the Senate Democratic leader, said the Fed's intervention might take the air out of the movement for a tax cut because easing monetary policy would do more to spur the economy in the short run than any tax cut could. 
The "people at the top" that Mr. Gephardt referred to were well represented at the meeting of business leaders, held at a hotel not far from the governor's mansion where Mr. Bush is packing up for his move to the White House. Mr. Bush packed the ballroom with some of the stars of American business, from Mr. Welch and Mr. Kvamme of Kleiner Perkins Caufield Byers, to John Chambers, the chairman of Cisco Systems, and Kenneth Lay, the chairman and chief executive of Enron and one of Mr. Bush's most enthusiastic supporters.
Their exchange began this morning before the Fed's announcement. When word of the action spread, Mr. Bush's top economic adviser, Lawrence B. Lindsey, slipped into the bar next door to watch CNN. "Great," he said, "The Fed is always right." Mr. Lindsey served on the Fed in the early 1990's.
Appropriately, hanging just over the bar is the mounted head of a Texas longhorn -- and a bull run on the market took off as Mr. Bush, Mr. Lindsey and the business leaders were moving to dessert.
Unlike President-elect Clinton's economic summit meeting in December 1992, which was broadcast live and featured the president-elect as seminar leader in a national Economics 101 lecture, Mr. Bush's consultations today were in private. And except for some carefully measured statements that largely restated campaign positions, he let the executives themselves do the talking -- either because he felt they could better build support for his program or because he does not yet feel comfortable musing about the economy and the markets live on television.
"It would be risky," one of the executives who attended today's session said. "He did fine in private. But you know what's it's like -- one slip about the dollar, and the markets would be reacting before he ever got out the door."
Without exception, the executives endorsed Mr. Bush's plan and said Mr. Greenspan had done the right thing today -- but perhaps a little late. "The only wish we had was that they had done it earlier," said Mr. Chambers, whose companies make the servers that drive the Internet. He said that Mr. Bush was "a very good listener, he is good at remembering who people are," what business they are in and how their business is doing.
What the president-elect heard, by and large, reinforced Mr. Bush's view that the economy is headed down faster than expected. Nancy Lazar, a partner at International Strategy and Investments, an investment firm in New York, said after the meeting that "my biggest fear is that the slowdown is more severe and long-lasting than people expect." She said a tax cut would be "a good start " and noted that it would take time, at least six months, for the interest rate cut announced today to flow through the economy.
Several executives at today's session were considered, and rejected, for top posts in the Bush cabinet, including Treasury secretary. A few more appear to be angling for subcabinet positions, and today was a chance for them to strut their stuff, though it had to be done carefully so as not to appear to be too eager for a job in Washington. 
Mr. Bush is about to inherit the job that one participant -- Steve Forbes -- sought until he was knocked out of the Republican primaries. Mr. Forbes said that a tax cut was "a good idea six months ago, 12 months ago, and it's a better idea now." The Fed, he said, "had a weird notion that there was something wrong with prosperity," but he believed that Mr. Greenspan had come around. "The Fed has taken one small step, and the president and the Congress have to take the next one."

HEADLINE: Call for Good Will Opens Narrowly Split Congress 

BYLINE:  By ALISON MITCHELL and LIZETTE ALVAREZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 3 

 BODY:
As President Clinton, spouse, looked on from the Senate visitors gallery, the 107th Congress came into session today so closely divided that the Democrats were able to take control of the Senate, however tenuously, for 17 days until the new Republican administration is sworn in.
 Still struggling over how to share power in such uncharted circumstances, the two parties pleaded for good will. And for a day, at least, they set aside some enmity as they watched some extraordinary, even unprecedented, scenes unfold. 
 Vice President Al Gore, presiding over the Senate in one of his final acts in office, won a standing ovation. He rose to accept the acclaim and laughingly reminded the chamber that "boisterous demonstrations" were forbidden. 
And for the first time in the nation's history, a first lady was sworn into office as a senator: Hillary Rodham Clinton, Democrat of New York. Although she was only one of 11 freshman senators, Mrs. Clinton was like a magnet as she sat in an electric blue pantsuit at her desk in the last row of the Senate chamber. A constant parade of kissing, handshaking and backslapping colleagues came to her side.
From above, President Clinton watched, sometimes whispering to his daughter, Chelsea, and at other moments looking amused or engrossed, his chin cupped in his hand. Mrs. Clinton even won a long hug from 98-year-old Senator Strom Thurmond, Republican of South Carolina. 
All day the fallout from the narrow election was evident and the mood swung from hopeful to bittersweet to confrontational. Not since the Eisenhower administration has there been anything close to the 50-50 split in the Senate and the narrow Republican majority in the House.
"This is a historic day," said Senator Tom Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota. "Never before in the history of our nation have we had a 50-50 Senate."
With Mr. Gore able to cast the tie-breaking vote in the Senate until Dick Cheney is sworn in as vice president on Jan. 20, the defeated presidential candidate declared Mr. Daschle the temporary majority leader. Mr. Daschle grinned broadly at his peculiar 17-day window of power and threw his arms out wide in a gesture of amusement. He promptly won an ovation from both parties.
"I must confess that in six years as minority leader, I've had a moment or two when I wondered if this day would ever arrive," he said. "I assure you I intend to savor every one of the next 17 days." 
Whether the narrow divide brings a new impulse to reach across the aisle or bitter gridlock will determine President-elect George W. Bush's chances of legislative success.
A fierce struggle is expected for the allegiance of the moderate and conservative Democrats who are interested in some parts of Mr. Bush's proposals for education, Social Security and Medicare overhaul.
Showing some willingness to compromise, Representative Richard A. Gephardt, Democrat of Missouri, the House minority leader, and Mr. Daschle said they would be willing to look at larger tax cuts than they had in the past because of the economic slowdown. But they stopped well short of endorsing Mr. Bush's proposed $1.6 trillion 10-year tax cut.
In the House, Representative J. Dennis Hastert of Illinois was elected to a second term as speaker and urged lawmakers to put aside the bitter feelings lingering from the contested presidential election. "It is only in Washington where there may be lingering animosity of the political parties," Mr. Hastert said. "My friends, we need to get over it."
He called on the House to work with Mr. Bush on an agenda including tax cuts, education measures and overhauling the Medicare and Social Security systems. He said Mr. Bush's call for a $1.6 trillion tax cut would "stimulate economic growth." 
"I believe we have a duty to our constituents to consider this proposal," Mr. Hastert said. "Together we can work with the new president to keep our economy strong and to give tax relief to all Americans."
One Democrat, Representative James A. Traficant Jr. of Ohio, who has been wooed by the Republicans with pork-barrel projects, broke party ranks today and supported Mr. Hastert for speaker. Democrats joined Republicans in their applause for the vote, a gesture of good riddance to Mr. Traficant, who has said he expects to be indicted as a result of a corruption investigation in Youngstown, Ohio.
Democrats said Mr. Traficant would no longer be treated as a member of their caucus. "He cannot call himself a member of the Democratic Party," said Laura Nichols, a spokeswoman for Mr. Gephardt.
Another conservative Democrat, Representative Gene Taylor of Mississippi, in protest, voted for Representative John P. Murtha, a conservative Pennsylvania Democrat, as party leader instead of Mr. Gephardt.
Despite two years of bitter struggle for control of the House, Mr. Hastert and Mr. Gephardt were gracious to each other. But it took just hours for House Republicans and Democrats to begin battling over procedure, as the Democrats opposed a package of rules for the new Congress. Democrats said they had not been consulted when the Republicans drew up the proposed rules and that they had not been given adequate representation on committees.
"Bipartisanship should be more than words," Mr. Gephardt said. "It should be backed up by deeds and action."
As part of the rules package, House Republicans abolished the Committee on Banking and created a new panel, the Committee on Financial Services, which includes jurisdiction over securities and insurance. The move could pave the way for the Republicans to bypass Representative Marge Roukema, Republican of New Jersey, a moderate, when they select new committee chairmen on Thursday. Ms. Roukema had been in line for the Banking Committee post.
While tempers did not flare in the Senate, the two parties were still trying to negotiate ground rules for operating with a 50-50 split.
Senator Trent Lott of Mississippi, the majority leader, said Democrats were no longer asking for co-chairmen. "We continue to talk and I think we've made progress," Mr. Lott said.
The Senate quickly passed measures naming Democrats as committee chairmen for the next 17 days and Republicans as chairmen come Jan. 20.
The Democrats are not threatening to do much during their short reign, but that could change if the power-sharing negotiations break down.
Some of the day's most poignant moments belonged to Mr. Gore, who was gracious, funny and impassioned as he swore in the new members of the Congressional Black Caucus and called them the "conscience of the Congress."
And when it came time for the vice president to swear in Senator Joseph I. Lieberman, the Connecticut Democrat who had been his running mate, he gave him a warm hug.

HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The New York Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Museums

* "BEAUTY, HONOR AND TRADITION: THE LEGACY OF PLAINS INDIAN SHIRTS," Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through Nov. 4). To Plains Indians of the 18th and 19th centuries, magnificently decorated hide shirts were symbols of bravery earned only by the most courageous in battle. Obsessively fringed and embellished with porcupine quills, paint, ribbon, hair and, later, tight patterns of colored glass beads, the shirts took on the spirits of their owners and even today are made for wear at powwows and in recognition of more peaceful accomplishments. Celebrating the power of this glory gear, almost 50 dazzlers in the museum's collection are on view, dating from about 1820 to the 1990's. Among the more fascinating examples are a brilliantly painted Crow shirt (1890) with beadwork in geometric patterns and frizzy fringes of dyed magenta and yellow hair, and a Lakota shirt, circa 1890, that sports United States Army insignia, the American flag and stepped tepees topped by crosses, all worked in porcupine quills and metal beads. Hours: 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. daily; Thursdays to 8 p.m. Free. (Grace Glueck).

* "SOL LeWITT: A RETROSPECTIVE," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3676 (through Feb. 25). Unexpectedly the most beautiful exhibition by a living artist in a New York museum in a long time and an antidote to the nonsense in several other museums around town. Just about every other wall is covered with wall drawings, alternately eye-popping and gossamer. Those out there (you know who you are) who flee from any artist linked to Conceptualism may want to stop and re-evaluate your views after seeing what's here. The master of chaste white cubes has undergone a transformation since his last retrospective in the late 70's. Now opulence emerges from the same seemingly prosaic instructions he came up with years ago. The appeal is still to patient observation, a lesson for everyone, delivered elegantly. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 1 to 9 p.m. Admission: $10; $8 for students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).

ADRIAN PIPER, New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Jan. 21). Combining Minimalism, Conceptualism and Performance Art, Ms. Piper has been working since about 1970 to force viewers into awareness of their personal complicity in what she views as a pervasively racist system. The best works in this retrospective produce disturbingly intimate psychological theater, as in the riveting video "Cornered" (1988), in which the artist calmly harangues viewers about their presumed complacency as white people. But much of her work has an off-putting, morally bullying tone. An exception is a small, wry, emotionally vulnerable 1981 drawing, "Self-Portrait Exaggerating My Negroid Features." Hours: Wednesdays and Sundays, noon to 6:30 p.m.; Thursdays through Saturdays, noon to 8 p.m. Admission: $6; $3 for students and the elderly (Ken Johnson).

* CHARLOTTE SALOMON, Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3200 (through March 25). Put aside as much as possible the grim death that has boxed Salomon, like Anne Frank, into the eye-glazing, inviolate category of Holocaust artist, a disservice to her. "Life? Or Theater?," her quasi-fictional diary of text and nearly 800 pictures cued to musical themes, will make you feel you are in good company while flattering your intelligence. The allusions are varied, the tone at times surprisingly light. Film was a big inspiration to Salomon. Images vary among close-ups, flashbacks, long shots and montage. She had an illustrator's gift for distillation and paraphrase. The result is a complex meditation on the connection between love and art. It is a coming-of-age story about a woman squeezing a whole life into one great gesture. Ultimately the energy counts most, a civilizing energy. "Take good care of it," Salomon told the man to whom she entrusted the work before she was shipped off to Auschwitz. "It is my whole life." So it was. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Tuesdays to 8 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students over 11 and the elderly (Kimmelman).

* "JOHN WESLEY: PAINTINGS 1961-2000," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Street, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Jan. 14). For 40 years Mr. Wesley's paintings have maintained the same mild form of constructive lunacy. The art world has a handful of indispensable visionaries like Mr. Wesley who help to keep everyone else honest. You may not enjoy his show, the first full-dress local retrospective, only because simple pleasure is not the intended effect. The images are borrowed from magazines and comics: Blondie and Dagwood, Donald Duck and young naked women, painted flat, like coloring-book designs, with delicate black outlines and off-key colors. The style alludes to Matisse, Hokusai, Greek vase painting, Art Nouveau and Toulouse-Lautrec. Emotion is there below the comic exterior, and it is pathos, mostly. Mr. Wesley offers up sex as unquenchable desire and woeful male inadequacy, a black comedy of men chasing after women they can only dream about. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $5 (Kimmelman).

* "WHO STOLE THE TEPEE?" Smithsonian Institution's National Museum of the American Indian, George Gustav Heye Center, 1 Bowling Green, Lower Manhattan, (212) 514-3700 (through Jan. 21). The question posed here is what happened to native traditions in the 20th century, with comments by 35 contemporary Indian artists in the form of craft work, paintings, drawings, sculptures and photographs. There are earlier artifacts, too, like a Choctaw beaded baseball cap decorated with a feather. Among the present-day standouts are a witty painting by Jim Logan, of Cree and Sioux descent, in which the Eurocentric figures of Michelangelo's "Creation of Man" on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel are replaced by an Indian God reaching out to touch the finger of an Indian Adam. If the show doesn't really answer the question it poses, it raises it with a healthy dose of Indian humor. Hours and admissions: See above. (Glueck).

* "YES YOKO ONO," Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Jan. 14). The eye roll, a vestigial reflex, has the effect of not allowing you to see what is in front of you. It is understandably used these days to respond to celebrity spectacles passing themselves off as art events in local cultural establishments. Occasionally, however, you will miss something. You should bear this in mind here. We see Yoko Ono as she was before she became a celebrity: a mischievous, wry conceptual artist with a canny sensibility, cool but not dry, sometimes sweet, even corny -- and way ahead of her time in giving acute visual form to women's issues. As well as anyone, she encapsulated an evanescent and shifting moment in art. Fame distorts, and the show helps set the record straight. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $5; $3, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

* JAMES CASTLE, "The Common Place," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Jan. 13). Though deaf, speechless and illiterate, Castle (1900-77) drew with miraculous originality and steadfastness of purpose for most of his life. This exhibition presents more than 100 drawings, assemblages and small books, all created using homemade and found materials. The artist's strangely somber views of the ordinary rooms and grounds of the Idaho farm where he grew up have a haunting, deeply moving presence (Johnson).

"CHAMBER WORKS BY FREDERICK C. FRIESEKE," Hollis Taggart, 48 East 73rd Street, (212) 628-4000 (through Jan. 13). An adept but unoriginal American Impressionist who spent his adult life in Europe, Frieseke did his best work from the turn of the century to the late 1910's. Reflecting influences of Whistler, Sargent, Bonnard and Vuillard, his watercolors and oil paintings from that period have a sensuous feel for paint, color and light. But a 1920 series devoted to a pudgy nude on a pink drapery-enveloped bed is like Renoir at his worst (Johnson).

"THE FINE ART OF LETTERS: THE WORK OF HERMANN ZAPF," Grolier Club, 47 East 60th Street, (212) 838-6690 (through Feb. 10). Although revered within the closely related worlds of type design, calligraphy and fine book publishing, Hermann Zapf is all but unknown to the millions who see his work every day. His alphabets are among the core fonts on most Macintosh and Microsoft computers; his revolutionary sans-serif typeface, Optima, is ubiquitous in publishing and advertising and was used on Maya Lin's Vietnam War Memorial in Washington. This dense, elegant survey includes examples of original broadsides and limited-edition silkscreen prints that showcase Mr. Zapf's gifts as a calligrapher, as well as type specimens, dust jackets, title pages and copies of his influential manuals. Because of Mr. Zapf's prodigious start (in Germany, in the 1930's, when type still meant hot metal), long career, high productivity and continued innovation, the show tells much of the story of 20th-century type design. But mainly it introduces an artist of astonishing gifts and is infused with his drive and clarity of vision (Roberta Smith).

CHRIS GALLAGHER, James Graham & Sons, 1014 Madison Avenue, at 78th Street, (212) 535-5767 (through Jan. 13). Working wet-into-wet, Mr. Gallagher paints richly colored, finely striated fields. In the best cases, alternately blended and crisply defined stripes arcing across the canvas create an optically pulsating, centrifugal energy, like the grooves of a spinning record or the rings of a distant planet (Johnson).

PER KIRKEBY, Michael Werner, 4 East 77th Street, (212) 988-1623 (through Jan. 20). Though separated by almost two millenniums, large monotypes by the Danish painter and sculptor and a set of small southern Arabian alabaster carvings from the first century A.D. -- wide-eyed heads, mostly -- go together just fine. Jittery, expressionistic abstractions suggestive of landscape, Mr. Kirkeby's works play the pulse of a nervously modern sensibility off the soulfully alert stillness of an ancient traditionalism (Johnson).

Galleries: 57th Street

HERMINE FORD, Grant Selwyn, 37 West 57th Street, (212) 755-0434 (through Jan. 27). Painting on blob-shaped plywood panels, this New Yorker, who had her first show in 1974, produces elegantly funky compositions in which flat fields of muted offbeat color -- avocado, eggplant, navel orange, dusty blue -- play off brief wandering lines and blurry, marginal textures. An unassuming buoyancy calls early Elizabeth Murray to mind (Johnson).

CRAIG McPHERSON, Mary Ryan, 24 West 57th Street, (212) 397-0669 (through Jan. 27) An impressively skillful pastel artist, Mr. McPherson has produced a spectacular tour de force in that delicate medium: wrapping continuously around three walls, 18 large paper sheets bear the panoramic nocturnal view of languidly rippling water reflecting red and green city harbor lights. More than 60 feet long, it verges on abstraction yet produces an enveloping, cinematically lush effect (Johnson).

GWYNN MURRILL, Washburn, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 397-6780 (through Jan. 20). Three bronze deer rendered life-size in a smoothly simplified manner by this Los Angeles-based sculptor have a tense, remarkably animated presence. An eagle and a cheetah seem artificially stylized by comparison. (Johnson)

KENNETH NOLAND, "Circles," Ameringer/ Howard, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 935-1110 (through Jan. 20). In recent years Mr. Noland has returned to the target format that made him a famous Color Field painter in the 1950's. Painted in various confectionary color combinations on square fields of metallic color, these new bull's-eyes have misty auras but an empty, generic look, as if the artist were channeling the spirit of Warhol. The Target department store people might take note (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

ROBIN LOWE, "Erehwon," Bonakdar Jancou, 521 West 21st Street, (212) 414-4144 (through Jan. 13). Mr. Lowe's large Magic Realist paintings look like scenes from a Jungian dream. A winding road leads into the forest. A lawn gnome with a lamp guards a broken-down farmhouse. A white goat drinks from an aboveground swimming pool in a stony field. Painting in saturated colors with hallucinogenic precision, Mr. Lowe gives vivid visibility to offbeat, psychologically intriguing fantasies (Johnson).

"NEUTOPIA," Audiello, 526 West 26th Street, (212) 675-9082 (through Jan. 27). Five artists playfully redesign modernity. Both Christopher Schank and Carlos Ancalmo skillfully build elaborate surrealistic, multilevel architectural structures of wood, foam, plastic and other materials; Pablo Vargas-Lugo turns cardboard boxes into works of surprising Constructivist elegance; Jay Davis's glossy pictures are like a combination of traditional Japanese landscape painting and science fiction illustration; and Anna Sew Hoy creates absurd conjunctions of child-size bicycles and giant blobs of putty (Johnson).

"THE PERFECT POSE," Lucas Schoormans, 508 West 26th Street, (212) 243-3159 (through Jan. 13). This show presents vintage celebrity and fashion photography made from the 1920's to the 1940's for Vogue or Vanity Fair magazines by 13 photographers, including Andre Durst, George Hoyningen-Huene and Edward Steichen. This is high kitsch, not high art, but you can still be seduced by, for example, the image of a pouty young Tallulah Bankhead sitting chin in hand at a glassy black bar in a duskily luminous picture by Cecil Beaton (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"DEATH RACE 2000," Thread Waxing Space, 476 Broadway, near Spring Street, (212) 966-9520 (through Jan. 13). Organized around a ramshackle wooden racetrack built by Andreas Schlaegel, Phillip Zaiser and Thomas Zipp, this sophomoric mess of a 30-artist exhibition means to satirize violent, addictive and otherwise excessive behaviors supposedly driving modern society to destruction. The few interesting works include a funny video by Omer Fast, who used his own voice to replace all sounds in scenes from a Mel Gibson movie, and a life-size machine-gun-toting camel built of cardboard by Alex Baggaley (Johnson).

"PARADISE GARAGE: KEITH HARING AND MUSIC," Deitch Projects, 18 Wooster Street, (212) 343-7300 (through Feb. 10). Celebrating Haring's involvement in the club scene of the 80's, this exhibition presents works shown at or made for the Paradise Garage, his favorite spot for music and dance. Haring's familiar cast of characters -- the barking dogs, crawling babies and manic little men -- are on hand, as is his exuberant decorative sensibility, but the paintings are not first-rate. Haring's best work far exceeded anything here for graphic invention and mythic resonance (Johnson).

"UNCOMFORTABLE BEAUTY," Jack Tilton/Anna Kustera, 49 Greene Street, (212) 941-1775 (through Jan. 13). Updating Bad Girl-style feminism, this uneven but interesting selection of unruly works by 12 women includes Kim Dingle's "Pris," a stocky mannequin of a little girl who looks as if she's about to explode out of her frilly white dress; Marilyn Minter's artful fusions of the painterly and the erotic; and Jocelyn Hobbie's mysterious "Girl in the Woods," painted in a style that looks like a cross between Botticelli and Alex Katz (Johnson).

Other Galleries

DENNIS OPPENHEIM, Ace Gallery, 275 Hudson Street, South Village, (212) 255-5599 (through Feb. 28). This medium-size, occasionally amusing survey is what you would expect: a fun-house mixture of documentary photographs, booming electronics, videos, cockamamie sculpture and installations. The art is, at heart, about how hard it is to make art. Among the early works is a mechanized marionette, "Attempt to Raise Hell" (1974), a self-portrait that smashes its head into a big cast-iron bell. Frustration, anger and violence have been Mr. Oppenheim's creative touchstones, along with a sense of humor. His legacy is to have turned futility into a medium, a singular plan, sometimes effective, but often not memorable enough visually (Kimmelman).

Last Chance

"AMAZONS OF THE AVANT-GARDE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sunday). A concise exercise, monographically arranged, this show focuses on six Russian women who painted around the time of the revolution. Several continued to work much later and do more than paint, but this is a tendentious affair, plausibly so. If just a couple of the women, Natalia Goncharova and Liubov Popova, were truly great painters, the exhibition still isn't a case of special pleading. The Russian avant-garde wouldn't have been what it was without them collectively. The story as it unfolds here seems, if anything, more remarkable, not less, for having as little to do with sex as it does and almost everything to do with painting. Many of the works have a surprising fortitude. Revolution. A brave new art world. The dream persists even though the form it takes keeps changing. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 9 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $8 students and the elderly (Kimmelman).

* SIAH ARMAJANI, "Glass Room," Senior & Shopmaker Gallery, 21 East 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 213-6767 (through tomorrow). You couldn't live in this endearingly homespun "glass room," but then it's not meant for that. Made of glass and plexiglass bricks and set on wagon wheels like a prairie schooner, it is packed with fanciful allusions and tributes: to country carpentry, old-style American farm life, vernacular rural architecture and, at the same time, the futuristic visions that glass seems to offer. Despite its transparency, it has a more private aspect than the long roster of bridges, houses, reading rooms, gardens and other structures -- some functional, some purely aesthetic -- with which Mr. Armajani has adorned the built world. Enigmatic yet accessible, sturdily constructed but for contemplation only, "Glass Room" is a sparkling addition (Glueck).

* "ART AND THE EMPIRE CITY: NEW YORK, 1825-1861," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). The point is that during the antebellum years New York began to become, well, New York, America's megalopolis and an international crossroads. The great metaphor was the plan to grid Manhattan: unsentimental, open-ended, utilitarian and democratic, it created the blank sheet on which the city could draw its future. Amusing, gigantic, only marginally an art exhibition, the show is really an ostentatious illustrated history lesson via hundreds of pieces of old crockery, etchings, paintings, rosewood firescreens, daguerreotypes and mother-of-pearl folding fans. Custom-made for today's acquisitive age, the exhibition is probably the only occasion on which a 19th-century brown ceramic water cooler and a six-sided pitcher with pictures of the presidential candidate William Henry Harrison have been presented in the style of the treasures of the pharaoh's palace in "The Ten Commandments." Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:15 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 8:45 p.m. Admission: $10; $5, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).

* "THE EMBODIED IMAGE: CHINESE CALLIGRAPHY FROM THE JOHN B. ELLIOTT COLLECTION," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sunday). In China the written word has traditionally been the highest art form and a source of political and emotional power. To see that power in action, check out this grandly scaled exhibition, which brings together two superb calligraphy collections -- from Princeton University and the Met -- in the most comprehensive survey yet seen in these parts. The dozens of scrolls covered with handwritten words collectively radiate a kind of conversational buzz and suggest a richly varied cast of personalities: fastidious court functionaries, impulsive social agitators, unworldly monks, visionary poets. Together they offer an ice-breaking introduction to an art that to anyone who doesn't know Chinese can seem unapproachable. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).

"AN ENGAGEMENT WITH FOLK ART: CYRIL I. NELSON'S GIFTS TO THE MUSEUM OF AMERICAN FOLK ART," 2 Lincoln Square, at West 66th Street, (212) 595-9533 (through Sunday). This show celebrates the largess of Mr. Nelson, a book editor and folk art collector who has given 113 objects to the museum with the promise of more. The works, from the late-18th to the mid-20th centuries, cover the traditional areas of folk art -- portraits, landscapes, sculptures, painted and decorated furniture -- but the focus is on American needlework: quilts, coverlets, blankets and the like. Among the quilt spectaculars is the "Samuel Steinberger Log Cabin Quilt, Courthouse Steps Variation," by a 19th-century immigrant. Painted furniture, too, shines in this show. The painting and sculpture pieces make a more modest impression, but over all what's on view forms a refined, solid ensemble that is very accessible. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 a.m. to 7:30 p.m. Free (Glueck).

"FOUR NON-OBJECTIVE PAINTERS," Katharina Rich Perlow Gallery, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 644-7171 (through tomorrow). Once an art world legend, the German-born painter Hilla Rebay (1890-1967) was a founder and the first director of the Museum of Non-Objective Painting, which evolved into the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum. She was also director of the institution from 1937 to 1952. In 1939, with the Guggenheim's backing, she brought her friend Rudolf Bauer, the painter, from Germany to the United States and promoted his work. Rebay and Bauer were devotees of Non-Objective painting, defined by Kandinsky as art with no detectable reference to real-world sources. Their paintings are displayed together here, but it turns out that Bauer, a weak painter who could nevertheless create spirited Kandinskyesque collisions of form and color, makes a better showing. Also on view is "Berlin at Night," a group of mildly naughty drawings by Bauer, who before his Non-Objective career was a caricaturist for satirical German magazines. And there are several paintings from the period by the American painters Balcomb Greene and John Ferren, but not a strong enough showing to amount to much (Glueck).

LEE KRASNER, Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Sunday). Despite its restless energy and moments of formal power and elegance, Lee Krasner's career in this economical retrospective looks more like one of tantalizing frustration than real fulfillment. In the 1950's and early 60's, Krasner painted splattery, ambitious Abstract Expressionist works, but they look indebted to other artists, Pollock and de Kooning mainly. Where she looks most herself is in collage; a set of large collages on canvas from the early 50's have raw density or explosive buoyancy. Collages made in the 1970's using 40-year-old charcoal drawings have a beautiful Cubistic elegance; they are the best works of her career. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. on the first Saturday of each month); Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Johnson).

"PIERRE ET GILLES," New Museum of Contemporary Art, 583 Broadway, near Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 219-1222 (through Sunday). No history of postmodern photography, fashion photography, celebrity portraiture, record album covers or the highbrow beefcake tradition would be complete without the work of the French photo team known as Pierre et Gilles, who have collaborated on over-the-top, tightly styled, hand-finished photographs since 1976 and become wildly famous in Europe in the process. In their first American museum retrospective, their work feels more than a little embalmed, existing behind a not-so-invisible shield of artistic conservatism. Certain images come to life as art objects -- most notably, one of a beautiful young sailor up to his chest in water with an iridescent night sky behind him -- but those are few. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).

* "POWER AND DESIRE: SOUTH ASIAN PAINTINGS FROM THE SAN DIEGO MUSEUM OF ART, EDWIN BINNEY 3RD COLLECTION," Asia Society at Midtown, 502 Park Avenue, at 59th Street, (212) 517-2742 (through Sunday). The album-size paintings known as Indian miniatures, produced for an elite clientele who demanded the finest workmanship, are rightly renowned for their suave forms and brilliant colors. They also embody the moral values, political ambitions and personal aspirations of the culture that produced them. All of these ingredients come into play in this show of 67 top-of-the-line examples from the 16th to the 19th centuries. They add up to a kind of grand but intimate theater, equal parts farce, melodrama and mystery play, where men strut like gods, gods have the failings of men and nature is a gorgeous curtain behind which infinity lies. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Cotter).

"RUSKIN'S ITALY, RUSKIN'S ENGLAND," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0610 (through Sunday). This show commemorates the 100th anniversary of the death of John Ruskin (1819-1900), artist, art and architectural critic, social reformer, educator and the first official professor of art in England. From its own collections, the Morgan has mined a biographical medley of letters, manuscripts, photographs, drawings, paintings and artifacts relating to the life of this Victorian giant, whose published writings run to 39 volumes. Although not really an art show, it includes paintings and drawings by Ruskin and artists he admired, among them J. M. W. Turner and the Pre-Raphaelites John Everett Millais, William Holman Hunt, Edward Burne-Jones and Dante Gabriel Rossetti. It touches on his widely influential books of criticism, his beautifully finished sketches of architectural structures, his teaching and his monographs on proposed social reforms. Not omitted are his 1877 attack on James McNeill Whistler, his failed marriage and attraction to young girls and his sad end after a long siege of mental illness. But there is much to celebrate in his life, and this show doesn't stint. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10:30 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and the elderly; free for children under 13 with an adult (Glueck).

* CINDY SHERMAN, Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, (212) 206-7100, Chelsea (through tomorrow). With her latest untitled series Ms. Sherman is back in front of the camera lens again, disguised as women who, you might say, used to be somebody, maybe. They grin at the camera in clownish makeup, wobbly wigs and discount blouses, proud, valiantly oblivious to or simply defiant of our condescension, like the beauty pageant queen who drops her baton in the talent contest but keeps beaming. Formal devices by Ms. Sherman get overlooked because of the human element: the pattern of pigtails against plaid shirt; the purplish freckled face of a woman with purple shirt and purple cap. This formal order becomes a rational structure that gives the work its mix of frigidity and heat, a perfectly ambiguous cocktail for an ambiguous moment and an antidote to the weary sophistication of which there is too much in art now (Kimmelman).

GRAPHIC: Photos: A view of Dennis Oppenheim's "Attempt to Raise Hell," in the South Village. A mechanized marionette smashes its head into a cast-iron bell. (Ace Gallery); A work by the artist Charlotte Salomon, depicted at left. (The Jewish Museum)

HEADLINE: Women Turn to Web To Avoid Sales Pressure 

BYLINE:  By CATHERINE GREENMAN 

 BODY:
WHEN Bonnie Whitehead used to shop for cars, she took her daughter along to deflect pressure from salesmen. Ms. Whitehead, a shipping company executive in Greensboro, N.C., found that when she and her daughter, MitziLynn, bickered over different models, the sales representative tended to bargain more.
 With MitziLynn now married and living in Arizona, Ms. Whitehead dreaded the prospect of visiting dealers alone when she started to look for a new car last year. In addition to wondering how she would fend off sales pressure, the idea of shopping without buying made her guilty. "Probably the thing I felt most uncomfortable about was going into a dealership, taking up some poor salesman's time, and then having him not get the sale," she said. "Once they spend a lot of time with me, I tend to feel apologetic." 
 So Ms. Whitehead decided to be forthright when she walked into a local Subaru dealership and said that she just wanted a test drive -- and that she planned to shop for a deal online. As it turned out, the dealer participated in the referral service offered at Greenlight.com, an online car-buying site, and he suggested that she try it. 
After entering her preferences on Greenlight's Web page, and working with a representative over the phone, Ms. Whitehead ended up buying a Subaru Outback, with the color and options she wanted, at a dealer in Burlington, N.C., about 30 miles away.
"I did a lot of research at Greenlight and could decide on my own without tying up someone else's time," she said. "I didn't have that same feeling of obligation."
Whether it is to research car prices or actually buy a car, many women find that using the Internet is a more comfortable -- and in some cases more profitable -- alternative to braving the salesman's turf: the showroom floor. "I think the most powerful thing a buyer can do is withhold the human element," wrote one visitor to the Women's Auto Corner, an online message board at Edmunds.com, a site that provides information for car shoppers. "That's where the dealers have the edge over many of us."
Only a handful of sites, including Greenlight.com and CarsDirect.com, work directly with car dealerships in a given area to strike an acceptable deal and guide the buyer through the transaction. By having a representative from either of these sites handle the negotiating, buyers could conceivably avoid setting foot in a showroom except to sign the contract and take the keys.
"Greenlight and CarsDirect are trying to offer customers a new way of buying cars," said Babba Shetty, an analyst at Forrester Research, a Cambridge, Mass., Internet research firm. "They're not trying to go around the dealer, but they have a hand-holding process with customers, almost like a concierge service for new-car buying."
Several sites, including Autobytel.com and CarPoint.com, provide referral services, handing off the shopper to a dealer for final negotiations. Edmunds.com and Kelley Blue Book (www.kbb.com) offer invoice and manufacturer pricing information as well as links to other car-buying sites.
Many women say they still feel ignored, or sense other forms of discrimination, when they go to dealerships. "I don't think the issues have changed," said Bonnie Rick, who oversees the Women's Auto Corner message boards at Edmunds.com. "There are still a lot of dealers who treat people poorly based on perceptions of gender -- and also race and socioeconomic status."
It is also generally believed that women get worse deals. "Women tend to pay more; I don't know why," said Art Spinella, president of CNW Marketing/Research, an auto-industry research firm in Bandon, Ore. "They pay higher interest rates for their loans and higher prices on the cars. It may be a case of not wanting to haggle, or not being willing to say, 'That's too much' -- not being aggressive enough."
A recent study of car pricing in California, conducted by the Yale University School of Management and the Haas School of Business at the University of California at Berkeley, suggests that women who use online car-buying sites save money.
"In every statistical analysis we've done, we've found that women pay about a half-percent more, or about $100 more per car, than men do," said Fiona Scott Morgan, associate professor of economics at the Yale School of Management. "Women who use the Internet do not pay this half-percent."
Professor Morgan said a likely reason for the findings was that dealers tend to perceive shoppers who come through the online sites as serious buyers. The study also found that both men and women who used Autobytel's referral service got an average price reduction of 2 percent more than if they had gone directly to a dealer.
CNW says that 412,000 vehicles were sold last year to women who used the Internet either to conduct research or make a deal. That represents 28.1 percent of all online car shoppers, up from 24.3 percent in 1999 and 19.6 percent in 1998.
Although many dealers work with the car-buying sites, some say that any consumer will get a better deal by coming to them directly. "Most consumers will make out better by doing their own research online, then by dealing with dealers directly, because the dealers are in the position to make the best deal," said Andrea Carsien, vice president of Teresco Enterprises, a dealership group in Springfield, N.J. "We have the product, the distribution and the chains. Autobytel doesn't have cars in inventory."
Ralph Sibbio, sales manager of the Manhattan Auto Group in New York, said a lot of dealers were trying to erase the stigmas around the treatment of women who buy cars. It is well understood, he said, that asking a woman if her husband or boyfriend would be coming in was very "old school."
"The Internet is not a threat to dealers," Mr. Sibbio said. "A consumer coming in educated usually is a quick sale."
Factors like manufacturer's sales incentives are such "moving targets," Mr. Spinella said, that it's difficult for the research sites to provide consistently accurate information. "The best way to do it is to get whatever information you can online, and understand that the information may or may not be to the dollar," he said. "Always assume that there is yet one more incentive out there that you don't know about or that they don't know about. After you have all the information in hand, the best place to buy is in a showroom, not over the Internet."
While the Internet arms both male and female shoppers with much more information than they once had access to, it has also made the buying process more confusing.
"The dealers who've been trained better to deal with different populations, in general, tend to treat women better, but the overall process has become more complex than it used to be," said Ms. Rick of Edmunds. "You used to go in, and if you think you got some money off, that was good. But now consumers have to think about the invoice price, rebates, incentives and holdbacks" -- money the manufacturers pay to dealers to help cover interest expenses.
But some women who bought cars online said they thought they got the best possible prices. "Ultimately, I felt like I wasn't going to get a better deal than what they had," said Deborah Roberts, an office manager in San Francisco who bought a Volkswagen Jetta through Greenlight last year. "I came out right where they were, and it was exactly what I was willing to pay."
And for some women, the relief of not having to contend with sales pressure is just as important a reason to shop online as whether they actually get the lowest price.
"When I went to the dealers it almost always came down to them saying, 'What's it going to take to put you in this van today?' " said Kathryn Hill, a museum consultant in Norcross, Ga., who bought a Mazda MPV van through Autobytel. "I hate being in a situation where I feel stupid and pressured."
Ms. Hill said the best part of buying through Autobytel was the no-hassle experience. "We put in a price request online Friday night, got a call from a dealer on Saturday, and drove out with it on Sunday," she said. "I wouldn't buy a car any other way."

HEADLINE: Mexico's Heavy Industries Threatened by Natural Gas Costs 

BYLINE:  By GRAHAM GORI 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
Blaming high natural gas prices, Hylsamex, Mexico's largest steel manufacturer, has laid off 1,350 workers and closed four plants since September. Other heavy industries say they will follow suit if the government does not curb the cost of natural gas supplied and imported by the national oil monopoly, Pemex.
 Hylsamex's latest plant closing, announced on Tuesday, prompted industry leaders to criticize the way that Mexico sets gas prices. Eight years ago, the government decided to peg prices to the Texas market, believing that one day natural gas would flow freely over the border. 
 Today, thanks in part to the North American Free Trade Agreement, the United States and Mexico do constitute one market. However, in contrast to the situation in the United States, only one Mexican company, Pemex, can produce the fuel.
But Pemex cannot meet the growing demand in Mexico. Because almost all the Pemex profits go to the government, it lacks the funds for exploration, development and production. Analysts estimate that Pemex burns off nearly 30 percent of its natural gas at oil wells, for want of equipment to capture it and move it to consumers. All of that lost energy could meet the growing demand and bring down the cost of natural gas.
If Mexico wants an open market where natural gas is sold freely across the border, industry leaders here say, it must increase exploration and production. 
"The solution is to recognize that the conditions in Mexico are significantly different from Texas," said Alejandro Elizondo Barragan, president of Hylsamex. "We need to establish a pricing system that works in the best interest of the country as a whole. What we're doing now is killing Mexico's industry and killing its workers."
Now, instead of producing iron, which requires loads of natural gas, Mr. Elizondo said that he would import pig iron from Venezuela, the United States and perhaps Russia, even though industry leaders and the Mexican government have reached a temporary agreement on gas prices.
Anticipating that prices will one day fall, companies will pay only $4 per million British thermal units; the market price is close to $10 per million B.T.U.'s. They will then have four years to pay back the difference from the market price at low rates.
Even so, industry analysts say this merely treats the symptoms of a more serious disease. They say the government must either change the pricing system to represent market conditions in Mexico, or spend more money to find and produce natural gas.
"The only long-term solution is not to protect Mexico's companies from market forces, but to seek measures that will allow increased investment" and domestic production, said Sondra Scott, Latin America director at Cambridge Energy Research Associates.
Gilberto Ortiz Muniz, an official at the Manufacturing Industry Chamber, said that glass, aluminum and ceramic companies in northern Mexico had announced that they were evaluating whether to move their factories out of Mexico to countries where gas prices were more stable.
Ms. Scott said the rationale behind the gas pricing system in Mexico is not necessarily flawed. Because of Nafta, the potential exists for the United States and Mexico to have a beneficial trade relationship with gas.
But for that to happen, "Pemex needs to recognize that it operates in a global economy, and start acting like a global company," Ms. Scott said. "Mexico has a lot of potential for natural gas production." 
President Vicente Fox has promised to increase the amount of foreign investment in exploration and development. But it is unclear whether the constitution must be changed to allow private companies to enter into the exploration and development market.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING; 
The industry closely watches True North's handover of Chrysler to the Omnicom Group.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliot 

 BODY:
TRANSITION is very much in the news these days, not only in Washington but on Madison Avenue, too. And there were important developments yesterday in the transition being closely watched by the advertising industry as True North Communications hands over its huge Chrysler Group creative and media assignments to the Omnicom Group.
 True North, based in Chicago, said it would take a one-time charge of up to $20 million in the fourth quarter and lay off about 150 employees in the wake of the loss of the assignments, with billings estimated at $1.8 billion. The Chrysler Group, part of DaimlerChrysler A.G., decided in early November to consolidate its accounts with Omnicom, dismissing True North units like FCB Worldwide after 21 years. 
 The steps being taken by True North are emblematic of the substantial effect on the giant agency companies of a spate of consolidations by major marketer clients. When billions of dollars worth of billings are consolidated by advertisers like DaimlerChrysler, Ford Motor, Hasbro, Philip Morris and Unilever, the fallout can be significant.
A restructuring charge of the type True North is taking "does qualify as extraordinary," said Michael J. Russell Jr., an analyst who follows advertising stocks for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York. "You don't expect to lose your largest client." The Chrysler Group assignments accounted for about 9 percent of True North's revenue in 2000.
Originally, True North had intended to work on its Chrysler Group tasks, which included producing campaigns for the Chrysler and Jeep lines of cars and sport utility vehicles, through the end of the stipulated contractual notification period, which was to conclude on May 3. Instead, True North agreed with DaimlerChrysler and Omnicom to finish up four months early.
It's almost as if President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore had agreed to leave office on Dec. 23 rather than on Jan. 20.
"We wanted to end this amicably, put it behind us and move on," said Kevin Smith, chief financial officer at True North. In exchange for agreeing to officially end its tenure as of New Year's Day, True North is being paid $13 million by DaimlerChrysler to cover lost revenue; the company will also cover some severance costs and other True North exit expenses.
"My sense is that Chrysler wanted to be fair here," said James Dougherty, an analyst who follows advertising stocks for Prudential Securities in New York."True North isn't doing anything that Omnicom isn't perfectly capable of doing" sooner rather than later, he added. "If it was dragging out, why not just get it over?"
And Omnicom, based in New York, agreed to assume some leases from True North and buy office equipment; the dollar amount involved is not being disclosed.
The restructuring charge True North is taking will be $17 million to $20 million, or 19 to 23 cents a share. Analysts had expected True North to earn 92 cents a share in the fourth quarter, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial.
"When we first announced the loss, we were hoping we would not have to take a charge," Mr. Smith said. "We hoped revenue would allow us to cover our exit costs." But when it became apparent that was not the case, he added, plans for the charge were made. One effect of severing ties with Chrysler on Jan. 1 rather than on May 3 is that True North will be ready earlier than expected to pursue another automotive client.
"That really wasn't the motivation," Mr. Smith said, adding: "We continue to look for an auto account. That will continue."
That met with approval from Mr. Dougherty, who said "bringing in another automotive account would go a long way" to improving the long-term outlook for True North.
As valuable as replacing the Chrysler Group would be, Mr. Russell said he considered "the most important thing for True North right now" to be the economic outlook for the United States in 2001.
That's because of all the large agency companies, True North is "the most U.S.-oriented" in terms of revenue and billings, he added, so it is especially sensitive to "what the U.S. economy will do in the next six to nine months."
That was on Mr. Smith's mind, too.
"Maybe Uncle Alan will cut the rate again," he said, laughing, referring to Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, which cut interest rates on Wednesday.
About 500 employees of FCB worked on Chrysler assignments in Southfield, Mich., and regional offices. More than 200 have been hired by PentaMark Worldwide in Troy, Mich., a unit formed by the BBDO Worldwide division of Omnicom to handle the consolidated Chrysler Group account. They include Mike Vogel, president and chief executive at FCB Detroit, who becomes chairman and chief executive at PentaMark Worldwide, and Bill Morden, group vice president and chief creative officer at FCB Detroit, who will take a post to be determined at PentaMark Worldwide.
After subtracting the employees hired by PentaMark Worldwide and those who have left FCB Detroit on their own, "we're looking in the range of 150 employees" to be cut, said Kathryn Woods, a True North spokeswoman in New York. She reiterated that True North management remained "comfortable" with analysts' forecasts of earnings per share for 2001. The average estimate is $2.14, according to First Call.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday, True North closed at $41.50, down 44 cents, and Omnicom closed at $89.06, up $2.81. The strong performance by Omnicom may have also been related to the interest rate cut and an agreement by Omnicom to sell its 29 percent stake in Headhunter.net, an Internet recruiting company.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Markets Moderately Lower After the Huge Fed Rally

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Wall Street stepped back yesterday, taking profits from the gains that came after the Federal Reserve's unexpected interest rate cut on Wednesday. Stocks finished moderately lower on very heavy volume after fluctuating throughout the day.
 The Dow Jones industrial average lost 33.34 points, or 0.3 percent, to close at 10,912.41, after rising 299.60, or 2.8 percent, on Wednesday. The Nasdaq composite index fell 49.86 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,566.83, after posting record one-day point and percentage gains on Wednesday, when it rose 324.83 points, or 14.2 percent. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.22 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,333.34.
Still, trading was heavy, with volume on the New York Stock Exchange surpassing 2.1 billion for the first time.
Volume on the Nasdaq was 2.6 billion.
Some pullback was expected after the Fed's half-point rate cut -- a reduction that was bigger and sooner than expected -- finally gave investors a reason to buy stocks, in particular the discounted technology issues. The market has fallen for months on a litany of bad earnings news, especially from high-technology companies.
"Investors awoke today to realize the reason the Fed lowered rates the way they did yesterday is because the economy is fairly soft," said Charles G. Crane, strategist for Spears, Benzak, Salomon & Farrell in New York. "As exciting as it was to have rates cut, that is not going to prop up profits in the immediate future."
Most analysts agreed with Mr. Crane that Wednesday's euphoric rally cannot be sustained yet.
Investors will still see more signs that the economy is slowing and warnings that first-quarter profits will miss expectations, they said.
The software maker Inktomi tumbled $4.63, to $13.88, after it lowered its first-quarter forecast. The company, which makes network software for delivering World Wide Web content, also said its fourth-quarter earnings and sales fell short because customers canceled orders.
But some technology companies built on Wednesday's sharp gains. Hewlett-Packard gained 56 cents, to $34.63, and Microsoft advanced 50 cents, to $48.44.
Given the lower prices in the battered technology sector, one analyst said he had expected investors to do more buying yesterday.
"If there is one surprise, it's that tech stocks aren't up more than they are," said Dick Dickson, technical analyst for Scott & Stringfellow in Richmond. "You have a back and forth between those who are bottom fishing and the get-me-out-even crowd."
Although technology issues fell, Mr. Dickson pointed out that they did not cause the bulk of the loss in the S.& P. 500. Rather, a drop in the safer blue chips undercut the S.& P. 500, which is considered one of the best indicators of the entire market.
American International Group was the biggest S.& P. loser, Mr. Dickson said. It fell $6.94, to $89. 
Drug issues also hurt the index, with Pfizer losing $1.75, to $41.81, and Merck dropping $4.13, to $85.
 --------------------

Treasury Prices Rebound
 (By Reuters) -- Treasury prices bounced back yesterday as struggling stocks and the widespread belief that the economy would probably slow further fueled hopes that Wednesday's interest rate cut by the Federal Reserve will not be the last.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 31/32, to a price of 105 13/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.03 percent from 5.16 percent on Wednesday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 28/32, to 111 27/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.44 percent from 5.49 percent on Wednesday.
