HEADLINE: Two Economic Policy Captains Working With Different Tools; 
Bush Makes Certain His Style Contrasts With That of Clinton

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 4 

 BODY:
Eight years ago, with the economy in trouble and a new administration scurrying to take over the White House, Bill Clinton called more than 300 business leaders to Little Rock, Ark., for a conference that sprawled over 19 hours, most of them live on television.
 At times playing the role of economics professor, at moments arguing with his guests over everything from taxes to health care, Mr. Clinton ran what amounted to a national economics talk show. 
 Larry King, foreshadowing what was to come, suggested at the session's end that Mr. Clinton might someday become the competition. "I can see us going head to head." he said, " 'Larry King Live' and 'Bill Clinton Live.' " 
This week in Austin, George W. Bush tackled the same problem with a distinctly different style -- in what may prove an early indication about how the presidency is about to change. He invited a much smaller group of business leaders and high-technology executives here to his hometown and sought their counsel in a room closed to the press and cameras. If there were any disagreements -- and there didn't seem to be many, by all accounts -- they were off the record. At the end of each day, a small group of executives stepped forward to talk about how enthusiastic they are about the president-elect's economic prescriptions, starting with his plans for a deep tax cut. 
Mr. Clinton later said the Little Rock conference helped change his view, moving him away from his campaign platform and toward a strategy of deficit reduction in hopes of lowering interest rates and spurring the economy. Mr. Bush said today that the lesson of his economic conference was to charge ahead with his program on an accelerated basis.
"I am thinking through my strategy right now," he said. "I think that tax relief is necessary. The question is how fast we implement it. It is possible that we may need to implement it faster."
If tax cuts were the substantive message of the week, the stylistic one was this: Any resemblance between the way Bill Clinton ran the White House, past or present, and the way Mr. Bush intends to run it it is purely coincidental.
Mr. Clinton's aides saw Little Rock as a way to sell Mr. Clinton's economic plans, and as a way to establish him as a national leader. 
"We wanted to build confidence in the president, and in his views, but we also wanted to show his wide-ranging ability to deal with these issues," said Mickey Kantor, who organized the conference and later went on to become Mr. Clinton's trade representative and then commerce secretary.
Mr. Bush's team is clearly pursuing a different strategy, one that leaves little to chance. While Mr. Bush has taken questions at relatively short news conferences announcing new members of his cabinet, his aides appear more leery of exposing him to hours of live give-and-take on issues that participants said ranged today from America's trade relations with China to immigration, privacy and education initiatives. But why not burn up free television hours -- in a week with relatively little other news -- with the president-elect building a consensus.
"We wanted very candid conversations," said Karl Rove, Mr. Bush's top campaign strategist, who today was appointed to become Mr. Bush's senior political adviser in the White House. "We knew we wouldn't have that if it was an open meeting." 
Mr. Bush's top economic strategist, Lawrence B. Lindsey, said today the participants clearly liked the idea of a private chat with the president-elect. "I don't mean to be critical of Little Rock," he said, "but people who were at both -- there and here -- told me they thought this was terrific."
Of course, putting a president live on television talking about the economy is always risky. It took Mr. Clinton more than a year to learn the dangers of talking about the dollar. And in a jittery market, any slips of the tongue -- free advice to the Federal Reserve, for instance -- can have unintended consequences. It's also possible, even likely, that today's sessions might not have made very compelling television.
In 1992 the country appeared to be mired in recession (only in retrospect is it clear that the recovery was already under way) and everything seemed in need of a fix: national productivity, the competitiveness of American manufacturing companies, skyrocketing health care costs, a budget deficit that would only grow larger every year.
There was a sense of crisis, which Mr. Clinton used to advance his agenda. Today, the deficit has turned to a surplus and the fundamentals of the economy seem in much sounder shape, even if the speed and intensity of the country's slowdown has taken everyone -- including the Fed -- by surprise.
Debating whether to front-load a tax cut so that it takes effect more quickly and stimulates economic growth -- something both Mr. Lindsey and Mr. Bush talked about today -- may seem less exciting than promising to remake American capitalism. And Mr. Bush's team has clearly concluded that it is better to organize a quiet ground swell of support for that position among business executives than to make the pitch directly.
Moreover, just as Mr. Clinton made sure there were few supply-siders on hand at Little Rock, Mr. Bush's team appears not to have invited anyone who believes that tax cuts are a terrible idea, or that the country would be better off getting rid of the national debt as soon as possible.
"We talked briefly about the need for fiscal stimulus," said Michael S. Dell, the founder of Dell Computer, which is based here. "There needs to be a multipronged approach," he said, "the Fed's rate cut and then a tax cut."
While Mr. Rove said that there was "a spirited exchange" on some questions of privacy in the Internet age, the participants said there were no real arguments. "We found him very, very crisp on all the high-tech issues," John T. Chambers, the president of Cisco Systems, said of Mr. Bush. Mr. Chambers said that much of the lunchtime session was spent discussing education of future workers. "A decade from now it will be jobs in the U.S. versus jobs in India or jobs in Jordan," Mr. Chambers said. 
Several of the executives pressed Mr. Bush to support an expansion of the number of visas granted to high-technology professionals seeking to work in the United States, a labor force Silicon Valley has come to depend upon.
Perhaps the most notable feature of the sessions over the last two days was who was missing. The Treasury secretary-designate, Paul O'Neill, was in Washington visiting senators who will vote on his nomination. That was in sharp contrast to Little Rock, which was attended by both Mr. Clinton's Treasury-secretary designate, Lloyd Bentsen, and the man who would succeed him, Robert E. Rubin. 
Also missing were any members of Mr. Bush's foreign policy team. Neither the secretary of state-designate, Colin Powell, or the future national security adviser, Condoleezza Rice, were in town for the meeting. 
And while trade was a major subject, Mr. Bush has yet to appoint a trade representative, and Bush aides have hinted that the job may be downgraded in status. Every president for the last 20 years has treated the trade representative as a cabinet-level post; Mr. Bush's aides say that is under review.
The second curiosity has been Mr. Bush's departure on Wednesday from the longtime White House practice of saying as little as possible about actions of the Federal Reserve. When Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, announced a half-point cut in interest rates during the first session with business leaders here, Mr. Bush embraced the action, telling reporters "I think the cut was needed."
That seemed inoffensive -- after all it put Mr. Greenspan and Mr. Bush on the same side of the issue. But it also amounted to what one former Clinton administration official called "a normative statement about Fed action," which creates the expectation that, whenever there are future actions by the Fed, the president will offer up his approval or disapproval.
Today Ari Fleisher, Mr. Bush's press secretary, said that was not necessarily the case. "I think the president-elect will judge events and make his determinations as different events warrant," he said.

HEADLINE: The Big Question: How Much Further Is the Fed Willing to Go on Rates? 

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Now that Federal Reserve policy makers have cut their benchmark interest rate sharply and unexpectedly, the question is how much further are they going to go?
 The nation's central bank can be expected to do whatever it thinks is necessary to keep the economy from heading into what President-elect George W. Bush called a "tailspin." (Remember that to slow runaway growth and head off inflationary forces the Fed raised interest rates much higher than many Wall Street forecasters expected.) 
 The problem is nobody knows how low the Fed will have to go to avoid a tailspin, after cutting the target for the federal funds rate by half a percentage point to 6 percent on Wednesday. 
History shows, though, that investors may be surprised by what the Fed does since the markets rarely guess correctly how high or how low rates will go. Investors will get some guidance today from the government's unemployment report for December, because it will give the latest indication of how weak the economy is.
What's more, many companies and investors may feel they are in a recession even if the economy technically avoids one, usually defined as two consecutive quarters in which the economy contracts rather than grows. The manufacturing sector is already in a slump. And the sharp slackening in growth that many economists expect -- down to just a 1 or 2 percent growth rate from the recent 5 percent pace -- is the kind of sharp deceleration that used to leave the economy in a tailspin.
"In feeling, it will be a recession," said James Glassman, senior United States economist at J. P. Morgan Securities. "The Fed can't do much about what is going to happen in the next six months."
That feeling may help bonds rally, but it is not likely to reassure the stock market, which ended down yesterday, after a euphoric rally on Wednesday when the Fed cut rates.
When the Fed was trying to slow the economy with six rate increases in less than a year, it proved to be more resilient than policy makers or Wall Street analysts thought. So the economy may now prove to be much weaker and harder to revive than people assume. If so, the Fed would cut its target rate more than now anticipated, and market rates could fall sharply.
In that case, stocks might take some time to resume a sustained climb because corporate earnings growth, already slowing, could decline. In addition, it is hard to say how equity investors will react to additional rate cuts. If they believe the Fed is moving too slowly, stocks could suffer.
But if the economy slows sharply, without tumbling into a traditional recession, maybe the Fed will not have to cut its target rate so much. That means Treasury interest rates may have neared a bottom, a fact reflected in the sell-off in the bond market and the jump in Treasury yields after the Fed's announcement Wednesday.
In this case, stocks may get support if the economic data shows that things are not getting worse. If, however, investors have become addicted to Fed rate cuts -- demanding one every time there is some disappointing news -- stocks may have a rough road ahead. Investors may also turn out to be cautious and wait for clearly positive earnings news -- which may not appear until the second half of this year -- before jumping back into the market.
All this is reflected in the range of forecasts for what the Fed will do from here on and reflected in where interest rates are right now.
Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson, said there were two ways to look at the Fed move:
"Does the Fed see something we don't or is the Fed applying new rules?"
He predicts an additional quarter-point cut at the January meeting, to 5.75 percent for the federal funds rate, and then "a wait and see" approach. By the next scheduled meeting in March, he said, some of the dislocations that have contributed to the slowdown, including harsh weather, high energy prices and power shortages, "may fade as the heating season comes to an end."
Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist at Merrill Lynch, said the Fed would be more aggressive. He expects a quarter-point cut at the end of the month and another cut of a quarter-point or half a point at the meeting in March. He expects the rate to be down to 5.25 percent or 5 percent by June. "The Fed has to accelerate the rate reductions to keep the economy on an even keel," he said.
Mr. Glassman said the Fed would cut even further, with a half percentage point reduction at the end of the month and further cuts that bring the fed funds rate target down to 4.75 percent by June. "In our mind the Fed is still stepping on the brake," he said. "So it has to get the foot off the brake quickly."

Gates Leading the Charge Into Consumer Electronics
The bearish news from the personal computer industry may be sowing fear in Silicon Valley, but none of that anxiety is apparent at Microsoft, whose software fortunes were built on the PC boom. Page C4. 

George to Cease With March Issue
George, the magazine founded by John F. Kennedy Jr. that combined politics and celebrity in an often unwieldy pairing, will cease publication with the March issue. C3.

EToys to Lay Off 70% of Workers
EToys said that it would lay off 700 of its 1,000 employees and close two of its smaller warehouses, a day after the company said it would close its European operations. Its chief rival, toysrus.com, said that its sales for the nine-week holiday season were $124 million, at the low end of analysts' expectations. C4.

True North to Take a Charge
True North Communications, which is handing over its huge Chrysler Group creative and media advertising assignments to the Omnicom Group, said it would take a one-time charge of up to $20 million in the fourth quarter and lay off about 150 employees in the wake of the loss of the assignments, with billings estimated at $1.8 billion. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C3.

Stocks Fall in Bout of Profit Taking
Stocks fell as investors took profits from gains after the Federal Reserve cut interest rates. The Nasdaq composite index, which surged a record 14.2 percent on Wednesday, fell 49.86 points, or 1.9 percent, to 2,566.83. The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 33.34 points, or 0.3 percent, to 10,912.41, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 14.22 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,333.34. C6.

Taubman May Sell Sotheby's Shares
A. Alfred Taubman, the former chairman of Sotheby's Holdings and the focus of a federal antitrust investigation, filed papers that signal his exploration of a sale of his controlling interest in the company. Mr. Taubman reported in a filing with the S.E.C. that he had hired Credit Suisse First Boston to evaluate his investment in Sotheby's and put a value on his 13.2 million shares, a step that some analysts read as a prelude to divestiture or merger discussions. Shares of Sotheby's rose $1.88, to $24.13. C11.

Reports Indicate Labor Weakness
In signs of weakness in the labor market, United States companies announced 133,713 job cuts in December, more than triple the number in November, a private survey showed, and the Labor Department said the number of Americans filing for new unemployment benefits climbed to its highest level in two and a half years. A third report showed that orders for new goods from factories rebounded 1.7 percent in November, beating forecasts. C5.

News. Corp to Lay Off Hundreds
The News Corporation plans to lay off several hundred workers at the New York and Los Angeles offices of the FoxNews.com, FoxSports.com and Fox.com Web sites as it consolidates its Internet operations. B1.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
New Focus for Gates Is Consumer Electronics

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: REDMOND, Wash., Jan. 4 

 BODY:
The bearish news from the personal computer industry may be sowing fear in Silicon Valley, but none of that anxiety is apparent on the sprawling corporate campus of Microsoft, whose software fortunes were built on the PC boom. 
 For even with domestic PC sales down 24 percent in December from a year earlier -- and even as Microsoft is warning that its own revenues are likely to falter as a consequence -- the frontier of consumer electronics is increasingly seen here as the next big thing. 
 Indeed, William H. Gates, the Microsoft co-founder who now calls himself chief software architect, seems focused on an entirely different business as his company prepares to introduce its X-Box video-game system, its first foray into the high-stakes, high-risk consumer electronics business.
In Mr. Gates's mind, winning in consumer electronics simply requires applying the same lessons the company has mastered in the computer arena. 
"This is about great software, and it's about evangelization," he said today in an interview in his office here. "Why did MS-DOS succeed and Microsoft Office succeed? In all those things it was about evangelization, and it was about getting great software engineers to put the pieces together. That's still at the core of this thing."
Aside from the cloud of an antitrust ruling that threatens to break up his company, Mr. Gates seems to see opportunity in almost every bit of potential adversity these days.
He believes that the company is in an excellent position to weather any economic downturn, he said, and even the pending merger of Time Warner and America Online -- which Microsoft has joined in challenging before federal regulators -- may have a silver lining. 
Moreover, Mr. Gates said he was becoming comfortable with his new role as the company's software architect, a job he took last spring after he handed the chief executive position to his longtime friend and partner Steven A. Ballmer.
Mr. Gates still has his office in the company's corporate suite. But he said he spent his days working on a variety of new problems, among them building new skills from the consumer electronics world.
Some days, he said, involve exploring problems like what happens when a child pulls the new X-Box off the shelf and it bounces on a hard floor, or the potential hazards in the sheaving of a cable that will come with the machine.
"If you'd asked me three or four months ago I'd have said, 'Hmmm, I don't know how I'm doing; I'm trying,' " he said. But he and Mr. Ballmer compared notes after the holidays, he said, and he believes that he has figured out how to be effective in his new capacity.
On Sunday Mr. Gates will travel to Las Vegas for the annual Consumer Electronics Show in an unaccustomed role -- that of neophyte and underdog -- to introduce the X-Box to an industry increasingly dominated by digital appliances and gadgets, including the competing game consoles of Sony, Nintendo and Sega. But he said the time for Microsoft's entry into the arena was ripe. 
"This year electronics driven by software is really starting to come into the home in a big way," Mr. Gates said. "You see it with music, you see it with photos, you see it with TV, you see it with the ways people are using PC's as a creativity center."
Microsoft's new strategy is not without peril, and Mr. Gates acknowledged that consumer electronics, like the PC business, is sensitive to the economic tides.
"Certainly the economy will affect what portion of consumers can move in the first year," he said. "Sure it will affect the volumes, and consumers are price sensitive."
But while he acknowledged the possibility of an economic downturn, Mr. Gates said he felt that Microsoft was in a better position to weather it than many other companies. And he said any weakening in the dollar might help Microsoft over all by stimulating international sales. 
"We've seen some ups and downs before, and we're not cutting back the investment we make," he said, noting that the slowdown had caused the company to cut back some projects. But he said Microsoft would again spend more than $3 billion on research and development -- an amount permitting it to create "a lot of great software."
In addition to being upbeat about the economy, Mr. Gates said he was not deeply concerned about the pending merger of Time Warner and America Online, which is expected to receive final approval in the next few days from the Federal Communications Commission. 
Microsoft's opposition has been based in part on its challenge to America Online in the field of instant messaging, an area in which the F.C.C. may place restrictions on the merged company. Mr. Gates said that the merger might actually open new avenues for Microsoft to create strategic alliance with other AOL Time Warner competitors, like the Walt Disney Company. 
"Nobody's ever doubted that merger would go through," he said. "This just reinforces the fact that we're not a media company and that will probably facilitate us working with Disney and Newsweek and whoever else is out there." Such cooperation may be increasingly valuable as Microsoft continues to move into media and entertainment ventures.
And even the Internet downturn has had an upside for Microsoft, he said: increasing the availability of talent. About 100 people have returned to Microsoft after leaving to join start-ups, he said.
"They saw the real world and returned," he said.
Despite his push into the gaming business, Mr. Gates confessed that he is by and large not an active gamer -- although he did confess to one 20-hour binge with a recent Microsoft game called Pandora's Box, written by Alexey Pajitnov, a designer of the popular game Tetris.
Still, Mr. Gates said he understood the game-playing psychology.
"When I was in college, for the games of that era, I was as hard core as anyone was," he said. "I wouldn't say I outgrew it, but you always have to have a finite number of addictions."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day yesterday about the Microsoft Corporation's move into consumer electronics misstated the timing of an appearance by William H. Gates at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas. It is today, not tomorrow.

HEADLINE: News Corp. Plans Hundreds of Layoffs at Web Sites 

BYLINE:  By JAYSON BLAIR 

 BODY:
Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation has decided to scale back sharply its ambitious efforts to provide original material on its Web sites and plans to lay off several hundred workers within the next few weeks. 
 Hundreds of jobs will be cut or lost through attrition at the New York and Los Angeles offices of the FoxNews.com, Fox Sports.com and Fox.com sites on the World Wide Web. Three executives said the Chelsea office of News Corporation's Internet division on West 18th Street, called News Digital Media, would be closed within two months. 
 The cutbacks follow a growing tide of layoffs at Internet companies in the city, and are a blow to Silicon Alley's hopes that Internet subsidiaries of large corporations would be spared the troubles afflicting smaller dot-coms. 
Jon Richmond, the president of News Digital Media, said in an interview yesterday that it was "very hard to speculate how many positions will be eliminated," but the officials believed that enough of them would be cut to save the company tens of millions of dollars each year. 
News Corporation officials said that although News Digital Media would be closed down, the Web sites and many of the workers would be moved to Fox News Channel, Fox Sports Channel and Fox Television. 
"What we are trying to do is shift the production and news-gathering operations back to the operating organizations where we can achieve economies through integration," Mr. Richmond said. "What we are doing is restructuring in a way that it probably should have been structured originally."
Mr. Richmond said Fox hoped that the new arrangement would improve the Internet sites through better coordination with the television divisions. "A byproduct of that, leveraging the strengths of the other operations, will be a significant cost saving," he said. "We will be able to combine news gathering, video production and a whole bunch of other things that will provide savings."
He added: "Some of those things will come from reduced employee costs, some will come from other things, like in video production. Rather than having both groups producing video, we will combine those efforts."
Mr. Richmond said it was too early to discuss when and how the layoffs would be handled, but two other executives, who insisted on anonymity, said most of the employees would be laid off and then given a chance to reapply for their jobs. A senior executive said, though, that all the employees remaining once the layoffs were completed would be given jobs in the other Fox divisions.
Several employees at the Web sites had been meeting with News Corporation executives in the last few weeks as rumors of the layoffs became increasingly common. 
Several News Corporation employees, who also spoke only on the condition of anonymity, said Laura Durkin, senior vice president of News Digital Media, told employees in a newsroom meeting in New York yesterday that Fox News Channel executives would meet with them at 11 a.m. today to discuss plans for the future of the Web sites. "There is no one who is going to be fired tomorrow," she told them. Other executives said the layoffs could be completed by the end of February.
In October, News Digital Media dismissed about 20 percent of its New York news staff members and told almost all of its sports staff members to move to Los Angeles or lose their jobs. The word came two days after Mr. Murdoch, News Corporation chairman, told investors at the Australian company's annual meeting that he did not have confidence in Internet business models that are based on advertising revenue. In December, News Corporation sent executives from Fox News Channel to help run more of the day-to-day operations of the Web sites.
News Corporation has not disclosed whether News Digital Media has lost money, but employees knew that there would be some changes, and that it was possible that the Internet unit would be integrated back into other Fox divisions.
"We knew that there were going to be layoffs," one News Digital Media employee said, adding that recent layoffs had reduced the company's ability to produce original reports. 
According to Media Metrix, a New York company that monitors and counts visits to Web sites, FoxNews .com has had a harder time attracting visitors than have its competitors. In September, FoxNews.com had just under two million unique visitors, less than a quarter of MSNBC.com's 8.9 million visitors. CNN.com had 7.5 million visitors, and CBS.com sites and ABCNews .com had more than three million. 
"At the end of the day, I think of them as a latecomer who was underfunded and thought they could translate their successes on television onto the Web, and there is little value to that," said Guy Hoffman, a partner at TL Ventures, a venture capital firm with headquarters in Wayne, Pa. "Those who say traditional content sites are done, they're baked, they're cooked -- they're wrong. But there will only be a handful."
News Corporation officials said that the Internet division employed almost 500 workers and that a little more than 320 of them work for FoxNews.com, FoxSports.com and Fox.com. News Corporation, which also owns The New York Post and Fox Channel 5, employs 26,500 people worldwide. 
News Corporation's American depositary receipts, which represent four shares of stock each, rose 69 cents yesterday to $36.50 in New York Stock Exchange trading.
In recent months, several large companies have limited their efforts to produce original Web material or give their Internet divisions more independence. Each month since the Nasdaq fell sharply in April, a handful of Silicon Alley companies have withdrawn initial public offerings of their stock, depriving these sites of the potential capital influx from the offerings. 
Anna Copeland Wheatley, a longtime Silicon Alley advocate and the editor in chief of AlleyCat News, a Silicon Alley trade magazine, said yesterday in an interview that the layoffs at News Digital Media were the latest demonstration that "original and independent content is a fantasy," a trend that she said was also shown by the problems at Internet companies over the last nine months.
Ms. Wheatley said, "The Alley right now is unsettled.
"Among a group of people there is a cautious optimism, which is, 'If we can just get through to the second quarter, we'll be O.K.,' " she said.

HEADLINE: Commerce Designate Has Easy Going at Senate Hearing 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 4 

 BODY:
Donald L. Evans, President-elect George W. Bush's choice for commerce secretary, told senators at his confirmation hearing today that he had no position yet on how to handle the politically touchy census, but promised to enforce trade laws vigorously and to keep his department free of political influence peddling.
 Mr. Evans, a Texas oilman who served as Mr. Bush's campaign chairman and is a longtime friend of the president-elect, was the first cabinet selection to undergo the required Senate scrutiny, and he received a cordial reception. Several senators predicted during and after the hearing, conducted by the Senate Commerce Committee, that Mr. Evans would face little or no opposition. 
 Senator Ernest F. Hollings of South Carolina, the committee's senior Democrat, was chairman of the hearing, because Democrats control the Senate until Dick Cheney succeeds Al Gore as vice president in two weeks. Mr. Hollings said at the end of the two-hour hearing that the committee hoped to send the Evans nomination to the Senate floor, with a recommendation that it be confirmed, in the first week after the inauguration.
Mr. Evans seemed to have charmed most committee members with visits to their offices in recent days, and he was asked relatively soft questions about how he would manage the department's many functions. The department promotes American companies, enforces trade agreements, reviews patents, researches the oceans, oversees the fishing industry, conducts the census and helps set standards and regulations for the technology industry.
Mr. Evans, who spent the last 25 years as a senior executive at Tom Brown Inc., an oil exploration company based in Midland, Tex., has never held a government position, though he did head the Board of Regents at the University of Texas, his alma mater.
Still, speaking in a soft Texas twang, he deflected the most sensitive queries with the deftness of an old Washington hand.
He expressed a strong interest in everything from the plight of the steel industry and rural access to high-speed Internet connections to research into global warming. He promised to work closely with senators in addressing each of those issues.
Some of the most pointed questions came from Senator John McCain of Arizona, who will resume the committee's chairmanship when the Republicans regain Senate control.
Mr. McCain ran against Mr. Bush for the Republican presidential nomination and has spearheaded a drive to overhaul campaign finance laws. Today he pressed Mr. Evans, who raised a record $100 million for the Bush campaign, on what he would do to make sure that the Commerce Department did not use its powers to reward major campaign contributors.
Mr. McCain warned him to avoid the kind of cloud that dogged Ronald H. Brown, President Clinton's first commerce secretary, who faced accusations that he had in effect sold seats on foreign trade trips to campaign contributors and allowed Commerce Department officials to raise political funds. The senator asked Mr. Evans to submit in writing within 30 days details of how he would prevent that sort of political activity, and he agreed to do so.
Several Democrats, especially Senator John Kerry of Massachusetts, sought to elicit a commitment from Mr. Evans to allow statistical sampling to supplement last year's decennial count of the population if Census Bureau experts find that achieving an accurate tally requires it.
In November, the Clinton administration shifted the power to adjust the census from the commerce secretary to the director of the Census Bureau, arguing that the nonpolitical professionals at the bureau would be a fairer judge of whether such an adjustment was needed to correct for an undercount. Under the regulation, the director could adjust the count only if a panel of experts within the bureau so recommended. Democrats are happy with that arrangement, and would like assurances that the new administration will do nothing to overturn it.
Many Republicans, though, citing the Constitution's requirement that the census be an "actual enumeration," have argued that such an adjustment would be illegal. Some also worry that since minorities, who tend to live in Democratic areas, are the people most likely to be missed by conventional counting methods, such an adjustment might aid Democrats when new Congressional and state legislative districts are drawn.
Today Mr. Hollings teasingly urged Mr. Evans to apply the standard that the senator suggested had been adopted by the Bush camp in the long battle over the Florida election outcome.
"Our hope," Mr. Hollings said, "is that you stick with Mr. Bush's position supporting sampling and opposing hand counts." 
Mr. Evans expressed no firm stand on the issue but agreed to come back before the committee when he decided what to do.
Senators of both parties were critical of the Clinton administration's record on trade law enforcement, and urged Mr. Evans to do more.
Senator John D. Rockefeller IV, Democrat of West Virginia, pushed Mr. Evans to help protect the steel industry. Mr. Rockefeller, whose state is home to several of the largest steel makers, said the industry was on the verge of extinction because of what he called unfair competition from abroad. He said Mr. Gore had failed to carry West Virginia, long a Democratic state, largely because the Clinton administration had done little to help ailing steel companies and workers.
Mr. Evans promised to examine whether to impose sweeping measures to protect the industry under existing trade law.
"There is a lot of talk about the information economy," he said. "But I am not one who believes that means you turn your back on the industrial base of this economy."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Donald L. Evans, left, commerce secretary-designate, thanked Senator Phil Gramm for introducing him to the Senate Commerce Committee. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs; 
Win a Free Book

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Watching President Clinton's 11th-hour attempt to broker a Palestinian-Israeli deal, you feel as though you're watching a high-stakes poker game in which Mr. Clinton keeps doubling the bet. It's 4 in the morning now, all the money is in the pot, the room is thick with cigar smoke and the players are on their last hand. It's winner take all, and just before the cards are put on the table, Mr. Clinton turns to George W. Bush and says, "Say, would you mind takin' my seat?"
 I'm glad Mr. Clinton has brought this Middle East peace game to a head. He has done the Lord's work, not only in clarifying what's a fair compromise but in clarifying who is up to it and who is not. In time, this will be seen as a real contribution. But for now, all this clarity is coinciding with a presidential transition, and the one thing that is not obvious is how the Bush team intends to deal with the hand it's inheriting. 
 Indeed, because foreign policy was virtually never mentioned during the campaign, and because Mr. Bush himself has no strongly expressed views, he's taking office with a vaguely defined foreign policy agenda, but with clearly defined problems. Yes, the Bushies have position papers. They have more attitude than articulated views. None of the issues they have clearly articulated views on are urgent, and on all the urgent issues they have no clearly articulated views.
 For instance, Mr. Bush favors building a national missile defense system -- but for now that is an idea for which there is no workable technology, no immediate enemy and no supportive allies. There's plenty of time to sort it out.
 On the other hand, I will give a free copy of George Bush Sr.'s memoir, "A World Transformed," to any reader who can answer these questions: What will be the Bush approach to the Middle East, and how deeply does he intend to be involved? Historically, Democratic Arabists have tended to try to manage the Middle East by resolving the Palestinian conflict, while Republican Arabists favored working through the Saudis. Which way will he lean? Either way, the Middle East that Mr. Bush inherits is likely to be a roiling mess -- one that he not only won't be able to avoid but one that -- well, if he knew what was coming he would be down in Palm Beach County right now, hand-recounting votes himself.
 What is the Bush policy on North Korea? President Clinton is leaving a deal on the table that he did not have time to consummate, by which Kim Jong Il would further constrain his missile program in return for food and other goodies from the U.S. Is the Bush team really ready to withdraw U.S. troops from Kosovo and Bosnia, at a time when our allies would totally oppose that and both countries may be starting to mend a bit? Mr. Bush has expressed a desire to be tougher toward Iraq, but the U.S. does not have a single Arab ally ready to openly cooperate with such a policy. 
 Mr. Bush has appointed proven executives -- Colin Powell, Donald Rumsfeld and Condi Rice -- to tell him what he should think on foreign policy, but none of them have wrestled closely with these issues for years, so they will have to appoint Republican foreign policy deputies to tell them what they think. And, truth be told, the Republican Party generally has done very little creative thinking on foreign policy since George Bush Sr.'s day.
 At the Congressional level, Republican foreign policy has been dominated by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee chairman, Jesse Helms, a nasty isolationist who virtually never travels, is convinced that China is still Maoist and Russia still Marxist, and is against virtually every multilateral global institution or operation. Those Republicans who did not agree with Mr. Helms spent most of the last eight years simply snickering at the Clinton foreign policy, implying that when the Republican "grown-ups" got back in, things would be different. But few have laid out a Republican alternative to Mr. Clinton's view that America's central role today is sustaining globalization -- economically, politically and militarily. 
 This vacuum was also due to the fact that many Republican foreign policy figures wanted to get back into the new administration, and therefore were reluctant to write anything too daring or anything that would engender the wrath of Mr. Helms, who gets to confirm them.
 So the grown-ups are back, but both they and their kids will have a lot of homework to catch up on. Don't worry. They've still got two weeks.

HEADLINE: New-Home Sales Were Strong Last Year, Despite November 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 5 

 BODY:
Sales of new homes for single families fell in November without straying off course to make 2000 the second-best year on record, a government report showed today.
 The 2.2 percent drop in November sales, to an annual rate of 909,000 houses, came after a 1.1 percent drop the month before, the Commerce Department said. Even so, lower mortgage rates helped push November sales up 1.6 percent from the November 1999 rate. 
 Analysts say the decision by the Federal Reserve to cut the benchmark interest rate this week should help the economy, bolster consumer confidence and buoy purchases after a December lull.
"We still expect strong numbers in the first few months of this year," said Ian Shepherdson, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y.
Bloomberg News estimated that sales of new single-family homes reached 898,000 in 2000. That would be second to the record 907,000 new homes sold in 1999.
And while the November sales level was the lowest since 860,000 in August, it is up from 895,000 in November 1999.
Sales fell in three regions in November: 20 percent in the Northeast, to a 68,000-unit pace; 7.6 percent in the Midwest, to an annual rate of 133,000; and 3.3 percent in the West, to a 261,000-unit pace. Sales in the South rose 3.5 percent, to 446,000 houses at an annual rate.
The median price of a new home fell 0.1 percent in November, to $169,900, from $170,000 in October, the Commerce Department said, and the supply of new homes for sale rose to 4.2 months in November from 4.1 months in October.
The average rate on a 30-year fixed-rate mortgage fell this week to 7.07 percent, the lowest in one and a half years. That is down from last year's peak of 8.64 percent in mid-May, according to Freddie Mac, the No. 2 mortgage buyer.
With the Fed on track to cut interest rates further, mortgage rates will probably remain attractive, analysts said.

HEADLINE: Benefits of Mental Care 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "9 Million Gaining Upgraded Benefit for Mental Care" (front page, Jan. 1):
 Treating the so-called worried well is not expensive, as claimed by the insurance industry, when you are heading off stresses that can drive cardiovascular disease, asthma attacks, some cancers and other conditions requiring costly hospital stays. 
 Significant economies may be produced through parity for addiction disease. While untreated, these patients dearly cost the community in repeated health care, accidents, unemployment and prisons; when treated, many of them can be headed off at the pass.
Nationally, treatment for alcoholics and those addicted to other drugs has for the last five years been rendered managed care-friendly by the American Society for Addiction Medicine -- and it's a bargain.

NANCY BRACH
Montclair, N.J., Jan. 1, 2001

The writer is vice president of the National Council on Alcoholism and Drug Dependence of New Jersey.

HEADLINE: Change Is in the Air as Thailand Prepares to Vote 

BYLINE:  By SETH MYDANS 

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 5 

 BODY:
Strange things have been happening in Thailand's deeply corrupt electoral process as the nation prepares to vote for a new Parliament on Saturday.
 Plenty of cash is still being handed out, but it is mostly hidden. Some candidates are buying votes with trips to the beach, scholarships, village development projects or temple donations with strings attached. One candidate hid so much fertilizer -- a gift for rural voters -- on the top floor of a building that cracks appeared in its walls. 
 The leading candidate for prime minister, Thaksin Shinawatra, has been charged by a countercorruption commission of hiding his assets by transferring stocks to his household help.
Things used to be a lot easier for what one newspaper here calls Thailand's "election animals." Strict new rules have been put in place to combat corruption and vote-buying, and candidates are fighting back with imaginative new tricks. It is a risky game. If they are caught, they could be summarily eliminated and barred from office.
But more is at stake than the shape of the next government. The election is the latest and fiercest battleground in Thailand's slow, hard-fought democratic revolution.
The country's efforts at reform have put it at the forefront of a difficult and uneven shift throughout the region toward more democracy and openness, in politics and government as well as in economics. The hierarchical, father-knows-best approach sometimes called "Asian values" is on the defensive.
"You can see the democratic trend all the way from South Korea to Taiwan to Thailand to the Philippines to Indonesia, and then across to South Asia in places like Bangladesh," said Muthiah Alagappa, a senior fellow at the East-West Center in Honolulu. "The wave in Asia is towards more open political systems. But the movement is going to be gradual and contested and with some reversals."
Some see Thailand as a test for peaceful reform in the region.
"Everyone is watching whether this election will produce a legitimate government and what will happen next," said Kavi Chongkitavarn, a political analyst at the English-language daily The Nation.
In almost every arena, Thailand is changing -- or trying to change. A liberal Constitution passed in the wake of the regional economic crisis of 1997 calls for far-reaching reforms with an election commission, an anti-corruption commission, a freedom of information act and a soon-to-be activated commission on human rights.
The country's long tradition of top-down government is also being challenged by an increasingly vigorous civil society as individuals and groups insist on being heard.
The regional trend has its recent roots in Asia's decade-long economic boom in the 1980's and 1990's, when authoritarian rule came under challenge as Western wealth and ideas flooded in. In Thailand and Indonesia, resistance grew to the political dominance of the military.
The changes received a second push from the crash of 1997, which spurred political change -- or at least political challenge -- around Asia. Unaccountable governments that had bought social peace with growing prosperity suddenly found their legitimacy questioned.
"All the bad luck that has happened to Thailand may have been blessings in disguise; it woke people up," said Sunai Phasuk, a political scientist at Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok, referring to the military crackdowns of the 1970's and of 1992, as well as to the economic shock of three years ago. It was external pressures like these that forced former President Suharto from office in Indonesia in 1998, emboldening the opposition and shaking his one-man rule.
Though other countries may be more peaceful, every one of them is feeling the undercurrents of change.
"All the countries of the region are going through this process," said William J. Klausner, a political scientist at Chulalongkorn University. "It's just a question of where you are on the spectrum."
In Malaysia, the entrenched and overbearing government now must take into account an invigorated political opposition and nongovernmental groups that are making themselves heard as never before in the 19-year rule of its patriarch, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad.
Singapore, as always, has things well under control, but its always calculating leaders are tinkering, aware that they must loosen things up to stay at the forefront of the new fast-moving world economy.
Vietnam is changing despite the hesitancy of its leaders. Still Marxist, still hidebound, they have committed themselves to the increased transparency and accountability that are the price of entry into the world marketplace. The original domino in the cold war, it now faces the prospect of becoming, in the words of Mr. Sunai, one of the new "dominos of democracy."
Laos, Cambodia and Myanmar -- the former Burma -- with their strongman governments, have two options: liberalize or find themselves being left behind, poorer and poorer, relics of the past.
The Philippines, as always, is a special case. The region's democratic standard-bearer, its uneven fortunes have sometimes been a justification, sometimes a rebuke to Southeast Asia's strongmen. It is now demonstrating how messy democracy can be with President Joseph Estrada in the midst of an impeachment trial on corruption charges.
In Thailand, almost every institution is being scrutinized and challenged, from the judiciary to the police to the Ministry of Interior to the Buddhist establishment to the corrupt and bloated government bureaucracy.
Small skirmishes fill the newspapers here almost every day: parents fighting against favoritism in school admissions, patients suing doctors for malpractice, farmers protesting against dam projects, villagers complaining about factories' pollution.
And the old guard fights back; the stakes are the wealth and power structure of a nation.
"The old system is not just going to go away," Mr. Klausner said. "They are fighting every day. That's the excitement of it. A lot of people are frustrated because the game has not been won, but we are in the midst of a process, and it's a struggle."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Thaksin Shinawatra, the leading candidate for prime minister of Thailand, campaigned in Bangkok yesterday. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Stocks Are Down for First Week of Year as Rate-Cut Rally Fades

BYLINE:  By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Stocks plunged yesterday, just two days after a euphoric rally that sent the Nasdaq composite index up 14 percent, as investors once more faced the reality of slowing growth in the economy and in corporate profits.
 While investors were cheered Wednesday by the news that the Federal Reserve was unexpectedly cutting interest rates, they were depressed today by the news that the job market was weaker than it had been earlier in the year and that more companies were issuing earnings warnings. 
 As a result of today's sell-off, the leading market indicators finished the first week of the year in minus territory, which is how they ended 2000.
Although the Fed reduced short-term interest rates by half a percentage point, it is likely to take some time before that rate cut and others that are expected to follow will provide enough lift to offset the weight of the sagging economy, which will be in the news regularly with each month's data. 
And the hope of many investors that the central bank will bail out the economy could lead to a lot of daily disappointments. While most analysts say they believe that Fed policy makers will try to avoid a sharp economic downturn, too many investors may believe the central bank can do this quickly. Indeed, some investors appeared to be betting that the central bank will lower its federal funds target rate to 5.25 percent, from its current 6 percent, by the end of this quarter.
"While the Fed is going to be successful, it is going to take three to six months to know that it is working," said John Manley, senior equity strategist at Salomon Smith Barney. And during that time, he added, "there will be days that hope springs eternal and days of despair."
The technology-heavy Nasdaq finished the day down 159.18 points, or 6.2 percent, at 2,407.65. For the week, it was off 2.5 percent. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 250.40 points, or 2.3 percent, to 10,662.01, and was down 1.2 percent for the week. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index dropped 34.99 points, or 2.6 percent, to 1,298.35, and was off 1.7 percent for the week.
The sell-off came on volume just under the average for last year, as 1.43 billion shares exchanged hands on the New York Stock Exchange. On Thursday, exchange volume was 2.13 billion shares, surpassing 2 billion for the first time.
Among the stocks leading the major indexes lower were the usual technology suspects, including Cisco Systems, Oracle, Qualcomm, JDS Uniphase, Veritas Software, Hewlett-Packard, Intel and EMC. Also falling were General Motors, Caterpillar, J. P. Morgan Chase, Boeing and Wal-Mart Stores.
Yesterday's sobering economic news was that new job creation in December was weaker than expected. The Labor Department reported that nonfarm payrolls rose 105,000 in December, with 56,000 of them government jobs.
Growth of private jobs in the fourth quarter, at 0.2 percent, was the slowest it has been since the third quarter of 1992, a year and a half after the end of the 1990-1991 recession. Manufacturing jobs declined by 62,000 and were down 1 percent over the last year.
On top of this came more corporate earnings warnings, which, since October, have pulled the forecast for fourth-quarter earnings down to 4.2 percent from 15.6 percent for the companies in the Standard & Poor's 500 index, according to First Call/ Thomson Financial. For the first quarter of this year, the earnings growth forecast is down to 5.2 percent from 14.2 percent.
Nordstrom, the retailer, said that its fourth-quarter profits would be about half of what Wall Street analysts had forecast, which is 38 cents a share. Shares of Nordstrom fell $1.50, to $18.88. Next Level, which makes broadband communications systems, said its fourth-quarter loss, which was forecast at 12 cents a share, would be bigger. Its stock rallied late in the day to end down just 6 cents at $10.75.
Bank of America and other banks fell because of concerns about the fate of their loans to California utility companies. The current electricity crisis, which the utility companies have said may force them to go bankrupt, is threatening these banks with losses.
In a statement after rumors of losses were reported yesterday morning, Bank of America said: "We know of no basis to support speculative rumors about our operations. We are conducting business as usual. The company has not experienced any significant losses in derivatives or other trading activities." The stock finished down $3.50 at $48.
In the bond market, the weakness of the economy seemed to outweigh any negative news on inflation that might be found in the December jobs report. While job growth was weak, the unemployment rate remained unchanged at 4 percent, near its 30-year low, and hourly earnings rose 0.4 percent, or 5 cents. "These still rather moderate inflationary and wage pressures will ease in the not too distant future as the result of a slowing economy," said Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Fleming Asset Management.
The price of the 10-year note rose 28/32, to 106 9/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.92 percent from 5.03 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 20/32, to 112 15/32. The bond's yield declined to 5.40 percent from 5.44 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: Labor Market Remains Tight, Despite Slowing Economy 

BYLINE:  By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The sharply slowing economy still has not done much to weaken the tightest labor market in 30 years.
 Even as manufacturing companies cut both jobs and workers' hours last month, companies in the much larger service sector continued to add to their record-high payrolls, allowing the unemployment rate to hold steady in December at 4 percent, the Labor Department reported yesterday. 
 But the pace of job creation clearly slowed in the spring of 2000, and remains much more sluggish than it was earlier in the year and during much of the latter half of the 1990's, the government disclosed in its closely watched monthly employment report. And the job market could deteriorate further in the months ahead. 
"These data really do indicate an economy that continues to decelerate rapidly," said Richard B. Berner, the chief United States economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter.
Apparel, automobile and metal-making companies all cut payrolls sharply last month, as did temporary-help firms, which are typically among the first to react to an economic slowdown as companies shed part-time workers.
Manufacturing employment fell by 62,000 in December, raising the total loss for the year to 178,000. Even the once red-hot service sector is no longer expanding at the pace it had been. 
Across the private sector, companies added only about 4,000 jobs a day during the last nine months of 2000, half the pace during the previous year.
For now, however, the unemployment rate remains near a three-decade low, as it has for more than a year. Hourly wages responded to the continued tightness last month by accelerating, helping prevent workers from losing much ground even though they logged fewer hours.
"We're pretty close to full employment," said Lakshman Achuthan, the managing director of the Economic Cycle Research Institute in New York, even if companies are pulling fewer new people into the work force than they were a year ago.
Total nonfarm employment increased 105,000 last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics said, with less than half of the gain coming in the private sector, which is much more sensitive to ups and downs in the business cycle. The increase in government payrolls reversed a similar-size drop in November, to a revised gain in total jobs of 59,000, and most analysts dismissed it as insignificant. 
The jobs report came two days after the Federal Reserve made a surprise cut in interest rates of half a percentage point. Analysts said the jobs data underscored the degree to which the rate cut was an attempt to lift the sagging confidence of investors and consumers and to provide a stimulus for the shrinking manufacturing sector.
The growth in hourly wages last month -- up 4.8 percent on an annual basis -- raises the potential of a worrisome combination of rising inflationary pressures and slower growth, which could complicate the efforts of the Fed to cut interest rates again in coming months to restart the economic engine.
Investors, fearful that the slowing economy will hammer profit margins early this year, seemed to show some doubts about whether the Fed will be able to be as aggressive in cutting rates as they had believed earlier this week. Yesterday, the Dow Jones industrial average fell more than 250 points, to 10,662.01, and the Nasdaq composite index plunged 6.2 percent, to 2,407.65.
But analysts now consider inflation a far less potent threat than recession. The price of commodities like oil and lumber, as well as imported goods, has fallen in recent months, and the decline in the average workweek last month -- to 34.1 hours, from 34.3 -- meant that average weekly wages actually fell slightly. A series of winter storms played a role in the reduction in hours, economists said.
The wage statistics cover so-called production employees, who account for about four-fifths of the nation's work force.
More broadly, the pace of job creation looks a lot as it did in both 1995 and 1989, and the Fed is now trying to ensure that the coming months resemble the slowdown in growth of the mid-1990's rather than the recession that began in 1990. Today, as during those earlier periods, private-sector job growth has fallen by about half during a single year.
In 1989, after job growth slowed, it fell in 1990 and 1991 and did not fully recover until 1993. After the 1995 "soft landing," by contrast, corporate investments in new technology and consumers' enthusiasm for new cars, appliances and computers helped job creation quickly recover.
The Fed rate cut this week came after a weak holiday shopping season and a sharp falloff in the growth of corporate investment spending caused Alan Greenspan and his colleagues at the central bank to worry that the economy was weaker than the unemployment rate and other lagging indicators had suggested.
In recent weeks, for example, large companies like General Motors, Office Depot and Whirlpool have announced plans to lay off workers or to reduce employment through attrition. The bulk of those cuts are expected to come during 2001. Across the country last month, companies announced plans for 134,000 layoffs, the highest number since Challenger, Gray & Christmas, a job placement firm in Chicago, began compiling such data in 1993.
"There are some weaknesses that will be showing up later" in the unemployment rate, said Sung Won Sohn, the chief economist for Wells Fargo.
Some analysts are also concerned that a statistical quirk may be veiling the job market's true condition. To account for job creation at new companies -- which are difficult to track month to month -- the government uses older data to estimate what happened most recently. But because many technology start-ups have cut jobs recently and new firms are struggling to receive financing, the Labor Department could be overestimating job growth.
"Job growth may actually have stopped in the last three months," said Dean Baker, the co-director of the Center for Economic Policy and Research in Washington.
Still, the Clinton administration said the report -- the final one to be released on its watch -- was confirmation of an unprecedented boom, in which unemployment has fallen from more than 7 percent to 4 percent and most workers have received raises.
"We can boast of broadly shared prosperity," said Alexis M. Herman, the departing secretary of labor. "This is a healthy slowdown. We've gone from spectacular growth to growth that is probably more stable and more sustainable."
The unemployment rates for teenagers and minorities are near all-time lows, and the number of people who want but cannot find full-time work has dropped to 13 million, from 20 million, Ms. Herman added.
President-elect George W. Bush has warned, however, that the economy may be on the verge of a recession, and he has said he wants to pursue his proposed tax cut aggressively in part to prevent a downturn. Mr. Bush also praised the Fed's rate cut this week as recognition of economic weakness.
"The economy is slowing down," Ari Fleischer, Mr. Bush's chief spokesman, said in a briefing in Washington yesterday. "We hope that the president is right and that there will be continued economic growth."

HEADLINE: Troubles Pile Up for California's Utilities 

 BODY:
California's troubled utilities took more hits yesterday from Washington judges, California regulators and Wall Street bond companies.
 Also yesterday, the Energy Department extended an emergency order requiring power producers to supply California's electricity market through Jan. 10. 
 The order requires California to certify within a week that it has taken steps to reduce electricity demand by 5 percent during peak demand periods. It also requires that any negotiated price above $64 a megawatt-hour be submitted to the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission for review to assure that the price is "just and reasonable."
The United States Court of Appeals in Washington rejected an attempt by Southern California Edison to force the Federal Energy Regulatory Commission to limit the wholesale prices that it pays power producers for electricity. The three-judge panel said the company "has not demonstrated that its right to this relief is clear and indisputable."
Although the state approved immediate rate increases on Thursday of about 10 percent, the amount was about half what the companies had asked for. That action reverberated in the bond markets, as Standard & Poor's, Moody's and Fitch Inc. downgraded the credit ratings of PG&E and Southern California's parent, Edison International. The two utilities have warned that they could soon file for bankruptcy protection if the situation does not improve.
Edison also said yesterday that it would lay off 1,450 more workers over several months to save money. Last month, it eliminated 400 jobs.

HEADLINE: Queens-Midtown Ferry Service To End in March, Company Says 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
Citing low ridership, New York Waterway announced yesterday that it would end ferry service between Queens and Midtown Manhattan.
 In an advisory distributed to afternoon rush passengers, the company said that it would discontinue shuttle bus service to and from the ferry's terminal at East 34th Street on Feb. 2, with the ferry itself ceasing operation after March 2. 
 "We have a route that's not doing anything," said Pat Smith, a spokesman for New York Waterway, the country's largest ferry operator. "The ridership is not there." 
The company runs 23 boats along 10 commuter routes, mostly between the World Financial Center or Midtown Manhattan and New Jersey cities like Weehawken and Hoboken. The commuter ferries carry about 32,000 people a day, Mr. Smith said.
During rush hour, Mr. Smith said, most of New York Waterway's boats operate at capacity, ranging from 64 to 396 passengers per ride. But the Queens route carries only 135 people each day, an average of 10 passengers per trip, he said. The Queens line, which follows the Queens Midtown Tunnel above water, has run between Hunters Point in Queens and East 34th Street since 1994 and has never been profitable, he said. The company plans to continue and expand service on its other commuter routes, he said.
Mr. Smith said that company officials had been trying to figure out what to do about the Queens service for months, but reached a decision just yesterday. "To be honest, this is just looking at the economics and the resources available," he said.
New York Waterway will work with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey to find a new operator for the service, Mr. Smith said. Representatives at the Port Authority did not return telephone calls yesterday afternoon.
New York Waterway might "get back in there with a smaller, faster boat" from Queens to Pier 11 near Wall Street as an experiment some day, Mr. Smith said, adding that that was "not a promise."

PERSON: SILA M. CALDERON 

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES; 
A New Governor Ushers in a New Era in Puerto Rico

DATELINE: SAN JUAN, P.R. 

 BODY:
SILA M. CALDERON is the first to admit that as a young adult she was not very fond of politics. In fact, she was not very fond of work.
 "Girls of certain families didn't have to work," said Ms. Calderon, the daughter of a wealthy entrepreneur whose holdings included ice cream factories and hotels. "My American friends would work as waitresses in the summer and I would go off to Europe with my parents." 
 Today, Ms. Calderon is both a shrewd politician and a bit of a workaholic. She believes that her parents, who taught her that a lady should look nice and tend to the home, would be proud, though her life bears little resemblance to the traditional homemaker role they had envisioned for her. After all, she did make history this week.
On Tuesday, Ms. Calderon was inaugurated as Puerto Rico's first female governor.
It was a day that brought thousands of supporters to Old San Juan's streets. Choirs sang. The presidents of Haiti, Venezuela, the Dominican Republic and Panama looked on. 
But after the musicians packed up and the dignitaries had been whisked away following her swearing-in ceremony, it seemed only fitting that Ms. Calderon would turn to her parents. And she did just that with a solitary stop on her way to La Fortaleza, the governor's headquarters and mansion where she will live and work during her four-year term.
"I went to their graves and just asked them to help me," Ms. Calderon said.
She will need all the wisdom and strength she can muster to tackle the numerous challenges ahead. Ms. Calderon, who ran on the Popular Democratic Party ticket, has already angered some politicians in Washington by advocating that the United States Navy immediately halt its bombing practices on Vieques island. She also opposes United States statehood for Puerto Rico, which her predecessor, Pedro Rossello, endorsed. And she comes after a scandal-prone government that has left many citizens here weary and distrustful of their leaders.
Ms. Calderon, 58, also knows that supporters of the two losing political parties will be scrutinizing her progress on her promises to deliver better services to the poor, upgrade the island's water system and general infrastructure and improve Puerto Rico's image.
"I think the image has nothing to do with the reality and I think that is one of my biggest challenges," Governor Calderon said.
She said Puerto Rico, a self-governing commonwealth of the United States, suffered from misperceptions about its economic stability and its patriotism. "We are proud of our citizenship and share the same love of democracy and liberty," she said. "At the same time we have our own culture we want to protect."
She said she would personally take those messages to Wall Street and Washington as an "ambassador" for Puerto Rico.
BORN in San Juan in 1942, Governor Calderon grew up steeped in the history of her native island. Her father would spend hours recounting to her Puerto Rican history and his admiration for the Popular Democratic Party and its message of democracy and social responsibility. And though he also emphasized a traditional role for women, it is perhaps not surprising that she was drawn to public life after graduating from Manhattanville College in Purchase, N.Y., where she received a bachelor's degree in government. 
Her first real introduction to government came in 1973 while attending the Graduate School of Public Administration at the University of Puerto Rico. Her labor relations professor liked her work so much that when he left during the semester to become Puerto Rico's secretary of labor he tapped her as his executive assistant. It was a turning point that introduced her to public service.
Over the next nearly three decades she would weave in and out of both the private and public sector, working her way up to vice president at Citibank and serving for eight years as mayor of San Juan, the job she left to become governor.
Because of what her parents taught her about history and social responsibility, "when I was asked to go into public service, I accepted." The mother of two grown daughters and a son (she also has five stepchildren from her 22-year second marriage) wants to lead Puerto Rico into a new era of respect and prosperity. But in the first days of tackling the issues of governing here, she and her staff have been distracted by more basic duties. They have had to figure out how to work the computers and copy machines in their new offices.
Less than 48 hours after her inauguration, Ms. Calderon discovered that the transition of power from Governor Rossello, who departed without appointing anyone to assist with the transition, will be far from smooth. The staff could not find computer codes. A news conference on Thursday was delayed by more than a half hour because no one could figure out how to make copies of news releases. And Ms. Calderon left one visitor waiting for three hours because administrative glitches threw her schedule off.
Yet ever mindful of her image, the new governor did her best to stay on time and on point during one important photo opportunity. As her staff worked nervously behind the scenes on the headquarters logistics, Ms. Calderon spent the early afternoon on Thursday air-kissing and shaking hands with local politicians at the governor's annual New Year's protocol greeting at La Fortaleza. Now, with her ceremonial duties tended to for the moment, the governor wants to get on with, as she puts it, being a "public administrator more than a politician."
She never liked the latter title to begin with. "Politics has lost its prestige and doesn't have a good name to it," she said. 
She has drafted several laws intended to stem corruption, which she hopes will restore the image of government, at least in Puerto Rico. "We deserve a government that's clean, open and honest just like we are," she said.
Also not lost on her is that among the thousands of supporters who lined Old San Juan's streets to view her inauguration were young girls who were seeing a new day in more ways than one at the birth of the new millennium.
"When I was a little girl everybody who had power were men," Governor Calderon said. "Now girls know that it is very normal for power to be shared with men and women."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Sila M. Calderon became governor of Puerto Rico on Tuesday. (Laura Magruder for The New York Times)
