HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey; 
'Flex' Buildings Offer Versatility Plus Lower Rent

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
IT used to be that office tenants would set up operations in sleek high-rise buildings and that light industrial users in need of an office would carve out a corner of a warehouse, put up walls, move in desks and install telephones and computers.
 But the lines between pure office and industrial functions have been increasinglyblurred in recent years, most notably, perhaps, by the growth of high-technology businesses. At the same time, rental rates for office space continues to rise. 
 The result, several commercial brokers said, is that companies are turning to high-technology "flex" buildings, which give them sophisticated office space at a lower cost as well as space that can serve other purposes under one roof, from storage to light assembly to research and development. Developers are responding with a spate of low-rise flex structures, about 10 buildings totaling 889,000 square feet for nine northern and central New Jersey counties, which are being built, converted or planned, according to CB Richard Ellis, the commercial real estate services firm. 
Typically, flex buildings have one or two stories and are designed to look like office structures from the outside, with details like finished facades, large windows, landscaped grounds and sufficient parking. But they also have high ceilings, floors that can hold heavy loads and the loading docks required by many industrial tenants. Such space can also be carved into individual units, each with its own entrance and utilities.
The appeal is that it enables "tenants to have control of their space, of their destiny," said Jonathan Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization/TCN Worldwide, a real estate services firm in Woodbridge.
Developers and brokers said tenants in the market for such space included biotechnology, telecommunications, software, electronics and pharmaceutical companies that are expanding, consolidating or opening satellite offices in the state. There is also interest from high-technology companies, medical concerns and data processing and call centers.
Such buildings have been around for some time. But Thomas Mallaney, a first vice president at the Paramus office of CB Richard Ellis, said demand had surged in the last two years as tenants sought a less costly alternative to office space. Along with annual rents that are generally $18 a square foot, compared with $23 to $24 a square foot for office space, he said high-technology flex buildings were more efficient because of fewer common areas like lobbies and less expensive to operate because each office has individual meters for utilities. 
Many of the flex buildings are near existing highways, offering easy access, Mr. Mallaney said. For that reason, he added, "companies increasingly are using much and sometimes all of the space for offices."
Mr. Schultz said that was the case for many of the deals his firm does today, including the recent lease by JDS Uniphase, a supplier of fiber optics. Of the 80,000 square feet the company is renting in a flex building on Industrial Way in Eatontown, 90 percent is being used for offices, he said.
The market for such space, which encompasses about 6.5 million square feet in the nine counties, "still is a niche" within the overall commercial marketplace, Mr. Mallaney said, and the pace of production is conservative, keeping supply in balance with demand. In the the fourth quarter, his firm put the vacancy rate for such space at 4.9 percent, virtually unchanged from the figure in the period a year earlier.
Those factors, developers said, are what spurred them to proceed with their projects. 
In Rockaway in western Morris County, construction is scheduled to start by April on Rockaway Hills Commerce Center, a 251,445-square-foot, three-building high-technology flex park on 45 acres, off Green Pond Road and not far from major roads like Interstates 80 and 287. Each of the buildings, which will range in size from 78,000 to 87,400 square feet, will have 24-foot ceilings and glass curtain wall facades. The $17 million project is being developed by CalEAST Industrial Investors, a joint venture between Jones Lang LaSalle Development, the development arm of the Manhattan-based real estate services and management firm, and the California Public Employees Retirement System, or Calpers. 
Scott C. Coopchik, director of development for the northeast region at Jones Lang LaSalle, said the market for high-technology flex space was tight in this part of Morris County, where the vacancy rate is less than 3 percent. The plan, he added, is to build the buildings on speculation, without a tenant in place.
"With everyone trying to cut occupancy costs, flex space is a competitive option for tenants," he said. "If you can save 20 to 25 percent, and still have a beautiful setting, they'll say, 'Why not?' "
Mr. Coopchik said the asking per-square-foot rents would be $15 for office space and $8 for warehouse space, compared with $23 for pure office space in that part of the county. 
Underscoring the demand for such space in Morris County is the leasing activity at Montville Corporate Centre III in the Pine Brook section of Montville. Its developer, SK Realty and Development of Fairfield, recently completed the last building in the four-building, 530,000-square-foot park on 130 acres along Chapin Road, close to I-287. 
The structures at the two-year-old park range from 98,000 to 165,000 square feet and have 22-foot ceilings and brick facades. All are now nearly fully leased at rents of $16 a square foot for office space and $8 for warehouse space, according to Ted Buyer, executive vice president of the development company. He added that the demand was greater than the supply for well-developed high-technology space.
In Sayreville in Middlesex County, First Industrial Trust of Montville is constructing two speculative high-technology flex buildings, each with 60,000 square feet. They will take shape at its Sayreville Business Center on the Main Street extension, just behind the toll booths at Exit 124 of the Garden State Parkway.
"The increasing cost of pure office space and decreasing vacancy rate is causing tenants that do not need glitz or glamour to look for an alternative," said Hayden Tiger, the company's regional director. Occupancy is expected by June, he said, noting that asking rents are $14 a square foot for office space and $7 a square foot for nonoffice space. 
Some developers see such space as the future of old industrial buildings. W. P. Commercial L.L.C of Chatham will begin work this summer on converting the 150,000-square-foot former Channel Lumber warehouse on 15 acres along Route 10 in Hanover into a flex building. The company is a recently formed venture between the Whitehall Fund, an affiliate of Goldman, Sachs & Company, and the senior management of Wellsford Commercial Properties Trust of Chatham.
The company bought the empty single-story building for among other reasons its location, one-eighth of a mile from a four-way interchange of I-287, said Mark Schaevitz, its chief operating officer for the New York region. He said his company's experience with this type of property included revamping the old Estee Candy warehouse in Parsippany into the 225,000-square-foot Morris Technology Center. And it also plans a similar conversion for a former 240,000-square-foot warehouse on 47 acres off Route 202 in Bridgewater. 
"We look for infill locations that are next to new multistory offices and can be renovated to provide tenants with quality offices at a lower rent, as well as the 'optionality' to combine offices with other uses," Mr. Schaevitz said. Those benefits, he added, will only increase in importance if the economy slows and "when things in the commercial marketplace are less than perfect." 
Mr. Schaevitz said asking rents at the projects, which will be marketed to both single users and multiple tenants, would be "several dollars cheaper" than new multistory office buildings in the area. That means $26 to $27 a square foot at the Hanover project, he said, adding that rents at the Bridgewater development, while not yet set, are expected to be similar.

GRAPHIC: Photo: A former Channel Lumber warehouse on Route 10 in Hanover is to be converted into a flex building. (Wellsford Commercial Properties Trust)

HEADLINE: The Lives They Lived: 01-07-01: Julian Carsey, b. 1935; 
Starting Over and Over and Over

BYLINE:  By Simon Winchester; Simon Winchester is the author of "The Professor and the Madman: A Tale of Murder, Insanity and the Making of the Oxford English Dictionary."

 BODY:
There used to be a comforting anonymity about Tom's Place, a smoky and moderately seedy bar on the waterfront in Jacksonville, Fla., where the barstools were invariably occupied by men and women who liked to drink a little and forget a lot. Corinne Silverton, who was studying to be a stockbroker after years as a part-time teacher in a series of nightmarish public schools, was a more-than-typical customer -- divorced, tired, unhappy and broke, she had a liking, entirely understandable, for nursing three quiet beers in an evening, hoping that while she was doing so the world that she felt had treated her so ill would leave her well alone. A companionable bartender named Doug helped to see that this was so: he made sure that Corinne's stool was always empty and ready for her, and that any unsavory characters -- who might well relish the prospect of an evening with an unhappy and vulnerable divorcee -- were kept at bay, or at least at a respectful distance. 
 Early one evening during the winter of 1993 -- not that winter has very much meaning in the hot concrete wasteland of this unappealing north Florida port -- Corinne came in to Tom's Place for her usual solace, only to discover that on her stool was sitting a shabby-looking and gray-bearded man, with a shot glass between his hands. He looked, she says now, like nothing so much as a retired and broken-down mailman. He was badly dressed and had a weary, lined, lived-in face and the red and rheumy eyes of a long-term drinker. She was about to protest the impertinence when Doug hushed her. You ought to meet this man, he told her, with a quiet insistence that she realized she should take seriously. "You'll find him interesting. His name is Jay Martin Adams." 
 And so Corinne Silverton sat down beside the unanticipated Jay Martin Adams that steamy January evening, and through the next many hours, helped by a few more beers on her part and by many more whiskeys on his, she listened patiently to the stories he had to tell. 
Of course it is axiomatic that all the drunks in all the waterfront bars the world around have stories to tell, all of which are long, most of which are incoherent and many of which are curious. Yet this particular story, ably related by this obviously well-educated stranger, while every bit as curious as expected, was also moving, poignant and, to some listeners perhaps, including Corinne Silverton, rather enviable.
Jay Martin Adams was not the mystery man's name, for a start. He was actually called Julian Nance Carsey -- this he confessed to Corinne a few days later -- and until one extraordinary moment some 11 years before he stepped down from a Trailways bus here in Jacksonville, he was known by that name to a wide and loving circle of family, friends and colleagues. But then came a moment -- an epiphany to some few, the start of an unfolding of a nightmare for many others -- that had its climacteric on the morning of Wednesday, May 19, 1982.
As goes the cliche, the day began with its ordinary-enough routines. Julian Carsey, known as Jay, then the president of Charles County Community College in the corn-and-tobacco country of La Plata, Md., had his usual breakfast, said a polite goodbye to his wife, Nancy, told her that he was off to the dentist and remarked casually that he would see her later. He omitted, Nancy would later recall, to give her the usual obligatory peck on the cheek. He drove off in his black Chevrolet Caprice, pausing only to grumble at the yardmen who seemingly weren't cutting the lawn to his liking. He drove away from his impressive and historically designated house in Pomfret, Md. But he did not go, as was supposed, to his faux-colonial office in La Plata nearby, nor indeed did he call in at the dentist. 
Instead, he telephoned his secretary and asked her to cancel his appointment. He told her to tell Nancy that he might have to go to Philadelphia to see his sister. He went to the bank, withdrew $28,000 and converted it into traveler's checks. He drove to what then was still called Washington National Airport, parked his car and put his keys carefully into what is still quaintly called the glove compartment, dropped five already-written letters and one postcard into the mailbox, walked casually up to the check-in counter for Pan Am and bought himself a one-way ticket to Houston. He went into the Clipper Club, poured himself a handful of vodkas and, an hour or so later, having met no one he knew, poured himself onto the plane.
The letters and postcard duly arrived and were duly read the following day. To the chairman of the college's board of trustees, Jay Carsey announced his resignation. To the college dean, he sent an enigmatic five-word note with a postscript that said, with magnificent economy, "pls handle." And to his wife, by now distraught and frightened and horrified by an event of which she had no more expectation than an asteroid strike, he wrote: "I am leaving because I know you can't. I am a physical and psychological disaster." 
He directed her to a tape recording he had left in his desk, which explained nothing, but gave her some details to make the practical consequences of her abandonment less trying. And that, effectively, was that. Thirty-odd hours had passed, and the former college president and community pillar was now buried deep in the vast dusty wen of Texas, having for all intents and purposes vanished off the face of the civilized earth, transported as far from the groves of academe as if he were on the surface of Mars. 
Nearly fifty years ago Philip Larkin wrote what remains the most classically insightful poem about the seductive powers of running away. It includes the line: "He chucked up everything and just cleared off."
What haunts most of those who read it is the undeniable approval that Larkin implied and that he suspects, with a poet's wisdom, all of us feel -- a visceral approval for what he termed this audacious, purifying, elemental move. Moreover, Larkin writes, "I'd go today,/Yes, swagger the nut-strewn roads,/Crouch in the fo'c'sle/Stubbly with goodness, if/It weren't so artificial,/Such a deliberate step backwards/ To create an object:/Books; china; a life/Reprehensibly perfect."
Jay Carsey chose to try to make a life for himself that was just that -- reprehensibly perfect. In trying to do so he made a gesture that must seem quite wonderfully bold and courageous to the millions for whom, as Thoreau once said, the quiet desperation of their humdrum lives has become too much. And it was because Jay Carsey tried, and because those remaining millions did not, that so many seem to find all that he did so desperately fascinating.
Only Corinne Silverton knows (or thinks she knows) the story of Jay Carsey in full -- since she lived with him until the end of the tape that was his life, or his lives. Nancy Carsey -- now remarried and living in Baltimore -- knew only the years that ended when her husband, who was then 47, drove off in his Caprice that day in 1982 and drove so brutally out of her life. And Dawn Carsey, who was to become his second wife, in Texas, three years later, knew only the second act, since after seven years of relative contentment he went on to leave her as well. But Corinne Silverton, who befriended him on that night in Florida, has now heard the entire story; and with her unique benefit of a singular lack of bitterness about the man -- for when he left her in August, it was most certainly not of his own choosing -- she seems able to look with the kind of disinterestedness of which Philip Larkin would approve at the phenomenon that was Julian Nance Carsey and his barely explicable career of serial disappearances.
The mechanics of that first evanescence are suggestive of desperation and perplexity. Jay Carsey spent only a short time in Houston. He thought at first about going off to Australia -- he and Nancy, who as a couple had been inveterate travelers, had been there before, and he had always loved the place. So he flew off to San Diego, from where he thought, unaccountably, that he might get a trans-Pacific flight. But in fact all he did there was go "trolling for women," as a 1989 book, "Exit the Rainmaker," had it, and then spend an entire afternoon sitting on a bench at the zoo and cutting up his 28 credit cards -- making it all but impossible, he then found out, to rent a car and drive to Tijuana. (More than a few of Jay Carsey's decisions like this call into question the widely held view that he was highly intelligent: those who met him, however, insist he was, and say this merely showed his panic and bewilderment.)
By the end of his stay in California he had more or less consolidated an exit strategy that had, in a sense, now been forced upon him. Without a home and, moreover, now without any plastic to his name, Jay Carsey had become, in American terms, a nonperson. He converted the traveler's checks back into cash by fibbing to a San Diego bank that he was a yacht broker needing sudden liquidity. He chose a new name (selecting the middle name Martin in a nod to a lawyer relation from Dallas who had managed to keep one of Bonnie and Clyde's cronies out of the electric chair -- a nice touch, he thought, given that he was now part outlaw himself). And he gave the title Jay Martin Adams its first airing by using it (before the days when airlines needed photo ID's) to fly east again, this time to one of the more insalubrious towns in Texas: El Paso. 
Here, among the dust and the shanties and the cockroaches, this Social-Security-number-less droog checked into the Y.M.C.A., found himself a bar, stopped bathing and changing his clothes and began living the new life with all the frantic nostalgie de la boue that one might expect -- a reaction, some would say, to all those years of respectability and stiff-necked socializing back in Maryland. He started chugging the vodkas and the whiskeys by the vatful, experimenting with whores in Chihuahua, teaching English to indigent Mexicans, lending money to win friends, smuggling gold, getting himself thrown in jail, eventually buying a share in a bar among the strip clubs and gin joints conveniently close to the local air base. A college president brought to this, he would doubtless say to himself, and would laugh and feel liberated and delighted in equal measure.
But lonely too. The temporary comforts of purchased one-night stands had, inevitably, a steadily diminishing allure. By the end of that summer he had encountered in the bar a woman as needy as himself -- a tough, thrice-married pool-playing city worker named Dawn Garcia. And over the coming months he placed his affairs in sufficient order to enable him to marry again -- largely by making two trips back East to be divorced from Nancy, neither speaking a word to her when they met in court nor even exchanging a glance, and offering little explanation or comfort to those old friends he saw. 
His new marriage lasted seven years. While by most accounts it was stormy -- with strong drink playing its usual corrosive part -- during this period Jay Carsey did begin to claw himself back up the ladder of respectability. True, when matters became tense between the pair he ran away again, briefly, and then returned, prodigal, his tail between his legs. And then an article duly appeared in People magazine /- "a quiet college president solves job stress his way: one day he just disappears" -- and Dawn and the down-at-heel barflies with whom the couple liked to associate and who recognized him from his photo in the magazine had to accept that he was something of a celebrity. But none of this stopped him from getting a new job back on the periphery of his old profession: he was offered, by an obviously very trusting president, a post teaching math at the El Paso Community College. Soon afterward -- since his students adored him and his staff colleagues found him charming and impressive -- he was offered an even more established post as an assistant dean. But this, smacking of the kind of stability that he no longer seemed to want, he smartly turned down.
What he did take was a job with the United States Air Force, working as a temporary teacher on a series of overseas bases. He and Dawn thus spent three years, until 1988, traveling between Greece and Germany, England and Turkey, Holland and the Azores, shuttling relentlessly between officers' quarters and living with government furniture and art, living a life that was no more than they both seemed to want -- a federally financed hymn to utter rootlessness.
Then they came back to Texas and to the veneer of permanence once more. And with this next period of fixity, so the fights and the arguments set in -- until just before Christmas 1992, when Jay Martin Adams drove to the airport, dropped his car in short-term parking and put the keys in the glove compartment, took a plane to Miami, spent a few sick, spiritless days in a cheap hotel by the sea -- and then boarded the northbound Trailways bus up I-95. 
Corinne Silverton met him at Tom's Place a few days later. He took her to an opera for their first date. Within a month, bowled over by his charm, his yarns, his exotic past, his intelligence and his beguiling helplessness, she had invited him to live with her. It was a replay, uncannily precise, of what happened with Dawn Garcia 10 years before -- except that this time he was being welcomed not into a small frame house in the old flyblown barrios of South Texas but into a flyblown but book-filled home in the modern cement wilderness that is downtown Jacksonville. 
And from that moment on, this melancholy, world-weary middle-aged woman, disappointed in her life and her loves almost since coming down to America from her birthplace on the high plains of Saskatchewan, began to preside over the remaining seven years of her strangely nomadic new friend's final phase of grounding. Corinne Silverton looked after Jay Carsey with a kindness and sympathy that seem to have been repaid by only brief moments of happiness and by long periods of despair. She watched with pride as he took jobs in a succession of local schools, she glowed in his reflected glory at the good reports he received, she took singular pleasure in the evident fondness that students and staff had for him, she happily traveled down to Mexico, on what was (since both were teachers) the pleasing respite of a school holiday for two. And all the while she watched with terrible sadness as the relentless chemistry of alcohol poisoning steadily stripped him of his health, his dignity, his ability and, eventually, his life.
Julian Nance Carsey died of cirrhosis of the liver on Aug. 20, at the age of 65. For two weeks no one in his immediate family claimed his body. (Corinne, being unrelated, felt reluctant to do so.) The sister whom he had said he would visit on that day he first vanished, back in 1982, never surfaced to express either regret or dismay. One good friend from Washington eventually paid for the funeral expenses, and early last September the man the residents of La Plata and Pomfret had all called Uncle Jay was reduced in a gas burner to a few ounces of gray ash.
Corinne Silverton is certain now that she knows just why he behaved the way he did. She largely discounts the psychiatrists' suggestions that he was internalizing his resentments -- that the budget cuts he was expecting at the college and his first wife's expensive tastes and the requirements of his social life were generating pressures on him about which he felt he could not talk, and with which he was mentally unable to deal. She also does not believe that he was ill -- other than physically, and such physical illnesses as he suffered came about entirely as a consequence of his heavy drinking. She rejects such modish notions that he was at the time of his vanishing in what psychologists term a "fugue" state, harmlessly divorced from reality, relentlessly irresponsible, incapable of dealing with the complex expectations of normal society.
Yet she will not say, specifically, what she believes it was that tipped Jay Carsey over the edge. She hints darkly that there were sinister reasons behind his decision to chuck up everything. Yes, she repeats -- sinister reasons. 
And in saying so, the tone of our conversation subtly shifts. Her body language changes -- her breathing gets a little faster, her face gets a little closer, a rime of perspiration appears on her upper lip -- in the way that you'd expect it to change if you were listening to a rant late at night in a waterfront bar, even though this conversation takes place over breakfast in the Jacksonville Hilton.
"He worked with the C.I.A., you know. He worked at Indian Head Naval Station, doing mysterious stuff. He traveled all over, for years, working for a program that was supposed to set up community colleges in strange places / Iran, Russia, countries like that. He knew some very strange people. He knew who Deep Throat was. And there were people gunning for him. People were out to get him. He told me -- he told me much more than he ever told Dawn or Nancy." 
I have little doubt that Silverton is a shrewd and sensible woman -- sad and brow-beaten maybe, and no doubt very gullible, but kind and courageous too -- and that she believes implicitly in what she has been told. Trusting Jay Carsey, or Jay Martin Adams, was for seven years a very cornerstone of her life. His claims, however bizarre, may well have served to fill a need in her -- to provide the vicarious thrill of an existence so much more satisfying than the dreariness of what otherwise stretched ahead. She scoffs at the idea and will offer only hints of other unspoken reasons.
"People like to say that he did what everyone dreams about -- he dropped out of society, he ran off," she explains to me. "It is much easier for everyone to believe that Jay simply liked to disappear, that it was all about a problem deep within himself. But in his case there was more to it than that -- much, much more. His story is so much more fascinating than you will ever know."

HEADLINE: Endpaper: Wayne McAllister, b. 1907; 
The Guru of Googie

BYLINE:  By Phil Patton; Phil Patton writes frequently about automobiles and design.

 BODY:
Wayne McAllister was building Las Vegas before Bugsy Siegel ever showed up. In 1941, McAllister designed the city's first theme hotel, El Rancho Vegas, which featured among other things a neon windmill. So it was natural that Siegel would turn to McAllister in 1942 to renovate his first Vegas hotel, El Cortez. What was less predictable is that McAllister would later turn down the opportunity to design for the gangster the famed Flamingo. A dumb or brave man, you might say, but perhaps also a man who could foresee the future -- the Flamingo's financial collapse and the hail of bullets that would kill Siegel in his living room. 
 McAllister, who died in March at 92, outlived not only his clients but also most of his buildings. With their giant signs and dramatic architectural gestures, those buildings gave life to the Great American Strip, shaping not just Las Vegas but also the roads leading into and out of countless American cities. 
 In 1928, at age 20, McAllister won a competition to design the Agua Caliente in Tijuana, a sprawling casino hotel that soon became the favored retreat for Hollywood stars looking to escape prohibition. Its success led to commissions throughout Los Angeles -- chrome-and-glass bars that made Hollywood and Vine the corner; chic supper clubs like Lawry's and Cinegrill; and whimsical, circular drive-ins like Simon's and Melody Lane. 
McAllister never took himself too seriously (he junked his entire archive, for instance), and he expected his buildings to vanish like the big, curvaceous cars that inspired them. (One hardy survivor is the 1949 Bob's Big Boy in Toluca Lake, now an official California Point of Historical Interest.) His best-known work, the Sands -- with its 65-foot neon-script sign like the chrome badge on a Cadillac grille and its porte-cochere like a tail fin -- was imploded in 1996. It lives on now in photos and in movies like "Ocean's 11," the 1960 Rat Pack vehicle that celebrates a time and a way of life that, for many, exists most distinctly as the memory of Wayne McAllister's brightly colored lights and zigzags and curves, seen through a passing windshield. 

GRAPHIC: Photos: Gas-guzzling architecture: From top, the Sands Hotel in Las Vegas, famous Rat Pack hangout; the Melody Lane drive-in; the Hotel Agua Caliente in Tijuana, Prohibition hot spot; Bob's Big Boy, Toluca Lake, Calif., in 1998; Bob's Big Boy in the 50's, before it was a landmark. (Melody, Nichols Collection, Bob's (1998), Marshall Laplante, Marc Wanamaker/Bison Archives)

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE 

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
Nuclear Power Play
 Czechoslovakia's involuntary role as a potential nuclear power during the Cold War is the unusual theme of a play by Joe Sutton at Long Wharf in New Haven through Feb. 11. 
 Its title, "The Third Army," derives from the "economic" army of investors that descended on the country from America and its friends in the west, eager to complete and control the Soviet Union's unfinished Temelin nuclear power plant, built during its 40-year reign over Czechoslovakia. The Soviets gained control of the country in 1945 when the American Army was ordered to withdraw.
The collapse of the Soviet Union and the subsequent instability left in its wake gave rise on the one hand to some nostalgia for Communism and on the other, to ambivalence toward the United States. 
Performances are scheduled on Tuesday at 7; Wednesday through Friday at 8; Saturday at 4 and 8:30; Sunday at 2 and 7. Tickets are priced from $14 to $45. The theater is at 222 Sargent Drive, just off I-95. Information and tickets: (203) 787-4282.

Sci-Fi Thrillers
Rex Reason and Faith Domergue find a less than warm welcome from the dreaded Metaluna Mutant when they arrive on the planet Metaluna in the 1956 sci-fi thriller "This Island Earth." The second half of Saturday's double feature at the Memorial Boulevard Auditorium in Bristol stars James Arness as the "Thing From Another World," a modern Dracula from outer space who lives on human blood. Kenneth Tobey and Robert Cornthwaite are co-stars in the 1951 chiller.
The program begins at 7:30. Admission is $5 for adults, $1.50 for children six through 12. Information and directions: (860) 583-8306

Lacquered Boxes
Visitors to the Bruce Museum in Greenwich will learn that there is more to those handsome, intricately decorated lacquered boxes from Japan than meets the eye. A selection n of 50 exceptional boxes dating from the 15th through the mid-19th century is on exhibit at the museum through Feb. 18. The exhibition is organized by Harvard University's Arthur M. Sackler Museum from the private collection of Elaine Ehrenkranz. The boxes were used, as boxes usually are, to hold cosmetics, food, writing materials and so on. 
Lacquering is believed to have originated in China and Japan around 5,000 B.C., applied with increasingly complex techniques to ceramics, wooden objects and basketry. The substance is made from the sap of the rhus verniciflua, a deciduous tree that is a cousin of poison oak, poison ivy and poison sumac. Woe to the harvester, refiner or lacquer-maker who did not protect himself from horrific allergic reactions by exposing himself in small amounts until he became immune. Once hardened on the box, though, the lacquer is harmless.
Inlays, appliques and three-dimensional adornments of armor, flowers, carriages and architectural forms appear not only on the exterior but inside the lid of some pieces. The lacquered surfaces reveal an endlessly creative force at work to produce shimmering effects sometimes incorporating bits of metal in sparkling designs of gold and silver.
The museum, just off Exit 3 of I-95, is open Tuesday through Saturday from 10 to 5, Sunday from 1 to 5. Admission is $4, $3 for children and adults 65 and older. Information: (203) 869-0376.

'Space Odyssey'
The Westport Public Library will weigh in on the hoopla surrounding "2001: A Space Odyssey." Keir Dullea, Fairfield County's own star of the film, will appear at the library on Thursday at 7 p.m. to talk about clips as they appear on the screen and to take questions from the audience. 
The film is to be re-released internationally in February after a special showing in Berlin. 
The library is at Bernhard Plaza in downtown Westport. Information: (203) 227-8411.

Words on Pictures
Three Fairfield County cartoonists will regale visitors who show up at the Westport Library today at 2 p.m. with tales of how they make a living drawing pictures. 
Mel Casson, who illustrates the comic strip "Redeye," which is reproduced by King Features in more than 550 newspapers, has had five cartoon books published. His work has appeared in United Features publications, The Chicago Sun-Times Syndicate and numerous national magazines.
Dick Hodgins, a former editorial cartoonist for The Daily News, was something of child prodigy, having sold a cartoon to The New York Mirror at the age of 12, for $1. And Howard Munce, cartoonist for humorist Judith Marks-White, is the author of three art books, has produced cartoons for many area organizations and is a book editor-designer.

Brazilian Music
The flutist Paula Robison will appear on Saturday at 5 p.m. and again next Sunday at 3 p.m. in Old Lyme, performing a concert of Brazilian music with two Brazilian jazz musicians: Romero Lubambo, guitarist; and Cyro Baptista, percussionist. 
The flute figures prominently in South American music, lending a wild, birdlike quality to jazz or native works rooted in folk songs or created by the continent's classical composers. Ms. Robison will perform some classical works for solo flute as well.
The concert will be held at the First Congregational Church at the corner of Lyme Street and Ferry Road. Tickets at $20 may be reserved by calling (860) 434-2252. Student tickets at $5 are available for Sunday only.

Studying Landmarks
Architecture buffs, professionals and students of the discipline will want to have a look inside the Yale Art and Architecture Building now and through the spring. 
Opening tomorrow, through March 2, is an exhibition titled "Saving Corporate Modernism: Assessing Three Landmarks Designed by Gordon Bunshaft." They are Lever House in New York City (1952), the Connecticut General Life Insurance Company (1958) and the Emhart Manufacturing Company (1963), both in Bloomfield.
Adjunctive elements enhancing such corporate structures are represented by the sculpture of Isamu Noguchi, interior design by Florence Knoll and Raymond Loewy, and landscape design by Joanna Diman.
Lever House is undergoing restoration, but the two remaining Bunshaft buildings are threatened with demolition. 
The saving of corporate landmarks will be the subject of a seminar scheduled on Feb. 9 and 10 at the Art and Architecture Building, which was designed by Paul Rudolph during his tenure as chairman of the architecture department at Yale. 
"These buildings," said Robert A. M. Stern, dean of the School of Architecture, "are not only great examples of modern architecture but ones which are in a special category where architects, designers and their clients collaborated to establish new paradigms for American business. They are landmarks of the history of architecture and of the history of business."
Exhibitions to open in March will feature the work of Eero Saarinen and Koetter Kim & Associates. And the ongoing restoration of the Art and Architecture building itself, led by Dean Stern, will become part of the exhibition series. Galleries in the building at 180 York Street are open free of charge Monday through Friday from 9 to 5, Saturday from 10 to 5. Information: (203) 432-2292. ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: Wanted: People to Collect All The Forgotten Money 

BYLINE:  By CHRISTINE WOODSIDE

 BODY:
JENNIFER SAMELA had forgotten about the savings account she set up for the 20th reunion of the Thomaston High School Class of 1975. Late last month, she noticed her name on a list of more than 22,000 people the Connecticut state treasurer's office is trying to find so they will claim their money.
 "We didn't have a 25th reunion," Ms. Samela said. That explains why the account she'd opened, with less than $100 left in it, ended up on the list. State laws required the bank holding the reunion funds to try to find depositors on dormant accounts, and, after five years, to turn the money over to the state treasurer. 
 Right now, the office of Connecticut State Treasurer Denise L. Nappier is holding $270 million that belongs to 500,000 people or their heirs who forgot or never knew about bank accounts, insurance policies, bonds, utility deposits, money orders, and similar assets held by Connecticut institutions.
Since September, a record number of people have inquired after amounts ranging from $50 to several thousand dollars, but they still represent a fraction of the total.
In three months, about 74,000 people asked after more than $9 million out of the $270 million in lost funds, said Bernard Kavaler, director of communications for the state treasurer's office. Of those, 45,000 of them filed claims.
"It's the strongest response we've ever had to an outreach effort like this," Mr. Kavaler said. "We received almost 45,000 e-mails alone."
Every two years, the state treasurer's office publishes new names of people "appearing to own abandoned property." The new list that came out late last month had 22,044 new names on it. In September, the list totaled 29,000. The campaign, with the theme of "Name It and Claim It," has a new web database with the address www.nameitandclaimit.org.
The unclaimed money remains in separate accounts and never reverts to the state, Mr. Kavaler said. The money earns interest, and when people claim their funds, they receive the accrued interest. He could not say what the interest rates are.
The situations leading to forgotten assets vary, he said. Forgotten insurance policies, old bank accounts, even the contents of neglected safe-deposit boxes. "A claim can be filed in perpetuity," he said. "If you can document that some funds we are holding are your great-grandmother's, and you have appropriate documentation that you're the legal heir, that money will be turned over to you."
He said one woman found that she had several thousand dollars coming to her from an old insurance policy and that she was able to use the money to spend on medical expenses for her son's illness.
Since the addresses aren't always current, finding the people can be very difficult. An unscientific analysis of 13 names on the list yielded the following information: two of them had listed phone numbers that matched the printed names and addresses. The rest of them couldn't be located because either they had moved or they had unlisted numbers.
The state doesn't try to call the 500,000 people on its database.
Mr. Kavaler said some companies do make a business of notifying people that they have assets and charge a fee to hand over the information. He said it's better if people just check the database and get the information for free.
Michael Antonelli, who lives with his family in Trumbull, had no idea his name was on the new list until a reporter called to tell him.
He called the state's hot line, at 800-833-7318, and a man informed him he had money coming to him.
"It turned out, if you're ready for this, to be a 1995 accounts payable check to my wife and me from AT&T in the amount of $60. He wouldn't give me any more information about that. He indicated he would send me the online claim form."
Mr. Antonelli said he suspected the money came in when he and his wife, Georgiana, switched their telephone service while they lived in Hong Kong and Tokyo for four years. He wondered if the company had tried to mail the check. Clearly, it gave up, since he's been back since 1998.
"I think I'll just spend it on golf balls," he said. "It will fund the year 2001 golf ball inventory."

HEADLINE: A LA CARTE; 
Trying to Get Beyond Hefty Appetizers

BYLINE:  By RICHARD JAY SCHOLEM; E-mail: licarte@nytimes.com

 BODY:
AT the earthy new Peppo and Lino's Italian Grill in Merrick, the most unnecessary, even silliest question a waiter can ask a diner is, "Would you like an appetizer?" The obvious answer is no, because the instant patrons sit down at their tables 8 or 10 bowls of rustic, garlicky starters are plunked down before them. Crunchy broccoli; aromatic escarole; mussels posillippo; plump meatballs; stuffed shrimp; deep-fried rice balls; garlic-flecked roasted red peppers; stuffed artichokes; olives; three-bean salad; sweet-potato strips; an onion, pea, mushroom mix; soft oniony potato salad with walnuts; and marinated, dilled zucchini are among the 12 or 15 rotating possibilities included in this automatically served Roman antipasto. 
 While there are slight night-to-night changes in this Italian culinary mosaic, there is one constant: an inability to finish the formidable appetizer array and still have room for an entree (even without a starter). Surprisingly, the entire expansive spread comes at no cost for customers who order any pasta or entree (it costs $10.95 for those who eat it as their meal). 
 Main-course prices are not inflated to compensate. The lowest-priced pasta is $8.95 and is accompanied by a bigger-than-usual dinner salad, while entrees go for as little as $9.95 and include potatoes and mixed vegetables. Come to think of it, we did try one starter, the crostini bar ($5.95), an echo of the antipasto with enough bread, sun-dried tomatoes, cheese, roasted eggplant and so on to feed four.
The charm of Peppo and Lino's (196 Merrick Road, 516-377-4369), which is patterned after a 1930's latticini in Brooklyn started by forebears of the owner, Chris Affronti,, goes well beyond its bargain-priced abundance. It is a warm, homey throwback, much like the Queens and Brooklyn neighborhood favorites of bygone days. Its traditional patrons want no novello dishes and no surprises on the table or the bill. Familiarity and economy are what they seek and Peppo and Lino's comes through with its family pictures, iron gates, woody walls, market umbrella, antique motorcycle, Neapolitan music, nostalgic aromas and portions that would delight truck drivers or lumberjacks.
Although some of the food here is ordinary, even lackluster, most of the old-fashioned Italian mamma dishes are satisfying. Linguine alla vongole ($11.95) was loaded with tender minced clams; a casserole dish of baked lasagna ($9.95) contained alternating layers of mellow tomato meat sauce and parmesan and fresh mozzarella cheeses; and linguine pescatore ($12.95), a mountain of pasta enveloped in a husky, robust plum tomato sauce, yielded a trove of shrimp, clams, mussels and soft calamari rings. But penne Italian ($10.95), though tasty, was light on meatballs and sausage and heavy on pasta.
Two entrees worth mentioning are gamberi con salmone ($15.95) and grilled pork chops, part of the $12.95 salad, pizza bread, entree, beverage, dessert early-bird steal-of-a-meal. The narrow slab of medium-rare salmon, crowned with three shrimp, came with a dab of mashed potatoes and a melange of crisp green beans, zucchini and carrots, while the medium-size grilled pork chop, buried under a tangle of onions, peppers, portobello mushrooms and sun-dried tomatoes, napped in a hearty, brown Madeira sauce, was cooked slowly rather than being rushed to the table. The result was a tender, juicy piece of meat.
Relatively few restaurants at this modest price level make their own desserts, but Peppo and Lino's does do some, including a light ladyfinger-fringed wedge of tiramisu ($3.95), a decadent chocolate malted mousse-like cake with a rich, dark chocolate icing ($4.95) and Sicilian cookies, two mild-tasting graham cracker cookies ($4.95) beside a drift of fluffy vanilla cream, blueberries and strawberries, but without the promised raspberries. They weren't the only thing missing. The promised pizza bread, in the early bird, also was absent. (It's a large, dense, yeasty roll with a tomato-onion-mozzarella surface).
The waiter probably will have to be told who ordered which dish and at meal's end it might be necessary to flag down a server to get your bill, but Peppo and Lino's serves great gobs of conventional Italian food at rock-bottom prices. So sit back, order a glass ($3.75) or bottle ($16) of wine, relax and enjoy.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property; 
The Rocketing New York Market Levels Off a Bit

BYLINE:  By JOHN HOLUSHA 

 BODY:
IS New York's real estate boom of the last several years drawing to an end? Some real estate executives say they see telltale signs of weakness: a rapid increase in the amount of sublease space coming to market, landlords more willing to negotiate terms of leases, a leveling of rental rates and a softening of sale prices.
 But others say these are just blips in an otherwise healthy situation. Discipline in capital markets, they say, has prevented any tendency to overbuild. As a result, fundamentals, including occupancy rates and rental levels, remain near record levels and continue to support the valuation of properties. 
 "This was the best year for real estate -- ever," said Michael T. Cohen, the president of Williams Real Estate, a brokerage and management company, referring to 2000. "But we can't ignore that the Dow and Nasdaq have taken a beating. It's as if people are waiting for the next market cycle to arrive." 
If the outlook may be a bit clouded because of national economic developments, the commercial real estate industry in the metropolitan area goes into 2001 with a lot of momentum left over from 2000. The few new office buildings going up in Manhattan are spoken for before a shovel is put into the ground, and old industrial leviathans on the island's far west side, like the Starrett-Lehigh Building at 26th Street and the West Side Highway, have become fashionable locations for office tenants.
New office buildings on Jersey City's waterfront fill up quickly as well, drawing Manhattan-based tenants like Chase Manhattan Bank and Goldman Sachs. The waterfront activity is extending north to Hoboken, where SJP Properties is building a 550,000-square-foot structure for the publishers John Wiley & Sons and Matthew Bender and a companion 550,000-square-foot building next to it on speculation.
Retailers continue to flock to the New York area, despite a shortage of prime retail space. According to a survey conducted by the Real Estate Board of New York, ground-floor average annual asking rents range from $122 a square foot on Broadway between Houston and Broome Streets in SoHo to $718 a square foot on 57th Street between Park and Fifth Avenues.
And hotels in the city remain all but full, despite the addition of 11 new hotels with 3,387 rooms during 2000. According to a report by Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm, the occupancy rate last year averaged 85 percent, up from 82.2 percent in 1999. The scramble for rooms by business visitors and tourists allowed hotel operators to increase their rates to an average of $214 a night in 2000, compared with $204.85 the previous year.
However, even the hotel boom seemed to slacken toward the end of the year. The occupancy rate in November was 86.5 percent, compared with 89.8 percent the year earlier, the second consecutive month with a decline from the corresponding month a year earlier, according to PKF Consulting, a hotel market specialist.
In the Manhattan office market, rents seem to be leveling off after rising sharply for most of the year. According to a report prepared by Insignia/ESG, the brokerage and services company, the average asking rent in Midtown increased to $62.40 a square foot from $48.28 a square foot from January to December 2000.
Asking rents in the two other major markets in the city -- Midtown South and Downtown -- followed a similar pattern, with the average for Midtown South increasing to $47.59 from $32.66 a square foot and Downtown rising to $44.70 from $33.63 a square foot.
But by the latter months of the year, the uninterrupted drumbeat of increases seemed to ease off, with the Midtown average of $61.81 a square foot in December, distinctly lower than the $62.85 a square foot recorded in September. But in Midtown South the December average of $48.61 was slightly above the November average of $47.59 a square foot.
"We are seeing a flattening in the growth of rents and a leveling out," said Franklin Speyer, an executive director of Cushman & Wakefield, another large brokerage and services company. "I expect to see rents stabilize at current levels through 2001."
Mr. Speyer said concern about the downward trend of stock prices and a shrinking of start-up technology companies known as dot-coms will exert a dampening effect on landlords' ability to increase rents. But some of those levels will be astonishingly high. "The asking rent in the top 65 buildings we track is $80 a square foot," said Steven A. Swerdlow, executive managing director of CB Richard Ellis, the brokerage and services company.
The problems of the dot-coms, many of which had aggressively leased space in anticipation of rapid growth, are turning up in figures for space that is being offered for sublease, according to Ruth Colp-Haber, a partner in Wharton Property Advisors, a brokerage that represents tenants.
According to figures compiled by her firm, a trickle of sublets coming to market in June -- four new spaces, totaling 37,207 square feet -- turned into a stream by October, when 62 new spaces totaling 1,071,683 square feet hit the market.
"Sublets are a harbinger of things to come," Ms. Colp-Haber said. "The first thing that a company in trouble does is lay off people and sublease the space they were in." She estimated that four million square feet of space was on the market at the end of the year.
Because sublet space is not included with space being offered directly by landlords, she said, published vacancy rates tend to understate the state of the market, particularly for individual properties. For instance, she said, the building at 600 Broadway is listed as fully rented, but in fact has 50 percent of its space available for sublease. Similarly, the building at 1440 Broadway and 40th Street officially has less than 4 percent of its space available. Adding in the sublet space pushes that figure to 12.7 percent.
"The venture capital firms have retrenched their funding of dot-coms, and they are being forced to cut back," Ms. Colp-Haber said. "Six months ago there was almost no sublet space available. Now there is a ton."
With rents flattening, brokers say they are seeing more flexibility on the part of landlords to negotiate leases. They say the landlords are holding firm on the rents themselves but are now more willing to sweeten other parts of the lease package.
"Today, you can negotiate with landlords and get concessions," said Mark S. Weiss, an executive managing director with Julien J. Studley, another tenants' broker. "That was not true nine months ago."
He said landlords are increasingly willing to contribute more to the cost of interior construction when a new tenant moves in. "The rent is the last to change, but there is more willingness to concede on work," he said. Interior building allowances had shrunk from $60 a square foot to $20 a square foot or lower as tenants scrambled to find space. Now they have started to rise as landlords have become more anxious to recruit tenants with strong credit.
"Now, instead of $20 a foot, we can get $35 a square foot," Mr. Weiss said. "In one case we got $40 a square foot. The market is still hot, but it's not red hot, white hot anymore."
Barry Gosin, vice chairman and chief executive of Newmark & Company real Estate, a brokerage and management company, said: "Landlords are a little more attentive, a little more cooperative. They understand the value of a good tenant. They want someone who is going to be there for 10 or 15 years rather than a technology tenant that may be gone tomorrow."
Mr. Gosin said that "the froth is off the market" but that there is still strong demand for space and little new construction. "There was zero building between 1990 and 1999, and that makes a difference," he said.
He added that he did not expect to see softness of the sort that occurred the last time the real estate market turned down, in the late 1980's. "New York is a different place today -- people want to be here," he said. "There would have to be a significant amount of layoffs to have an impact."
The leveling off of the growth in rents may have an impact on the sale price of properties, including trophies like Rockefeller Center, which recently was sold, and the World Trade Center which is still on the market.
"We are seeing the first sign of an erosion in prices," said Peter Hauspurg, the chairman of Eastern Consolidates Properties, a sales broker. "I can smell it in the last month." He said buyers were less willing to pay the prices being demanded by owners.
"During 1999, the expectations of both buyers and sellers were rising," he said. "Now the expectations of the buyers have turned down, while the sellers are still up. The result is a stillness in the investment sales market."
And what a market it is. Mr. Hauspurg cited figures given by Prudential at a conference on real estate investment trusts a few years ago showing that one-sixth of all commercial property value in the entire United States is in Manhattan. "The figures were that there is $2.7 trillion in commercial value in the nation, with $650 billion in the tri-state area and $450 billion in Manhattan," he said.
Nevertheless, prices might be softening a bit. Anthony E. Malkin, the president of W&M properties, an investment and management group, noted that the general expectation when Rockefeller Center was offered for sale last year was that the price would be somewhere between $2 billion and $2.5 billion. Later, he said, expectations dropped to a range of $1.8 billion to $2 billion.
And, indeed, when center was sold at year-end, the price was near the low end of the estimated range: $1.85 billion.
"There are two categories of players in this market: those who have to sell and those who don't," Mr. Malkin said. He said many of the opportunity funds that invested in property while prices were still low have to sell in a relatively short term to reach their promised rate of return on capital.
Some buildings have sold for unusually high prices on a square foot basis, noted a survey conducted for PricewaterhouseCoopers, the accounting and consulting firm. The building at 1301 Avenue of the Americas at 53rd Street sold to Equity Office Properties, a real estate investment trust, for $420 a square foot. The Seagram Building on Park Avenue and 52nd Street sold by Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association to RFR Holding for what the report called "a startling" $560 a square foot. Real estate executives noted that three-quarters of the leases in the Seagram Building would expire within the next five years, giving the new owner the opportunity to push rates up to current market levels.
But those may be the high points, the report said. "Although it is no surprise that investors are willing to pay top dollar for real estate in a market characterized by all-time low vacancy rates and all-time high rental rates," the report said, "some investors speculate that the recent surge of properties put up for sale signifies that this market has peaked."
But even if prices have peaked, there are not a lot of bargains to be snapped up, some executives warn. "There may not be 10 to 12 bidders for each property, but there are still six to eight," said Kevin F. Haggarty, an executive managing director of Insignia/ESG. He said that with rents close to $80 a foot and with a 2 percent vacancy in prime office buildings, prices are firm. "One of the roles I play is in managing buyers' expectations," he said.
Benjamin V. Lambert, the chairman of Eastdil Realty, a sales and financing company, said, "We may see market activity slow, but I don't see a big change in pricing." 
In Hoboken, the market is strong enough to warrant building the second phase of the Waterfront Corporate Center on speculation, according to Steven J. Pozycki, the president of SJP Properties. "We know the economy is slowing somewhat, but we believe this location and the amenities will attract a tenant needing 150,000 square feet of space or more," he said. He said the two buildings would be delivered sequentially, with the first, to be occupied by the Wiley and Bender publishing houses, coming to market in the first quarter of 2002 and the second six months later.
Following are highlights of important segments of the real-estate scene in New York:

Capital Markets
Lenders' Discipline Restrains Builders
Ultimately, many executives say, the state of the capital markets will determine the prices paid for properties, because the availability and the price of capital are factors in almost all transactions.
Discipline in capital markets is what distinguishes the current period from earlier times, when a flood of money for construction led to overbuilding and a sharp decline in rental rates, said John Lyons, the president of Granite Partners, a financing company.
"Lenders will not lend on a project without 50 percent preleasing," he said. "As such, we are not seeing the overbuilding that we saw in previous cycles."
Because of this, he said, even if there is a downturn, it is likely to be smaller in depth and shorter in time.
Even though most real estate loans are made on a one-on-one basis between a lender and a developer, securities markets, such as the one for commercial mortgage-backed securities, influence the terms and conditions of the transactions, Mr. Lyons said. This is because if an institution wants to sell a loan in public markets, it must meet the underwriting standards set by those markets. 
Even if capital markets are influencing the terms of deals, they are providing plenty of money to fuel transactions, said Howard L. Michaels, chairman of the Carlton Group, which arranges financing and property sales. "We have been doing $1 billion in financing every 60 to 90 days," he said. "We have not seen any signs of a slowdown, despite talk of a slowdown."
The power of the capital markets ensures that there has been little "dumb money" available for development, said Dale Anne Reiss, practice manager for E&Y Kenneth Leventhal, an accounting and consulting firm. "Developers are like junkies and money is their drug," she said, "but the markets were incredibly disciplined."

Retail Space
Rents Ease a Bit On the Ground Floor
The possibility that e-commerce would replace shopping in stores faded during 2000, according to brokers specializing in retail real estate. "Bricks and mortar are stronger then ever," said Benjamin Fox, an executive vice president of Newmark New Spectrum Realty Services. "New Yorkers like to get out and shop."
He said the rise in rental rates for office space had actually helped retailers because landlords do not have to squeeze the last dollar out of their ground-floor space to make the economics of their properties work.
"We are starting to see some moderation in rents because owners-developers are doing so well upstairs that they don't need top dollar downstairs," he said. "This allows them to select the right tenants, which is important, because the ground-floor tenant is a big part of the identity of a building."
Because estimates of retail rents had varied widely in the past, the Real Estate Board of New York for the first time conducted a survey, released during the fall, using 12 brokerage companies. Not surprisingly the rents varied widely with location, with Fifth Avenue between 50th and 59th the most expensive in the city.
The stores along that stretch tend to be large, from 1,049 square feet to 11,541 square feet, with rents ranging from a low of $550 a square foot to an eye-popping $1,100 a square foot. The median was $615 a square foot.
In the rapidly developing SoHo retail region, in stores along Broadway from Houston to Broome Streets, rentals are distinctly more modest, ranging from $75 to $225 a square foot.
"A lot of French and English stores are moving here and many are going to SoHo," said Faith H. Consolo, vice chairman of Garrick-Aug, another retail specialist. One that did not was Fauchon, a French fine-foods store that opened in 5,000 square feet of space in the Hotel Drake at 56th Street and Park Avenue, a neighborhood where retail rents range from $250 to $300 a square foot.

Hotels
A Tourist Boom That Has Not Quit
Occupancy rates remained high as an influx of visitors easily filled the few thousand new rooms to open during the year. This has prompted a flurry of activity by developers seeking to get in on the city's seemingly unending tourist boom.
"Lots of people are coming to us with small, niche proposals," said Sean Hennessey, director of PricewaterhouseCooper's New York hospitality practice. He said some of them were for the conversion of office buildings to hotels and some for new construction. Given the scarcity of building sites in Manhattan, most of the proposals are for hotels with 100 to 200 rooms.
"Hotels of this size are not usually economical, but with rates this high they can work," Mr. Hennessey said. He said hotels unaffiliated with any of the national chains have a good chance of succeeding in New York because of the desire of some travelers to express their lifestyle by choosing a small, quirky hotel, like the Library, at 41st Street and Madison Avenue, where the floors are marked according to the Dewey Decimal System and rates are about $350 a night. 
"These hotels," he said, "differentiate themselves not by the usual things such as room size, but by how hip you are."

HEADLINE: JERSEY; 
No-Count Guests at a Census Bash

BYLINE:  By NEIL GENZLINGER

 BODY:
THE Attack of the Number Crunchers has begun, but don't worry. Even those of you who are intimidated by statistics -- which is to say, virtually all of you -- can survive it, using the simple system delineated here.
 The crunch in question is the data from the 2000 census. The first batch, the total head count for New Jersey and the rest of the country, was released last week with great fanfare. (For the record, the numbers showed that New Jersey grew 8.9 percent in the last decade, which in layman's terms means that if you weighed 150 pounds in 1990, you weigh 163 pounds today.) More data will be parceled out as the year progresses -- about what color we are, how much money we make, what we do for a living -- until eventually we know almost as much about ourselves as we know about Madonna's sex life. 
 The problem is, this information will be delivered primarily by bureaucrats and professors and will thus be full of technical terms like "percentage" and "congressional reapportionment," making it as incomprehensible as it is boring. That is why I spent almost an entire coffee break developing a simple method for dealing with the avalanche of figures headed our way. I call it the Party of 10 System(R). If you prefer, you can call it the Idea I Stole From One of Those Chain E-Mail Letters.
It works like this: Imagine that there are 10 guests at a party and that the guests perfectly represent the demographics of New Jersey. So, starting with the obvious, five would be male, five female. Every time new census statistics come your way, your mental picture of the guests can get more detailed. For instance, the next data might tell us that six of the guests are New Jersey natives (that's what the 1990 census showed) or that all but two are white (again, 1990).
The chain e-mail that inspired the Party of 10 System(R) used a similar gimmick to describe the world's population, except with a base of 100 and a heavy dose of moralizing. ("Seventy of the people would be nonwhite, 30 would be white; 89 would be heterosexual, 11 would be homosexual; 6 would possess 59 percent of the entire world's wealth, and all 6 would be from the United States.") The intent seemed to be to make recipients pause and think, and it certainly worked. Mostly what I paused and thought was that I should stop reading irksome chain e-mails.
Anyway, one beauty of the Party of 10 System(R) is that it lets you make quick, clear comparisons across decades or even centuries, without having to account for inflation, leap years, etc. This can dramatically underscore important social trends.
For instance, history books suggest that had our imaginary party convened back in 1820, only one of the 10 guests would have been able to read. Had our party convened three weeks ago, however, virtually all of the guests would have been able to read, yet not a single one would have heard of Donald DiWhatshisname, the guy who's going to be our governor for the next year.
Similarly, in 1990 the party of 10 would have included 3 people under the age of 21. A century ago, in contrast, 4 of the guests would have been children but, remarkably, none would have been named Britney, Britany or Brittanie.
I've taken the liberty of developing some Party of 10(R) projections using 1990 figures, interviews with experts and impressions I've developed by eavesdropping on people at the supermarket. The full census figures, when released, will almost surely show these things about the 10 party guests:
* Six will be in the work force. Four of those will drive to work alone; none will feel guilty about it.
* Three will have at least some college education; none will understand how this whole electricity-deregulation thing works.
* Eight will be "somewhat concerned" or "very concerned" about global warming. Nine will think it's been "too danged cold" this winter.
* One will have been born in a foreign country. Seven will live in the same houses they lived in five years ago. Nine will experience occasional wanderlust but will not act on it because going to Newark Airport scares them.
* One will have been the victim of a crime in the last year. Eight will have turned up at that casting call last summer for bit parts in "The Sopranos."
* Six will attend some form of religious service at least occasionally, but all 10 will agree with this, from Horace: "We are just statistics, born to consume resources."

HEADLINE: ROAD AND RAIL; 
On a Slow Train To Fast Times

BYLINE:  By BILL KENT

 BODY:
For William Shelby, who has been punching tickets on New Jersey Transit's Atlantic City rail service between Philadelphia and Atlantic City since it began in 1989, the daily mix of poker-playing gamblers, casino employees, commuters, conventioneers and college students, "is a community that's always celebrating something -- weddings, birthdays, raises on the job. We all know each other and, believe me, these people would be devastated if the service was to stop." 
 The line remains New Jersey Transit's most expensive and least used rail service. But there is no plan to stop service. 
 Though New Jersey Transit's executive director, Jeffrey Warsh, said he had no intentions of raising ticket prices, reducing operations or otherwise "walking away" from the operation, he admits that the average daily ridership of 1,300 riders is "much lower than we'd like to see." 
Except for morning and evening rushes, when trains are mostly full, runs are typically half occupied or less. On a given day, half of the train's passengers are casino employees, a third are gamblers or regional visitors, with the rest being New Jersey residents who work or attend college in Philadelphia. Ridership is heaviest on summer weekends, during morning and evening rush hours, and also during major Atlantic City conventions and trade shows. 
Originally intended to relieve automobile congestion in Atlantic City, act as an economic generator within Camden and Atlantic Counties and provide access to Amtrak trains at 30th Street Station in Philadelphia, the Atlantic City railroad service was set up in 1989 with $108 million in federal and state funds. For the next five years, Amtrak provided so-called Gamblers Express trains nonstop between Philadelphia and Atlantic City, with New Jersey Transit operating a slower commuter service. 
Amtrak discontinued its Atlantic City service in 1994, citing low ridership. New Jersey Transit increased its schedule from 17 to 28 daily trips. Those trips come with a cost. For every passenger who paid the $6 one-way full fare, New Jersey Transit spent an additional $10 -- more than three times what the agency spends on northern and central New Jersey commuter rail lines. 
Ridership has remained low, Mr. Warsh said, because of a number of factors. He cited residential development near the tracks in Camden County, which requires the train to slow down to reduce noise. Add time for stops at Cherry Hill, the Lindenwold Hi-Speed Line station, Atco, Hammonton, Egg Harbor City and Absecon, and the one-way trip takes about 95 minutes, 10 minutes longer than New Jersey Transit buses on roads parallel to the tracks. 
Then, in Atlantic City, the railroad terminus is in the city's Convention Center, nearly a half-mile west of the nearest casino. Train passengers can either pay to take taxis or use their tickets to get a free ride on an Atlantic City jitney, but city traffic regulations forbid jitneys from picking up or discharging passengers directly in front of casino hotel entrances, so in addition to changing vehicles, they have to walk a few extra yards to the casino door. 
Even when summer shore traffic can back traffic up for several miles along the Atlantic City Expressway, "most of our customers just don't find the train an acceptable form of transportation," said Tim Wilmott, an executive who oversees the Harrah's and Showboat casinos in Atlantic City and is also president of the New Jersey Casino Association, the gambling industry's lobbying group. 
"They prefer to drive in their car and park in a garage and not be dictated by a schedule," he said. "Back in the 90's we tried marketing to the train, offering some of the incentives similar to bus programs, and we got nowhere." 
Less than 10 percent of the casino industry's 45,000 employees take any kind of public transportation, according to New Jersey Transit. Gene Clark, Senior Vice President of Human Resources for Park Place Entertainment, said most casino employees drove to work and parked in lots on the Atlantic City Expressway, catching shuttle buses that take them directly to their jobs. 
As many as 300 Park Place employees have applied for vouchers that pay a portion of their public transportation costs, Mr. Clark said, but use them mainly on buses.
"Few of them use the train on a regular basis," Mr. Clark said. "The trains run every hour and a half, but the buses run more frequently. Miss the bus and you're only out a few minutes. But if you miss the train, you're down a lot of time." 
The train is also inconvenient for employees who don't live near stations. "We have a lot of employees who live some distances north and south of Atlantic City, and the train runs east to west," Mr. Clark said.
Passengers who park their cars at New Jersey Transit station stops have complained of break-ins and vandalism to their vehicles. Mr. Warsh said that New Jersey Transit had increased police patrols of the station parking areas. 
He pointed to a 1995 study that showed that train passengers who worked or vacationed in Atlantic City and neighboring shore resort towns generated $6.3 million each year in state tax revenues. That study was done at a time when as many as five new casino hotels, adding as many as 15,000 new jobs, were planned to be open for business by the year 2001. Had they opened as scheduled, passengers on Atlantic City trains would have doubled, he said. 
So far, only one of those projects has broken ground, the $1 billion, 2,010-room Boyd Borgata, due to open in 2003.
Mr. Warsh said three additional projects will increase ridership within the next decade: a $30 million residential and office development adjacent to the train's Cherry Hill Station, a transportation center for Galloway Township and a southern spur of the train line from Winslow Junction to shore towns in Cape May County. 
Until then, Mr. Shelby, the conductor, enjoys reminiscing with some of his older passengers, who "remember when taking the Blue Comet train out of Grand Central Station to Atlantic City was the height of luxury, first class all the way. We're no Blue Comet, but for the families who ride with us ride in the summer for a day at the beach, we do just fine."

GRAPHIC: Photo: The 95-minute run from Philadelphia ends at the terminal in Atlantic City, shown here, a half-mile from the nearest casino. (Gregg Kohl for The New York Times)
