HEADLINE: DEVELOPMENT; 
How Their Garden Grows

BYLINE:  By JILL P. CAPUZZO

DATELINE: PLAINSBORO 

 BODY:
The landscape between bustling Route 1 and the Delaware and Raritan Canal is deceptively placid, the horizontal interrupted only by evenly spaced, soldier-straight rows of trees meant to block the wind, or the occasional lone tree or shrub. This was once the renowned Princeton Nurseries. What is growing there now is dissension.
 With a portion of this land set to be bulldozed to make way for 220 luxury apartments, this is a classic battle between developer and community. But in this case the developer is Princeton Forrestal Center, the for-profit arm of Princeton University. Princeton Forrestal has been credited with both helping to create the state's leading high-tech corridor and with systematically consuming the bucolic setting, albeit with tasteful structures. 
 Many make no distinction between the university and its corporate entity.
"Wouldn't it be nice if Princeton University, one of the wealthiest universities in America, donated the property to be a park to be used by thousands of people in the area?" asked Susan Smiley, who lives in Princeton Landing, one of Princeton Forrestal's first developments, and walks along the canal towpath each day.
A public park, or an arboretum, as some have suggested, appeared unlikely for the site after Plainsboro Planning Board last month approved Princeton Forrestal's proposal for the Villas of Tuscany, 18 buildings of clustered apartments at Mapleton and Seminary Roads. Included in the plan was one major concession to the public park concept -- that the 30 acres of land abutting the Delaware and Raritan Canal would be forever preserved as open land. 
Some opponents said that the protected land lies in a flood plain and that the developers had no choice but to preserve it.
David Knights, marketing director of Princeton Forrestal Center, said that some of the land along the canal was suitable for building but that Princeton University's president, Harold Shapiro, made a commitment in 1988 to preserve the entire 101 acres of land running along the canal as long as development rights were transferred to the east side of Mapleton Road. That commitment followed a furor over Forrestal's 1987 attempt to develop the Princeton Nurseries land with 1,050 homes, some which would be built close to the canal. Public outcry plus a downturn in the economy led Princeton Forrestal to table all development plans at the nursery for the next decade. 
Princeton University bought Princeton Nurseries in 1986, when the family that owned it sold the land to pay off estate taxes following the death of one of the brothers that operated it. The nursery moved its base to Allentown. The 488-acre site was the last major tract of land acquired by Princeton Forrestal, which since the 1950's has purchased a total of 2,200 acres, all in Plainsboro and South Brunswick. From the mid-70's through the 90's, Forrestal land has been developed for retail, office, research and residential space, but the nursery property has remained largely untouched. 
With the apartment project ready to go, the next phase of development at the nursery site calls for a two-million-square-foot office building, also in the Plainsboro part of the tract. Princeton Forrestal has zoning approval from Plainsboro for the building but is "not working on a plan" at the moment, according to Mr. Knights. This plan has the community fuming over its potential to bring thousands of cars daily to the already bottlenecked roads in the area.
"The amount of nonresidential building they want to put on this property is insensitive to the characteristics of this neighborhood," said Karen Linder, a resident of Kingston. "There's no plan for the traffic impact on Kingston. They need to stop temporarily and do some regional planning." 
While acknowledging that Kingston has a traffic problem, Mr. Knights said Princeton had been planning for three years for the anticipated development, investing heavily with such additions as the $20 million Route 1 overpass at College Road, $1 million in new sewer lines, and a reconfiguration of Mapleton Road to redirect traffic. 
Opponents point fingers at Plainsboro officials as much as at Princeton Forrestal for allowing development to proceed with what they view as little regard for the environment or the community.
"Princeton University owns a huge amount of land in Plainsboro," said Charlie Dieterich, co-chairman of Friends of Princeton Nursery Lands, a group formed to save the nursery. "Plainsboro needed business ratables, Princeton U. needed income for endowments, and the two just made a very favorable deal." Mr. Dieterich's group has been more successful with the 200 acres of Princeton Nurseries property in South Brunswick, where township officials are now negotiating to buy portions of the land for preservation.
Plainsboro's mayor for 21 of the last 27 years, Peter Cantu, said his township had a record of preserving open space, including the 30 acres of undeveloped land that are tied to this project.
"This application has its roots in zoning approvals that go back to the mid-80's," Mr. Cantu said. "The presentation that was put before us provided the planning board with no basis to reject the application." 
Before the apartments can be built, the developers first must remove and contain soil contaminated with the pesticide dieldrin. The project also needs final approval by the Delaware and Raritan Canal Commission, since the road work falls within 1,000 feet of the canal. Princeton Forrestal says it expects neither step to block the project.
Much of the negative response stems from an emotional bond that residents have with Princeton Nurseries, once the nation's largest wholesale nursery. Started in 1913, the operation introduced more shrub and tree species to the United States than any other nursery in the country. Species like the October Glory red maple, the Snow Queen hydrangea and the Princeton Century gingko, while abundant throughout the country, are now sparse on the grounds where they were first cultivated. 
The most notable trees standing today are the windrows of 30-foot-tall arborvitae, which William Flemer planted after returning from duty in Europe during World War I. The windrows will not be affected by the proposed apartment complex but the same cannot be said of the office building. Mr. Knights said Princeton Forrestal would be sensitive to residents' attachments to the windrows, which he called "gorgeous," but said that the nursery "is not an historic site in any way, shape or form. There are magnificent vistas, and they are all being preserved." 
William Flemer III, who lives in a 1742 house on the canal side of the property that will be protected, said it made him "very sad" to think about the pending buildings across the street but that he recognized Princeton's right to develop the land it purchased. 
"I wish we were still running it, and I wish we didn't have to sell it," said Mr. Flemer. "We had a number of potential buyers at the time and it seemed the university was the best, that they would have more regard for the environment and not try to cram every building on every acre. They bought it as an investment and they have the right to capitalize on that investment. I can't condemn them for that."

HEADLINE: Growing Pains For State Plan 

BYLINE:  By JOHN SULLIVAN

DATELINE: CAPE MAY COURT HOUSE 

 BODY:
SQUEEZING a sheaf of paper into a crumpled cone in his fist, William Juliano pleaded with a group of state planners in the Cape May County administrative building.
 "It is a nightmare," he said. 
 Mr. Juliano, the new owner of an aging office building at the intersection of Routes 9 and 47 in Middle Township, was anxious to learn whether his project was about to go up in smoke. He had bought the property in October, intending to build stores there. The town had encouraged the plan as part of an effort to revitalize the street corner, once the site of the Cape May County social services department. 
That was before he learned that a state official in Trenton had carefully drawn a new line on a map laying out the state's master plan, establishing boundaries between development and preservation in sensitive areas of New Jersey. Confused about whether his project would thrive or die under the change, Mr. Juliano went looking for guidance at a public hearing on the state development plan, held last month in Cape May. Where the map was shaded would make or break his building's future: whether it was in the bright white star of the town development center or in the pale green of an environmentally sensitive zone. 
Contending that he would never have agreed to the project if he knew the rules could change so suddenly, he said, "I would have walked away," 
As a longtime developer, Mr. Juliano has had his share of battles with state regulators. But this was something new for Mr. Juliano and for state officials as well: a project caught in the jaws of a suddenly powerful state plan.
The plan itself isn't new. Legislation to create the state plan was proposed in 1985, and the original version was adopted in 1992. On one level, the plan has never had any legal teeth. By itself, it cannot block any development. But it can influence the state regulators who grant development permits, particularly in environmentally sensitive areas. 
What's different is that under directionfrom Governor Whitman, state agencies have begun to use the plan to guide their regulations and spending. Whether granting sewer permits along the shore or widening a two-lane intersection to three lanes, state regulators are now expected to check whether their decisions conform to the plan. 
"It is a very significant alteration in the way New Jersey governs itself, the way the economy operates and the way it shelters its citizens," said Patrick O'Keefe, chief executive of the New Jersey Builders Association. 
The builders' association, a powerful lobbying group, supported the original 1985 legislation. But it is now bitterly opposed to the plan and its proposed expansion, including its extension to coastal development regulations last year.
The issue, Mr. O'Keefe said, is that the plan is supposed to be a guideline for local government, not a state mandate. Many local officials oppose the plan for the same reason. 
"One of the great misunderstandings about the plan is the contention by the planners that it is voluntary, even as they selectively mandate adherence to it through various state agencies," Mr. O'Keefe said.
Environmental groups and planning advocates, on the other hand, say that it's about time the state put teeth into the plan.
"For people in New Jersey who are fed up with overdevelopment and sprawl, the state plan has been a symbol of hope," said Jeff Tittel, state director of the New Jersey Sierra Club. "But after 10 years, it has not delivered anything."
EVEN as people debate whether the plan -- officially the New Jersey State Development and Redevelopment Plan -- is too strict or not strict enough, the state is moving toward introducing its second incarnation, expected to be approved by the planning commission sometime next month.
"The teeth in the act has always been that state government will spend money and establish regulations in support of the plan," said Barbara Lawrence, executive director of the statewide planning group New Jersey Future. "It is not just supposed to be a book on a shelf."'
One place where the plan has clearly not remained on the shelf is Red Bank. The central town of the wealthy peninsula section of Monmouth County, Red Bank had slumped into hard times in the 1980's. Its central street, once a classic New Jersey downtown of shops and diners, was lined with vacant buildings, liquor stores and a few struggling businesses. The population had plummeted to 9,000 from a high of 15,000; each year, more lights went dark along Broad Street.
But in the early 1990's, with a change in town government, Red Bank's leaders decided to take an aggressive role in developing the downtown.
"We took some old buildings, a school building, and we got federal and state money and we rehabbed them as housing," said Mayor Edward McKenna. "We took some liquor licenses and retired them. We turned a problem corner with a fast-food restaurant into a mini-park."
The town, once called Dead Bank, is now a shining example for state planners, the town they cite to convince people of the success of controlled development. Since the town began to change its zoning, its taxing and its planning seven years ago, business has returned to Broad Street.
In the week before Christmas, the streets were crowded, the brick and stone buildings open and polished. Along two blocks, the Bon Ton clothing store rubs shoulders with Garney Men's Shop and Solomon Smith Barney. The Buy Lo Liquor store has been replaced with the Grill and Grape cafe. For Mayor McKenna, a drive through town is a chance to relive municipal planning triumphs.
"We tried to follow the state plan," he said. "It encourages development in an area like ours by encouraging rehabilitation and not sprawling out into neighboring farms."
At the core of the state plan, since it was adopted in 1992, is the belief that New Jersey needs to strengthen its cities and its town centers -- a strategy called "Fix it First" by highway engineers or "Smart Growth" by urban planners. 
"The genesis was the great office building boom of the 1980's, and the suburban growth corridors along major highways," said James Hughes, dean of the Bloustein School of Government at Rutgers. "Eighty percent of the office space ever built in the state went up between 1980 and 1990, and most of it went up along the corridors: Route 1, Route 287, Route 80."
As people moved closer to their new jobs, they looked for convenient places to live and to shop. Residential development followed.
"That caused tremendous spillover into the adjacent formerly rural areas," Dr. Hughes said. "It generated ru-burbia, the hybrid form of suburbia and rural that we see spreading out to the western part of the state."
With the new development came what has since become a familiar litany of complaints -- logjam traffic, environmental problems, shrinking forests and fields. By the late 1990's, New Jersey had become the first state to face the possibility of total development. Within 30 years, every available plot of land could be occupied.
In her 1998 inaugural address, Governor Whitman called on the state to increase planning and preserve open space. In later speeches, she referred to the state plan as "the backbone of decision making" for state and local government, ordering major regulatory agencies to follow the plan when issuing permits or awarding grants.
In the meantime, state planners spent the span between 1992 and 1999 meeting with county and municipal leaders and trying to reach a consensus on a revised version of the plan. The product of those discussions, now subject to public hearings, is expected to be formally adopted by the planning commission next month.
For the most part, the updated plan is the same as the 1992 version, with the major theme of concentration of development and the rebuilding of cities and older suburbs. State planners expect New Jersey to hold another 900,000 people by the year 2020, and they hope the development needed to house and employ the new residents will lie in cities and older suburbs.
"It is not about blocking growth in rural areas, it is about concentrating it," said Herb Simmens, executive director of the New Jersey Planning Commission.
Mr. Simmens said the choice was stark: New Jersey can continue to spread until it runs out of land, throwing up houses on acre-sized lots and office parks on farmland. Or municipalities can try to organize development into town centers.
"One scenario is to grow by 10,000 people on 5,000 acres and another is to grow by 10,000 people on 1,000 acres," he said.
In theory, it is a simple choice -- less sprawl means less traffic, less environmental damage. But opponents of the plan say translating the theory into practice will be much harder than planners predict.
Mr. O'Keefe of the builders association said it was simpler and far more profitable to build on vacant farmland than on an old industrial site in an inner city. "Where the private sector believes there is a market, development will occur," Mr. O'Keefe said. 
If the state wants to encourage building in the inner cities and old suburbs, he said, it will have to come up with money to address a range of expensive problems: bad schools, high property taxes, crime, pollution and sagging infrastructure. 
"All those issues are the public sector's responsibility, and as long as the state government turns its back on the urban areas, the ability of the private sector will be limited," Mr. O'Keefe said.
The fate of New Jersey's cities in the 1990's was mixed. While Hoboken and Jersey City have boomed along with Manhattan's red-hot real estate market, other cities like Trenton and Camden have not done as well. Newark, the state's largest city, has seen more development than any time since before the riots of the late 1960's. Home ownership in Newark, while still below the state average of 64.5 percent, has risen to 26 percent last year from 14 percent in 1986, and office space has filled as new businesses locate downtown.
Newark's Mayor, Sharpe James, attributes the growth to a strategy of attracting the commercial development with a sales pitch for the city's existing transportation system and building infrastructure. 
The New Jersey Performing Arts Center is a prime example. By building the center in downtown Newark, the state drew spending customers into the city. Mayor James said the proposal to build a sports arena in Newark would serve the same purpose.
"We need to create the economic engine to turn the growth that was earmarked for the suburbs to the inner cities," he said.
Mayor Jim McGreevey of Woodbridge, who is expected to be a Democratic gubernatorial candidate this year, advocates strong coordination between environmental and economic planners.
But for urban areas, he said, planning alone is not enough. The state needs to recognize that taxpayers will have to subsidize some city improvements -- through payments for industrial cleanup or job training -- if urban areas are to accept a large portion of growth.
"If planning is to work, it must be in concert with basic economic principles," he said. "In New Jersey, it will always be less expensive to pave over farmland than to remediate a former industrial site in an urban center."
That conclusion is clearly demonstrated in Ocean County, one of the battlegrounds of suburban development. Once an area of open fields and summertime shore towns, Ocean County is quickly filling with offices and subdivisions. At quitting time, cars spill out of the offices and stores clustered along Route 9, creating traffic jams in spots like the intersection of Route 37 and Hooper Avenue in Jackson Township.
Under the state plan, areas like Ocean County are generally planned for slow growth, with development mainly confined to town centers. In the long run this worries people like Leonard Connors, the mayor of Surf City and a Republican state senator.
Senator Connors said the plan ignored the fact that Ocean County had already developed far beyond its means, with overtaxed roads, schools and public facilities. He said decades of sewer extensions and lax development regulations "gave us the gun to blow our brains out." But it is impossible to turn back the clock, he said, and the state needs to continue to invest in the area. 
"I am all for preserving land, I am all for stopping sprawl, I am all for the environment," he said. "But I do not think the cost should be borne by one group of individuals. Stopping sprawl is a shared responsibility, shared by all people."
Eileen McGinnis, the governor's policy director, said the state must establish guidelines for future growth, and that drawing the lines would never be easy.
"You need to have a rational way, based in law, that allows the state to say this development should occur or should not occur," she said.
Unlike the cities, where the fights are over money, in suburban and rural areas the battle over the state plan primarily involves environmental regulation. Last year, developers and environmentalists fought over state coastal regulations, which determine what can be developed in areas like Ocean County; although the governor modified the regulations somewhat, she kept the state plan guidelines in the coastal rules.
The next battle is expected to involve water and sewer regulations, which govern where new building can occur throughout New Jersey. For much of last year, legislators argued over the rules as developers and planning advocates lined up support on each side. The Legislature opposed the governor's proposal, which relied heavily on the state plan. The Assembly voted to overturn the proposed regulation, and a Senate committee recommended similar action.
Senator Donald T. DiFrancesco, the Senate president, said he expected to pass compromise legislation within the next few months. Mr. DiFrancesco, who is in line to replace Governor Whitman when she takes over as director of the federal Environmental Protection Agency, said the state plan was a "good blueprint" for development.
But he said the plan was viewed by too many municipalities as a threat to local government, which has a long tradition of independence in New Jersey. He said the state should devote more effort to forging a consensus with local governments, rather than forcing them to adhere to the plan.
"There have always been a lot of misconceptions about the state plan, and fears about it," he said. "They have to be convinced and shown how it is going to positively impact their communities.'
Joseph Mariziti, chairman of the state planning commission, echoed the importance of consensus, but he said time was running out as parcels of land continue to be swallowed up.
"There is a sense of urgency," he said. "This generation of New Jerseyans has the last opportunity to effectively plan the growth of this state."
THE alternative is to be swept along on the tide of development. That is largely what happened in West Windsor, a town at the center of the 1990 development boom. Once a bedroom community on New Jersey Transit's northeast corridor, West Windsor saw building after building spring up along Route 1, followed by large housing developments.
Mayor Carole Carson said the town had adapted, buying much of the remaining farmland and leasing it to tenant farmers. Still, the growth has strained resources, crowding the high school and stretching police and fire protection.
The town is about to lose its last battle, she said, with the Toll Brothers company, one of the largest builders in the state. After six years of clashes in court, she said, it was almost inevitable that the company will "begin moving dirt" sometime this spring for a housing project just off Route 1. Right now the area is marshy woodland, a wide expanse of small trees and tangled brush. Toll plans to cover much of the area with new single-family houses, plus apartments and town houses.
The company says that although the town does not want the project, it is exactly in line with the state plan's goal of concentrating development near public transportation.
"We are immediately adjacent to the rail system and the Princeton Junction train station," said Wayne Patterson, a senior vice president for Toll. "It is logical for growth and it is planned in the state master plan."
Throughout New Jersey, Mr. Patterson said, "There is a tremendous need for housing. You can't just shut everything down."
That is what Mr. Juliano believed. Although he had battled state regulators over other projects, he did not anticipate any problems with the office building in Middle Township. In fact, as he told planners at the meeting in Cape May Courthouse, he had bought the building with the cooperation of town officials.
"I had the consensus of the town and the Cape May freeholders," he said after the hearing. "They said they wanted the area developed because it was an eyesore."
Only after buying the building in October did he learn that the state planners had adjusted their maps. Any changes could be critical, affecting a variety of permits needed for construction of a large commercial development.
"I couldn't sleep at night," Mr. Juliano said. "I don't want a conflict between the township and the planning commission with me in the middle."
After the meeting, environmental regulators agreed to review detailed maps to determine the status of Mr. Juliano's project. It turned out that he need not have worried after all. The line between development and preservation was on the other side of the street.

HEADLINE: COPING; 
I Lost It at the Movies

BYLINE:  By PETER MARKS

 BODY:
IT was such a little request.
 "Please, sir, I want a small coffee" (or something equally obsequious), I said to the man behind the refreshment counter at the 25-screen multiplex on 42nd Street. 
 It wasn't much to ask, considering how desperately I needed fortification. The task at hand had been escorting my 8-year-old, Lizzie, to "102 Dalmatians," a grim, clattering Disney sequel whose voluminous defects made no impression on my daughter, a canine lover so dyed in the fur she would sooner eat Brussels sprouts than accept that a dog story could go wrong on celluloid. 
The counter man produced a bottle of water to bring back to Lizzie (cost: $3!), but my small cup of java did not materialize. After some rummaging, the clerk explained that he was out of small cups. Behind him loomed a tower of "large" cups; actually, this being the concession stand of a modern movie theater, they were more in the bucket family. I checked out the price of a large. It was roughly the same as a share of a tech stock I was considering. So I suggested a compromise: pour my small coffee into one of the big cups. 
I might as well have been offering him a deal on land in Florida. The clerk's brow furrowed, his jaw clenched. He motioned to his boss, who strode over with confidence and authority. Ah, a man in charge. I sensed a ruling coming in my favor.
"Nope," the manager said, with out-of-the-question finality.
"Why?" I asked incredulously, singing the word in that characteristic New York vocal style: the high-pitched whine.
His reply came in the relaxed rhythms of a man who knew how to say everything and nothing all at once: "It's an inventory issue." 
An inventory issue. I slunk away with the overpriced bottle of water, struck by the compounding absurdity of the manager's explanation and my outsize pique at having to return, undercaffeinated, to the spectacle of Glenn Close being baked into a cake by a pack of puppies.
I've watched countless times as ticket holders in the newfangled vertical movie houses of New York treated their stubs as all-day passes, sneaking into second features with impunity. Employees often seemed to look the other way. Yet they continue to maintain iron-fisted fiscal control over economy-size coffee cups?
Something, it seemed to me, was out of whack. The combination of the dreary movie, the staff's intransigence and the exorbitant prices left me morose. Moviegoing was supposed to be about escape; I felt the need for an escape from the escape. Once, it was just bathroom lines and the woman in the row in front of you with the hairdo modeled after the World Trade Center. Now, there were inventory issues.
Was I the only person who felt the effort was less and less worth it, that a surliness was encroaching everywhere? It's no longer possible, for instance, to shush talkers in a theater. They double the volume when you politely ask them to lower it.
During "Gladiator," a woman decided I was her personal coat rack and took profane umbrage when I pointed out that she had placed a blimplike down-filled jacket in my lap. At "Best in Show," a family oblivious to the ruckus they were creating smuggled in a crunchy, odoriferous dinner for four.
Yes, the new multiplexes, with their physical amenities, can be a vast improvement over the older, smaller theaters. I'd give a special Oscar to the film executive who first uttered those glorious words, "stadium seating." And with all deference to the North Shore Animal League, I can even take a big, commercial doggie movie to heart now and then. Lizzie and I emerged swollen-eyed and inconsolable from "My Dog Skip," a heartbreaking story about a young boy and his Jack Russell terrier. 
But my experience of late has been more of the "102 Dalmatians" variety. Maybe the disappointment I'm feeling leaving the theater is the result of impossible expectations, though even studio executives have been complaining about a lackluster year for critical and commercial hits. All I know is that I can no longer recall the last time any friend of mine remarked in passing, "We went to a great movie last night."
On weekends, my wife and I play the same scene over and over. One of us declares a hankering for a good movie. The other reads aloud from the listings. After a dispiriting recital and an informal cost-benefit analysis, we inevitably stay in and order Mexican food.
So I've begun to step back from first-run filmdom. But all has not been a cinematic blackout. My retreat has prompted an advance on the archives, and the old VCR is working overtime. Over the holidays I began a vigil at the Hitchcock shelves in the video store, and was soon renting everything from "Notorious" to "Vertigo." I aimed a remote at Channel 54 on the cable box, where American Movie Classics resides, and soon devoured the likes of "High Noon," "The Man Who Knew Too Much" and "Cabaret."
Far from the madding movie houses, I'm feeling better about movies again. And luxury of luxuries, I sip my coffee from any size mug in the cupboard.

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Finding Value in the Wreck of Technology

BYLINE:  By JAN M. ROSEN 

 BODY:
DISILLUSIONED by the Icarus-like performance of the technology-laden Nasdaq, a once-highflying market, many investors took the one consolation available last month -- selling shares so they could claim tax losses. That, of course, sent the battered stocks down further.
 The Nasdaq composite index fell 39.3 percent last year, and was off 54.4 percent from its high, with technology shares largely responsible for the plunge. In contrast, the more diversified Standard & Poor's 500-stock index lost only 10.1 percent of its value last year. Have the resulting low prices created opportunities in technology funds, or would investors still holding such funds be well advised to recognize reality and join the exodus? 
 Both independent investment advisers and fund managers see more buying opportunity than reason to sell, especially after the Federal Reserve lowered interest rates last Wednesday. But the euphoria over dot-coms is dead; technology portfolio managers are now looking toward infrastructure companies with solid earnings and business models. Among those cited by several managers were Cisco Systems, JDS Uniphase and Sun Microsystems -- "the steel mills of the Internet," as Michael Stolper, an independent investment adviser, called them. 
"It looks like most of the pain is behind us," said Mr. Stolper, whose firm, Stolper & Company of San Diego, invests in both stocks and mutual funds for institutions and affluent individual clients. Technology "is the only sector fund we see as an evergreen," he added, because it is key to enhancing productivity. Still, he cautioned, "when you get this kind of carnage in a sector, it takes time to come back."
HE said that the Fed's move would set the stage for a market recovery, including technology, in the second half. Mr. Stolper, who likes the T. Rowe Price Science and Technology fund, said that it was important to sort through the sector one company at a time -- and, given the complicated nature of technology, he preferred to leave that to a specialized fund manager.
Similarly, Jack Holden, vice president of Fort Washington Investment Advisors and portfolio manager of the Touchstone Value Plus fund, which has significant technology holdings, describes himself as "a big believer that tech will continue to improve productivity." Even so, he predicted that many issues could be battered further over the next six to nine months.
"Later, there will be a lot of good names you could buy," he said, using the value approach to investing. In its recent boom years, technology has been favored mainly by growth funds, not value funds.
"We're starting to see a lot of stocks that are coming into our wheelhouse," based on their market valuations, Mr. Holden said. He compared the recent surge, then tumble, of technology issues to "the energy bubble" in the 1970's and 1980, when oil shortages led to tremendous demand for anything "that looked or smelled like energy." In 1980, the energy sector's market value peaked at 28.3 percent of the S.& P. 500, he said; at the end of 2000 it was 6.7 percent. Technology peaked in March 2000 at 34 percent of the value of the S.& P. 500, he said, but by the end of the year it was down to 22 percent.
"I don't expect it to fall to 6 percent," Mr. Holden said. Still, technology share prices climbed much higher than justified by their fundamental value, and technology "has not troughed yet," he said.
"These stocks look cheap, but it's a value trap," he added. "They can get cheaper. As value investors, we like tangibles" like hardware and software, he said, pointing to "good, solid infrastructure plays like Cisco, Sun, Nortel and JDS Uniphase."
He is cautious even with those companies, he said, because "I'm not sure how deep the economic slowdown will go." But "a lot of bellwether names will play out long-term," he added. "After the euphoric bubble, people are starting to say valuations do matter."
His largest technology holding is Lexmark International, the printer company spun off by I.B.M. His reasons have less to do with technology than with the old Gillette model of making money on the blade, not the razor. Profit margins on printers are not impressive, he said, but margins on color ink cartridges are about 60 percent, "and if you have kids, you know how much they print out from the Internet."
He also holds Computer Associates, which writes mainframe software. He sees good prospects for the company because "I.B.M. is rolling out its new mainframe."
Larry Carroll, president of Carroll Financial Associates, an independent financial planning firm in Charlotte, N.C., said that he saw a moderate buying opportunity in technology but that "the Nasdaq is not going to hit 5,000" this year.
"I see a 15 to 20 percent bounce in tech stocks in the first quarter," he said. "Because of tax-loss selling at year-end, the market is oversold, and it really sets it up for a nice bounce."
Further, Mr. Carroll said, the tax-loss selling has given the technology funds a tax advantage they did not have previously: tax-loss carry forwards that they can use to offset future capital gains. As a result, the funds' shareholders will not face the big tax bills they had to pay in recent years. "It will make these funds much more tax-efficient," he said.
Among mutual funds, he particularly likes Pimco Innovation and Pimco Global Innovation. 
Terry E. Banet, vice president and portfolio manager at J. P. Morgan Investment Management, also likes infrastructure plays like Cisco, EMC, Sun, Microsoft, Intel and Texas Instruments. "Our philosophy is that we don't bail out of a sector," she said. "The rate of growth is slowing, but technology is not falling into the abyss. It may grow 50 percent instead of 60 percent." She sees the growth coming in "network mission-critical pieces," not in sales of personal computers. 
Her advice to fund investors is "to go back to asset-allocation decisions," and to review their tolerance for risk in deciding whether to sell current technology fund holdings or to buy new ones.
Mr. Stolper, for one, sold some technology fund shares last spring because their gains had overweighted his holdings in that sector. "It wasn't prescience or brilliance," he said. Still, by following a disciplined approach to asset allocation, he avoided much of the pain felt by many investors.
For investors who make similar asset-allocation decisions, Ms. Banet advised: "Don't snap back to cash. We like to stay invested. Technology is one area of the market, but the United States is not built on technology alone." She said drugs, finance and consumer goods were also important sectors to consider.
James W. Broadfoot, president of Ivy Management Inc. and manager of the Ivy Global Science and Technology fund, cautioned that because of the sector's volatility, it was especially important for investors to have a long-term perspective. Over the next 18 to 24 months, he said, he is optimistic about the prospects for a number of large-cap technology issues he holds, like Intel, Cisco Systems, Sun Microsystems and EMC.
"It would be a tremendous mistake to get out today. There is no question in my mind that technology is going to be a big growth engine in the economy for years to come," he said.
Another optimist is Marian U. Pardo, a managing director of J. P. Morgan who heads the small-cap equities group, which manages more than $6.6 billion in assets for institutional and individual clients. She said she saw huge opportunities for investors in technology funds. 
"It takes a strong stomach" in a battered market, Ms. Pardo said, but the fund managers who will make the most money for shareholders in the long run are the ones who figure out which companies "will rise from the ashes."
To find those managers, she said, look for experience -- portfolio managers who have been through several business cycles and know how to handle volatility.

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES; 
Same Yardstick, Different Races

BYLINE:  By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of The Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Annandale, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week. E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
AS any track coach knows, a mile is nothing like a marathon. Many runners who do well over short distances lack the endurance for long ones.
 Successful investing, of course, is more like a marathon than a mile. It involves a long-term commitment. Many mutual fund investors, however, do not remember that principle -- and one reason for their forgetfulness is that Morningstar's ratings sometimes blur the distinction. 
 When comparing a fund that has been around for just three years with another that has a record of a decade or more, Morningstar assumes, in effect, that the younger fund can keep up its returns indefinitely.
That does not mean that investors should ignore Morningstar. No rating system is perfect, because aggressive and conservative investors seek different kinds of guidance. But if you understand the ins and outs of Morningstar's rating system, you can use it more intelligently.
Morningstar is fully aware of the problems of comparing younger and older funds. According to Don Phillips, Morningstar's managing director, these pitfalls are one reason that the firm discourages investors from automatically interpreting changes in a fund's ranking as buy or sell signals. On occasion, Morningstar has publicly bemoaned the fact that investors give its rating system more importance than it warrants. Furthermore, Morningstar has resisted pressure from investment firms to rate funds that have been around for only a year. 
Still, many investors continue to make decisions based on changes in a fund's Morningstar ranking. According to the Financial Research Corporation, based in Boston, mutual funds that received four or five stars from Morningstar in 1999 enjoyed net inflows of $224 billion for that year, while those rated lower suffered net outflows of $132 billion.
Top-rated funds receive five stars from Morningstar, while those at the bottom get one. The ratings are based on Morningstar's measure of risk-adjusted performance, and grading is done on a curve. The middle 35 percent receive three stars, while only 10 percent get one star and 10 percent get five.
The approach is straightforward enough. But problems arise when Morningstar uses it to grade funds with records of widely varying lengths. How can these funds be fairly compared with one another? 
Morningstar's solution is to calculate a separate star grade for each of three periods -- the last 3, 5 and 10 years. (Funds that are less than three years old are not rated.) Morningstar then combines those grades into one overall rating. If a fund has been around for only three years, its overall rating is the same as its three-year grade. But if a fund is at least 10 years old, Morningstar's system gives a 50 percent weighting to the 10-year grade, 30 percent to the 5-year and 20 percent to the 3-year.
Under this approach, however, a greater percentage of younger funds than veterans earn five stars. That is because luck plays a bigger role in shorter-term performance, resulting in greater extremes. So a higher percentage of 3-year-old funds than 10-year-olds earn five stars.
As a result, some investors are drawn to younger funds whose performance might have come in large part from luck. The wise investor would favor a veteran fund over an upstart, even if the upstart had slightly better lifetime performance.
Some people may argue that Morningstar's approach works on balance, since a greater percentage of three-year-old funds than decade-old funds also receive just one star. But that does not discourage fund families from offering new funds in hopes of garnering five stars -- and the huge influx of new capital that inevitably follows. If the upstart then turns into a loser, it can be quietly shut down and replaced.
Morningstar's favoring of younger funds was first noted in 1998 by academics including William F. Sharpe, a 1990 Nobel laureate in economics, and Marshall Blume, of the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. 
A new study has found a different problem in the way Morningstar compares young and old funds. The study, by Matthew Morey, a finance professor at Pace University, discovered a statistical quirk making it more likely that the overall star ratings of older funds will rise than fall. As a result, even investors who use these ratings only to assess veteran funds can go astray, by holding on to a deteriorating fund longer than they might otherwise. The study is available at webpage.pace.edu/mmorey/ mstarage11.pdf.
Can Morningstar do anything to correct these problems? Mr. Phillips said there was no easy way to avoid them in combining a fund's performance over different periods into a single rating. 
But two finance professors, Andrew Metrick and Robert Stambaugh, both of the Wharton School, say Morningstar could use some statistical techniques to reflect the inherently higher risk for younger funds.
Imagine that you are choosing between two funds -- one that has existed for just a few years and one for two decades. If both have average annual returns of, say, 20 percent, and their returns have been equally volatile, most of us would invest in the veteran fund. We would appreciate intuitively that investing in the younger fund carries much higher risk.
Until and unless Morningstar takes this risk into account, how should you go about picking a mutual fund? Here are three guidelines:
* Take Morningstar at its word that its ratings should not be seen as buy or sell signals. Its ratings should be where your research begins, not ends.
* Be wary of any fund that has been around less than five years. This may seem harsh, since many domestic equity funds fall into this category. But to put it bluntly, there is too much garbage among younger funds, even those whose returns seem impressive. Following this rule means missing the chance of finding a gem, but also avoids the much higher likelihood of investing in a loser. A corollary is to be wary of any fund whose manager has changed over the last five years.
* When comparing funds that are at least 10 years old, do not rely on Morningstar's overall rating but instead on its 10-year grade only. That eliminates any statistical distortion.

HEADLINE: NOTICED; 
Latest Economic Indicator: A Depression Doll is Hot

BYLINE:  By RUTH LA FERLA 

 BODY:
STEP aside, Diva Starz, those brazen, 9-inch Kewpies bleating, "Let's go to the mall." Make way for Kit Kittredge, a creature of a higher order. 
 Introduced last fall, Kit is the latest in the wildly popular American Girls historical dolls collection. She stands 18 inches high in her Mary Janes, as quaint and perky as she is intriguing to the 7- to 12-year-old fans whose affluent lives are so unlike her own. She steps out of a distant time, but one with perhaps a disquieting echo for today: the Great Depression. 
 Kit, a creation of the Pleasant Company of Middleton, Wis., which is a division of Mattel Toys, is just the latest artifact to wash up in a wavelet of Depression-age nostalgia, one that encompasses reproduction gooseneck lamps, rag rugs, iceboxes and walnut swivel chairs. But she may well be the most compelling. 
"Kit looks so real," said Katerina Klavon, 9, of Silver Spring, Md., who just purchased her own Kit doll with savings from gifts and her allowance. "She really seems like she's just going to say, 'Hi, nice to meet you.' But what really picked up my interest was reading about how she helped her family get through the Depression." 
That sort of enthusiasm has helped make Kit the most coveted of the seven American Girl dolls, and at a time of plunging consumer confidence and intimations of recession, also the most eerily relevant. 
Conceived by her makers as a beacon of pluck in times of adversity, Kit is to her admirers both an antidote to "affluenza," that malaise that pop psychologists have identified as afflicting the contemporary rich, and a symbolic link to a fast-receding past. 
"My idea was to give parents a way to start conversation with a child, to introduce the notion that high times may be transient, to prepare ourselves," said Valerie Tripp, the author of the six-part book series that accompanies Kit. There is also a kind of superstition at work, she conceded: "If I talk about the demon, it won't come."
In invoking hard times, the doll's manufacturer took a calculated risk. "It crossed our minds that a character like Kit might turn off the public," said Julia Prohaska, brand director for the Pleasant Company. She placed her bets, however, on "an interesting quality about girls this age," she said, adding: "They are fascinated with hardship. And we had a gut instinct they would find this story compelling, maybe all the more so because they live in such relative comfort."
Since the doll's introduction in September, its initial sales have outperformed those of all predecessors, including Felicity of the Colonial era and Molly from World War II, Ms. Prohaska said. The company does not disclose sales for individual dolls, but says it has sold a total of five million, and 60 million books, since the collection was introduced in 1986.
To some students of popular culture, Kit symbolizes a way of life that, harsh as it was, seems in retrospect to have been more stable, emotionally rich and rewarding than the lives we know. 
"To some extent we've romanticized the Depression," said Dr. Michael Marsden, an expert in popular culture, now provost and vice president for academic affairs at Eastern Kentucky University. "The stories of survival, what people did to make ends meet, actually became, in the minds of our parents and grandparents, illustrations of a time of great suffering but also of great heroism." 
In an era of unprecedented affluence, the notion of people setting aside their own wants to think about others can seem exotic, he added. From a modern vantage, Kit is an alien, but she provides her devotees with something like a moral compass. 
"Our mothers and fathers used to tell stories about having to make potato soup and put cardboard in their shoes when they had nothing," recalled Dr. Marsden, who is in his late 50's. "Such tales were meant to show our parents' ingenuity, their creativity, how they learned to survive." Viewed from this perspective, "the Depression was a moral triumph," he said, adding, "Today our society needs to be reminded of its own successes, moral as well as social." 
The first book in Ms. Tripp's series, "Meet Kit," portrays the 9-year-old heroine as crushed but resilient when she learns that her family must take in boarders to make ends meet. By the second installment, "Kit Learns a Lesson," Kit is pinching pennies and volunteering in a soup kitchen. Small wonder that contemporary mothers find her so endearing -- the dimpled embodiment of thriftiness, courage and resourcefulness many thought went out with Nancy Drew. 
"Kit could be a touchstone for contemporary girls, whether or not they actually go through hard times," said Didi Barrett, chairwoman of the board of Girls Incorporated of New York City, a youth organization for girls 6 to 16. Ms. Barrett, the mother of Annabel, 9, plans to present her daughter with a Kit doll of her own. She finds Kit a worthwhile role model, she said, never mind her cost, a dizzying $84 (including the latest paperback, "Kit's Surprise: A Christmas Story"), which might seem at odds with the character's message of thriftiness.
Sue Levytsky, a freelance writer in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., for one, noted the irony in an expensive toy meant to impart the lessons of hard times. Ms. Levytsky, who purchased a Kit for her 6-year-old daughter, Arden, observed dryly: "The fact that Kit is a Depression doll gives some of us a larger permission to buy. You tell yourself there's some credibility attached to this thing because the doll gives your child a hands-on historical learning experience." 
Kit's creators argue that her fans draw a kind of spiritual sustenance from the doll and her story. "Children are impressionable," Ms. Tripp said. "They have fears. In a disposable culture, they begin to wonder, Am I plastic and disposable too? What Kit has to teach them is that when everything that they own is gone, what they have left is a work in progress, which is their character."
Long before she was a doll, Kit took shape in Ms. Tripp's imagination as "a sturdy little character who marches ever forward," the author said in an interview. In her first book, Ms. Tripp describes her heroine as an avatar of spunk, a practical girl who "thought it was a waste of time to worry about a problem if you could be doing something to solve it." 
To her fans, Kit's can-do spirit is infectious. Katerina, the Maryland 9-year-old, said: "She taught me that you have to do something about it when you get in trouble. I think Kit had a lot of courage to get the money so the family could have their electricity turned on for Christmas. Hearing about the Depression sort of upset me a little, but it didn't scare me." 
Kit recalls an era that, despite its challenges, seems in hindsight to have been blissfully simple. Her pet possession -- a clanky black manual typewriter -- exerts a fascination even on a gadget-obsessed generation that reflexively calls in the experts whenever a piece of technology breaks down.
Growing up in the 1930's, "we weren't so dependent on outsiders," said Marcia Day, 72, a retired home economics teacher in Hinsdale, Ill. She added, "These days, you even get your lettuce cut up for you." Ms. Day said she was thrilled when the youngest of her six granddaughters was given a Kit doll. "When we were young, we didn't run to the Disney store to buy new toys," she said. "We made our own out of old spools, shells and buttons. Kit's like that. I would like to think she helps my grandchildren understand the worthiness of improvisation, imagination and self-reliance.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Arden Shwayder, 6, and her Kit doll, a reminder of harder times. (Allan Barnes for The New York Times)(pg. 4); Kit, the resilient Depression doll (apples not included) from the Pleasant Company. (pg. 1)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
The Party Crashers, Growling Loudly

BYLINE:  By DANNY HAKIM 

 BODY:
SPIRO L. VRUSHO wanted to end 1999 with one more confection from the new-economy banquet. 
 Like so many other investors, Mr. Vrusho, 65, a retired I.B.M. salesman who lives in Stamford, Conn., had already piled his plate high. He had bought Microsoft, Intel, Cisco Systems, Oracle and WorldCom. He had bought and sold the Kinetics Internet fund, the best-performing mutual fund of 1998. He had bought all five mutual funds run by Garrett Van Wagoner, a money manager based in San Francisco who is known for his aggressive technology investing. And Mr. Vrusho had bought a mutual fund that tracked an Internet stock index. 
 Mr. Vrusho, known as Spike, was drawn to those investments in part by what he saw on CNBC and in Money, Smart Money and three other financial magazines he reads regularly. Thus emboldened, he thought there was room for one more rocket in his portfolio. So he bought $35,700 worth of the new Jacob Internet fund. "I believe in technology, and I'm willing to take, even at my age, some swings, with the feeling that technology will go back up," Mr. Vrusho said. 
So the swings came. Unless they have spent the last few months encased in a block of ice in Times Square, investors already know how the bull market went bust. After several years when investors took double-digit gains for granted, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 10.1 percent in 2000, and the average growth fund was down 11.3 percent. It was the first down year for growth funds, and stock funds more generally, since 1994. 
Technology and telecommunications, sectors that soared in 1999, flamed out in 2000 -- though they were reignited, at least briefly, when the Federal Reserve cut interest rates last week. Energy, health care and financial services rebounded in 2000 from past setbacks. 
Value fund managers, who search the market's bargain bins instead of paying for the latest fashions, came back strong last year. By year-end, they had stanched the billions of dollars in monthly outflows that they had suffered for so long. 
The market reversal last year confirmed that a new investing milennium had not arrived. Diversification and investing for the long term still made more sense than buying stock in companies hardly deserving of early-stage venture capital. 
For many investors, old realities are starting to suggest themselves only now. Mr. Vrusho picked the worst-performing mutual fund last year in Jacob Internet, out of more than 8,000 possibilities. By year-end, the fund had fallen 79.1 percent, his investment had shrunk to about $10,000 and he conceded that he was "a little bit uncertain about my strategy." 
And even defensive. "I am thinking about value funds, but I haven't analyzed them enough," he said. "And I do have some cash," which is the last resort of the chastened. 
As the year progressed, and more investors learned humility the hard way, many turned away from stock-picking and toward mutual funds, including the stodgier ones. "A lot of investors who had been feeling really smart in '99 started to appreciate the role a professional money manager can play in your life," said Christine Benz, a senior analyst at Morningstar, the fund tracking firm. "Picking your own stocks doesn't look so easy." 
Even some of the most storied investors suffered. In April, George Soros started scaling back his hedge fund empire, partly because of hits from Internet stocks. He changed the name of his once-aggressive Quantum fund to the Quantum Endowment, signaling a more modest approach that caused many of his investors to depart. 
WHO can win, if even Mr. Soros cannot? The 76-year-old mutual fund industry, perhaps.
The fund business has faced many threats over the last year, primarily from newfangled financial products. Exchange-traded funds promote themselves as cheaper versions of index mutual funds that have the added flexibility of trading throughout the day, like stocks. And Foliofn, a fledgling company in Vienna, Va., offers a way to buy stocks in bundles that look a lot like mutual funds.
Do-it-yourself traders were reminded again last year that many fund managers could not muster a better return than the market over all. And firms both online and off are now selling privately managed stock accounts to the middle class. 
In September, Red Herring magazine summed up the accumulated doubts about how a financial product invented in 1924 would fare in the 21st century. "The Death of Mutual Funds" read the headline, under a picture of a toppled dinosaur. A recent report from Forrester Research heralded "the coming demise of mutual funds." The report predicted that funds would lose more than $1 trillion of assets, from $6.8 trillion now, and shrink to 5,000 funds, from more than 8,000, by 2010. 
That may yet prove true. By November, investors were growing so frustrated with their losses that stock funds' net sales dropped sharply, to $5.7 billion, by far the slowest monthly sales of the year and well below the $19.2 billion in October. 
BUT mutual fund extinction hardly seems imminent. After all the clamor, 2000 was a record year for sales. By the end of November, stock funds had net inflows of $297.4 billion for the year, already crushing the previous sales record of $227 billion for all of 1997, according to the Investment Company Institute, a trade group.
One reason was the waning appetite for self-reliant investing. The typical customer at Charles Schwab, for instance, put a larger chunk of his portfolio into mutual funds last year than in 1999, reversing a trend. 
Investors, however, are not necessarily ready to forget technology and load up on Chevron or Ford. If they are not so confident in their own ability to pick stocks, they are by no means ready to give up aggressive-growth funds. The rate cut by the Fed last week, after six increases, is likely to reaffirm their faith. "People are still looking for the great moonshot year like '99," Ms. Benz said.
Value funds, however, remain earthbound, if relatively stable. In 2000, the average value fund was up 9.72 percent, according to Morningstar, slightly more than the gains of almost 8 percent in 1999 and 1998. 
Growth funds were much more volatile. They were down 11.33 percent, on average, last year, after gaining 55.09 percent in 1999 and 22.18 percent in 1998. "Yes, value funds are doing better, but that doesn't compare to the 50 percent, 100 percent gains of growth funds" in 1999, Ms. Benz added, "when even a lousy tech fund gained 100 percent."
Carl Wittnebert, research director at TrimTabs.com of Santa Rosa, Calif., said that last year, the fund flows tracked by his firm defied the expected trend -- that the average investor would bail out of volatile companies when they cooled. "It's incredible to me that people haven't lost faith in aggressive growth and technology," he said. "The biggest fear that remains for people is that they will miss out on those lottery-like returns. Why haven't they sold all their technology funds en masse? Because they're in fairy land."
For decades, the industry has encouraged investors to buy funds that feature the narrowest sectors or the greatest growth. If the fund companies preach diversification, some people who monitor the industry say, they will sell whatever moves off the shelf, and that has meant ever more sector funds. 
"The public is forgetting about reducing risk through diversification, and the industry is aiding and abetting them by providing them narrower and narrower focused funds," said Burton J. Greenwald, who runs a fund consulting firm in Philadelphia that bears his name. "You're slicing the baloney thinner and thinner. You go from health care to biotech to genomics. There's no end to it."
The new economy spawned an especially powerful chain reaction of mutual fund fission. Technology funds begat Internet funds, which begat infrastructure, networking, e-commerce and wireless funds, followed by funds that invested in briefly glamorous alphanumeric combinations like B2C and B2B. Several funds even took stock tips from World Wide Web message boards.
BY the end of last year, fund companies were trying desperately to contain the radiation. They went so far as to strike the word "Internet" from the titles of some funds and add the word "value," previously a marketing untouchable, to other funds. 
The Monument Internet fund was up 273.2 percent in 1999 and down 56.9 percent in 2000. Today, it is called Monument Digital Technology. 
"The investors that are rewarded the most are the ones that are diversified and don't bet on one style of investing," said Robert J. Froehlich, global investment strategist at Scudder Kemper Investments and the new, reassuring voice of the firm's advertising campaign. "In 1999, people weren't investing; they were playing the lottery."
If growth and technology funds continue to falter, investors will eventually desert. These funds' losses, greater than those of the S.& P. 500, helped account for the sharp drop in fund sales at the end of 2000. Still, it is hard to let go, even for an investor like Mr. Vrusho, who watched his portfolio lose one-third of its value last year.
He is not close to abandoning his technology holdings, not even Jacob Internet. "These kinds of swings are expected in aggressive funds, and you have to take the risk to get those big gains," he said. He plans to invest an additional $4,000 with Jacob Internet and its 31-year-old manager, Ryan Jacob, this month. 
Mr. Vrusho was one of Mr. Jacob's early adherents, and their fortunes have since corresponded. Mr. Jacob once ran the Kinetics Internet fund, one of the first Internet funds. He joined it at age 28 in 1998, when it had a mere $149,754 in assets. He daringly bet them all on the likes of Yahoo, GeoCities and Lycos. By year-end, the fund had gained 198 percent. So many new customers jammed the fund's few phone lines that the headquarters, in the home of a retired Long Island postal worker, a friend of the fund owner's mother, had 24 more lines installed in one day. 
Mr. Jacob landed on the cover of Kiplinger's Personal Finance magazine, and one customer dedicated an online fan club to him.
Now his performance has gone from first to worst. "I'm glad the year's almost over," he said in late December. "It's been a brutal year for everyone." 
Yet he still has $60 million to work with. His investors, by and large, have not abandoned him. "Money comes in every day, money goes out every day," Mr. Jacob said. Withdrawals have been modest. "You keep waiting for outflows, but it doesn't happen."
Thanks in part to Mr. Vrusho. In six months, he turned $58,000 into $115,400 by investing with Mr. Jacob at Kinetics Internet. Now, Mr. Vrusho is not ready to give up on his new fund. "I've been doggedly holding on to it," he said. "My feeling is that if he takes such a big beating now, he'll improve dramatically in the future."

LENGTH: 2273 words

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
A Manager's Fight to Keep a Winning Streak Alive

BYLINE:  By PATRICK McGEEHAN 

 BODY:
ON April 4, when William H. Miller III visited a class at the Columbia Business School, he sounded like the old-school value investor that his critics say he is not. Technology holdings had helped power his Legg Mason Value Trust to an unmatched, nine-year winning streak against the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index.
 But on that day, as he addressed the students in Michael Mauboussin's securities analysis class, he said that technology stocks had risen too high and added that, although they had been dropping, they were headed for a greater fall. 
 "Valuations have not mattered in four or five years, and they have reached an extreme level," Mr. Miller told the class. "We've reached a period where valuation will begin to matter again, so we have begun reducing our technology weighting." 
To Mr. Mauboussin, the message was dire: "He said it's over for technology." 
Mr. Miller was right. The Nasdaq composite index had finished that day at 4,149. It dropped 20 percent in the next eight trading days and finished the year at 2,471. 
Until early 1999, when Mr. Miller seemingly could do no wrong, that tale probably would have ended with him making just the right adjustments, so that his fund could race ahead of the overall market and score big gains again. But by late 2000, Mr. Miller appeared to have lost the golden touch. 
His phenomenal success had led investors to pour billions of dollars into what had been an obscure fund sold through Legg Mason, a brokerage firm based in Baltimore.
But some rivals were crying foul. They argued that a value investor -- supposedly one who trolls among companies that have fallen out of favor -- had no business owning some of the pricey stocks, including America Online and Dell Computer, that had propelled the Value Trust's rise.
The fund's early investors had no complaints. The average annual return for the Value Trust since Mr. Miller, 50, took over its management in October 1990 has been more than 23 percent, compared with 18.2 percent for the S.& P. 500.
His consistency has made him a reluctant, rumpled star of the investment world. In style and demeanor, he more closely resembles Warren Buffett and his investing partner, Charles Munger, than Peter Lynch, the promotion-minded former manager of the popular Fidelity Magellan fund.
"In my view, he's the best mutual fund manager in America," said Mr. Mauboussin, an investment strategist at Credit Suisse First Boston, who said the Value Trust was the only actively managed fund he owned. "He's had a couple of things that have really land-mined this year. But the guy made more money than God in AOL and Dell."
During a presentation to reporters in mid-December at the "21" Club, Mr. Miller's modest nature was on full display. He projected a Calvin & Hobbes cartoon strip that showed a boy saying, "How can something seem so plausible at the time and so idiotic in retrospect," as a water balloon bursts in his hands.
"That's the way that I feel with a lot of the stocks we bought this year," Mr. Miller said. He made no attempt to sugar-coat the truth: It has been a while since he made a big bet on a stock that did not soon blow up in his face.
"The three names we bought last year all collapsed; the one we bought this year collapsed," he said, then joked: "So, I think we'll buy none next year."
At that point, with less than three weeks left in the year, the Value Trust was dead even with the S.& P. 500. Value Trust had fallen far behind the market early in the year as dot-coms and other technology stocks rocketed on. But then Mr. Miller's timely sales of chunks of AOL and some other winners, along with his purchase of bank stocks, narrowed the gap, renewing his chances of keeping his streak alive.
"We're not having a disastrous year because we sold a lot of tech and rolled into financials in the spring when the financials were getting croaked," he said. His fund's return would have been 10 to 20 percentage points worse than the market's, he said, "if we had just sat and done nothing all year."
As the year-end neared, Mr. Miller knew what it would take to pull out another market-beating performance. First, financial stocks would have to match the market's return for the next few weeks. That would probably happen, he said then. Then, one or more of the beaten-down technology stocks in his portfolio, either Gateway, Amazon.com or Nextel Communications, would have to rally. That was a longer shot, he said. 
Either way, the outcome was out of his hands. He planned to make few, if any, changes to the portfolio and would not even stick around the office to see how things turned out. Instead, he planned to retreat during the holidays to Santa Fe, N.M., the home of one of his passions, the Santa Fe Institute, a research organization where scholars like Murray Gell-Mann, the Nobel Prize-winning physicist, hold forth on esoteric matters.
For more than a decade, Mr. Miller has made pilgrimages to the institute to study complex, adaptive systems, a simple model of which might be an ant colony, a more complex one the stock market. Among the applicable lessons he has learned from other institute regulars, he said, are how some apparent competitors, be they birds or computer makers, can coexist and thrive.
Mr. Mauboussin remembered when Mr. Miller first broached the subject of complexity theory a few years ago. They were sitting in another of Mr. Miller's favorite places, his seats overlooking home plate at Camden Yards in Baltimore.
"I went to an Orioles game with him -- he's got great seats -- and he said, 'You know, you're a guy that ought to start looking at this complexity stuff,' " Mr. Mauboussin recounted. Mr. Mauboussin followed Mr. Miller to Santa Fe and now lectures there on the futility of trying to outperform the stock market consistently.
But he has not persuaded his friend to stop trying. Mr. Miller says he is paid to deliver higher returns, after fees and taxes, than investors could get from a low-cost index fund. So, he has made a science of deconstructing the S.& P. 500, studying its moves like a baseball scout. 
But instead of turning the Value Trust into a virtual index fund -- as so many other managers have done by stuffing their funds with the largest stocks -- Mr. Miller adheres to what he considers the tenets of value investing, originally set by Benjamin Graham. In short, Mr. Miller buys stocks that he thinks are selling significantly below the present value of their future cash flows.
But that does not always lead him to cheap stocks. He was widely criticized two years ago by other money managers for owning AOL and Dell, two stocks that had soared. Mr. Miller always gave a measured response, no matter the tone of the attack.
In July 1998, when James J. Cramer, a fast-trading hedge fund manager, published a vituperative column on theStreet.com, a financial Web site that Mr. Cramer founded, Mr. Miller thought the Value Trust was an intended target. "Value in this world has simply become a masquerade," Mr. Cramer wrote, "a mean-spirited marketing tactic that lures people in the door who would otherwise have no desire to own such nosebleed stocks." 
In a "Dear Jim" letter, also published on the site, Mr. Miller said that he had not wavered, but that maybe his critics had. "Finding good businesses at cheap prices, taking a big position and then holding for years used to be sensible investing," he said. "What they seem to object to most is that we didn't sell Dell at $8 like the other value guys did." Six months later, Dell's price had doubled again.
The Value Trust is often mentioned in news media reports as a likely target of a new campaign by the Securities and Exchange Commission for truth in labeling in mutual funds. Discussing the issue, Mr. Miller said, "It's a no-win situation to go fight the S.E.C. on stuff that they want to do."
But, he added, he doubts that the S.E.C. will tell him to take the "value" out of Value Trust. "The name Value Trust is not a description of the types of companies that we own; it's a description of our objective in delivering value to our shareholders," he said. "If they're going to determine what counts as value, they'll never find any justification from any finance textbook or anybody who ever has written about value or valuation."
Mr. Miller would know. A graduate student in philosophy at Johns Hopkins before he joined Legg Mason in 1982, he is a voracious reader on subjects as diverse as economics, physics and poetry. He is always recommending books to friends and fellow portfolio managers.
Asked for his current reading list, he peered into a black leather briefcase stuffed with documents before remembering that his books were in another bag. Wherever it was, he said, it contained a biography of the philosopher Charles Peirce and a paperback edition of "Lives of the Poets," a 992-page history of English-language poetry. 
As philosophical as he is analytical, he readily acknowledges mistakes but offers no apologies for the recurring implosions in his portfolio. Eastman Kodak, his only new pick last year, was off 40.6 percent. But he points out that two of his recent winners, Waste Management and McKesson HBOC, looked like big mistakes when they fell sharply after he started buying them.
The freshest disaster is Gateway, the computer maker, whose stock dropped 36 percent on Nov. 30 after the company warned that sales were slowing. Mr. Miller had been loading up on Gateway shares since 1999, and Legg Mason funds owned about 10 percent of the company when the stock plunged that day to its lowest price in almost two years. Mr. Miller bought more. 
He takes pleasure in buying when others sell. As other fund managers were stockpiling cash late last year to meet shareholder redemptions, he was spending all he could afford. Mr. Miller was selling his winners, like Fannie Mae and United Healthcare, and buying more of the holdings, like Dell, Nextel Communications and Amazon.com, that had fallen the most.
Even as investors were fleeing his fund before it paid out $7.82 a share in taxable gains on Dec. 22, Mr. Miller would not play up to Value Trust's directors. At a November meeting in a Legg Mason boardroom, he told them that shareholders who had owned the fund for less than a year should sell it. By doing so, many could take the losses on their income tax returns and avoid receiving the distribution of taxable gains. Though Mr. Miller took those gains by selling stocks last year, most of the benefits had gone to earlier investors.
Mr. Miller's position endangered his own income, which is tied to the profitability of Legg Mason's fund-management subsidiary, of which he is chief executive. 
In mid-December, as much as $20 million a day was flowing out of Value Trust, and its assets had shrunk by $1.5 billion from their peak of $13.7 billion.
The distributions were unavoidable, given his decision to sell his technology winners before they crashed, Mr. Miller said. "I would rather tell the shareholders, 'We're about even with the market; the market's had a bad year, and we've had a distribution,' " he said, "than I would say to them, 'The market's down 7 percent; we're down 20 percent, but you don't have to pay any tax.' " 
Mr. Miller was confident that his shareholders would return. But that was no sure thing after a year in which he looked less like Midas and more like Pyrrhus.
IT was only in the waning weeks of December that Value Trust started to build a lead on the S.& P. 500 -- not so much because the fund's stocks were rising as because they were not falling as fast as the market. Technology stocks, which accounted for the largest segment of the S.& P. 500 but the second-largest share of Value Trust, after financial stocks, continued to decline.
Mr. Miller received the help he needed from financials like Citigroup and Fannie Mae, and an unexpected lift from Waste Management, which gained almost 60 percent for the year.
But instead of bouncing back, his favorite technology stocks slumped further. AOL fell 9 percent between Christmas and New Year's Day, extending its loss for the year to more than 53 percent.
With three trading days left, Value Trust was down 8.1 percent, compared with a 9.5 percent loss for the S.& P. 500. Mr. Miller, who had taken his family to Santa Fe but was checking in with the office regularly, was not ready to declare victory.
On Thursday, Dec. 28, the next-to-last trading day of the year, Value Trust had such a good day that Mr. Miller finally thought his streak was secure. The fund was about two full percentage points ahead and, he said, "We would have had to have one of the worst days in the fund's history on Friday to not beat the market."
Still, Mr. Miller called in on Friday morning for reassurance, because, as he said, "You never know." By then, Legg Mason's chairman, Raymond A. Mason, and other colleagues were eager to congratulate him on another market-beating performance. In the end, Value Trust lost 7.11 percent, beating the S.& P. 500 by nearly three percentage points. 
When he returned to the office on Tuesday, Mr. Miller found it decorated with celebratory banners. He was treated to a catered lunch of sushi, one of his favorite foods, followed by cake and Champagne. As a tribute, one of his fellow fund managers, David Nelson, wrote a poem that chronicled the race to the wire, entitled " 'Twas the Week Before New Year."
"People have been unduly appreciative," Mr. Miller said, noting that his fund had, after all, recorded a loss. His new year started the way the old one ended: Value Trust fell 2.5 percent on Jan. 2, giving it a slim lead on the S.& P. 500, which dropped 2.8 percent.
