HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
Winning Managers' Strategy: Selling Short

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
DURING the abysmal fourth quarter of 2000, when the average domestic diversified equity fund lost 7.66 percent of its value, the bears had a picnic.
 As a result, many of the best performers for the quarter were managers who bet on a market decline. Atop the winners' list was a handful of index funds that "short" stocks, or sell borrowed shares, hoping to replace them at lower prices -- among them the first-place Rydex Dynamic Venture 100, up 73.02 percent, and second-place Profunds Ultrashort OTC, up 69.08 percent. They use a mix of short sales and futures and options to move in the opposite direction of the Nasdaq 100 index -- and about twice as fast -- so that they gained when the index tumbled. 
 Shorting stocks also drove the returns of the more conventional CGM Focus fund, the No. 1 performer among actively managed funds and No. 3 over all. Other leading funds benefited from rising commodity prices and falling interest rates.
Some of the winners discussed how they navigated the treacherous quarter and how 2001 might unfold.

A Bet on a Tech Tumble
G. Kenneth Heebner, a longtime growth investor, led the three-year-old, $68 million CGM Focus fund to a 44.44 percent return for the quarter. Some 62 percent of the portfolio assets were invested in short positions. 
"It's not my philosophy to find stocks that I think are overvalued and write them down," Mr. Heebner, 60, said from his Boston office. But, he added, he was "motivated to do large short positions by extraordinary circumstances."
"I believe that we have a monumental speculative bubble in technology stocks that I've never seen before in my 30 years of investing," he said.
Typically, he has owned an eclectic portfolio of growth companies and has shorted no more than 10 percent of the value of the fund.
Mr. Heebner declined to identify the biggest winners among his short positions, saying only that they were "companies with negative cash flow that I think will probably go out of business." He predicts that the carnage in technology "will continue for some time." 
Among his long holdings, a big winner was Philip Morris, the tobacco and food giant, up 51.5 percent in the last quarter. "I think the legal risks have peaked," he said, "and the class-action lawsuits that pose threats to the company will pass over time as judgments in favor of smokers are overturned by the federal appeals courts or even the U.S. Supreme Court."
Another winner was Timberland, the outdoor footwear and clothing concern. "The company saw a dramatic growth in sales because they make a fantastic product and because of the cold weather," Mr. Heebner said, adding that Timberland had significant free cash flow and no debt on its balance sheet.

Gains From Lower Rates
Falling interest rates bolstered the financial services sector, helping the $136 million Vontobel U.S. Value fund to a sixth-place finish among domestic diversified stock funds, with a gain of 20.3 percent.
"Financially defensive issues continued to rise in the fourth quarter when earnings disappointments manifested themselves elsewhere in the market, and the prospect of the Federal Reserve easing rates became more apparent," the fund's manager, Edwin D. Walczak, said before the Fed did so on Wednesday.
Mr. Walczak, 47, is a long-term investor who seeks companies with strong franchises that sell for less than what he considers fair value.
One of his biggest performers was the Federal National Mortgage Association, or Fannie Mae, up 21.8 percent last quarter as a result of falling interest rates. "The volume of fixed-rate mortgages went up because declining interest rates induced people to buy homes or to refinance their mortgages," he said.
Ace Ltd., a Bermuda-based company that provides reinsurance, or wholesale insurance bought by insurers, was another winner, up 8.5 percent. "Reinsurance rates were down last year and there was too much capacity in the system," he said. "All through this year, reinsurance prices have been getting better."
He also made money in CVS Drugstores, the chain based in Woonsocket, R.I., which rose 30 percent last quarter. "There's nothing fundamentally new about their business," Mr. Walczak said. "I think the stock price rose as people moved out of technology and other troubled areas of the market into more defensive, reliable earnings generators."
He is not optimistic, however, about stocks over all. "We never have a view of the market, per se, because we're bottom-up stock pickers," he said. "But I would advise clients to lower their expectations for market returns for the next several years relative to what we've had in the past."

Getting Back to Basics
Another winner was the $45 million Rydex Basic Materials fund, which owns 40 to 50 companies in the sector. It took fifth place over all with a gain of 24.6 percent (although it is not on some lists because none of its share classes, with different expenses, exceed $30 million).
By analyzing sales, assets and earnings, John H. Escario, 31, the fund's manager, looks for the most liquid companies that are closely tied to each part of the industry.
Stocks of basic-materials companies were down roughly 30 percent, on average, through September and then rebounded sharply, he said. "When the high-tech names sold off, valuation suddenly became a priority," he said, "and basic-materials stocks were beaten down fairly badly coming into the fourth quarter."
Paper and forest products companies, which had been undergoing consolidation, proved the hottest, Mr. Escario said. His biggest winner, Willamette Industries, up 68.4 percent, is fighting a takeover bid by Weyerhaeuser. Another big winner, International Paper, up 43.3 percent, acquired the Champion International Corporation earlier this year.
"When prices are strong, you have big investments of capital into capacity. Then, when prices slip, you have oversupply in the market. One way companies sought to mitigate this cycle is by buying" existing capacity, Mr. Escario said.
Acquisitions also drove the performance of Dow Chemical, up 48 percent. The company is acquiring Union Carbide. "They're buying capacity with the thought that they will be able to produce more effectively and at lower costs," he said.
Prospects for the broader industry do not look quite so bright. Many companies have announced shortfalls in their fourth-quarter earnings, Mr. Escario said, and the industry is dependent on a strong economy.

SECTION: Section 14; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk; Pg. 1

LENGTH: 2785 words

HEADLINE: A Vanishing World 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL J. WAKIN

 BODY:
YOU can see it in the lime rickey.
 For years that elixir of limes, soda water and cherry and lime syrup defined the Mill Luncheonette as a classic joint in Morningside Heights, along with its famous egg creams and $1.49 breakfast special. Black-clad students from Columbia and Barnard sat on vinyl-covered counter stools and stared hard at the faded Formica decor in literary reverie. Schoolchildren browsed through the comic books and old-timers smoked its plastic-tipped cigars. 
 In 1986, a Korean immigrant, Sung Kun Yun, bought the Mill, and over a decade he added a Korean dish here, a Korean painting there. Slowly, a Korean restaurant materialized near 113th Street and Broadway. 
But one thing remains the same. Lime rickeys are still on the menu.
Morningside Heights, too, has its sweet and sour vestiges, like the neighborhood characters who wander upper Broadway. As always, the neighborhood has a persevering population of middle-class families with children, non-Columbia people living nonacademic lives, and a constant student population that flows through the neighborhood like water over a rocky stream bed.
Nevertheless, as in countless other neighborhoods, the tide of gentrification sweeping north along the Upper West Side has erased much of this neighborhood's past. In its wake have come Starbucks, investment bankers and $750,000 two-bedroom apartments. Big neighborhood issues now involve getting the children into expensive private schools or finding a garage for the Lexus.
But that tide is also lapping at something intangible: shared memories of an intellectual, literary and political world that make this slice of Manhattan highlands something special. After all, this is Morningside Heights, where political firebrands railed against Columbia University and where composers, writers and journalists gathered, drawn by the neighborhood's intellectual setting, architectural charms and rich class mix. Only if you look hard can you still see the spirit of the People's Republic of the Upper West Side, the early-20th-century grandeur of the Acropolis on the Hudson.
Other places gentrify. But few -- Greenwich Village is one -- have a sense of history and richness of character like Morningside Heights. When gentrification goes through a place like Boerum Hill, there may be sadness and economic distress, but there is no great sense that a place with deep intellectual and spiritual roots has been overrun. 
Some of Morningside Heights' heritage is myth; it has been decades since Jack Kerouac haunted the West End. But for those who treasure the neighborhood's unique quality, particularly longtime residents who have breathed its rarefied air for decades, the threat is real. That the recent wave of change has come so swiftly adds to the intensity of people's feelings.
True to Upper West Side tradition, there are many opinions. Most residents are happy to say goodbye to high crime and shabbiness. Others will assert that the neighborhood has become too yuppie, or too Columbia, or too bland, and is still pretty dirty. Or they will say it is as down to earth as ever.
But in the eyes of many, something has been lost in the last five years.
"There was just an energy that is really not here any more," said Barbara Hohol, who is co-president of the 111th Street Block Association and drives a 1989 Toyota Corolla with the license plate GADFLY. 
"There was a street life that doesn't exist anymore, both among the older residents, people who came here in the 40's and 50's, and the recent immigrant groups," added Ms. Hohol, a jewelry maker who has lived in Morningside Heights for 40 years and whose Upper West Side roots go back to her grandmother. "A large segment of the population that is moving in now is doing so because it's a classy apartment in a neighborhood you want to live in." The changes, she said, aggravate "the loss of the sense of the history."

A Wave of Affluence Sparks Resentment
Morningside Heights runs from 110th Street to 122nd Street, with institutions dominating north of 114th Street. Broadway forms the spine, and Riverside Park and Morningside Park form its flanks. More loosely, the neighborhood's sphere of influence extends south to 106th Street and north to 125th Street, where it encompasses some large public housing projects. This larger district embraces expensive co-ops to the west, where residents plant tulips together and escape to weekend homes, and tenements to the east, where the mainly Hispanic population lives on the stoop and shops in bodegas on credit.
The wider area contains 55,000 souls and the city's highest concentration of institutions that tend to mind, body and spirit. They include not only Columbia, but also the Cathedral of St. John the Divine and Riverside Church -- the city's great progressive pulpits -- along with Union Theological and Jewish Theological Seminaries, the Manhattan School of Music, St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, Teachers College and the Bank Street College of Education.
Greater Morningside Heights is unquestionably more affluent than it was just a few years ago. Median family income, adjusted for inflation, rose from $33,000 in 1980 to $49,000 in 1990 to $56,500 in 1997, the most recent year for which census data are available. The proportion of families earning above $150,000 a year more than doubled between 1990 and 1997, from 4.5 percent to 11.6 percent. The proportion of professionals and people working in finance, insurance and real estate edged slightly higher.
"Now we have a lot of investment bankers or traders or e-commerce people who never would have been caught dead above 96th Street," said Klara Madlin, whose business, Klara Madlin Real Estate, has focused on the area since 1984. Typical of the prices, she said, is a five-room apartment on Broadway at 107th Street that sold for $355,000 in 1993 and fetched $740,000 last year.
The new wave of wealth has generated resentment among the Hispanic working-class population east of Broadway. They feel pressure from landlords to move, and they see more upper-middle-class whites moving in. They see trendy bars and restaurants sprouting on Amsterdam Avenue. 
"There are families that have been here 30, 40 years that know this as home but are seeing things shifting all around them," said Luis Roman, president of the local Democratic club, the Broadway Democrats. 
Those families, he said, "find themselves suddenly with a lack of security, a real lack of confidence in the idea that they are going to continue being able to live there."
"We really could be looking at the last generation of Dominicans and Puerto Ricans living in that neighborhood," he said.
Altagracia Hiraldo, 42, is part of that generation. She has lived east of Broadway since arriving from the Dominican Republic in 1979. Her husband, Juan, runs Hiraldo's School Karate-Do, which has become a neighborhood gathering place.
Sitting in the school's office in front of a picture of Mother Teresa at prayer, Mrs. Hiraldo described how the neighborhood's family feeling has been threatened by the newly arriving rich. "This is what we don't want to lose, our unity in our community, our love for each other," she said, as thumps and grunts sounded from a classroom. "This is not a neighborhood that needs rich people. This is a neighborhood that needs people who want to be a part of us."
A lament over the loss of variety is a common refrain, not unusual in New York but heartfelt here because of the area's longstanding pride in its diversity.
"It's a very diverse neighborhood, and perhaps as diverse as any place in New York," said Peter Marcuse, an urban planning professor at Columbia who has lived on 113th Street for a quarter of a century. "The danger is that it gets homogenized slowly; that slowly, all the eating places get to be yuppie eating places. I think that process is happening, and given the continuing prosperity, it is going to happen further."
Another hallmark, political activism, is in decline, and although this too is familiar -- consider Berkeley -- the change here is striking, given the area's history as a hotbed of protest.
"You see people out on the street, but there's less community activities and political meetings," said Curtis Arluck, a Democratic district leader and a 25-year resident. "There just seems to be less participation."

Along With Intangible Changes Come Major Tangible Ones
Mirroring intangible changes are stark physical changes, most of which involve Columbia, the institution responsible for some of the most notable chapters of the neighborhood's history. Columbia, which opened its campus here in 1897, first began buying buildings in 1919, worried that faculty and staff members could not afford good apartments and did not want to live in tenements. In the 1960's alone the university bought more than 100 buildings.
Opponents held Columbia responsible for the closing of single room occupancy hotels and the eviction of thousands of poor black and Hispanic residents. Anger rose to a flash point in 1968, when plans to build a gym in Morningside Park provoked protests and led to a monthlong student strike that paralyzed the university.
Times have changed. The university opened three large buildings in the last two years to relative peace: a 14-story residence hall and a glass-walled student center, both on Broadway, and a business and law building on Amsterdam Avenue.
Two current projects have some people up in arms. In October, Columbia broke ground for a new building for the school of social work on 113th Street west of Broadway, a 10-story structure that some residents say will block light and air and loom over surrounding structures. The university recently announced plans for a 12-story faculty residence-plus-elementary school at 110th Street and Broadway, with construction to begin in a year.
In November, Columbia halted work on the social work building. The university is now considering moving the project to an empty lot about 10 blocks north.
Meanwhile, a spate of relatively pricey restaurants -- Le Monde, a brasserie, and Tomo, a sushi bar -- has emerged along Broadway in the last few years, many on Columbia-owned sites. Columbia says the neighborhood demands such places. Critics say they are image polishers for students' parents.
"If Columbia is permitted, along with other institutions in the neighborhood, to build whatever they want to build, the neighborhood will be transformed," said Daniel O'Donnell, chairman of the land use committee of Community Board 9. "It will look like Third Avenue in the 60's. They are trying to make it more like a mall, more palatable to people who come from outside the city."
In recent years the university has tried to involve residents more in planning and has sought to be attentive to their concerns.
"I think the important thing is for us to always be open to hear about people's concerns and aspirations for their neighborhood and for us to be as responsive as we can," said Emily Lloyd, Columbia's executive vice president for administration. It is to the university's benefit, she said, that the area remain a dynamic neighborhood. 
"That's what people like about it," she said. "It's not Hanover, New Hampshire."
Former opponents give Columbia credit. 
"Columbia has become more and more interested in working with what I refer to as the lifers," said Ms. Hohol, the 111th Street activist. "Because we're the memory. And there aren't a whole lot of us left."
But not everyone grants Columbia the purest of motives in today's more prosperous, less contentious times. Columbia's leaders are taking a gentler tack because they can, said Robert Roistacher, head of the Morningside Heights Residents Association, who praises the current administration. The administrators are in an easier situation "because they don't have to do the ugly, dirty work," Mr. Roistacher said.
"They can sit back and have decent reputations," he said.
The need for new buildings is in part a matter of numbers. Columbia's student population has swelled from 15,000 in 1975 to 20,000 today, plus more than 5,000 employees, as well as 4,900 students at Teachers College, and 2,300 at Barnard.
It wasn't Columbia, though, that provoked the most recent anger. That distinction goes to the Manhattan School of Music for breaking ground in April for a 21-story residence at 123rd Street and Broadway with little notice to the community.
"It was the most arrogant, disgusting lack of concern for their neighbors I have ever witnessed," said Mr. O'Donnell of Community Board 9. "You want to make Donald Trump look like a nice guy? Behave like the Manhattan School of Music."
David Rahm, the school's chairman, said that after planning and discussing a building on the site several times without success, "We wanted to wait until we had everything, the financing plans and permits in place, before we officially announced construction of the building." The size of the building was also reduced, to 19 stories.

The Scenery Changes, But the Spirit Survives
What about the intangibles of Morningside Heights? A case can be made that, as with the lime rickeys at the Mill, plenty of the old spirit survives.
Though the Squirrel Lady died in June, and is mourned by the creatures of 111th Street that she fed, distinctive characters still wander the neighborhood streets. They include the peacocks that strut around the grounds of St. John the Divine, the used-book sellers on Broadway, and Bobby, more formally known as Robert Fibel, 57, who wears a satin baseball jacket, runs errands for shopkeepers and changes the calendar pages at the local Chase branch.
The Saturday touch football game started in the late 60's by a group of Columbia graduate students continues in Riverside Park, many generations and rickety knees later. A walk along Broadway can still mean an endless series of street corner conversations. 
The Moon Palace, a longtime Chinese restaurant that gave Paul Auster the title for his 1989 novel, closed in 1991. But neighborhood institutions like Mondel's chocolate store, the Symposium Greek restaurant, the V & T pizzeria and the Hungarian pastry shop still flourish. So does Tom's Restaurant, whose facade became embedded in the cultural landscape thanks to a Suzanne Vega song and, more widely, as the diner frequented by the "Seinfeld" characters.
New institutions, like the Mill in its latest incarnation, have begun their own traditions. Mr. Yun has already built up a loyal clientele and has watched local children grow up.
Mr. Yun, 60, has worked many a job in his life, but, commuting to the city from Nyack, in Rockland County, he is well settled in his restaurant, surrounded by Korean wall hangings, masks and calligraphy. "I enjoy life here," he said. "It is now part of my home here, like part of my hometown."
Thanks to the neighborhood's institutional nature, remoteness from Midtown, and character as a place where people both live and work, its past is unlikely to be entirely erased. The Landmarks Preservation Commission says it is considering creating a historic district within Morningside Heights. 
Mall-type stores and large chains are not seen as imminent threats. And the university's current development policy, as set out in a 1998 planning document, is aimed at "enhancing the neighborhood by reinforcing its essential characteristics and architectural setting." 
Maybe what is disappearing fastest from Morningside Heights is collective memory.
How many people remember the bitter struggle over the Columbia gym, or the anti-Vietnam War battles with police, or the sit-ins against evictions from Columbia-owned buildings in the 1960's?
Of an earlier era, how many remember that the West End was the haunt of Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and William Burroughs? Who knows Morningside Heights as the land of Lionel Trilling and the Van Dorens, Mark and Carl of literary fame and Charles of quiz-show infamy? Who recalls it as the prowling ground of Whittaker Chambers on spy duty?
Who remembers the poor who made the place truly a crossroads of class, now that only 2 of the 33 S.R.O. hotels that existed in 1961 remain? 
Recent history seems to be joining the remote past in the well of oblivion. Few people probably know of Morningside Heights' earliest structures, the Bloomingdale Insane Asylum, founded in 1821, and the Leake & Watts Orphan Asylum, built in 1843. A rectangular chunk of the orphanage, with paint peeling off its classical columns, still squats next to St. John the Divine. Though renovated and put to use by the cathedral, it stands where the long-envisioned south transept is destined to arise. Cathedral officials say that could be many years away.
Who knows if you will still be able to find a lime rickey then.

(Photographs by Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)(pg. 1); FACES OF THE HEIGHTS: -- Sung Kun Yun and his wife, Chun Hee, top, serve Korean food -- and lime rickeys -- at the Mill Luncheonette. Barbara Hohol, middle, a lifelong resident, mourns "the loss of the sense of history" that gentrification has wrought. For Altagracia Hiraldo, here in her husband's karate school, the new prosperity threatens the sense of community. "This is not a neighborhood that needs rich people," she said. (pg. 11)

HEADLINE: MUTUAL FUNDS REPORT; 
After a Dreadful Year, Signs Of a Brighter Future Overseas

BYLINE:  By VIVIAN MARINO 

 BODY:
FUND investors who tried to escape Wall Street's volatility last year, especially during the final quarter, found little solace by venturing overseas. 
 But some managers of international funds see opportunities ahead, particularly in Europe. Many stocks are attractively priced, and more companies are improving shareholder values through mergers and acquisitions, new management and stock buybacks. Some managers also find potential value in parts of Latin America and Asia. 
 "World stocks, outside technology and telecommunications, over the next 12 to 36 months should do extremely well," said David G. Herro, portfolio manager for the Oakmark International fund, which invests in Europe, Latin America and the Pacific Rim. "I say this with a sense of caution, though, instead of a sense of euphoria."
Fund investors put an estimated $50 billion more into international equity funds than they took out in 2000, which brought assets to around $532 billion last year, compared with $584 billion in 1999, according to Strategic Insight, a fund research firm in New York.
Yet there were few rewards for those investors. Last year was the sixth in the last seven years that the average international fund failed to keep pace with its domestic counterpart. The international funds lost 6.56 percent in the fourth quarter, on average, and 15.02 percent for the year, while United States equity funds fell 8.47 percent for the quarter and 1.26 percent for the year, according to Morningstar Inc. The biggest laggards were funds invested in the emerging markets and Japan, where economies remain in the doldrums. 
There was no carry-over from 1999, when international funds rose around 50 percent, on average, riding high on the good fortunes of Internet and telecommunications stocks. Instead, many foreign funds that invested heavily in technology plunged last year, as deeply as their American counterparts. 
THE funds' problems were compounded by rising oil prices and adverse currency movements, particularly the slide of the euro, which, along with a decline in the Japanese yen, further eroded dollar-denominated returns. The euro lost 6 percent of its value against the dollar last year, although many experts suggest that the currency has hit a bottom and will slowly start to move up this year. "The euro clearly hurt," said Kunal Kapoor, a senior analyst at Morningstar, "but technology and telecommunications was the big story."
For the most part, funds with little exposure to technology fared best. Many, like Mr. Herro's $753 million Oakmark International fund, or the $6.15 billion Oppenheimer Global fund and the $128 million Atlas Global Growth, beat or offset the downward trend by focusing more on undervalued, often old-economy, stocks. Oakmark International had a 7.4 percent return for the fourth quarter and 12.5 percent for the full year. Oppenheimer Global lost 3.5 percent for the quarter but gained 4.1 percent for the year, while Atlas had a 4 percent quarterly loss and a 3.2 percent annual gain.
Mr. Herro, 40, director of international equities at Harris Associates of Chicago, an adviser to the Oakmark Family of Funds, said he had steadily pulled out of technology and telecommunications as they became increasingly overvalued. "We looked a little silly" at first, he recalled. "But we viewed what was happening overseas in the last 12 to 18 months as a speculative bubble. What we did was lighten up on those things that have done very well for us."
Only about 1 percent of the fund's portfolio remains in technology. A majority is now in industrial cyclicals, financial services and consumer durables, mostly in Europe. Of course, even those sectors could falter if Europe's economy slows significantly and the euro fails to rebound.
Some of the biggest contributors to Oakmark's performance, Mr. Herro said, were Diageo, the giant British food and spirits company; Somerfield, a British grocery store chain; Hunter Douglas, the Dutch manufacturer of window coverings; and Metso, the Finnish paper-making equipment company. Yet these companies remain undervalued despite good earnings. he added.
Mr. Herro says an increasing number of European companies are making an effort to improve shareholder returns, often under the watchful eye of American shareholders and pension fund systems that are being privatized in Europe. Companies are initiating mergers, spinning off units or buying back more of their shares, he said. "They recognize that their stock price is really a source of capital -- they have to have a healthy share price if they want to use that as capital to expand," he said.
Among those attracted to Europe by the new dedication to shareholders is William Wilby, 56, the fund manager of Oppenheimer Global and Atlas Global Growth. He favors companies like the German automaker Porsche. "It is a classic case of a company that is restructuring," he said. "It had new management five or six years ago and revamped its product lineup," which will include its first sport utility vehicle in 2002. He also likes Reckitt Benckiser, a British household cleaning products company, which, he said, is "not vulnerable to a technical downturn," and one of his American holdings, Cadence Design Systems of San Jose, Calif., a maker of software used to design computer chips. 
Mr. Wilby also sees long-term opportunities in Latin America, where there has been a steady move toward privatization of state-owned companies. Among his favorites is Televisa of Mexico, which has a huge library of Spanish-language films. Like many other managers of international funds, he remains wary about Japan. But he sees investment opportunities in select companies, including Eisai, the health care concern that has developed a drug for Alzheimer's disease, and Kyocera, a manufacturer of electronic equipment.
Oppenheimer Global still has a sizable exposure to technology -- roughly 19 percent, compared with 18 percent in health care, 16 percent in financial services and 13 percent in consumer cyclicals, the majority of them in Europe. But the fund has been moving out of technology stocks. "The market was exceptionally frothy," he said. "It's going to be several years before they come back."
Not all international funds with high exposure to technology did poorly last year, however. One standout was the $23 million Amidex35 fund, which invests in stocks of the 35 largest Israeli companies, about two-thirds of them in technology or related businesses. Most of these stocks trade on the Nasdaq. 
The fund lost 16.95 percent for the fourth quarter but it gained 19.15 percent for the year. Its largest holdings include Check Point, a leader in Internet security; Amdocs, which provides billing software to big telephone companies; and Mercury Interactive, which helps improve Web site performance.
Boaz Rahav, 31, the Amidex35 manager, said Israeli technology companies had outperformed their counterparts around the world because many offer innovative products and services not readily available elsewhere. "Not all superior solutions in technology are in the United States," he said.

HEADLINE: MONEY & MEDICINE; 
Learning to Manage Managed Care

BYLINE:  By JENNIFER STEINHAUER; Jennifer Steinhauer covers health care for The Times. Her column on the economics of health care appears the first Sunday of each month. E-mail: jestei@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
 WHEN is a disease rare enough to require a medical specialist outside an insurance network? The answer is less obvious than one might believe. While tonsillitis in even the smallest town could be treated by the local doctor, Ebola virus in Manhattan would clearly require some extremely specialized advice. 
 But Joseph Burke's case was not so clear, and the morass he entered underscores how the worst of illnesses can create the most complicated insurance problems. Central to his case is a clinical difference in opinion (was his cancer truly rare?) and a technical issue (was the out-of-network care he believes he needed initiated in the proper manner?). 
Mr. Burke was 26 and working for Viacom in 1998 when he noticed one day that his left breast was sore and swollen. His primary care doctor surmised that he had an ingrown hair and sent him on his way.
A month later, no improvement. A month after that, he began having horrible headaches. He could not get into the subway in the morning without being soaked with sweat. He said a call to his doctor yielded this diagnosis: the flu. "At this point I felt as if I were a hypochondriac," he said recently. "I decided to just stop calling the doctor." 
He began to research his symptoms, and one potential cause for them left him shaken. He was at the right age for testicular cancer, and other members of his family had suffered from cancer. Subsequent tests and CAT scans confirmed the worst. Six months after the original breast pain, the cancer had spread well beyond his testicles. His doctor, he said, referred him immediately to Dr. George Basl, a specialist in testicular cancer at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York.
Mr. Burke felt lucky in one respect: As a member of the Freedom Plan of Oxford Health Plans, he understood that he could go to an out-of-network doctor, as long as he paid his $3,000 deductible. But then came the technical rub. Under that plan, a patient has two choices when he goes out of network. Do it without a referral, and accept that the insurance company will only pay 90 percent of what it considers reasonable and customary payment for the services rendered. Or get precertification to go out of network from the in-network doctor -- given ostensibly because the patient needs specialized care -- and receive full coverage.
MR. BURKE said he had numerous conversations with Oxford representatives to clear full payment for his coverage. Oxford said clearance was never given. Further, no one can agree on whether Mr. Burke was even officially referred to Dr. Basl by his primary care doctor. A spokeswoman for the insurance company, Maria Gordon Shydlo, said Oxford had no record of the referral, although Mr. Burke was able to provide Dr. Basl's letter to the referring physician. Dr. Basl said he had no idea what arrangements were made regarding the referral.
But then again, Ms. Shydlo said, the referral would have been moot without the precertification, a process dropped by a competing company, the UnitedHealth Group, in 1999, because it so enraged doctors and patients and, as it turned out, saved the company no money.
Mr. Burke, who now works for Monster.com and is no longer covered by Oxford, appealed to Oxford on the basis that he had a rare disease that only a few hospitals specialized in treating, and that he was misdiagnosed by an in-network provider for six months. That appeal was denied. Ms. Shydlo said: "Oxford's network has some of the finest oncologists at the finest hospitals."
So how rare is testicular cancer? The disease was diagnosed in roughly 6,900 American men in 2000, according to the American Cancer Society, compared with 180,400 diagnoses of prostate cancer and 89,500 of all lung malignancies. In the United States, cancer of some form was expected to be diagnosed in 619,700 men during 2000.
While Dr. Basl refused to discuss Mr. Burke's case specifically, he contributed to an article in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute in 1999 that concluded that the treatment of advanced testicular cancer is generally more successful in centers that do a high volume of cases. (Memorial Sloan-Kettering treated 2,023 such cases from 1995 to 2000.) 
Ross Sadler, the assistant director for managed care at a large New York hospital that he insisted not be identified, said that whether or not Mr. Burke had gone through the precertification process, the issue should have been brushed aside, given the seriousness of his disease and his diagnosis delay, which had dire consequences. 
As for Sloan-Kettering, it would like its money -- $16,429.23 for all services -- from anyone, and has sued Mr. Burke, who is in remission, to get it. Mr. Sadler advises consumers to ask their doctors for proof that they have been precertified once a referral is made, and to do what benefits managers do all day: carefully study the fine print. 
"It comes down to the basics, being aware of your plan," he said. "Once you understand it, don't give up. Apply the 10-call rule. Call 10 times in one day; you will get your message across."

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: RIDGEWOOD -- CITYPEOPLE; 
Decorum and a Touch of Runyon Mark a Career at the Wheel of a Hearse

BYLINE:  By DAVID KOEPPEL

 BODY:
When Ray Brenciforte came home from the Korean War, the city's economy was booming and so were its mostly mom-and-pop funeral homes. A limousine to a local cemetery back then might cost as little as $33.
 After a stint delivering air-conditioners, Mr. Brenciforte got a union job driving a hearse for a Brooklyn livery service. While being a funeral chauffeur might not be "much of a station in life," he said, it gave him steady work and a stable way to support his family. So he has stayed at it, for the last 40 years. 
 Mr. Brenciforte has worked for the last 25 years for Castarelli's, a livery service in Ridgewood, Queens. To him, the world of chauffeurs, funeral directors and cemetery workers is not nearly as bleak as it seems, peopled by Runyonesque characters with colorful nicknames and outsize personalities.
There was Jimmy Coca-Cola, a driver with an unusual penchant for the soft drink. There was Tonto and Tammany and Joe Black, nicknamed not for his funereal disposition but for his dark olive skin.
If the nostalgic New York that Mr. Brenciforte remembers ever really existed, he acknowledged that it is long gone now. As he sees it, dedicated and empathetic union drivers have been replaced by per diem hacks, and the funeral director with the personal touch has been superseded by corporate suits. Motorists, who once treated a funeral procession as something sacred, now show little regard.
"They just don't respect it," said Mr. Brenciforte, who lives in Midwood, Brooklyn. "It's a real problem. Sometimes people will make obscene gestures at me. They'll cut right in and block a funeral, they couldn't care less. Traffic is worse than ever."
Leading a procession of a dozen or more cars filled with grieving family members and guiding them safely to the cemetery can be tricky on the city's labyrinthine roads, he said.
"I try to put them at ease," Mr. Brenciforte said of drivers in the procession. "I tell them to stay alert and to take it nice and slow." 
He added, "A lot of people don't really understand the nature of the funeral business. It's about empathy, about putting yourself in the family's place." 
Mr. Brenciforte is a published poet whose taste runs from Whitman to Wilde. He has written a poem about the funeral business that he refers to as his "dirge," a dark tribute to the job to which he has devoted his life.
But Mr. Brenciforte has recently cut back to driving two funerals a week. He no longer spends much time at the "barn" (the livery term for a garage) and has seen many colleagues retire or die.
As he winds down, his appreciation for his job grows.
"I realized I'm performing a necessary service," he said. "When people tell me you did a nice job, that I was dignified and polite, that gives me a great feeling." DAVID KOEPPEL

GRAPHIC: Photos: To Ray Brenciforte, the world of funeral chauffeurs is not nearly as bleak as it seems. (Photographs by Rebecca Cooney for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE; 
A Troubled Plaza Shows Up Close to Home

BYLINE:  By ANDREW FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
Public plazas have been in the news. 
 Last fall, a major report was issued pinpointing plazas around the city that legally should be open to the public because they were built in exchange for allowing developers to build larger and taller buildings. 
 Soon after, 70 volunteers from the Municipal Art Society and community boards fanned out around the city to survey the accessibility, quality and amenities of those plazas. 
One who took to the streets was Holly Leicht, the society's director of design planning and advocacy. She was dismayed to find a problem close to home, the plaza at the Revere, a condominium at 54th Street near First Avenue.
"It was like a concrete wasteland with a couple of pathetic trees," said Ms. Leicht, who lives on the Upper East Side. Construction debris had taken over the plaza, she said, a gate stood in front of the entrance and the site was locked at night. 
The 6,500-square-foot site also includes a section on First Avenue where a Starbucks cafe has placed tables and chairs. In the report on New York's public plazas, which was written by the society, the City Planning Department and Jerold S. Kayden of Harvard University, the plaza was rated "marginal," the worst of five categories. Legally, the study says, the plaza should be open 24 hours a day and should never used for storage or what Mr. Kayden calls "cafe creep."
Jonathan West, board president of the Revere, said equipment had been stored on the site while the lobby and stairs were being renovated, a project set to be completed in the spring. Anyone can sit in front of Starbucks, he added, whether a patron or not. He said the gate was designed to keep homeless people out of the space. 
Mr. Kayden said extended renovations and fears about the homeless are often used as excuses when owners encroach on public spaces. 
Since the study was published, the city has stepped up enforcement. The Law Department has filed suits against owners of three offending buildings, the Buildings Department has 30 enforcement actions pending and the City Planning Department has written to 16 owners whose buildings are in violation. ANDREW FRIEDMAN

HEADLINE: Word for Word/Tweaking the W.T.O.; 
The Long and Winding Cyberhoax: Political Theater on the Web

BYLINE:  By BARNABY J. FEDER 

 BODY:
IT'S well known that some regions of cyberspace -- Internet chat rooms, for instance -- are rife with poseurs and imaginary characters. But the World Wide Web is also a breeding ground for more elaborate deceptions, as demonstrated by the following cautionary tale about gall and gullibility in the information age. 
 The story begins with www.gatt.org, which looks at first glance like an official Web site of the World Trade Organization, the five-year-old Switzerland-based successor to the organization that oversaw the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Unfortunately for the organizers of an October legal seminar on international trade in Salzburg, Austria, a glance was all they gave it before clicking on the "contact" link and sending a speaking invitation to Mike Moore, the W.T.O.'s director-general. 
 Big mistake: it turns out the site is run by the Yes Men, a loose-knit group of anti-free-trade activists that views hoaxes as a legitimate weapon of protest. 
Excerpts of what transpired follow, culled from e-mail correspondence and faxes posted at www.theyesmen.org/wto. BARNABY J. FEDER
It didn't take long for the Yes Men to accept the invitation in Mr. Moore's name, with a caveat:
Thank you for your kind invitation. 
I may not be able to attend personally, but I would like very much to send a substitute. Would this be possible? Please let me know and I will begin the search process. 
Thank you,
Mike Moore
The director of the seminar's sponsor was happy to oblige:
Dear Mr. Moore: 
Michael Devine advises me that you wish to send a staff member to speak at the 26-29 October conference in Salzburg. 
If you will confirm name of the individual and contact information, I will have further information sent. 
Regards, Dennis Campbell
Center for International Legal Studies
At this point, Charles Cushen, a computer programmer in Los Angeles who had been masquerading as Mr. Moore and "Alice Foley," Mr. Moore's secretary, created Andreas Bichlbauer (choosing the name at random from a Vienna phone book), and made travel arrangements for Dr. Bichlbauer and two "security agents," including a cameraman. Dr. Bichlbauer raised eyebrows with his speech, titled "Trade Regulation Relaxation and Concepts of Incremental Improvement: Governing Perspectives from 1970 to the Present":
Dear Ms. Foley: 
We were somewhat puzzled by Dr. Bichlbauer's participation at the conference. . . .
The essential thrust of his speech appeared to be that Italians have a lesser work ethic than the Dutch, that Americans would be better off auctioning their votes in the presidential election to the highest bidder and that the primary role of the W.T.O. was to create a one-world culture. 
In the late afternoon, a cameraman (I think it was the same one who filmed Dr. Bichlbauer's speech) appeared at the hotel and sought to interview our delegates. He said Dr. Bichlbauer had been hit in the face with a pie outside the hotel and wanted to know if the delegates thought Dr. Bichlbauer's speech had provoked the attack. . . .
Several of our delegates (including work-ethic impaired Italians) approached me to express concern about the speech, the alleged pie incident and the cameraman who sought interviews in the late afternoon. 
Your clarification will be appreciated. 
Regards, Dennis Campbell
Alice Foley's immediate reply:
Indeed you are correct, Dr. Bichlbauer was in fact "pied" after speaking at the Salzburg C.I.L.S. conference. At present we are not completely certain of all the details, but it appears that the cameraman you mention had something to do with it. . . . This cameraman . . . seems to have essentially been an agent provocateur who planned the pieing from the start. . . .
We hope you understand that this sort of incident reflects primarily the unfortunate circumstances under which the W.T.O. must accomplish its work, and that our security can never be entirely adequate to the situations we face.
After another message from Mr. Campbell in which he reiterated that some delegates found Dr. Bichlbauer's remarks offensive or flippant, the doctor offered his side of the story:
I was disappointed to hear from Alice Foley that some people in the audience on Saturday disliked my lecture. . . . Those who were upset by the lecture were clearly unreceptive to any message departing from the simple W.T.O. "party line" as it is presented in larger arenas. At this conference we hoped to examine this "party line" through repackaging in a clearer and more carefully delineated fashion, for the sake of more lucid examination and a greater awareness of "issue extremes" for use in more politic descriptions -- those intended for the consumption of larger blocs of the consuming public. . . . 
Two days later, hoping to elicit further response, Mr. Cushen slipped again into his Mr. Moore persona:
Dear Professor Campbell: 
I was dismayed to learn of your unfortunate experience with our representative, Andreas Bichlbauer. . . . I will recommend that Dr. Bichlbauer be required to attend a refresher course on public speaking, communication and policy before any further appearances on behalf of the W.T.O. . . . 
However, having examined the presentation exhaustively, I am forced to conclude that never in any particulars do Dr. Bichlbauer's statements . . . depart from the spirit -- if not the precise letter -- of our intentions and aims. That is, while we of course do not advocate vote-selling or siesta-banning at the present time, it is quite true that efficiency and the streamlining of culture and politics in the interests of economic liberalization is at the core of the W.T.O.'s programme, and such practices as described by Dr. Bichlbauer are useful in clarifying the long-range interests of global development as promoted by our organization and others.
On Nov. 1, Alice Foley had more bad news for Professor Campbell:
The situation has, I regret to say, somewhat deteriorated from an already unpleasant state of affairs: Dr. Bichlbauer has contracted a rather serious infection from the pie, which forensic analysis shows contained an active bacillus agent. It is not certain whether foul play was involved. . . . I know that this question will sound harsh, but could any of the lawyers present have been angry enough at Dr. Bichlbauer's lecture to do this? . . .
On Nov. 6, using addresses collected in Salzburg, Alice Foley e-mailed six conference participants with the message that Dr. Bichlbauer was near death from his infection and concluding:
Please, please let us know if anything at the conference struck you as strange, or if you can imagine anyone performing this masterpiece of cowardice, that so threatens to delete Dr. Bichlbauer from our midst in the prime of his usefulness.
A similar e-mail message sent two weeks later to 77 delegates elicited a range of responses, most indicating that the insult to Italian work habits had made the biggest impression. Dr. Bichlbauer's death was announced via e-mail on Nov. 27. The legal center's response on Nov. 29 provided the first clear sign that it finally recognized the hoax and asked the Yes Men to "let it rest." Alice Foley issued the following pseudo-clarification to the delegates:
Those who found Dr. Bichlbauer's talk "peculiar," "puzzling" and so on were alert to a situation that has only now become clear to our overcentralized eyes: Dr. Bichlbauer was an impostor! . . . He, his "security guard" and his "cameraman" . . . belong, it turns out, to an anti-trade cabal called "The Yes Men," whose interests run exactly counter to our own, and who will stoop to any level whatsoever to make points. (The point they were attempting to make with this trickery, according to the handwritten letter which we received by this morning's post, had something to do with "corporate power" and "democracy," though the syntax and handwriting of the letter are, truth be told, too execrable to make much of. . . . It is of course extremely embarrassing to us that we can have been conned, like common dowagers, in this way. . . .
Postscript: A W.T.O. spokesman said last week that while his organization deplored the Yes Men's deceptive Web site and the hoax, it respects the nature of the Internet as a forum for free expression. Mr. Cushen said "Mr. Moore" had recently received an invitation to a textile conference in Finland and that his group was hoping to scrape together the money needed to send a successor to Dr. Bichlbauer. "We think the ethical thing to do is to represent the W.T.O. more honestly than they represent themselves," he said.

HEADLINE: FIVE QUESTIONS for CHARLES S. GIAMBUSSO; 
Delta's Labor Troubles: View From the Cockpit

BYLINE:  By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
THE storms that jolted much of the country over the New Year's holiday hit Delta Air Lines particularly hard. Because many of its pilots have declined to fly voluntary overtime, Delta said it was forced to cancel hundreds of flights, stranding thousands of passengers. 
 The airline announced last week that it would cut its schedule by nearly 3 percent to compensate for the shortage of pilots. This week, Delta plans to appeal a federal judge's refusal to issue an injunction against the Air Line Pilots Association in what Delta calls an illegal job action. 
 Charles S. Giambusso, 50, is head of the Delta chapter of the Air Line Pilots Association, which represents nearly 10,000 pilots. He is based in Salt Lake City, where he is a Boeing 727 captain. He spoke last week on the day the airline and the union resumed their contract negotiations.
 LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN

Q. Delta contends that the union and pilots are orchestrating a slowdown to pressure it in bargaining. Is that true?

A. It is absolutely not true that the union is orchestrating any kind of slowdown or job action. In fact, we have done just the opposite. We have been trying to encourage the pilots to work extra overtime and help the company out during a time when they are short of pilots. The pilot group itself has spontaneously reacted in a way that has been negative. And it has been exacerbated by the company's decision to use litigation to try to force the pilots to do something that they are not legally obligated to do.

Q. Why are pilots at Delta so angry?

A. I think their patience reached an end in late October. We had been negotiating since September of '99 and our amendable date the day the terms of the previous contract ended was May 2. At the end of October, the company put their counterproposal on pay on the table. Many pilots were quite disappointed.

Q. Isn't it irresponsible and even unethical for pilots to inconvenience passengers as part of a dispute with management?

A. The pilots aren't looking at it that way. They are very intelligent, highly educated guys, and they understand that it is important that our customers are well served. Over the summer, pilots flew a record amount of overtime. I think that when the holidays came around, many pilots decided that they could not maintain that pace and wanted to spend some time with their families. A few pilots might be trying to stir the pot, but there was no concerted effort to do anything to harm customers, or really even harm the company.

Q. Where are the gaps between the two sides?

A. We are still apart on pay. The company's proposal does not create an industry-leading pay proposal for us. We are apart on retirement and we're significantly apart on scope, or job-protection issues. But we are still at the bargaining table. I have a high expectation that there will be progress at the table.

Q. With the economy weakening now, aren't the expectations of labor groups at Delta and other airlines exceptionally high? Aren't you in danger of crippling the airline?

A. We have gone for over four years during the boom times in the airline industry working at discounted rates because we gave concessions in '96 because they had had a previous period of bad performance. Now we are looking for a return on that investment. We are very realistic in our analysis of what the company can afford. We have no desire to cripple the company.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH; 
A Voice That Says a Rate Cut Is Not the Cure for All Ills

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
SINCE the Federal Reserve Board cut interest rates last Wednesday, le tout Wall Street has risen up like a chorus, saying that stocks are always the best place to be when rates are falling. Well, pas exactement.
 One who has not joined the crowd is Byron R. Wien, chief United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and one of those rarities anywhere -- an independent thinker. "It isn't a sure thing that just because the Fed eases, the stock market goes up," Mr. Wien said. "The key differentiating factor is whether we are in a recession." 
 Investors can be forgiven for wanting to believe that rate cuts from Mr. Greenspan translate automatically into stock market gains. That is, after all, what their recent experience has taught them. "Everyone remembers what happened when the Fed eased in 1995 and 1998," Mr. Wien said. "But both were because of financial crises, not recessions." The 1995 crisis started with the devaluation of the Mexican peso, and the more recent turmoil was a result of Russia's default on its debt and the collapse of the huge hedge fund, Long-Term Capital Management. 
Longer memories are required, however, if investors are to recall the way stocks reacted to rate cuts that were prompted by a recession. Mr. Wien has gone back 10 years to help explode the myth that just because the Fed eases, stocks always rally strongly. 
In June 1989, after a period of rising interest rates, the Fed began to ease, initially cutting the Fed funds target rate from 9.81 percent to 9.56 percent. The day of the first cut, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index stood at 326.69. 
Roughly 18 months later, when Fed funds were at 7 percent and the nation was in recession, the S.& P. had risen a mere 2 points, to 328.72. 
Stocks did rally somewhat during that time, of course. In July 1990, the S.& P. index traded as high as 368.95, a gain of 13 percent from the June 1989 level. But investors who held on wound up making no money during the period. Only in early 1991, when investors sensed that the recession was ending, did stocks start to stir. 
No one knows, of course, if what is now just an economic slowdown will turn into a recession, defined as two consecutive quarters of negative growth in gross domestic product. Mr. Wien, for one, thinks that the economy will dip into a shallow and relatively short recession in the first half of this year. And the employment report last Friday, which showed a sharp falloff in labor demand, only cemented his view. 
Although stocks rallied wildly on the Fed's move last Wednesday, they spent the remainder of the week skulking back into negative territory. The Dow Jones industrial average closed the week down 1.2 percent and the Nasdaq composite lost 2.5 percent of its value during the first week of 2001.
"This economy is unraveling at a very rapid rate," Mr. Wien said. He also believes that economic recovery in the second half will be muted and that corporate profit surprises will be more downside than up.
As a result, investors who think they can jump back into stocks with both feet just because the Fed is behind them should consider an alternative investment: boring, dull United States Treasury bonds.
As the Fed cuts rates aggressively this year, Mr. Wien thinks that yields on the 10-year Treasury could drop to 4 percent. That is a sharp decline from Friday's close of 4.93 percent. If Mr. Wien is correct, the decline would translate to a gain of roughly 8 percent for an owner of such a security, not counting the 5.75 percent coupon. And at virtually no risk to capital.
Although Mr. Wien conceded that corporate bonds, particularly those of lower-quality issuers, look attractive at current prices, he is hesitant to recommend them as ardently as Treasuries. Investors picking through the junk-bond market must be extremely selective, he said, because the economic slowdown will probably bring a raft of bankruptcies among these companies.
There is no doubt that the Fed will do what it must to rescue the economy. But don't look to stocks to star again soon.

HEADLINE: Of Church, State and Journalism 

BYLINE:  By FELICITY BARRINGER 

DATELINE: SALT LAKE CITY 

 BODY:
THIS city has a simple logic. First Street begins a block from the temple of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints; the remainder of the streets radiate out from there. The map mirrors Utah's civic life. For Mormons and non-Mormons alike -- the city's population is split about 50-50 -- the central reference point is the church. It is the spiritual home of 11 million members and the financial repository of an estimated $20 billion in assets.
 Over the last 18 months, AT&T executives have learned Salt Lake's psychic map all too well. Their effort to unload The Salt Lake Tribune, an $81-million-a-year pipsqueak of a business within their $112 billion corporate empire, has aroused sectarian resentments that this prosperous, seemingly placid city cannot seem to shake. 
 At the center of it are the morning Tribune, founded 129 years ago by Mormon dissidents, and its afternoon rival, the church-owned Deseret News. Each is run by executives who assert that their paper's core values -- or its survival -- face a mortal threat from the other. Though viscerally at odds over business strategy, they handcuffed themselves together in a joint operating agreement under which they share presses, circulation crews and advertising staff members. The arrangement, 48 years old, has kept both in business and profitable, but it has also bred allegations of mismanagement and bad faith. Each newsroom periodically grumbles that the other skews the news. 
AT&T stumbled inadvertently into this beehive. It got The Tribune when it bought the newspaper's owner, TeleCommunications Inc., the cable television company based in Englewood, Colo. Almost as soon as the TCI deal closed, AT&T began looking to sell the newspaper so it could focus on expanding cable services. Two years later, that cable strategy is dead -- AT&T decided to spin off the business last year -- though it took the company until last week to reach a deal. The company agreed to sell the paper to the MediaNews Group for $200 million to try to end the irritation. Tribune executives lost their first court challenge to block the deal, but plan to be back in federal court with new claims this week.
Unlike cable companies or Internet services or insurance brokers, newspapers have complicated, often passionate relationships with the communities they serve. The Tribune does not rank in the top 75 newspapers nationally; it sells about 135,000 copies daily in a state with 2.2 million people. But its size belies its role as a civic counterweight to the Mormon Church in Salt Lake, one of the fastest-growing markets in the country.
The financial, legal and political path that put The Tribune in the hands of MediaNews Group is a tale from which different witnesses extract different lessons. James E. Shelledy, The Tribune's editor, told his readers in a Dec. 3 "letter from the editor" that the "L.D.S. leadership, quite understandably, wants its sectarian spin on certain news events to have at least as loud a voice as The Tribune's, however that is attained."
John Hughes, Mr. Shelledy's counterpart at The Deseret News, sees the sale as the logical conclusion of an unworkable business partnership. "The management of The Tribune," he said, "repressed and oppressed The Deseret News." AT&T executives view it as a way out of an untenable situation that was tying up resources.
CONVENIENTLY enough, the deal with MediaNews, headed by W. Dean Singleton, also satisfied church officials, whose cooperation can help any corporation wanting to expand telephone or cable operations in Utah, the fourth-fastest-growing state in the country.
The fight has left this city's air thick with mistrust and the residue of grievances, old and new. And at the psychic center of it all is the church. With suspicions unsupported by clear evidence, some non-Mormons fear that The Tribune -- the newspaper that speaks for them, without fearing or favoring the church -- is about to fall silent.
"I think any time you have one powerful institution and particularly a predominant religion in a community, those who are not part of that feel that there is an excessive, excessive control, especially politically," said Ross C. Anderson, the city's Democratic mayor.
"Although the L.D.S. church does not often get involved in political issues, when it does, its position seems to dictate exactly what's going to happen in our legislature," he continued. "And that obviously causes resentment among those who don't feel adequately represented." About 90 percent of state legislators are Mormon Church members, as is the state's senior United States Senator, Orrin G. Hatch, the chairman of the Senate Judiciary Committee.
Mr. Shelledy, who has been The Tribune's editor for a decade, said the situation in Salt Lake had no parallel. "While there are a lot of Catholics in Boston and a lot of Jews in New York and a lot of Baptists in Tulsa, those particular religions do not have the business structure that the Mormon Church has, nor anywhere near the intensity it has in this state," he said. "There's a dual function here. There's a religious function of the church and a business function of the church and it all runs out of one office." In this situation, he added, "the check and balance ends up being the paper that says: 'Hey, wait a minute here, is this really what we want to do?' "
Mr. Shelledy has run many articles asking uncomfortable questions about the church. The Tribune has examined a successful church proposal to buy part of Main Street and turn it into a church-controlled plaza, and it has written about the difficulties of Mormons who are openly gay. Last year, it ran a three-part series on one of the most painful incidents in church history, a Mormon-led massacre in 1857 of California-bound settlers at a place in southern Utah called Mountain Meadows.
Still, the resentment here works both ways. Some church members contend that Mormons are held to a double standard. For instance, they say a Utah resident who speaks out against loosening of local liquor laws for the 2002 Winter Olympics is seen as religiously motivated, whereas an Australian taking the same position before the Sydney Olympics last summer would not have been.
For observant Mormons, The Tribune is a constant irritant. They complain that it gratuitously rubs the community's nose in less-than-relevant but potentially scandalous moments in Mormon history. When the Mountain Meadows Massacre series ran last March, the church's president, Gordon B. Hinckley, took the unusual step of calling in The Tribune's publisher, Dominic Welch, for a formal dressing-down.
BUT the church's irritation over The Tribune's content was minor, compared with the anger expressed by business executives of The Deseret News. They contend that the managers of The Tribune, which is the managing partner in the joint operating unit, the Newspaper Agency Corporation, have systematically thwarted their legitimate business goals and cost them tens of millions of dollars.
"The Tribune did bring the present pass on themselves," said Mr. Hughes, a courtly, Welsh-born Christian Scientist who served as editor of The Christian Science Monitor and a spokesman for the State Department before becoming the first non-Mormon editor of The Deseret News four years ago. "They have been arrogant over the years."
He and other managers at The Desert News say that under Mr. Welch, the partnership's financial performance has lagged behind the booming economy. They complain that they pay the same amount as The Tribune for extra advertising pages, even though The Tribune's circulation, and costs, are double their own. They wonder if they were overcharged for newsprint from a mill in which Kearns-Tribune, the company that owned The Tribune, had a 6 percent stake.
Most important, they contend that before he was replaced as chief of the joint operating agency last week by The Tribune's new owner, Mr. Welch was putting up costly roadblocks to their plan to change The Deseret News to morning publication, a move they regarded as necessary if the paper was to thrive. The roadblocks included a requirement for a new press, which could cost $15 million or more.
Mr. Welch has dismissed such complaints. "The Deseret News is the failing newspaper," he once wrote in a letter to his bosses at AT&T. "The joint operating agreement was forged to keep it in business." The News, he noted, produced just 30 percent of agency revenues, but got to keep 42 percent of the profits. The News's wish to move to morning publication, he said, would require both papers to ignore late sporting events and government meetings unless someone paid for a "major remodeling" of their joint production facilities. Since The News wants it, he said, The News should pay for it.
The Tribune has held the upper hand in the business partnership from the day it was created in 1952 to keep the then-financially precarious News alive. While the Newspaper Agency Corporation was owned equally by the two newspapers, The Tribune had the right to name the N.A.C.'s president, ceding it effective control. It also had enough clout to eventually sidestep an agreement that nominally gives each paper the right to veto the sale of the other's half of the joint production facility.
Still, the venture was lucrative enough that by 1970, Kearns-Tribune had many other assets, including a silver mining company in the Park City area. Most important, however, it owned about 7 percent of the Class B stock of a small Rocky Mountain cable company that had just had its initial public offering. That company was TeleCommunications, and each Class B share had 10 times the voting power of ordinary Class A shares.
The value of those supervoting shares boomed as TeleCommunications expanded under its chairman, John Malone. That, in turn, encouraged some restless descendants of Senator Thomas Kearns, who had bought The Tribune in 1901, to try to cash out by selling the closely held Kearns-Tribune. Other family members resisted, largely to retain the newspaper's independence.
One compromise was struck in the 1970's, when several Kearns-Tribune shareholders bought out their relatives. A second came in 1997, when Mr. Malone -- eager to bring the large bloc of supervoting TCI shares under his control -- agreed to vest control of The Tribune with The Salt Lake Tribune Publishing Company, an entity run by The Tribune's managers. He also agreed to give that company the right to buy back the newspaper at its market value five years after the takeover.
The deal, in which Kearns family members and some employees received $731 million in TCI stock tax-free, was sealed that summer. Everyone associated with Kearns-Tribune and TCI had reason to be happy. More than 45 Kearns heirs realized hundreds of millions of dollars, and TCI was free to strip Kearns-Tribune of all assets except The Tribune.
Executives of The Deseret News Publishing Company were less happy. Their right to veto the sale of jointly owned newspaper production facilities -- and, perhaps, exact a little revenge on The Tribune -- was frustrated by the way the sale was arranged. Kearns-Tribune and TCI had swapped stock in the Kearns-Tribune Corporation itself -- which, incidentally, held The Tribune's assets, including its 50 percent share of the newspaper production company. Technically, there was no direct sale of the newspaper's assets.
The only good news for the church-owned publishing company was that it had a new partner and thus a place to appeal Mr. Welch's decisions about the partnership's operations. AT&T officials like Leo Hindery Jr. were sympathetic, and tried to pressure The Tribune's managers to accede to some of The News's demands, particularly those that would permit morning publication. But the impasse proved unbreakable. 
When The Deseret News threatened to sue its rival -- and AT&T, as its parent -- contending various misdeeds, AT&T stepped up efforts to sell The Tribune to its managers or to the church.
In a sworn affidavit in a federal lawsuit brought by the Tribune Publishing Company to block the sale, Steven Garfinkel, an AT&T lawyer, described a situation in which The Deseret News Publishing Company was preparing to sue AT&T, as The Tribune's owner, for $120 million. Deseret complained that AT&T was "failing to adequately promote The Deseret News, misallocating costs of operating the two papers to the advantage of The Tribune, and frustrating Deseret News Publishing in exercising its right" to publish in the morning.
"In order to find a way out of this dispute and dispose of an asset that simply had no place in AT&T's future," Mr. Garfinkel's affidavit continued, "AT&T explored the possibility of a sale of Kearns-Tribune to either" the Salt Lake Tribune Publishing Company or Deseret News Publishing.
The News was interested; Lloyd Poelman, one of its lawyers, said he had attended a meeting at which Senator Hatch was briefed on the talks between AT&T and The News. As chairman of the Judiciary Committee, Senator Hatch, a Republican, could have had a crucial role in scrutinizing any executive branch antitrust ruling on the church's purchase of the only competing daily in Salt Lake.
But the church never intended to silence the voice of The Tribune, Mr. Hughes said. "It's absolute nonsense; it's not so," he said. "We deny it, and they call us liars."
AT&T finally decided that The Deseret News had little taste for an antitrust battle, but was ready to exercise its veto on the sale of jointly owned assets to prevent Tribune managers from buying the bigger paper. So while AT&T continued to negotiate with Mr. Welch and The Tribune's managers, it also opened a line to Mr. Singleton, the chief executive of MediaNews.
In the last 17 years, Mr. Singleton has built MediaNews Group into the seventh-largest United States newspaper chain, with 48 dailies, 88 other publications and annual revenue of more than $1 billion. He had been interested in The Tribune for years. A Baptist, he has a reputation as a hard-driving executive, cost-cutter and competitor. His Denver Post won a bloody circulation war with The Denver Rocky Mountain News.
Mr. Singleton enlisted a Mormon employee, James Wall, the general manager of The Denver Post, to find out whom to talk to at The Deseret News about how it would receive his bid for The Tribune and what The News would want from him as a partner in the production company. (Mr. Wall became publisher of The News last fall.) Mr. Singleton met with L. Glen Snarr, chairman and president of the Deseret News Publishing Company. Most of his requests were "things we were accustomed to" in other joint operating agreements, Mr. Singleton testified later in federal court.
In September, AT&T tried one last time to find a solution acceptable to both warring parties without selling The Tribune to a third party. Even so, Mr. Singleton submitted a bid a month later. AT&T officials said they shelved it.
BY late October, The Tribune's managers had committed to raising the money to buy the newspaper -- Wells Fargo Bank had conditionally agreed to lend them most of the $180 million price -- and to indemnify AT&T against the likely claims of The Deseret News. When the two parties last talked, just before Thanksgiving, the managers had raised their indemnification proposal to $33 million. That was still $17 million short of what AT&T wanted.
But The Tribune's managers believed, as one testified last month in a Federal court hearing, that this and other unresolved issues were just "nits." They expected the deal to close by the end of the year, if not sooner. Mr. Garfinkel, however, testified at the hearing that he did not characterize the open issues as mere "nits." His parting words before the Thanksgiving break, he said, were to the effect of "I'm looking forward to wrapping these things up."
That remark was soon overtaken by events. On the Monday after Thanksgiving, C. Michael Armstrong, AT&T's chairman, directed that negotiations with MediaNews be resumed, an AT&T executive testified. Five days later, on Dec. 1, the deal was done. When Mr. Singleton and an AT&T executive came to The Tribune building to break the news, shocked Tribune managers barred the newspapers' doors and raced to federal court seeking an injunction to block the sale.
On Dec. 15, after a two-day hearing in which the publishers of the two papers pointedly avoided each other, Federal District Judge Tena Campbell denied the request for a temporary order blocking the sale. In her 33-page opinion, Judge Campbell said she had found no compelling evidence that The Tribune would lose its "independent voice and unique characteristics" under MediaNews Group ownership. MediaNews, she continued, "has agreed 'to honor the terms of the management agreement that ensures the independence of The Tribune's reporting and editing functions.' "
AT&T and MediaNews closed the sale when Mr. Singleton paid $200 million in cash and delivered a guarantee from the Deseret News Publication Company renouncing all potential claims against AT&T. (The guarantee had come after Mark H. Willes -- the former chief executive of the Times Mirror Company and a nephew of Mr. Hinckley, the Mormon Church's president -- told The News's editor, John Hughes, that Mr. Singleton would be a reliable business partner.)
Immediately after the sale closed, Mr. Singleton appointed himself and another MediaNews executive as The Tribune's representatives to the newspaper production company jointly owned with The News. Mr. Singleton, now the partnership's chairman for life, followed up by presiding over a vote by the board to oust Mr. Welch as president. It replaced him with a Singleton employee, the current head of a joint operating agreement in York, Pa.
All of these actions matched up well with The Deseret News's wish list, presented to Mr. Singleton last summer when he first became an active bidder. But MediaNews negotiators later told Tribune executives that some things on the wish list had been rejected -- including a request to tone down The Tribune's coverage of church-related issues.
The various changes that Mr. Singleton made to the joint operating agreement are now the focus of a new lawsuit that the Tribune Publishing Company plans to file in the next few days.
In the deal, Mr. Singleton inherited the option agreement that theoretically gives the Tribune company the right to buy back the newspaper in 18 months. But Mr. Singleton testified that he told an old friend and former Tribune executive last summer, that the option "was not exercisable."
NOT surprisingly, news coverage of the sale in The Tribune and The News has been colored by their different perspectives. Both views resonate in this divided city.
During a radio talk show interview in the midst of the trial, The Tribune's feisty editor, Mr. Shelledy, said, "We believe in separation of church and state." His host rejoined: "They do, in that country," referring to the rest of the United States as if it were a country apart.
For his part, Mr. Hughes, whose second wife is a Mormon, said his Mormon friends now made comments like: "So the rascals over there are finally getting their comeuppance. They brought this on themselves." Among his non-Mormon friends, he said, "there is quite an uproar."
Philip McCarthey, a Kearns heir who says he is determined to fight whatever legal battles are required to get The Tribune back, nonetheless believes that this is, at its core, a business fight. But, he said, "living in this community it's always going to be seen as a religious issue."
