HEADLINE: Graduates; 
Saying No to Public Service

BYLINE:  By Richard Brand; Richard Brand, president of the University Press Club at Princeton, has reported from Europe and South America.

DATELINE: PRINCETON, N.J. 

 BODY:
Robert L. Hutchings, who as a member of the National Security Council and as ambassador at large to Eastern Europe had the ear of Presidents Ronald Reagan, George Bush and Bill Clinton, has one of the most difficult jobs in academia today.
 As assistant dean of the Woodrow Wilson School of Public and International Affairs at Princeton, Mr. Hutchings's goal is to place graduates in public service jobs, and that means persuading them to refuse six-figure offers from investment banks and consulting firms in favor of the standard $32,500 offered by the State Department and other federal agencies. 
 That is tough, not only because the pay is low, but also because in the post-cold-war era, diplomacy and government work have lost much of their luster. Also, graduate students who have seen their college classmates reach vice presidencies within a few years at private companies know that it is practically impossible to ascend as quickly through government ranks. It can take up to two years before a candidate for the Foreign Service who passes the exams and gains security clearance is invited to join. 
Because of the changes brought by a new job market, many of the policy schools that once sent an overwhelming majority of their graduating classes into government work are now redefining their public service mission. But as more public policy students choose careers in the private sector, policy school administrators are becoming bitterly divided.
Deans at several elite programs, like the Woodrow Wilson School and the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard, have expanded their definition of public service to include work at nonprofit organizations. But they are troubled that, even so, up to 40 percent of their classes take jobs with private companies.
"I worry that some of our best and brightest choose not to go into the State Department or other federal jobs," Mr. Hutchings said. "We take seriously the public service mission of our school. We have no quarrel with people who want to pursue private sector careers, but we discourage them from coming here in the first place, because that's not what we do."
Joseph S. Nye, a former Assistant Secretary of Defense and the dean of the Kennedy School, where 800 students are pursuing master's degrees, agrees. "The Kennedy school defines its mission as training public leaders," he said. "The area of concern is that the younger American students who would have previously gone into government are less likely to go into government today."
Private companies and many nongovernmental organizations like the Red Cross offer jobs that students believe have more power and prestige in the new global economy, he said, adding, "I think the government is going to have to make major efforts to make their careers more attractive."
"Part of that is financial, and the other part is the challenges presented to students," Mr. Nye said. "A lot of students are idealistic, and they will take a job for less money, but only if they think they can do something more interesting."
In contrast, deans at some other policy schools encourage their students to take jobs at private companies.
Louis W. Goodman, dean of the School of International Service at the American University in Washington, for example, says that students can often be more effective by working for private companies and "doing pro bono work." American is the largest international affairs school in the country with 2,300 students, and today only 15 to 20 percent go into the public sector, while a quarter go into other forms of public service. "When S.I.S was founded in the late 1950's, 85 percent of our students went to work in the public sector ," Dean Goodman said. 
According to the Association of Professional Schools of International Affairs, in 1998, the most recent year for which complete statistics are available, fewer than 35 percent of policy school graduates took government jobs, and 19 percent took jobs with nongovernmental organizations. Nearly 40 percent accepted offers from private companies.
Thirty years ago, nearly all policy school students went straight to work for the government, Marcus Grundahl, the association's director said, adding that several policy schools now are "competing with M.B.A. programs" for students.
"There has just been a complete revolution in the nature of public service and how it's been defined since the 1960's," said Prof. Jeffrey Herbst, a specialist in African affairs at the Woodrow Wilson School. Twenty-five years ago, he said, students interested in privatization in Africa may have worked for the Agency for International Development. "Now they work for a major accounting firm, let's say Arthur Andersen, which has a contract with the Zambian government to work on privatization," he said. 
Monica Inzaina, 23, is about to complete a two-year master's degree in international communications at the School of International Service. She said she had always wanted to work for the government abroad.
A native of Colonial Heights, Va., Ms. Inzaina speaks three languages, gets top grades and was an intern last summer at the State Department. The job was "an incredible experience," she said. 
But Ms. Inzaina now says she would be surprised if she took a government job. "The posts you get are not that good," she said. "You're not going to end up in Rome or Paris until you've done your duty in the world." Now she is interviewing with several companies, including Cisco Systems. Ms. Inzaina added that her plans to get married factored into her decision.
"I definitely have student loans in the back of my mind, and the thought of dragging somebody else through my debt is unacceptable," she said. "I want to give back to the community, but I think there are different ways to give back."
Lisa Anderson, dean of the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia, which encourages recruitment on campus by private companies as early as October, empathizes with student like Ms. Inzaina
"For 20 years, young people have heard politicians and government leaders talk about the virtues of the private sector," Dean Anderson said. "That students are not going to work for the government does not mean they aren't working for the public good. Many see the private sector as an essential tool in the development of the third world."
Dean Hutchings of Princeton disagrees, saying that many of the students who enrolled at policy schools as idealists leave as pragmatists with high-paying private-sector jobs, encouraged by their schools to do so.
"A lot of other public policy schools, I must say, have simply redefined their mission in light of the new job market and the changing nature of the way students enter their careers," Dean Hutchings said. "When they place people with private sector consulting firms or work in private industries, they consider it a great success. We consider that we've missed somewhere if that's the case."
THE Woodrow Wilson School sent 75 percent of its graduates to work for governments or nonprofit organizations last year, more than any other school in the country. Dean Hutchings attributes the school's placements to an emphasis on policy training and to financial assistance programs that enable students to leave without crushing student loan debts. At the Kennedy School approximately 70 percent went into public service, while Columbia's program sent less than half of its class into public service last year, according to figures from the schools.
Before enrolling as one of 300 students at the School of International and Public Affairs at Columbia, Sandra Steyskal, a 28-year-old Stockholm native, spent three years working around the world for Orbis International, a nonprofit organization in New York dedicated to preventing blindness worldwide.
"I came to Columbia, because I wanted to increase my credentials and experience in building and designing humanitarian assistance and development programs," she said. Nevertheless, she said, she has since had job interviews with a leading bank. 
"There are a lot of people like myself who came certain that they would enter the public sector and then become interested in working in the private sector," Ms. Steyskal said. Like many other policy school students, she says she expects to move between private and nonprofit jobs in her career.
Professor Herbst cited "the downsizing of government," as a big factor in students' rush into the private sector. "It's not just that they're banging on the doors of federal bureaucracies and not being let in," he said. "Many people don't even bang on the doors, because they assume correctly that there are no positions available."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS & INVESTING: DIARY; 
Step 1: Grit Teeth. Step 2: Buy Junk Bonds.

BYLINE:  By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
ARE returns on high-yield bonds, now nearly 15 percent, an indication that junk has become too junky to justify responsible investment? Or do they represent a lush opportunity that arises only a few times in a bond buyer's lifetime?
 Either shunning obvious risk or embracing it may prove a big mistake. But if professional advice counts for much, the odds these days favor those who grit their teeth in the face of possible recession and consider buying shares of a high-yield fund. 
 "There is really a very interesting value for investors, something that happens once a decade," said Jack Malvey, chief global fixed-income strategist at Lehman Brothers. "I'm thinking about it for myself." 
After a year when funds that invested in United States Treasury issues gained 17 percent and high-grade corporate bonds gained about 10 percent, junk bonds do not look inviting: They fell nearly 10 percent and now trade at an average of about 78 cents on the dollar.
Indeed, junk has not delivered double-digit returns since 1997; it registered a tiny loss in 1998 and rose 4.8 percent in 1999 -- all during a period when stocks had gains of more than 20 percent a year.
The junk-bond default rate, meanwhile, was 5.4 percent for the 12 months through November 2000, Moody's said. As of mid-December, according to Merrill Lynch, 32.8 percent of high-yield debt was considered distressed -- with yields at least 10 percentage points higher than the rate for long-maturity Treasuries. That was the biggest percentage since March 1994. And despite the interest rate cut engineered last week by the Federal Reserve, some economists still say the economy may tip into recession.
As junk-bond prices sink and defaults rise, trading or even valuing them can become more difficult. Even high-yield municipals are vulnerable. In October, Heartland Advisors of Milwaukee said that the combined assets in two high-yield municipal funds it managed had shriveled to $58 million from $120 million in a single day because of a change in valuation methods. The news was a lesson in the hazards of speculative securities, particularly the lack of liquidity of smaller, unrated issues and the difficulty of pricing them. 
"There are a huge number of debt problems sitting around the United States," said Henry Kaufman, the veteran Wall Street economist, referring to growing distress among borrowers of all sorts. Between high-quality and junk bonds, he said, "spreads may widen still further." 
Increasingly last year, said Martin S. Fridson, chief high-yield strategist at Merrill Lynch, bank lenders tightened standards, squeezing the weaker borrowers. Telecommunications junk was the weakest performer, as companies borrowed heavily to build new systems. Energy, supported by high oil and natural-gas prices, was the strongest.
Despite those risks, there are counterbalancing reasons to try junk: junk yields that now average nearly 14 percent, compared with 4.92 percent for the bellwether 10-year Treasury bond, a spread that implies a level of casualties far exceeding historical norms.
The record default rate, reached during a recession and a junk-bond market collapse in 1991, was 10 percent. "The high-yield market is forecasting a 13 percent default rate, which has never occurred and is not going to happen," said James T. Swanson, a manager of bond portfolios at MFS Investment Management in Boston. Except for some lurking disasters among telecommunications companies -- some of whose bonds could become worthless, he predicted -- most of the damage has already occurred, as the current depressed prices reflect.
In fact, the bullish argument goes, the standard comparison with Treasury bonds overstates the distress among junk-bond issuers. Treasury yields have been depressed, perhaps artificially, by huge government surpluses and the aggressive retirement of long-term debt. The increasingly scarce 30-year bond, for example, currently yields no more than the two-year note; the normal yield curve would have the long bond yielding substantially more in return for its longer risks. 
JUNK-BOND enthusiasm has even spread to William H. Miller III, chief executive of Legg Mason Funds Management in Baltimore and a historically successful stock picker. He defines junk bonds as one of the market's unusual bargains. "I think this is where there is easy money to be made," he told a symposium last month. 
Regardless of market prospects, specialists are almost unanimous in advising individual investors to stick either to standard mutual funds or to closed-end funds, instead of buying individual junk bonds. The closed-end funds often sell at handsome discounts to the market value of their bonds. They can be managed without the risk that investor redemptions will force the abrupt liquidation of bonds that are hard to sell.
Burton J. Greenwald, a fund consultant in Philadelphia, said investors ought to consider bond funds, including junk funds, instead of automatically putting their money into stocks. "Everybody seems to agree you're about to see lower rates and a slower economy," he said. Dips in stock prices can no longer be confidently seen as a chance to pick up stock bargains, he said, but will become a spur to look at alternatives.
But he and others fret that unsophisticated investors may be unduly impressed by the low prices of junk bonds and the correspondingly high yields. "Some may be seduced," Mr. Greenwald said. He urged investors to remember that advertised fund yields are for past, not future, returns, and that junk bonds pose risks more like those of equities than of high-quality bonds.
Moreover, unlike an individual bond that an investor can choose to hold to maturity and have all his principal returned, decisions in junk funds are in the hands of portfolio managers whose actions, for good or ill, may have unfavorable tax consequences. "There is no par value" in a fund, Mr. Greenwald observed.
The danger of buying funds on the basis of advertised yield alone was underscored by Mark McCray, senior vice president and a bond fund manager for Pimco Advisors. "Sophisticated fixed-income investors understand that both income and price performance make up the return on an investment, while individuals fixating on the yield axis only may fail to account for the risks they are taking," he said. "When the net asset value of a fund drops precipitously, whatever incremental yield investors were getting is obliterated by the negative price performance."
But given those cautions, most analysts say 2001 may be a fine year for high-yield bonds, especially if the Fed's interest rate cut last weekhelps to head off a recession. Mr. Fridson of Merrill Lynch projected that the risk-free 10-year Treasury bond would return 5.46 percent this year and that junk would outperform it by 8.87 percentage points, for a return of 14.33 percent.
Though sizable gains may not occur for awhile even with the Fed rate cut, he said: "This is an awfully good opportunity. These bonds are just too cheap."

SECTION: Section 3; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk; Pg. 2

PERSON: VINCENT BOLLORE 

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR; 
Raiding French Banking's Citadel

BYLINE:  By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS 

 BODY:
VINCENT BOLLORE is known in France as a capitalist who began without capital, a quiet but audacious deal maker and corporate raider who grew with other people's money, borrowing to buy low, sell high, repay debts and still have plenty left. 
 But Mr. Bollore's audacity in choosing his most recent corporate target, the venerable French bank Lazard Freres, got him noticed far beyond the small club of corporate raiders in France. Mr. Bollore, 48, rattled one of the most recognized names in investment banking and walked away with more than double the money he put into the effort. 
 "He gave an electric shock to an investment bank that was in decline," said Sophie L'Helias, a French lawyer who knows him. 
Over several months last year, Mr. Bollore (pronounced bo-lo-RAY) paid about $250 million to buy 31 percent of Rue Imperiale de Lyon, a French holding company that controls more than 17 percent of Lazard, which in turn owns about $12 billion worth of assets in a range of other companies. 
The struggle was watched with the intensity of a grand chess contest, not least by minority shareholders in the cascade of companies that, like Chinese boxes one inside the other, controlled the Lazard assets. 
On one side was Mr. Bollore, who had assembled a $4 billion portfolio of shipping, manufacturing and tobacco interests. On the other, the patrician French financier Michel David-Weill, 67, whose grip on the holding companies controlled the fortunes of Lazard. 
As Mr. Bollore saw it, investment banking in Europe was booming, but Lazard was not. He had allies among Lazard's minority investors, who did not want Lazard's decline to come at their expense. At stake for them was the value of holdings in several companies within the Lazard galaxy. They wanted Lazard to increase the value of their investment through share buybacks. Under Mr. David-Weill, Lazard resisted.
In late November, Mr. Bollore surprised the financial world and sold his stake to the French bank Credit Agricole for $270 million more than what he paid. Yes, Mr. David-Weill was rid of a pesky interloper, but the deal made Credit Agricole a powerful Lazard shareholder, and the price it had paid heartened minority shareholders by implying a hefty premium for all shares in the Lazard galaxy of companies.
And investors in Lazard companies, including some in the United States, saw the value of their shares surge by more than half -- in the throes of a bear market.
Mr. Bollore said he got everything he wanted in the Lazard struggle. In an interview, he said that if he could jar lethargic French corporations, all the better. "I like pushing people to move a little," he said. "In France, we are poor at this."
Mr. Bollore, the son of a struggling paper maker in Brittany, left his family's business as a youth to work at a Paris investment bank and study law at night. Later, he worked at the prestigious Compagnie Financiere Rothschild. 
When the family business was failing in the 1970's, Mr. Bollore, then in his 20's, persuaded Edmond de Rothschild to acquire a controlling stake. The enterprise continued to lose money, and in 1981, when Mr. Bollore offered to take it off Mr. Rothschild's hands for one symbolic franc, today about 15 cents, the deal was accepted. After expanding the company geographically, Mr. Bollore amassed an empire by taking minority stakes in other companies, turning them around and acquiring control or selling them.
Along the way, he forged some lasting friendships. A family friend and early adviser was Antoine Bernheim, the Lazard partner who stood by his side with advice during the struggle with Mr. David-Weill. Mr. Bernheim is deputy chairman of the Bollore group. 
Mr. Bollore also formed close ties to Claude Bebear, former chairman of the big AXA insurance group and an arbiter of French finance.
By the 1990's, Mr. Bollore had graduated to bigger deals. In 1991, with the help of AXA and the big French bank Credit Lyonnais, he took control of Delmas-Vieljeux, a major shipping group with important routes to Africa. 
Many of his coups illustrate the priority of business over personal ties. In 1996, he acquired control of Groupe Rivaud, a financial conglomerate, despite the resistance of Rivaud's chairman, Edouard de Ribes, a boyhood friend of Mr. Bollore's father.
Even when Mr. Bollore has not gotten his way, he has usually come out ahead financially. In 1998, he started a yearlong battle for control of Bouygues, the huge construction group that had branched out into television and wireless phone services. Mr. Bollore lost, but not before pocketing $215 million from the sale of his stake. Almost immediately, he began acquiring shares in the French film company Pathe, alarming its chairman, Jerome Seydoux. A month later, in January 1999, Mr. Bollore sold his stake, pocketing $115 million.
Mr. Bollore brings with him a keen understanding of how French business works, and he shrewdly deploys his windfalls to strengthen his industrial empire. That has needed strengthening lately, for while the cigarette business he controls in Africa remains profitable, his shipping lines have come under pressure from a price war started by Maersk, the Danish shipping giant.
Like many of his targets, Mr. Bollore has used interconnected holding companies to control the family business. His goal, however, is to combine those companies into one within four or five years, while assuring his family keeps a 51 percent controlling stake.
Investors like the results of his efforts so far. Last year, shares in Bollore Investissement, the principal holding company, gained more than 7 percent, against a weak French stock market.
An avid yachtsman, skier, tennis player and comic-book collector, Mr. Bollore is married and a father of four. His corporate raids, he said, raise capital for growth, without trips to the stock market that would dilute family control. The raids, he said, would continue.
"It's easier, of course, when the market is bullish, and harder when it's going down," he said. Then, with a boyish grin, he said: "Normally, we go where other people don't dare, or don't think about. With Bouygues, no one dared; with Pathe, no one thought of it. With Lazard, it was both."

HEADLINE: California's Power Woes 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
 Re "The Market Flaw California Overlooked," by Steven Stoft (Op-Ed, Jan. 2): 
 California's generating resources are insufficient to supply its power demands at comfortable prices, a result of the longstanding unwillingness of California regulators to permit construction of new generating capacity at adequate levels of cost recovery. 
Instead, they placed their trust in the ability of "demand side management" programs (like free water heater wraps) and electric appliance efficiency standards to produce "negawatts," thus obviating the need for new generating units.
Now that California needs them, the hoped-for negawatts are nowhere to be found. And the power price caps recommended by Mr. Stoft would only continue, by new means, California's failed policy of discouraging new power supply.

MARK F. MORSS
Columbus, Ohio, Jan. 3, 2001

The writer is an economist, American Electric Power Corporation.

HEADLINE: The Nation; 
The High-Stakes Politics Of Spending the Surplus

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex. 

 BODY:
PRESIDENT-ELECT GEORGE W. BUSH spent much of last week building support for his tax-cut plan, meeting here with like-minded business executives and asserting that a dose of fiscal stimulus would neatly complement the Federal Reserve's surprise interest rate reduction in the effort to reverse the economy's downturn.
 But while the incoming administration and its allies in Congress were busy peddling the $1.6 trillion tax cut as anti-recession insurance, conservatives also had their eyes on an even bigger ideological prize. 
 Their goal is not just to put the growing federal budget surplus to use on their terms. It is to return the government to the days when every initiative had to be weighed against keeping the budget balanced. By getting the surplus out of Washington via a tax cut, they hope to check what they acknowledge is a bipartisan impulse to spend any money that is put on the table. 
"Starve the beast," said one prominent conservative.
Should Mr. Bush succeed in pushing through a tax cut similar to the one he has proposed, he would wipe out a good portion of the projected surplus. And if his own calls for increased spending for the military, education and prescription drug coverage for the elderly are added to the tab, he could eliminate it.
That would put conservatives right where they want to be, having used the surplus to their ends and emerging with a cudgel with which to beat back attempts to use tax revenues for purposes they do not like.
"There's really a two-tiered argument for the tax cut," said Stephen Moore, president of the Club for Growth, a conservative political action committee. "One is the fiscal stimulus, supply-side argument. The other is that it's the best way to stop a spending spree. Tactically, it makes sense to do the tax cut quickly or you won't be able to repel the spending momentum that comes from both sides."
Over the last few years, budget surpluses have grown with each calculation, like a pot of gold that replenishes itself faster than anyone can empty it. But those surpluses have grown only because Washington has been deadlocked by divided government, unable to agree on what to do with the windfall. 
With Republicans in charge both on Capitol Hill and at the White House, that deadlock is probably at an end. Although they will probably have to compromise to get legislation through the evenly divided Senate, it is possible Republicans could end the coming legislative year having claimed for their own most of the money that is on the table for tax cuts and spending. By current estimates, that amounts to something better than $2.5 trillion over the next decade, the portion of the surplus generated outside of Social Security. 
Unless the economy were to get a lot more robust in a hurry, the surplus pot would then be empty for years, perhaps decades, to come.
"You only decide once how to dedicate the surplus," said Jacob J. Lew, the Clinton administration's budget director.
To the extent that Republicans are pressing for tax cuts to keep Democrats from getting their hands on the money, they are bringing back a strategy similar to that used by Ronald Reagan right after he became president in 1981. Mr. Reagan's team very explicitly saw the large tax cut they pushed through as a way of blocking calls for new spending and checking the inexorable expansion of the size and influence of the federal government.
But Mr. Reagan was unable to stop Democrats, or Republicans, from spending more, nor would he pare back his demands for more money for the Pentagon.
"If you look back to the 1981 economic policy, they were creating a squeeze on spending that was supposed to force hard decisions," Mr. Lew said. "It didn't work. We got enormous deficits that spiraled out of control and put the economy in peril."
Like Mr. Reagan, Mr. Bush is promising to get tough on spending. But even under Republican control since 1994, Congress has kept the fiscal floodgates open, and there is now bipartisan agreement on the need to spend more on issues like education and health care.
There are a few big differences between today and the Reagan years. For one, the economic desirability of fiscal responsibility is much more deeply rooted in the political system. For another, even if the entire non-Social Security surplus were to be apportioned, the government would still have a huge buffer in the form of the surplus being generated by Social Security -- more than $2.5 trillion over the next decade.
The two parties have agreed that the Social Security surplus should go only to paying down the national debt or overhauling the retirement system, and not to tax cuts or new spending. Still, the existence of the money would greatly reduce the risk of running up the kinds of deficits that dragged down the economy in the late 1980's and early 1990's.
INDEED, the nation now confronts its needs -- economic, social, military -- from a position of remarkable fiscal strength. Despite the threat of recession, the budget situation that Mr. Bush is inheriting from Bill Clinton is light-years better than the morass of deficits Mr. Clinton inherited from Mr. Bush's father. The fight now is over how to spend the bounty. 
Grover Norquist, president of Americans for Tax Reform, a conservative research group, said that until the surplus is off the table it will be difficult for conservatives to turn back the expansion of government. Welfare reform, reductions in aid to farmers and the devolution of power over domestic programs to the states only moved ahead after Republicans made balancing the budget their goal in 1995, he said.
"Budget discipline forces the reforms," he said.
Democrats have their own claim to fiscal responsibility through their insistence on reducing the national debt. But they say it is ridiculous to create an atmosphere of restraint when there is a national consensus about the need to address so many issues.
"You can have a fair difference of opinion about priorities," Mr. Lew said, "but it is a bad idea to pretend you can create an environment in which goals that have public support can't be considered."

GRAPHIC: Photo: President-elect George W. Bush emerging from a meeting with Alan Greenspan on the state of the economy. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Restoration; 
What It Used to Be Just Ain't What It Used to Be

BYLINE:  By ROBIN TONER 

 BODY:
THEY'RE back, all those old hands and familiar faces from the reigns of Bush the elder, Ronald Reagan and Gerald R. Ford. All that comfortable expertise that kept the Republicans in the White House throughout the 1980's, prompting the commentator Christopher Matthews to declare it "the Daddy Party," in whose capable hands the nation entrusted the cold war and the economy.
 The word in Washington now is "restoration," as in the return of a ruling family ousted by an angry electorate (in the case of George I in 1992, whose son, George W. Bush, now returns after eight years in the provinces) or a civil war followed by a beheading (in the case of Charles I in 1649, whose son, Charles II, returned to the throne 11 years later). For Republicans, it is a deeply reassuring time, a return to order, to stability, to the way things used to be and should have stayed. 
 Except things aren't what they used to be. Washington has changed during the unruly Clinton years, in ways that may prove unsettling for returning Republicans. It is faster, rougher, more partisan. "I left government in late '83 and returned in '93 and I was stunned by how much of a change had taken place," said David R. Gergen, who served in the Nixon, Ford, Reagan and Clinton administrations. "We entered a new world in the 1990's, politically." 
Congress has become utterly unpredictable -- no longer controlled by the Democrats, but not really controlled by the Republicans either. Even Representative David Dreier of California, an optimistic Bush ally and chairman of the House Rules Committee, acknowledges, "No one has dealt with a situation as close as this."
Policy-making is different, too. Major initiatives -- say, restructuring Medicare as President-elect Bush is proposing -- are now hashed out in the open, amid a barrage of interest group advertising and high-tech lobbying, a legacy of the health-care wars of 1993-94. "Part of Bush's choices, I think, is a longing to go back to the old world -- where seasoned men made the decisions and everybody listened," said Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York. In recent years, seasoned men seem to have become just one more constituent group.
The old hands on the Bush team were not exactly off in Kazakhstan for the past decade, as Representative Barney Frank, Democrat of Massachusetts, put it. Most have stayed involved, in commissions, campaigns or private-sector jobs just barely removed from the public sector. Two come straight from the Senate. But nothing is quite like the intensity of the White House.
The leisurely news cycle of the 1980's is long gone. CNN was a force in the last Bush administration, but the number of media outlets has exploded since then, not to mention the Internet. "It used to be you had to feed the media beast," said S. Robert Lichter, president of the Center for Media and Public Affairs. "Now you have to corral it." Mr. Lichter added, "When some of these guys were last here, the only video game was Pong."
And, of course, the issues have changed. To state the obvious, foreign policy is no longer consumed with managing the cold war, and no single overarching threat has emerged to replace it. A recent report by the intelligence community concluded that global issues like food and water shortages, disease and changes in population will increasingly affect the national security of the United States -- issues requiring a far different mindset than the rivalry of superpowers.
And without the towering threat of the Soviet Union, foreign policy has become more politicized, the old notion of differences "ending at the water's edge" a quaint remnant of another time. 
On the domestic front, one happier change for the Republicans is the existence of a surplus as far as the eye can see. But there's also a slowing economy and a skittish stock market, a matter of immense concern to what has become a nation of stockholders over the past eight years. The domestic agenda, which increasingly reflects an aging society, is complicated -- issues like prescription drugs, Medicare and Social Security -- and particularly hard to deal with during the permanent campaign. Even some of Mr. Bush's allies think he has underestimated how hard it will be to win bipartisan support for a Medicare overhaul with the House up for grabs in 2002.
These difficulties may be obscured, at the moment, by the sweet sense of Restoration in the House of Bush. It is an old story line: the father rejected, the son welcomed back by a regretful nation, avenging old wrongs. Charles I waged a long struggle with Parliament, culminating in civil wars and his own beheading on charges of treason. Parliament's victory led to the rule of Oliver Cromwell. But after his death, the nation turned to Charles II, who returned amid great rejoicing.
The Bush story is, yes, a tad less dramatic. And Kevin Phillips, the political analyst and author of "The Cousins' Wars: Religion, Politics and the Triumph of Anglo-America" (Basic Books, 1999), takes a hard-nosed view of the whole business: "In the sense that restorations always bring back the old crowd, that's one of the handicaps. Their A-team is the same crowd that lost to Jimmy Carter, for Pete's sake."
The adjustments facing the new Bush cabinet can, of course, be overstated. As Mickey Edwards, a former Republican congressman, put it, "It isn't like they just drifted off and came back like Rip Van Winkle." Indeed, some were in on the beginning of the zeitgeist shift, like Gen. Colin L. Powell, who was chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff into the early years of the Clinton administration and fought, in the Persian Gulf war, the first war televised in real time.
"They've adapted too; they grew up in that atmosphere," said Tom Korologos, a longtime Republican lobbyist now helping with the Bush transition. "That's the beauty of the Bush cabinet -- they're all adults. This group can run a government tonight."
But Mr. Phillips scoffs, "They've been off picking the tall cotton in the corporate world, and that gives you a different mindset."
A CLOSE analysis of Bush I may help. Just weeks after the elder Bush took office, dramatically offering his hand to Congressional Democrats in his Inaugural Address, Democrats rejected his nominee for defense secretary, Senator John G. Tower. It was considered a seminal event in the partisan wars that followed -- not least because it triggered Dick Cheney's move to defense, which opened the way for Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia to win a position in the Republican leadership.
After that, mostly during the Clinton years, came the deluge: a Republican takeover of Congress in 1994, the fall of House speakers, the impeachment of a president, a president elected without a popular vote majority and a brutal near-parity between the two parties that means the next campaign is already under way. The old Democratic Congressional majority that confronted Mr. Bush's Republican predecessors was not easy, but it was stable.
"You could cut a deal, and it would stick," Mr. Gergen said. "The negotiations that go into putting together a large bipartisan bill are far more difficult today than they were in the past."
On the Hill and off, the rules are different. If the new president likes, he can take solace from Charles II, who thrived in the new political world that Cromwell had helped create -- in contrast to his successor, James II, an unpopular ruler who died in exile.
Jim Jordan, executive director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, gave a hint of what awaits just beyond the glow of this newest restoration. "If he thinks this is going to be the Texas Legislature, and has people in for barbecue and horseshoes and that's enough, he's in for a surprise," Mr. Jordan said.

GRAPHIC: Photos/Drawings: The players in a Restoration costume drama: George Bush as the deposed Stuart king, Charles I; Bill Clinton (somewhat miscast) as the puritanical revolutionary, Oliver Cromwell; and George W. Bush as the avenging son, Charles II. (The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Bush Gathers G.O.P. Governors To Discuss Taxes and Education 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., Jan. 6 

 BODY:
President-elect George W. Bush met today with Republican governors, thanking them for their help during the campaign and signaling his desire to keep them involved with his efforts on issues like education.
 On the day that Congress certified his Electoral College victory, Mr. Bush brought 19 governors to his ranch near Crawford, Tex., for a tour and working barbecue lunch. In brief remarks to reporters, he again stressed the need for a tax cut to help offset the slowing of the economy. 
 Mr. Bush and his aides said they were considering whether to rework their tax cut proposal so that it could put money back into people's pockets this year. As originally drafted, Mr. Bush's plan would not take effect until next year.
"I hear a lot of concern from the business community, the high-tech community and the small-business community," Mr. Bush said, adding that he was also concerned about high levels of consumer debt. "People are worried about the economy, and I will decide whether or not to accelerate the tax relief package after I get sworn in."
Mr. Bush and the governors covered topics including environmental regulation, but the focus seemed to be mainly on education.
"I asked the governors to help me work with members on both sides of the aisle to pass an education reform package that will include more flexibility for states," Mr. Bush said.
There is some common ground between the parties on all of the issues at the top of Mr. Bush's agenda. But there is also considerable risk that progress could be thwarted by deep divisions over aspects of the issues.
On education, there is bipartisan consensus about providing more federal money to states and streamlining some of the bureaucratic requirements Washington places on state and local authorities. But most Democrats adamantly oppose Mr. Bush's call to allow parents of students in failing public school districts to put their share of federal funding toward private school tuition.
Similarly, while Democrats are open to supporting a limited missile defense system, they are skeptical about the costs and technical feasibility of the bigger shield Mr. Bush has in mind. And while Democrats have become increasingly open to tax cuts, they continue to press for reductions that are more limited and more directed at low- and moderate-income people than the plan Mr. Bush has proposed.
In two days of meetings earlier this week, Mr. Bush discussed the economy, tax cuts, technology and education with corporate executives and economists. On Monday he is scheduled to meet here with Vice President-elect Dick Cheney, his choice for defense secretary, Donald H. Rumsfeld, and members of Congress to discuss military issues.
Mr. Bush has also been busy packing. Moving vans are scheduled to arrive next week at the governor's mansion here to transport his family's goods to the White House.

HEADLINE: U.S. Economic Ills Spell Risk Abroad 

BYLINE:  By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 

 BODY:
The last time the Federal Reserve was forced to cut interest rates in a hurry -- in October 1998 -- it was to protect the United States from a fast-spreading currency crisis in Russia, after more than a year of economic turmoil in Asia. It was called the "contagion effect," and the strategy was to stop it before it infected a booming American economy that had become the predominant force for growth around the world.
 Little more than two years later there is now fear of a different kind of contagion effect, this one radiating from the United States. The sharp slowdown here alarmed the Fed so much that it took the highly unusual step on Wednesday of acting between scheduled meetings, slashing short-term interest rates by a half a percentage point. 
 And what is already clear is that the faltering American economy is not just a domestic problem for the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, and for President-elect George W. Bush when he takes over the White House in two weeks. In the last few days it has also become evident that it could rank among Mr. Bush's early international troubles, along with the violence and fragile negotiations in the Middle East, a difficult relationship with Russia, collapsing sanctions on Iraq and lingering questions about the nature of Washington's engagement with China. 
For nearly seven years, the United States has so dominated the world economy that other nations have come to depend, more than ever, on constantly rising demand from the United States for products of all kinds. America's role as the main engine of global growth has been all the more vital because the world's second-largest economy, Japan, has been stagnant for nearly a decade -- and now appears headed into yet another recession.
Suddenly, officials around the world are afraid that as America's engine sputters, they could become the first to suffer. "There is no safety net," one senior Japanese official said Friday from Tokyo. During the Asian crisis, he noted, it was the United States that sucked in manufactured goods from around the world, helping stabilize the world economy.
That is unlikely in 2001, and Mr. Bush may discover, as President Clinton did time and again -- from Mexico City and Jakarta to Tokyo and Moscow -- that as financial troubles spin around the world, diplomatic troubles follow.
Here in Washington, there are questions about whether Mr. Bush's team, still trying to get organized, is ready for the kind of side-effects the American slowdown could generate around the globe. Mr. Bush's foreign policy advisers are experienced in handling Russia and defiant states like Iraq, but many of the new challenges of managing financial instability that leaps national boundaries came largely after most of them left when Mr. Bush's father lost the White House in 1992.
The treasury secretary-designate, Paul H. O'Neill, formerly served as chief executive of Alcoa, the huge aluminum manufacturer, and knows both the world and Mr. Greenspan well. (Mr. Greenspan, once a member of the Alcoa board, recruited Mr. O'Neill for his corporate job.) But Mr. O'Neill has never managed the kind of rolling financial turmoil that has beset parts of the world off and on since the most recent Mexican currency crisis began in 1995.
And, like Colin L. Powell at the State Department and Donald H. Rumsfeld at the Pentagon, Mr. O'Neill is still scouting for his deputies, who will have the day-to-day responsibility for managing the slowdown at home, and containing its effects abroad. 
"The highest priority is to get your team together in the Treasury, and that may be more important in the globalized world than putting together the traditional teams in State and Defense," said Jeffrey R. Shafer, the vice chairman of Salomon Smith Barney International and a former undersecretary of treasury for international affairs in the Clinton administration. "The crises that hurt the most are the ones you don't see coming."
During his campaign, Mr. Bush repeatedly expressed doubts about using the International Monetary Fund to bail countries out of trouble, saying it created a "moral hazard" by sending a signal to investors that Washington would help them out of trouble. But it is unclear whether his view might change if declines elsewhere in the world worsen America's own financial picture by cutting into American exports -- one of the keys to growth in the United States. 
"This is a case," said one former senior member of Mr. Clinton's economic team, "where something that sounds pretty simple on the campaign trail can look a lot more complex once you get into the Oval Office."
In interviews with finance ministers, business executives and analysts around the world -- all conducted after the Fed's interest rate cut sent a message that the American economy was deteriorating much faster than anticipated a few months ago -- it became clear that the wrench thrown into the gears of the world's dominant economy is sending sparks flying everywhere.
Most countries are not yet feeling the effects. But with the International Monetary Fund declaring on Thursday that it would dramatically revise the optimistic projections for world economic growth that it published just a month ago, few doubt that they are in for a rough year -- perhaps rougher than the United States' own.
The United States absorbs about 20 percent of all of Asia's exports, and its insatiable demand for more was the key to the quick recovery in Southeast Asia and South Korea.
"Telecommunications equipment, semiconductors, computers and peripherals are all things that the U.S. and the rest of the world couldn't get enough of in the past few years," said David G. Fernandez, an economist at J. P. Morgan in Singapore. "The same factors that allowed them to have the V-shaped recovery" -- one where the plunge down is followed by a sharp bounce up -- "have turned fully against them."
Government officials around Asia say they doubt America's problems will plunge them into the kind of crisis that struck in the summer of 1997. That was when many of them discovered that linking their own currencies to the fast-rising dollar meant they could neither sell their goods nor repay enormous loans from Western banks and investors.
Chatumongkol Sonakul, governor of the Bank of Thailand, where the Asian crisis began, insisted this week that his country was no longer as vulnerable as it once was.
"We're not too worried like last time when we were really unstable," he said in an interview. Thailand's foreign debt has fallen dramatically, he said. "We're still overborrowed. But these are reasonable numbers coming from where we were."
Masahiro Kawai, the World Bank's chief economist for East Asia and the Pacific, said many of the countries that were in such dire straits two years ago have in the meantime accumulated "large foreign exchange reserves" that should help see them through a brief downturn.
But a lengthy recession could well trigger new resentments against Washington. When Thailand hit turbulent times, there was a sharp adverse reaction against the United States -- which did not immediately come to the country's aid. Indonesia is already in the throes of an anti-American mood, and across Asia a prolonged slowdown now could rekindle suspicions that the United States turns the trade spigot on and off for its own advantage. 
The effects may also be felt acutely in Mexico, which sends more than 80 percent of its exports to the United States -- accounting for 21 percent of Mexico's gross domestic product. Goldman, Sachs is already predicting a sharp economic slowdown in Mexico this year. That could greatly complicate the task of the country's new president, Vicente Fox Quesada, the world leader Mr. Bush talks about most frequently.
There are other, more complex, troubles anticipated in Latin America. The same oil price increases that have vexed American consumers have helped bolster Russia, Mexico, Venezuela, Colombia and Ecuador. Now the slowing American economy seems likely to reduce oil demand, and with it prices. Consumers here will be relieved; much of Latin America may be back in trouble.
Similarly, there is a fear that investors, pulling back from risk around the world, will make it far harder for developing nations to borrow. The stakes are particularly high for Argentina, which needs $21.8 billion in loans this year and is already on the I.M.F.'s list of potential trouble spots. 
Europe seems less vulnerable. It is less dependent on the rest of the world, and its new currency, the euro, has recovered somewhat in recent weeks as America has weakened. But because the Europeans are hardly major importers of goods, they are not a solution to problems emanating from the United States.
Perhaps the biggest risks -- and the most immediate diplomatic challenge for Mr. Bush -- involve Japan. Three times in the last decade Japanese officials declared that their long economic decline was over, and three times they were wrong. What little growth the country is experiencing comes in large part from massive deficit spending by the government, some of it urged on by American officials, which has created an unsustainable national debt. 
Just before the presidential election, Lawrence B. Lindsey, Mr. Bush's chief economic adviser, gave a speech in Washington sharply critical of how the Clinton administration has dealt with Japan. He argued that it was time to lecture the Japanese less about how to reform their economy and spend more time working to introduce competition.
But if the American economy declines, pressure will almost certainly build in Washington to get Japan jump-started, in hopes that it can buy more American goods and help the United States out of its problems -- just as the United States, in recent years, has aided Japan.
"Japan is probably the most fragile country in Asia right now, and the one where a recession could create the most problems elsewhere," Daniel Tarullo, a professor at Georgetown University and previously one of Mr. Clinton's top international economic advisers, said Friday.
The Japanese, however, are hardly in a mood right now to think about boosting their imports of American goods. In fact, they need to export to the United States more than ever to compensate for the refusal of their own consumers to buy much. 
A quick decline by the United States "will be a double whammy for Japan," said Kazuo Mizuno, senior economist for Kokusai Securities in Tokyo. And a double whammy for the world's two largest economies could easily be a double whammy for the new administration.

HEADLINE: Dueling Power Centers 

 BODY:
You know you are in the rosy glow of transition time when a new presidential team hits Washington and starts boasting about how it will not permit the sort of bitter infighting that has afflicted every modern administration. We wish the members of President-elect George W. Bush's team well on this score. It is about time harmony broke out in the Republican Party. But from Mr. Bush's final cabinet and senior White House staff choices, it is possible to define three power clusters, and it is also possible see how these groups might have very different ideas about how best to serve Mr. Bush's interests.
 The president-elect has assembled a White House staff of fiercely political, loyal and protective aides. He has sprinkled the cabinet with a team of hard-edged ideologues on the environment and social issues. Then there is a wedge of powerful personalities occupying the jobs of vice president, secretary of state and secretary of defense. 
 Mr. Bush joked to reporters last week that the "Texas Iron Triangle" he had in Austin had now moved to Washington. But the earlier precedent for the new White House managerial structure is Ronald Reagan's famous "troika" of Jim Baker, Mike Deaver and Ed Meese. Mr. Bush has picked Andrew Card to be his chief of staff, Karen Hughes to handle communications and the schedule, and Karl Rove as the political enforcer.
In political terms, these three will be primarily concerned with building Mr. Bush's personal popularity, positioning the G.O.P. for the mid-term elections and laying the groundwork for a 2004 re-election campaign. One of the first decisions for the Card-Hughes-Rove triumvirate will be how much running room to allow the cabinet ideologues. For while their boss campaigned as a uniter, not a divider, he has put some very divisive figures in his cabinet in those areas where voters are most concerned about the conservative agenda. We are thinking of the group consisting of Attorney General-designate John Ashcroft, Labor Secretary-designate Linda Chavez, Interior Secretary-designate Gale Norton and Energy Secretary-designate Spencer Abraham. Turning those four loose on abortion rights, affirmative action, the environment and energy policy could alienate the suburban moderates who put Mr. Bush in office and dash his hopes of expanding his minority vote in the future.
This dilemma is not a new one for Republican White Houses. In the Reagan years, there were constant battles between so-called pragmatists led by Mr. Baker and conservatives led by Mr. Meese and Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger. And as the historian David Greenberg points out, the last time that Republicans were in control of the White House and the Congress, President Dwight Eisenhower had similar difficulties. Ike, he notes, promoted business-friendly tax cuts for the moderates but tangled constantly with people like Senators Joseph McCarthy and Robert Taft on his right flank. 
What may set the Bush administration apart from these earlier Republican regimes is the last, most unusual and potentially most potent of its three power clusters. This G.O.P. version of the wise men consists of Vice President-elect Dick Cheney, Gen. Colin Powell at the State Department and Donald Rumsfeld at Defense. While untested as a diplomat, General Powell has a superstar reputation that almost overshadows his president in much the way that Henry Kissinger threatened to overshadow President Gerald Ford. Moreover, General Powell has strong views in the domestic sphere, favoring affirmative action and abortion rights in an administration not friendly to either idea. We will be watching this year's budget battles to see how he reacts if Congress tries to cut family planning assistance from the State Department, a favorite cause of the Republican right in years past.
As formidable as the general may become, Mr. Rumsfeld is not likely to be pushed around by him. Mr. Rumsfeld has battled and won against Mr. Kissinger, after all. As for Mr. Cheney, the vice president-elect has clearly emerged as this administration's prime minister, as The Economist put it. Mr. Cheney is a conservative, but not a suicidal one. The first test is likely to be taxes. Right now there is a blur of voices coming out of the Bush operations in Washington and Austin, with some hanging tough on a giant tax cut for the wealthy and others suggesting that the new president will be ready to deal fairly quickly on the package's size and shape. Mr. Cheney is the member of the team likely to provide his boss the most experienced perspective on what will fly on Capitol Hill. 
But Mr. Bush, no matter how many advisory groups he assembles, will still have to decide whether he is a moderate or militant conservative on taxes, social policy and the environment. That means the bickering that worries the president-elect so much when it happens between the parties could break out among his own advisers. It's happened before with Republicans in Mr. Bush's new neighborhood.

HEADLINE: PERSPECTIVE; 
A One-Man Dream Team as Well as A-, B- and C-Rods

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE 

 BODY:
The New Year's list from readers to the lipsite@aol.com grows with requests for what I should be pontificating about in 2001. C'mon, I only have two heads.
 How should I know whether Tiger Woods is ultimately good or bad for golf? You don't think I actually watch it, especially now that it has this facade of cool. The current besottedness with Childe Eldrick is based on his filling the money hole left when the world's most expensive model, Michael Jordan, hooped off. The more Michael fades like an old Polaroid print, the more Tiger burns bright. 
 Besides beating everyone else, Tiger, like Michael, has an innate self-confidence that doesn't need the end-zone dance. His public face is corporate and smooth, he takes care of business and just so long as he doesn't try to conflate himself with a game that has outlived Bobby Jones, Arnold Palmer and Bagger Vance, he will be allowed to lease his image.
Meanwhile, the PGA needs to figure a way to use Tiger's current dominance to market the tour as the Quest to Bag the Tiger without allowing that to become a tacit abdication of control. The last time a charismatic athlete so dominated a sport and was also on the verge of taking it over economically, the Justice Department busted Cassius Clay for refusing to be drafted. Within minutes, boxing commissions around the country stripped Muhammad Ali of his heavyweight title. Tiger knows his history. He wouldn't want Ernie Els to be his Joe Frazier.
As if it isn't enough that the world's greatest golfer is a man of color and the hottest rapper, Eminem, is white, we have Marion Jones on the cover of Vogue and Venus Williams everywhere else. When have we ever had two such sipid female sports stars at the same time?
While I'm not voting on which of the two is the sexiest female sports figure alive, Alex Rodriguez is not the sexiest male, despite current polls. No question about that. Just look at A-Rod's price tag. Sexiest male has to be Tom Hicks, the tycoon who could afford to buy him.
Yes, I do wish pro football players would display some real manhood and boycott, or at least protest through work slowdowns (missed blocks, stopping short of the end zone, dancing in the huddle), teams that don't hire the coaches they want. In particular, I'm thinking of African-Americans who make up 75 percent of the players and only 2 of the 31 head coaches. Several months ago, the executive director of the National Football League Players Association, Gene Upshaw, who is black, told owners at a league meeting that free-agent black players might be more likely to sign with a team with a black head coach.
This is a touchy issue, especially since the hiring of head coaches is so whimsical, so based on the comfort zones of white owners and general managers. What about the comfort zones of Jets players who might take less money to stay and play harder for Maurice Carthon, an experienced assistant, than yet another white proven failure?
As for college athletes who can't read or write, I don't think they should be forced to attend classes, take tests or write their own papers. I have received a number of e-mail messages from college professors -- no names, please -- expressing fear and loathing of their athletic departments. A high school teacher wrote, claiming to have been among those complicitous in sending an illiterate on to compete in last week's so-called national championship at the Orange Bowl. No names, please.
Students though they may be, the competing quarterbacks in that event would have made George Gipp, the original tramp athlete, proud of his legacy. Josh Heupel, son of his high school coach, went to Weber State and Snow Junior College before ending up at Oklahoma, the ultimate winner. Chris Weinke, at 28 the oldest player by five years to win the Heisman Trophy, got to Florida State after a career as a minor league infielder. 
I agree that any market that can't support a competitive major league baseball team doesn't deserve it. If those people in, say, Kansas City, Pittsburgh or Minneapolis, would rather go boating or camping than watching the B- and C-Rods perform live for them, they shouldn't have a franchise. Revenue sharing is for football. Balanced rosters are for soccer. Socialism for the moguls of the national pastime? Forget it. George Steinbrenner goes out and buys us a winner. Does he ask for more than love in return?
I also agree that it's not too early to support the city's bid for the 2012 Olympic Games. That's any city except New York. There are certainly cities that might benefit from the Games -- Kansas City, Pittsburgh and Minneapolis come to mind -- but New York is not one of them. The Olympics puts a city on the Happy News Network for a year, makes a few local developers richer and gives some political leaders a chance to meet and pay off some very sophisticated Olympic officials whose children and mistresses need shoes and tuition. Also, the International Olympic Committee's rented academics come to town and set up think tanks and cultural events, affording the illusion that we are really in Athens and Pericles is our mayor.
A city able to play host to the World Series within its boundaries, and move fans by public transportation, cannot be enhanced by the Big Idea of 1896. Unless, of course, golf becomes an Olympic sport again and you-know-who is the one-man Dream Team.

Lack of AIDS Drugs Imperils Romanian Children
Thousands of the Romanian children who contracted the virus that causes AIDS from needless blood transfusions a decade ago are still alive, but high prices charged by Western drug companies, Romania's deep poverty and the failures of the country's weak governments have ensured that life-saving anti-retroviral drugs are beyond their reach. 1

HEADLINE: Union Leaders Plan Fight Against Bush's Labor Selection 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The nation's labor leaders are mobilizing to try to defeat President-elect George W. Bush's selection of Linda Chavez as labor secretary, saying her opposition to the minimum wage and her conservative views on affirmative action make her unfit for the office.
 John J. Sweeney, the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s president, said yesterday that he had already urged Democratic leaders in Congress to defeat Ms. Chavez. On Tuesday, several union leaders said, the labor federation's 54-member executive council will officially announce its opposition to the confirmation of Ms. Chavez, a conservative columnist and former Reagan administration official. 
 "She has spent the past 20 years opposing just about every important program, from the minimum wage to affirmative action to so many things important to working families," Mr. Sweeney said in a telephone interview. "It is very difficult to think of working with someone who is opposed to some of our basic labor laws, yet says she's going to enforce those laws. She's just not the right person to be secretary of labor."
Union leaders acknowledged that they faced an uphill battle in trying to stop the confirmation, but they said it was important to fight against someone they view as hostile to unions and unenthusiastic about enforcing workers' rights. 
Several union leaders said they hoped they could block the nomination by winning the support of all the Democrats in the Senate, which is divided 50-50, and a handful of labor-friendly Republicans. The unions' determination to defeat Ms. Chavez was first reported yesterday by The Washington Post.
"I think the American labor movement has a responsibility to oppose her, to point out to the American people and to the United States Senate what kind of individual would be put in charge of the issues affecting working families in America," said Gerald McEntee, president of the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees and chairman of the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s political committee.
Tucker Eskew, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, voiced confidence that Ms. Chavez would win Senate confirmation, despite labor's opposition.
"As secretary, upon confirmation, she will strongly enforce the laws of the land and strongly enforce the laws that look out for working Americans," Mr. Eskew said. "She comes form a working-class background. She has a record of promoting the interests of working Americans and she will do so as labor secretary."
To drum up opposition to Ms. Chavez, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. is distributing copies of her writings, which, union leaders say, often take a contemptuous or extreme stance on basic workers rights.
In her columns, Ms. Chavez has ridiculed sexual harassment lawsuits as being brought by "crybabies," has argued against the notion that women face a glass ceiling thwarting promotion into the senior ranks of business, and has likened supporters of an increased minimum wage to Marxists. She has condemned proposals to raise the federal minimum wage, saying such a step would reduce jobs and force many companies out of business.
Ms. Chavez, who was staff director of the United States Civil Rights Commission under President Ronald Reagan, is president of the Center for Equal Opportunity, a Washington research group. The center, a fervent opponent of affirmative action, says it is devoted "to the promotion of color-blind equal opportunity."
Labor union and civil rights groups have voiced concerns that Ms. Chavez may not enforce federal rules that require thousands of federal contractors to use affirmative action criteria. 
Ms. Eskew said: "She will strongly enforce the civil rights laws of the nation, while increasing equal employment opportunities, including for workers under federal contracts. She has a history of supporting the tenets of what the president-elect calls affirmative access, an aggressive effort to reach out to Americans of all backgrounds, without establishing quotas or racial preferences."
After her selection was announced last week, Ms. Chavez sought to reassure workers, promising to promote safety on the job and to enforce the nation's labor laws. After noting that her father was a house painter and that her mother stood for long hours working in department stores and restaurants, she said, "I intend to keep faith with the men and the women who still work at jobs like those my parents held." 
Still, labor leaders, who played a major role in Vice President Al Gore's campaign, often describe Ms. Chavez as antiunion. Although she worked as a lobbyist for the American Federation of Teachers two decades ago, she has written that teachers unions are often bad for the nation's schools. She has also condemned various strikes as being bad for the economy and has written that the idea of doctors' forming labor unions "ought to strike fear in the heart of every American." 
Defending Ms. Chavez's writings, Mr. Eskew said that as a columnist, she was expected to be provocative. "We'd like the opponents to be reminded of the difference between a newspaper columnist and a cabinet secretary," he said. "The words of a columnist don't necessarily predict the works of a cabinet secretary."

HEADLINE: SHIFTING OF POWER FROM WASHINGTON IS SEEN UNDER BUSH 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Jan. 6 

 BODY:
One thing is already clear about how President-elect George W. Bush intends to govern the nation: state and local officials will have far more leeway to shape and operate the full range of federal social, regulatory and public works programs.
 Across the spectrum of domestic policy issues, from health and welfare to education, transportation and environmental protection, the new administration promises to shift power from the federal government to the states, and state officials of both parties said they expected the promises to be kept. 
 As governor of Texas, Mr. Bush often declared, "Texans can run Texas," and aides said that motto indicated the respect he would show state officials -- an attitude that is also reflected in his choices for posts in the cabinet and on the White House staff.
In interviews this week, governors and other state officials said they expected Mr. Bush to work closely with the states and to give them more discretion in deciding how to use federal money and meet the goals of federal laws. 
"George is more inclined than the current administration to trust state legislators and governors -- Democrats and Republicans -- to make decisions," said Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania, a Republican.
Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat, said, "I do believe that the states will end up with more flexibility to manage Medicaid and other health and human service programs."
Mr. Bush met with 19 Republican governors today at his ranch in Crawford, Tex. Page 17. 
Ari Fleischer, a spokesman for Mr. Bush, said the meeting was an early sign of how Mr. Bush would govern. "He believes deeply that many of the nation's answers can be found in the state capitals," Mr. Fleischer said.
The people chosen to head the federal agencies that manage social, regulatory and public works programs have extensive experience in state and local government. Some of them have already spoken out about the need to give states more leeway to run those programs as they see fit.
Andrew H. Card Jr., who will be Mr. Bush's chief of staff, developed an excellent rapport with state and local officials when he was director of the White House office of intergovernmental affairs under President Ronald Reagan. Mitchell E. Daniels Jr., who also held that job under Mr. Reagan, is now in line to be director of the White House Office of Management and Budget, with broad authority to review federal regulations before they are issued.
Health care is a notable example.
Like many governors, Mr. Dean said he had been frustrated in efforts to get federal approval for innovations intended to cover more people under Medicaid and the new Children's Health Insurance Program. But Mr. Dean predicted that Gov. Tommy G. Thompson of Wisconsin, the man chosen to be secretary of health and human and services, would be more receptive to state experiments. Mr. Thompson, a Republican, "is one of the innovators himself" and has experienced similar frustrations in dealing with Washington, Mr. Dean said.
Seventeen states have expanded health insurance programs for children to cover parents as well, and new research shows that parents are more likely to enroll their children if the adults are also eligible. But Wisconsin, New York, Arizona and other states have had difficulty getting permission from the Clinton administration to use federal money for such family coverage.
Gov. George E. Pataki of New York, a Republican, said it was "outrageous that the Clinton administration had failed to act" on the state's plan, which was approved by the State Legislature in 1999 and was to take effect on Jan. 1 of this year. Clinton aides said they needed more information from the state.
Christine C. Ferguson, director of the Rhode Island Department of Human Services, said she expected a new climate in Washington, more hospitable to state proposals to cover more people by combining Medicaid with the new children's health program.
Even people once skeptical of the states now see many of them as engines of progressive social policy.
Sara Rosenbaum, a professor of health law at George Washington University, said Wisconsin "runs one of the best Medicaid programs in the country." Its new Badger Care program, which covers working families with slightly higher incomes, has been "a stunning success," she said.
With Congress unable to overhaul the basic Medicaid statute, Ms. Rosenbaum said, federal officials have good reason to waive selected provisions of the law "so states can reach more people with better-quality health care."
But some environmentalists are worried. Carl Pope, executive director of the Sierra Club, said: "States already have a lot of power in the environmental arena, and many simply decline to use it. So we are not in favor of giving them more discretion." While some states have vigorously enforced limits on air and water pollution, Mr. Pope said, others have not.
Alison P. Kaufman, chief Washington lobbyist for the State of Connecticut, said: "We are very optimistic about the relationship we will have with the new administration. Governor Bush has always had an open ear to all the governors. We don't expect a complete turnaround, but the philosophy of the new administration will be much more open to consultation with the states, to flexibility for the states."
Liberals and Democrats said that was not necessarily a bad thing. In recent years, they noted, they have often had more success at the state level than in the Republican-controlled Congress.
Joseph A. Dear, chief of staff to the governor of Washington, Gary Locke, a Democrat, said: "States don't want to be treated like just another stakeholder, another interest group. That approach drives them crazy. If the new administration finds a way to accord states the recognition that they are political entities, not interest groups, and that they can be trusted, that might be very beneficial and could improve the performance of government in delivering services to taxpayers."
Mr. Dear said he saw signs that the new administration would give the State of Washington more room to maneuver on a complex issue: how to save endangered species of wild salmon without disrupting the state's urban industrial economy.
"If the actions of the new administration match the words of the president-elect," Mr. Dear said, "that could help our salmon recovery efforts."
Mr. Bush and his appointees can use a variety of instruments to shift power to the states. Under Section 1115 of the Social Security Act, they can grant waivers for experimental health and welfare programs. They can write new regulations, eliminating some of the strings attached to federal aid. They can consolidate federal grants earmarked for specific purposes. 
The federal-state relationship has been evolving for more than 200 years. President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal and President Lyndon B. Johnson's Great Society vastly increased the size and power of the federal government. President Richard M. Nixon proposed a "new federalism," and Congress agreed to give states billions of dollars in federal "revenue sharing," with no strings attached. Mr. Reagan consolidated dozens of federal aid programs into nine block grants. But in 1996, Democrats blocked a Republican plan to convert Medicaid into a block grant, with a lump sum of federal money for each state.
In his first inaugural address as governor, in 1995, Mr. Bush promised to revive the 10th Amendment, which, he said, "gives to the states all powers not specifically granted to the federal government." His choice for secretary of the interior, Gale A. Norton, often invoked the amendment when, as attorney general of Colorado, she battled with the Environmental Protection Agency on air pollution rules and other issues.
Gordon M. Ambach, executive director of the Council of Chief State School Officers, said: "We expect there will be more flexibility for states and localities in various federal programs like teacher training, reducing class size and providing education for children in poverty and children with disabilities."
But Mr. Ambach noted that Mr. Bush had also emphasized accountability for student performance and for the use of federal money.
"The federal government will rely heavily on the states to set standards for students, to carry out testing and to report the results school by school," said Mr. Ambach, who was the state education commissioner in New York from 1977 to 1987.
Jerry T. White, superintendent of a school district with 370 students in rural Frenchville, Me., said he hoped and expected that the Bush administration would reduce the amount of paperwork he must do to account for the use of federal money.
"We must file eight reports each year describing in detail how we spend $16,000 under four different federal education programs," Mr. White said. "Local schools are buried in paper and red tape."
State and local transit officials welcomed the selection of Norman Y. Mineta to be secretary of transportation, noting that he had been mayor of San Jose, Calif., and a strong advocate for local control.
"As a member of Congress, he was one of the principal authors of a 1991 law that let local officials decide whether to use federal money for highways or transit projects -- buses and subways -- at their discretion," said Daniel Duff, vice president of the American Public Transportation Association. 
Bill Clinton was governor of Arkansas for 12 years, but as president he often clashed with state and local officials, who contended that he sometimes usurped their prerogatives.
The most notable clash came in 1998, when Mr. Clinton issued an executive order setting forth new reasons for the federal government to intervene in state affairs. The decree prompted a bipartisan outcry from state and local officials. The National Governors' Association called it "wrongheaded and unacceptable." Edward G. Rendell, a Democrat who was then mayor of Philadelphia, complained, "No state or local government official was consulted."
President Clinton revoked the order 15 months after he issued it.
Aides to Mr. Bush said he would show greater sensitivity to issues of federalism. In his eyes, they said, state officials are not supplicants, subordinates or mere middle managers, but equal partners with a role rooted in the Constitution.
The Bush transition team is already listening to state concerns on environmental issues. When Gov. Christie Whitman of New Jersey was chosen to be administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, she said she knew "what it's like to be on the receiving end of mandates from Washington."
Ten of the 29 people advising the Bush transition team on the environmental agency are current or former state officials. "We expect greater involvement of states in the development of E.P.A. rules, legislative proposals and policies," said Robert E. Roberts, executive director of the Environmental Council of the States, which represents top state officials.
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt of Utah, a Republican, said he believed that the new administration would be pervaded by a philosophy favoring the devolution of power to the states. But Mr. Leavitt added: "We recognize that bureaucracies are bureaucracies. They have an inclination to preserve their own power. That's human nature. It will require continual effort by the states to counterbalance those forces."
