HEADLINE: Punta del Este Journal; 
As Elite Resort Slumps, Argentina Doesn't Cry

BYLINE:  By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, Jan. 7 

 BODY:
Punta del Este is known throughout Latin America as the playground of the Argentine rich and of European royalty -- a place where jet setters sip Champagne on their yachts, rent Mediterranean chalets for $10,000 a month and stroll up and down the boardwalks with their French poodles.
 The pine-shaded beaches are delightfully balmy even during the hottest of Januarys. And when it rains, the visiting grand dames of Buenos Aires go to the gym at the Conrad Hotel wearing their diamonds and Italian designer sweat suits for all to see. 
 But speak to any Uruguayan businessman here and you hear another story, one full of dismay about the deep, two-year-old recession gripping Argentina that some say will smother this resort or force it to transform itself into something more akin to Atlantic City. 
Concerned that they will have a second disappointing season in a row, they have reduced hotel and rental rates by 15 to 20 percent. Restaurants are offering tourist specials. Car rental agents are bargaining to attract customers at the airport as if they were hawking in a Middle Eastern bazaar.
Anticipating losses, Punta's most exclusive art dealership shut its doors and moved to Miami. With better than 75 percent of Punta's tourism dependent on Argentines, local newspaper stories about how Christmas sales in Argentina slumped 22 percent sent quivers down the spines of the boutique owners on Avenida Gorlero.
"I feel like a pilot who has taken off and discovers a serious malfunction," said Pepe Perille, 35, who opened a restaurant last year featuring sushi and disco dancing.
The alarm ranges from the histrionic to the philosophical in this resort that is in season for a precious 10 weeks -- from the third week of December to the end of February -- and then reverts to a virtual ghost town by April.
"Rely on the Argentine economy?" asked Ana Maria Bozzo, owner of La Posta del Cangrejo, one of Punta del Este's most fashionable hotels -- with $345-a-night pastel bungalows and photographs of former President George Bush and King Juan Carlos of Spain in the lobby. "Better to rely on God. Every year the big question is what is going to happen to Argentina, and you just never know."
Punta's crisis is a product of long-term social trends as well as five years of generally mediocre economic performance in Argentina. Wealthy and upper-middle-class Argentine families once took a month or two off in Punta, as a matter of recreation and prestige. 
But now they generally take shorter vacations. And with their overvalued pesos pegged to the strong dollar, they go increasingly to Europe, the United States and Brazil.
The construction boom here that spanned much of the 1960's, 70's and 80's, fed by capital flight from Argentina during periods of political unrest and bouts of hyperinflation, ended in the early 1990's, leaving several unsightly skeleton towers of incomplete structures and half-vacant apartment buildings.
Local business owners and political leaders, who found it unseemly to promote their resort in the past, have taken some strong measures to maintain their hold on their half-million annual visitors.
Sensitive to several critical stories in the Argentine press last year, the local government has pressed food stands on the beaches to cut their prices for ice cream and other refreshments in half, and it has broken up the monopoly franchise that one company had to clean the beaches, hoping that competition will result in cleaner boardwalks and sand dunes.
It has extended the hours discotheques can remain open to 7 a.m. and eased noise restrictions. And after some brainstorming with business leaders seeking new marketing ideas, local officials announced that from now on topless bathing will be welcome.
Very few women are actually going topless in Punta -- no more, and maybe fewer, than in previous years when topless bathers had to be more discreet, say watchful lifeguards. Argentine women like to wear skimpy bathing suits, but they are generally more conservative than, say, the French, Italians or Spanish.
"Now that topless is legal it's less appealing," said Orlando Uviroga, 21, a lifeguard at Las Terrazas de Manantiales beach. Nevertheless, the announcement that topless bathing would be allowed brought a strong negative reaction from the Roman Catholic Church of Uruguay and, as Uruguayan businessmen eagerly hoped, a news media frenzy in Argentina.
Buenos Aires is in the middle of a heat wave, and with Congress and schools out for the summer break, television news producers have chosen to fill their shows with rather complete coverage of the topless bathing issue in Punta. Gente, Argentina's glittery version of People magazine, featured the subject on its cover this week, with a multipage photo layout of two fashion models, Daniela Urzi and Andrea Bursten, sunning virtually au natural in Punta.
Seeing a competitive threat, in recent days Pinamar and other Argentine beech resorts have announced that they, too, welcome topless bathing.
"Topless is the talk of Punta del Este," said a smiling Ruben Rijo, manager of the San Marcos Hotel. "I hope to God it helps bring back the Argentines." But most people just wink at the topic, knowing it is more hype than reality.
While taping a promotional cable television show on Punta's boardwalk today, the Argentine clothing designer Roberto Giordano picked up on the subject of the moment in a teasing monologue, while tourists gawked at four of his models. "Here we are at the nudist beach," he said, laughing, even though there was no one topless in sight. "They are just covering themselves because they don't want to appear in the media."
Luis Sader, a leading real estate executive, said, "Topless may have modernized Punta, but we're still in a crisis."
Even before the current crisis, Punta had gradually moved downscale, responding to the changes in social patterns. It has tried to attract more middle-class Argentines and shifted its marketing toward Brazil, Paraguay and Chile. 
Taxi stands began to replace their aging fleets of powder yellow Mercedes-Benzes with powder yellow Volkswagens. Discos and fast-food chains proliferated, replacing much of the understated elegance of a previous era. And the wealthiest sold much of their property and moved to more secluded beeches further up the coast.
But many of the changes have only partly taken hold.
The Conrad, a Las Vegas-style hotel that opened four years ago with an immense and gaudy casino, has been only a modest success and has not spurred much interest among international hotel chains. And a hoped-for surge of Brazilian tourists has not fully materialized, in part because of the devaluation of the Brazilian currency in 1999.
"Punta del Este is ending one era that lasted 60 years," said Ramon Isequilla Real de Azua, president of the Punta del Este Development and Tourism League. "And what comes next we just don't know."

(Armando Sartorotti for The New York Times) Map of Uruguay shows the location of Punta de Este: The prosperity of Punta de Este depends on wealthy Argentines.

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
The First Unionization Vote by Dot-Com Workers Is Set

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
This week a fixture of the old economy, the labor movement, will take a small but significant step into the new economy as the first unionization vote is held at a dot-com.
 While unionization efforts move slowly forward at high-technology giants like Microsoft and Amazon.com, 13 customer service representatives at etown.com, a Web site that provides information on consumer electronics, are on a fast unionization track, scheduled to vote Friday on whether to join the Communications Workers of America. 
 At Amazon, the unionization push has gained some momentum in recent months as a result of a new- economy complaint: many workers say their hourly pay is too low now that their stock options are underwater. At etown, a five-year-old company based in San Francisco, the impetus for a union has grown out of complaints common in the old economy -- the workers say pay is too low, management often does not listen to them and managers frequently do not stick to their promises. 
"The group's focus is just to be heard, just to have a voice," said Eric Anderson, a 22-year-old customer service representative at etown who is one of the most outspoken union supporters. "I'm also upset that I step up to the plate continuously and I'm not seeing the things that they promise me and offer me."
The unionization campaign at etown, a division of Collaborative Media, shares another trait with many old-economy companies -- management is fiercely resisting the organizing drive. Indeed, the communications workers union asserts that etown fired two leaders of the organizing drive because they favored unionizing and that the company dismissed 13 other customer service representatives to derail the organizing drive.
Executives at etown, which has yet to make a profit, readily acknowledge that they are urging workers to vote against a union, but they deny dismissing any workers to undermine unionization efforts. The company, which still has 99 workers in San Francisco and New York City, laid off the 13 customer service representatives last month, etown officials say, not to thwart the unionization drive, but as part of a cost-cutting effort, which included 29 layoffs throughout the company, aimed at satisfying etown's investors.
Like many other managers at high-technology companies, Steve Ramirez, etown's vice president for marketing and communications, voiced fears that unionization would raise costs and make it harder to turn a profit.
"We are not profitable," Mr. Ramirez said. "This certainly is a financially difficult time for ourselves as well as the high-tech industry and anything that adds to our cost structure is going to be a significant operating problem for us."
Even though the etown organizing drive involves only a handful of workers, the vote this Friday has taken on considerable importance for the union movement after most of its efforts to unionize new-economy companies have foundered.
"It's a smart strategy for labor -- they're trying to show their relevance in areas that are growing," said Gary Chaison, a professor of industrial relations at Clark University in Worcester, Mass. "If they can crack one high-tech company open, it will give them some real momentum. And in terms of union resurgence, it signifies that this is not your grandfather's labor movement, that this is no longer the smokestack labor movement."
Labor organizers say they expect some success in the high-technology industry for a little-understood reason. Many jobs in the new economy are unglamorous grunt work: answering phones, responding to customer complaints, filling orders and stuffing warehouse shelves.
But high-technology executives say unions have no place in their industry, asserting that unions usually resist the characteristics the industry thrives on: innovation, flexibility and entrepreneurship.
At etown, some union supporters are voicing optimism about Friday's vote, which is being supervised by the National Labor Relations Board. But some other workers predict the results will be very close.
The customer-service workers, who are paid $420 to $640 a week, petitioned for a unionization election after they complained that management was delaying and breaking promises on raises and promotions, was requiring too many employees to work overtime and often juggled their schedules around too much.
"It's very clear that management was consistently dishonest with its employees," said Chase Rummonds, a 31-year-old former customer service representative. " A union will lead to a negotiated contract, a tangible public document that states unequivocally what the agreement is between management and employees. It's the only way to force honesty between management and its employees."
Mr. Rummonds was dismissed in October, three days after he led a sickout that sought to protest management's failure to heed employee concerns on raises and other matters. Mr. Rummonds insists that he was fired merely because he backed a union; federal law bars companies from dismissing workers for that reason. But company officials said Mr. Rummonds was fired because he was disgruntled with the job and refused to promise that he would not take part in another sickout.
Mr. Ramirez of etown said the company had worked hard in recent weeks to resolve tensions and problems. Even one union supporter, Mr. Anderson, acknowledged that management, feeling the heat of a unionization drive, has become more attentive in listening and more consistent in making good on promises.
"They have asked for a second chance," Mr. Anderson said. "It really is up to everyone about whether they believe them. That's what the election's coming down to."
Mr. Anderson insisted that even if the union were to lose in Friday's vote, it would in ways emerge victorious because the fears of unionization have put pressure on management to treat workers better.
Company officials insist that a union will be an unwelcome intruder in the company. "We're facing an effort to bring in an unaffiliated third party that doesn't know our business, doesn't know our industry and doesn't know our employees," Mr. Ramirez said. "There's very little value that such a party can bring to the conversation."
Professor Chaison saw another reason that managers at new-economy companies fight so hard to beat back organizing drives. "Companies like Amazon are in a position where they have to rationalize to make a profit, and they feel that unionizing could finish them off," he said.
Mr. Anderson, the etown worker, said union supporters in no way wanted to hasten the company's demise. "No one wants to make the company not work," he said. "That wouldn't be a very smart idea."

HEADLINE: Camden Church Groups Seek Far Broader State Aid for City 

BYLINE:  By IVER PETERSON 

DATELINE: TRENTON, Jan. 8 

 BODY:
Two influential Camden church organizations asked today that the state provide $500 million to rebuild the city's broken streets and collapsing sewers, provide new housing and attract new investment. The figure is far in excess of the $100 million proposed by a state consultant's report as well as two larger proposals now before the State Legislature.
 The groups, Camden Churches Organized for People and Concerned Black Clergy, have provided important political support for the state's varying proposals for New Jersey's poorest city, which have ranged from strengthening the city's management system to staging a complete takeover. The organizations, which represent most established churches in the city, endorsed the takeover idea last summer after all other efforts by the state failed. 
 Yet today the groups' leaders said in effect that the price of that continued support would be a more ambitious aid and reform package than one proposed in November.
A state consultant proposed generating about $100 million in added money for the city, mainly by improving management and imposing cost savings. Two takeover bills before the Legislature include provisions for ambitious economic development and rebuilding plans, estimated to bring hundreds of millions of dollars to the city. No specific figures have been developed.
The Rev. Heyward Wiggins, pastor of the Bible Tabernacle Church and president of Camden Churches Organized for People, said the state had to do more than keep the city of 83,000 on life support.
"For too long, Camden has been urged to wait, to suffer in silence, while the needs of others are attended to first," he said. "But it seems that Camden's turn for attention and recovery never comes, and our people's patience sometimes turns to hopelessness."
Mr. Wiggins noted that the city's mayor, Milton Milan, was recently convicted on corruption charges. But, he said, Camden's recovery does not rest only on rooting out corruption. "We must recognize that Camden's difficulties run much deeper than a few corrupt leaders," Mr. Wiggins said. "Any serious attempt to set Camden on the road to recovery must address the underlying cause of Camden's condition -- and that is lack of resources."
Tom Damm, the spokesman for the State Division of Community Affairs, said the takeover packages in the Legislature included provisions for "hundreds of millions" in aid to the city, but not the amount the church groups were seeking. He said any final rescue package would not approach $500 million.
"Money alone is not going to solve Camden's problems," Mr. Damm said. "We need accountability and strong management, and that is what the legislation offers."
Msgr. Robert McDermott of St. Joseph's Cathedral in East Camden said that Camden Churches Organized for People had estimated that there were 300 miles of collapsing sewers and decayed roads in the city, and that it would cost about $300 million to repair them all. The remaining $200 million would go toward housing and for economic development, including incentives for investment in the city.
But fixing the roads and sewers, Mr. McDermott said, was the first step toward providing the environment needed to attract new investment. "Money and people are not going to flow into Camden until the infrastructure is repaired," he said, "and the government is the only thing that can fix that part of the landscape."
The administration of Gov. Christie Whitman is negotiating with legislative leaders over language that addresses the state's demand for strong controls and the belief of many legislators that the city's autonomy should be protected. The state provides about $70 million of the city's $110 million operating budget.
